abstract: MY DEAR SIR: South Carolina, after twentyseven years, Mr. RUETT says thirty years, of constant and increasing efforts by her leaders to induce her to secede, has declared herself out of the Union; and this, too, without the slightest wrong or injustice done her people on the part of the Government of the United States.
lead_paragraph: TROY, Dec. 31, 1860.

abstract: Since the surrender of the United States revenue cutter Aiken to the Secessionists by her commander, Lieut. COSTE, public expectation has been directed towards the United States revenue steamer Harriet Lane as the vessel most likely to be called into service for any purposes for which an armed vessel of the Government might be required at Charleston, and it was yesterday announced by telegraph from Washington that this vessel was to be dispatched to Charleston with sealed orders. In anticipation ofsome sudden orders, Capt. FAUNCE has had the bunkers of the Harriet Lane filled with coal, and everything placed in readiness to move promptly at the order of the Government.

abstract: Yesterday was the most exciting day experienced in Washington since the opening of the present session of Congress. In view of the recent intelligence of movements at Charleston, the principal interest centred in the Congressional proceedings--it being expected that some allusion would of course be made to events which have transpired during the brief holiday recess.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday was the most exciting day experienced in Washington since the opening of the present session of Congress. In view of the recent intelligence of movements at Charleston, the principal interest centred in the Congressional proceedings -- it being expected that some allusion would of course be made to events which have transpired during the brief holiday recess. In the Senate galleries a great crowd was gathered -- the attraction being a speech by Senator BENJAMIN, of Louisiana, which he intimated in advtance would be a secession speech. After some preliminary business, Mr. POWELL, of Kentucky, Chairman of the Special Committee of Thirteen on the State of the Union, reported that the Committee had been unable to agree, and asked that the journal of their proceedings be printed. Mr. DOUGLAS intimated a desire to speak upon the subject, but postponed his remarks until Wednesday. Mr. CRITTENDEN'S joint resolution was made the special order for Wednesday. Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, offered a resolution, which was objected to and laid over, requesting the Secretary of War to inform the Senate relative to the condition of the arms in the national armories, &c. The special order -- Territorial business -- was then postponed, and Mr. BENJAMIN proceeded to make his expected secession speech, which he closed with a declaration that the South could never be subjugated, A scene of indescribable confusion thereupon ensued in the galleries, which were finally cleared by the Sergeant-at-Arms. Mr. BAKER, of Oregon, obtained the floor for a rejoinder, but yielded to a motion to adjourn. The House also had an exciting session. The Speaker presented the communication from the Secretary of War, published in yesterday's TIMES, and it was referred to the Select Committee on the Abstraction of the Bonds. Several resolutions were offered, having for their object an inquiry into the condition of the forts and arsenals, but being objected to, they were laid over under the rules. Mr. PRYOR, of Virginia, offered a resolution declaring that any attempt to preserve the Union by force would be impracticable, and demanded the previous question, which was ordered. After considerable objection to the vote being taken, and a somewhat excited discussion, the resolution was tabled, 98 to 55. The Committee on Military Affairs, on motion of Mr. STANTON, of Ohio, was then instructed to inquire into the manner in which arms had been distributed during the year 1860, the condition of the forts, arsenals, &c., and whether the fortifications are suitably garrisoned -- the Committee having power to send for persons and papers. Messrs. DAVIS and HOLMAN, of Indiana, each presented resolutions relative to the recent action of the South Carolina Convention, but the House adjourned before any action on them was taken.

abstract: By reference to the report of yesterday's proceedings in the Board of Supervisors, it will be seen that our remarks on the impropriety of adding $1,000 a year each to the salaries of Judges BARNARD AND WHITE and Surrogate WEST, have had the effect of saving the City from these additional burdens, and from the favoritism of paying Messrs. WHITE and ...
lead_paragraph: By reference to the report of yesterday's proceedings in the Board of Supervisors, it will be seen that our remarks on the impropriety of adding $1,000 a year each to the salaries of Judges BARNARD AND WHITE and Surrogate WEST, have had the effect of saving the City from these additional burdens, and from the favoritism of paying Messrs. WHITE and BARNARD one-fifth more than is paid to their older and more experienced associates in the Supreme and Superior Courts. In whatever light Mr. Supervisor TWEED may see fit to regard this result, we cannot believe that the general public will sympathize to any severe extent in his condemnation of this particular example of "the power of the Press."

abstract: The office of City Chamberlain is fast becoming a public nuisance: now wrested from a blameless officer by a combination between the Mayor and Board of Aldermen; next seized by the Aldermen alone, as one of their legitimate perquisites; again recaptured, to a certain extent, by the Mayor's suspension of the Aldermanic nominee; and finally abolished ...
lead_paragraph: The office of City Chamberlain is fast becoming a public nuisance: now wrested from a blameless officer by a combination between the Mayor and Board of Aldermen; next seized by the Aldermen alone, as one of their legitimate perquisites; again recaptured, to a certain extent, by the Mayor's suspension of the Aldermanic nominee; and finally abolished altogether, for the time being, so far as duties are concerned, by the order of Comptroller HAWS to the various receiving officers of the City and County, to the effect that, "until further notice," they shall deposit their collections daily in the Chemical Bank, "subject to the joint draft of the depositor and Comptroller." Let us then see to what point the dispute as to this office has led us.

abstract: GREAT SALT LAKE CITY, Friday, Dec. 7, 1860. If any people, living in the same latitude, have been favored with a finer spell of weather than we have been enjoying lately at Salt Lake, they certainly have cause to rejoice. Previous to yesterday the time was, perhaps, the finest and mildest, for the season, known in this region since white men first molded Salt Lake prairie clay into adobes.
lead_paragraph: [From Our Own Correspondent.]

abstract: New-Year's Calling, according to old-time fashion in New-Amsterdam, is fast becoming a custom more honored in the breach than in the observance. The good burghers in the day of the Dutch domination were wont to make the first day of the year the occasion of family reunions and revivals of old friendships.
lead_paragraph: New-Year's Calling, according to old-time fashion in New-Amsterdam, is fast becoming a custom more honored in the breach than in the observance. The good burghers in the day of the Dutch domination were wont to make the first day of the year the occasion of family reunions and revivals of old friendships. But we have changed all that. Of late it has come to be thought of rather as an opportunity for forming new acquaintances, and quietly dropping those which may have ceased to be desirable. Further than this it is to very many merely a season for testing their capacity for strong drink; or, for learning and retailing the small scandals of families; or, for squaring the circle of their female society, -- determing how many it contains, that is, (its superficial contents, generally) and visiting all in order that they may boast of the achievement afterwards. Then there are others who look upon the 1st of January as the day specially appointed and set apart for the drawing of matrimonial lotteries. They seek to know ladies whom they may or may not have met before, visiting them with an eye to beauty of person or of purse. Led by an introducing friend, they enter new gardens of lovely, budding plants, and flit from flower to flower until they settle upon the sweetest. They regard with suspicion every silken rose leaf's rustle, for to them the fair are decked but to decoy; and, to their way of thinking, the only object of the nothing shrubbery is too woo some green thing, -- to entail a husband. And to they play their part, seeking the Goddess Fortune, e'en in their New-Year's calls.

abstract: A neat volume called Nina, or Life's Caprices, and recording the vicissitudes of a Hungarian lady who recently died in this vicinity, has recently been published in aid of the "Home of the Aged and Orphan of the Brooklyn Church Charity Foundation." It is a true narrative of an eventful life, and abounds in interest. The institution which is to be benefited by its sale is one of great merit, which does all the good the means at its command will permit. The book is sold by I.A. NICHOLS No. 268 Union street, Brooklyn.

abstract: GOV. MEDARY has resigned the office of Governor of Kansas, and has issued his farewell address. In it be claims that he has aimed to discharge his duties faithfully and honestly, and with a strict regard for the interests of the Territory. He urges the necessity of all men of influence laboring to the best of their ability to secure quiet in the Territory, especially in this crisis, when a disrupture of the Union is threatened. In the possibility, he says, of a separation, which it is almost sacrilegious to imagine. Kansas would herself, with such boundaries, be an empire, lying in the geographical centre of the States, and midway between the Atlantic and Pacific, and peaceful herself, would be virtually out of the regions of trouble, and a neutral highway betwixt the interests of the two oceans. With a large Territory, combining mineral with agricultural treasures, she would soon command a position and influence for the safety of her own citizens that no other State could occupy in times of strife and discord, such as must follow the dissolution of our National Government. Lightly as such reasonings may have been received a year ago, they are to day of sorrowful importance.

abstract: On Wednesday next the Senate is expected to take up for final action, the bill from the House of Representatives, for the construction of a Pacific Railroad, the measure having been made a special order for that day. The pending bill extends the aid of the Government to the construction of two roads--one by the central and the other by the Texas route.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday next the Senate is expected to take up for final action, the bill from the House of Representatives, for the construction of a Pacific Railroad, the measure having been made a special order for that day. The pending bill extends the aid of the Government to the construction of two roads -- one by the central and the other by the Texas route. To an outside observer it would appear certain that the Senate will promptly concur in the action of the House. There are few men who have studied the subject, probably, who have the slightest idea that more than one of these roads will be completed during the next 50 years, if even then; but, paradoxical as it seems, that is the very reason why a bill providing for two roads is the only one that can become a law. Each section is confident that its own route is the best, and, as a consequence, a majority of both Houses cannot be obtained for a single road bill which rejects entirely the claims of the opposite section. So intense has become the pressure of local interests on this subject, that representatives of the people dare not vote for a bill which does not secure their own section an equal chance in competing for the location of a work of such vast magnitude and importance. Hence all single road bills have failed, and will fail.

lead_paragraph: To-day history opens the unwritten volume of the coming year; and the chapter gaily begins with the illuminated initial of " A Happy New-Year!" But who shall cast the horoscope of 1861? In the metropolis, this first day of January is the merriest of all holidays -- an era of friendship, sunshine, and good cheer; and as the old god Janus, (after whom the month is named,) has said that omens are attached to the commencement of all things, we augur a favorable year from the universal joy of the day.

abstract: Capt. Walling and Officer Irving, of the Twentieth Ward, having prosecuted a vigorous search for the murderers of Joseph Sutcliffe, steward of the ship William and Mary, who was attacked and robbed on Christmas Eve while passing through Thirty-ninthstreet, their labors resulted in the apprehension of five young men, whose bad character, taken in connection with other circumstances, affords ground for the belief that they are guilty of the murder.
lead_paragraph: Capt. Walling and Officer Irving, of the Twentieth Ward, having prosecuted a vigorous search for the murderers of Joseph Sutcliffe, steward of the ship William and Mary, who was attacked and robbed on Christmas Eve while passing through Thirty-ninthstreet, their labors resulted in the apprehension of five young men, whose bad character, taken in connection with other circumstances, affords ground for the belief that they are guilty of the murder. The names of the prisoners are Jeremiah Flynn, alias Blueskin, Michael Gillespie, Hugh Mooney, James Scott and James Blythe, all of whom were yesterday committed to prison by Justice QUACKENBUSH, pending further developments. These men have been in the habit of frequenting a drinking-place kept by Michael Connors, at the corner of Forty-first-street and Eleventh-avenue, and it was there that their arrest was effected. Connors stated that a species of bludgeon or slung-shot had recently been stolen from his place, and the wounds of which Sutcliffe died must have been inflicted with an instrument of that description. Mr. John O'Flaherty, the companion of the murdered man, has fully identified Flynn as the ruffian who led on the assault.

abstract: Mr. BUCHANAN came very near giving the nation a jubilee yesterday. He had a narrow escape from bringing down upon his head, as a New-Year's greeting, the thanks and applause of millions of American freemen. The telegraph announced in the afternoon that Gen. SCOTT had been appointed Secretary of ...
lead_paragraph: Mr. BUCHANAN came very near giving the nation a jubilee yesterday. He had a narrow escape from bringing down upon his head, as a New-Year's greeting, the thanks and applause of millions of American freemen. The telegraph announced in the afternoon that Gen. SCOTT had been appointed Secretary of War ad interim, and that the Cabinet Councils had been purged of their disunion virus by the resignations of Messrs. THOMPSON and THOMAS. Wherever the report went, it created universal rejoicing. Men of all parties exulted in the prospect of again having a Government around which the hope and the courage of the nation could rally, and which could be relied upon under all contingencies to maintain unsullied the honor of the American flag. If the news had proved to be true, the President would have been greeted to-day with salvos of cannon from one end of the Union to the other. And this would have happened, -- not from any wish, as the groveling partisan of the Constitution affects to fear, for the establishment of a military dictatorship, nor from any personal devotion to the fortunes of the veteran Chieftain of our Republic; -- but because the nation reposes with unwavering confidence on his single-hearted patriotism, and on the high-toned, wise and unswerving devotion to the Union and the Constitution which he would bring to the duties of that great office.

abstract: --A wedding in high life transpired in Philadelphia on Friday, Dec. 28. Alfred C. Beighmanns, Secretary of the Belgian Legation at Washington, was married to Miss Lily L. Macalester, daughter of Mr. Charles Macalester. The bridegroom was accompanied by a number of the attaches of the Foreign Legation at Washington, and by Consular representatives in other cities.
lead_paragraph: -- A wedding in high life transpired in Philadelphia on Friday, Dec. 28. Alfred C. Beighmanns, Secretary of the Belgian Legation at Washington, was married to Miss Lily L. Macalester, daughter of Mr. Charles Macalester. The bridegroom was accompanied by a number of the attaches of the Foreign Legation at Washington, and by Consular representatives in other cities. The bride was magnificently dressed in white moire, with Brussels veil and orange blossoms. The bridesmaids wore white tulle, trimmed with bows of violet colored silk, wreaths and corsages of violets, with short tulle veils fastened gracefully under the plait of the hair, the bouquets generally corresponding in color with the dresses. The ladies who officiated in this capacity were Miss Harriet Lane, Miss Hopkins, Miss Kissam, Miss Kane, Miss Lewis, Miss Paul and Miss Wurts. Senor Don Tassara, Baron Grabow, Consul Kortright, Senor Don Villaiba, Dr. Pancoast, Count Resac and Richard Coroin. Esq., acted as groomsmen, and Rev. Mr. Shields performed the ceremony.

abstract: The last meeting of this Board for 1860 was held yesterday. abstract: The secession of South Carolina from the Union formed by the adoption of the Consti tution of 1787, raises very important and serious questions touching the rights of the citizens of all the other States and of all subjects of foreign Governments.
lead_paragraph: The secession of South Carolina from the Union formed by the adoption of the Consti tution of 1787, raises very important and serious questions touching the rights of the citizens of all the other States and of all subjects of foreign Governments. By the United States Constitution it is declared that the Constitution and the laws made in pursuance thereof shall be the "supreme law of the land" -- that the judicial power of the United States shall be vested in one Supreme Court, and in such inferior Courts as Congress may establish. This provision, conferring the power upon the General Government to establish tribunals of its own in every State, was to enable the citizens of the other States, and subjects of all foreign Governments, to prosecute their rights in each State under the jurisdiction of the United States. It had for its object a harmonious distribution of justice throughout the Union -- and to confine the States in their judicial sovereignty to cases between their own citizens -- and to prevent an undue exercise of power by any State over the rights of citizens of other States, or over the rights of foreigners, and thus preclude a conflict of laws. These conflicts of power and right necessarily arise after contracts have been entered into.

abstract: The statement telegraphed from Washington that the Harriet Lane had been, or would be, ordered to Charleston, has not yet received any confirmation in the shape of orders from head-quarters. Capt. FAUNCE holds himself and vessel in readiness, however, to obey any summons from the Department. The opinion among the officers appears to be that for any purposes of a blockade two sailing vessels, with auxiliary steam, would serve a much better purpose than a single vessel which wholly depends on steam. There are two channels, or principal entrances, to Charleston harbor; one, the north channel, which will admit vessels drawing fourteen feet of water, and the other, the south or main ship channel, the two being over five miles apart. There is also the beach channel to the northward, through which vessels of light draft may pass at half a full tide. Of course, it would be impossible for one vessel to guard all three passages at the same time. The Government appears to have changed its plans, and have decided to employ vessels of a larger class, which, in any contest with the forts, will be found more effective than a small steamer like the Lane could be, however well she might be manned.

abstract: Last evening, between the hours of 6 and 7, the people -- really the people of all parties and sections -- assembled in the Park to do honor to Maj. ANDERSON, and fired one hundred guns for the noble stand he has taken in favor of the Union, by evacuating Fort Moultrie and possessing himself of Fort Sumter. Some very prominent Democrats, we understand, and one leading Democratic member of Congress, were at the "head and front" of the proceeding. But, in fact, everybody was pleased with the tribute to ANDERSON's great move on the political chess board.

abstract: WIFE MURDER. -- A man named JOHN STANLEY, residing in Columbia, near Harrison-street, was found by the Police, yesterday morning, lying on the floor in a state of beastly intoxication. Near him was his wife, insensible from a severe wound on the head which he had inflicted. He was taken to the Station-house in the Third Precinct, and on the way there expressed regrets that he had not killed his wife. His regrets were useless, for her injuries were supposed to be of a fatal character.

abstract: To decide every case as much as possible on its own peculiar circumstances, to avoid abstract disquisitions and long or complicated chains of argument, to refer everything to custom rather than to principle, and to avoid above all things general and sweeping propositions, has been the traditionary policy, and has become the inveterate habit of English statesmen. The direct contrary is the practice of American Presidents. Essay writing is a part of their vocation. They assume the office of public instructors as well as administrators, and write annually a long thesis on the principles of government, which is destined rather to increase the bulk than improve the quality of that species of literature. On the present occasion, when events are hurrying on with so much rapidity, when nobody knows accurately what this own position will be, because nobody can as yet determine accurately the position of his antagonists or that of his allies, it might have seemed that President BUCHANAN was dispensed from the duty of compiling an elaborate essay on the legal and moral obligations which knit together in members of the American Union. But custom, pedantry or nervousness has produced a Message which has much more the appearance of being made to calm his own apprehensions and misgivings than for the purpose of convincing or satisfying anybody else. In truth, the Message has satisfied nobody. It has lowered the price of stocks in New-York, and given North and South an opportunity of complaining, with very considerable justice, that each has been misrepresented and slandered.
lead_paragraph: To decide every case as much as possible on its own peculiar circumstances, to avoid abstract disquisitions and long or complicated chains of argument, to refer everything to custom rather than to principle, and to avoid above all things general and sweeping propositions, has been the traditionary policy, and has become the inveterate habit of English statesmen. The direct contrary is the practice of American Presidents. Essay writing is a part of their vocation. They assume the office of public instructors as well as administrators, and write annually a long thesis on the principles of government, which is destined rather to increase the bulk than improve the quality of that species of literature. On the present occasion, when events are hurrying on with so much rapidity, when nobody knows accurately what this own position will be, because nobody can as yet determine accurately the position of his antagonists or that of his allies, it might have seemed that President BUCHANAN was dispensed from the duty of compiling an elaborate essay on the legal and moral obligations which knit together in members of the American Union. But custom, pedantry or nervousness has produced a Message which has much more the appearance of being made to calm his own apprehensions and misgivings than for the purpose of convincing or satisfying anybody else. In truth, the Message has satisfied nobody. It has lowered the price of stocks in New-York, and given North and South an opportunity of complaining, with very considerable justice, that each has been misrepresented and slandered.

abstract: New-Year's Calling, according to old-time fashion in New-Amsterdam, is fast becoming a custom more honored in the breach than in the observance. The food burghers in the day of the Dutch domination were wont to make the first day of the year the occasion of family reunions and revivals of old friendships. But we have changed all that. Of late it has come to be thought of rather as an opportunity for forming new acquaintances, and quietly dropping those which may have, ceased to be desirable. Further than this it is to very many merely a reason for testing their capacity for strong drink; or, for learning and retailing the small scandals of families; or, for squaring the circle of their female society -- determining how many it contains -- that is, it's superficial contents, generally -- and visiting all in order that they may boast of the achievement afterwards. Then there are others who look upon the 1st of January as the day specially appointed and set apart for the drawing of matrimonial lotteries. They seek to know ladies whom they may or may not have met before, visiting them with an eye to beauty of person or of purse. Led by an introducing friend, they enter new gardens of lovely, budding plants, and flit from flower to flower until they settle upon the sweetest. They regard with suspicion every silken rose leaf's rustle, for to them the fair are decked but to decoy; and, to their way of thinking, the only object of the nodding shubbery is too woo some green thing, -- to entoil a husband. And so they play their part, seeking the Goddess Fortune, e'en in their New-Year's calls.

The food burghers in the day of the Dutch domination were wont to make the first day of the year the occasion of family reunions and revivals of old friendships. But we have changed all that. abstract: THANK GOD, there are indications that we again have a GOVERNMENT OF THE UNITED STATES! Our news from Washington reports that the President has at last repelled the fatal seductions of Disunion, and aroused to a sense of his duties and...
lead_paragraph: THANK GOD, there are indications that we again have a GOVERNMENT OF THE UNITED STATES! Our news from Washington reports that the President has at last repelled the fatal seductions of Disunion, and aroused to a sense of his duties and responsibilities as the Executive, -- sworn to uphold the Constitution and the laws of the American Union. It is reported that he has informed the South Carolina Commissioners that they cannot be received or treated in any other capacity than as Commissioners from one of the States of the Union; -- that he has decided that Major ANDERSON shall be reinforced to any extent which his emergencies may require; -- and that two vessels of war, lying at Norfolk, have been ordered to be made ready for immediate departure to the port of Charleston.

abstract: We published on Monday circular letters from the Comptroller issued to the various heads of Departments, directing them to recognize neither Messrs. DEVLIN or PLATT as Chamberlains of the City, but to deposit all City moneys in the Chemical Bank, subject to his orders. Yesterday, however, a conference was bad, in which the Comptroller, Mr. BRONSON, Counsel to the Corporation, and Mr. JNO. E. DEVLIN, who represents DAN. DEVLIN, (the newly-appointed City Chamberlain,) took part. Mr. BRONSON having given an opinion as to the legality of Mr. DEVLIN's appointment, the consummation was reached by issue of the following order, addressed to all the heads of Departments, and which recognizes Mr. DEVLIN as the City Chamberlain;

abstract: Yielding to the irresistible pressure of the people of Texas, Gen. HOUSTON has summoned a meeting of the Legislature for Jan. 21. Indications are not wanting that this act of compliance is far from cordial, and that the old hero sympathizes not at all with the policy and aims of secession.
lead_paragraph: Yielding to the irresistible pressure of the people of Texas, Gen. HOUSTON has summoned a meeting of the Legislature for Jan. 21. Indications are not wanting that this act of compliance is far from cordial, and that the old hero sympathizes not at all with the policy and aims of secession. There is a direct bluntness about the call which confirms such belief. The meeting, for instance, instead of being fixed after the popular Convention, which meets Jan. 28, should have excited public feeling to an irreducible heat, is made preliminary to that assembly, thus rendering what conservative influences may still survive in the Legislature available timely to tranquillize the prevalent excitement. Nor is the necessity for the measure argued solely from the state of Federal relations. It is also ascribed to the turbulent condition of the frontier Indians, and to the important circumstance that "the Treasury is without means either to defend the frontier, or to meet ordinary expenses of the Government."

abstract: You have met under circumstances of more than usual interest, to perform the high and responsible duty of making laws which are to affect the honor, welfare and happiness of millions.
lead_paragraph: You have met under circumstances of more than usual interest, to perform the high and responsible duty of making laws which are to affect the honor, welfare and happiness of millions. High, because no earthly power is superior to that which prescribes rules of action for all; and responsible, because you are acting in a representative capacity, and are therefore charged with sacred trusts. If anything were needed to heighten the importance of your position, you have but to reflect that you represent the sovereignty of the State of New-York, the noblest, the grandest commonwealth that ever had existence; an empire of nearly four millions of people, imperial in all its proportions, with interests the most varied and hopes the most exalted. It has a proud history and a proud name to preserve. Those who fashioned our institutions have passed away, but their works stand, immortal monuments of their wisdom and patriotism, and accepted as fit models by other States. It remains for us to say whether these shall continue to be worthy of emulation, whether we appreciate the legacy committed to our keeping.

abstract: Our dispatches from Washington this morning lead to the hope that, with the opening of the new year, a different course of policy towards the Southern agitators has been determined upon by the Administration. The sloop-of-war Brooklyn, which...
lead_paragraph: Our dispatches from Washington this morning lead to the hope that, with the opening of the new year, a different course of policy towards the Southern agitators has been determined upon by the Administration. The sloop-of-war Brooklyn, which has recently returned with the expedition sent out to survey the proposed route for, a railroad across the Isthmus at Chiriqui, together with another war-vessel at Norfolk, has been ordered to be kept in readiness to proceed to Charleston at a moment's warning, and a rumor is current that all the important Southern posts are to be immediately reinforced. Another significant indication is to be found in the fact that the militia of the District of Columbia is to be reorganized, the Secretary of War having, at the recommendation of Gen. SCOTT, appointed Capt. CHARLES STONE as Inspector-General for the accomplishment of that object. A still further indication will be recognized in the action of the President yesterday. It was understood that he would send in to Congress a special message in reference to affairs in South Carolina, but this was delayed, and instead, he sent in a nomination for "Collector of Revenue in the neighborhood of Charleston Harbor." The name of the individual nominated to this important position is not known with certainty, though WILLIAM MCINTIRE, of New-York, is mentioned as probably the person.

abstract: It has long been the custom of Judges in our criminal Courts to suspend sentence in those cases where the prisoner, though legally convicted, is yet, in view of palliating circumstances, or on some other ground, morally innocent. That the exercise of such a prerogative of the Court, when regulated by the discretion of an upright and intelligent Judge, may sometimes better conduce to the ends of justice than an inflexible adherence to the line of judicial duty as prescribed by the laws creating the Court, may not, perhaps, be successfully denied. There can be no dispute, however, that when Judges, elected as they often are, by the acclaim of bar-room rabbles, are allowed to relieve from the penalty of the law any partisan or friend who happens to be convicted before them, without accountability to any quarter for the motive of their action, there is, to say the least, great danger to the permanence of those barriers by which the genius of our laws seeks to restrain the judicial tribunals from every legislative or executive act.

abstract: The Map given above presents an accurate view of the Harbor of Charleston, with the relative position of the several forts which were built by the General Government for its protection. It is reduced from the Chart of the Coast Survey. Persons familiar with New-York Bay will have no difficulty in tracing upon the map certain striking resemblances between the two harbors. Approaching Charleston from the ocean, it may be seen lying a few miles distant between the rivers Ashley and Cooper -- the latter corresponding to the East, and the former to the North River. The low grounds on the right of the entrance will answer very fairly to Long Island; those on the left to Staten Island -- the difference being best expressed by the supposition that the heights of our Northern islands had been flattened down, and as it were ironed out, almost to uniformity with the sea level. Upon these desolate flats plant here and there a few bare, straggling, stunted trees, stretching at rare intervals like sentinels along the shore; and an adequate idea may be had of the framework in which this tropical picture is inclosed. Proceeding inward, and keeping the map of our finer harbor in view, with due corrections for distances, and the substitution of Moultrie for Hamilton, Sumter for Tompkins, and Castle Pinckney for Castle William, and the similitude will be found sufficiently exact for all practical purposes. Fort Moultrie, on the right, is distant from Sumter at the left, a fraction over a mile; while Castle Pinckney, lying close to the city, is some 3 3/4 miles from both.
lead_paragraph: The Map given above presents an accurate view of the Harbor of Charleston, with the relative position of the several forts which were built by the General Government for its protection. It is reduced from the Chart of the Coast Survey. Persons familiar with New-York Bay will have no difficulty in tracing upon the map certain striking resemblances between the two harbors. Approaching Charleston from the ocean, it may be seen lying a few miles distant between the rivers Ashley and Cooper -- the latter corresponding to the East, and the former to the North River. The low grounds on the right of the entrance will answer very fairly to Long Island; those on the left to Staten Island -- the difference being best expressed by the supposition that the heights of our Northern islands had been flattened down, and as it were ironed out, almost to uniformity with the sea level. Upon these desolate flats plant here and there a few bare, straggling, stunted trees, stretching at rare intervals like sentinels along the shore; and an adequate idea may be had of the framework in which this tropical picture is inclosed. Proceeding inward, and keeping the map of our finer harbor in view, with due corrections for distances, and the substitution of Moultrie for Hamilton, Sumter for Tompkins, and Castle Pinckney for Castle William, and the similitude will be found sufficiently exact for all practical purposes. Fort Moultrie, on the right, is distant from Sumter at the left, a fraction over a mile; while Castle Pinckney, lying close to the city, is some 3 3/4 miles from both.

abstract: Jerntia Whiting vs. Chas. S. Slosson, Daniel E. Delevan et al. This was a motion to dissolve an injunction formerly obtained against the City Inspector and others, three of whom are Health Wardens.
lead_paragraph: Jerntia Whiting vs. Chas. S. Slosson, Daniel E. Delevan et al. -- This was a motion to dissolve an injunction formerly obtained against the City Inspector and others, three of whom are Health Wardens. It appears that the plaintiff is the owner of the premises Nos. 19, 21 and 23 Park-avenue, in the City. Slosson owns the premises northerly adjoining. A private drain or sewer, on the rear of plaintiff's lots, connects with the sewer in Thirty-fifth-street. There is no sewer in Fourth avenue. The defendant Slosson, as alleged, made an opening into the plaintiff's private drain, so as to connect his premises with the Thirty-fifth-street sewer. The defendants join in averring that their action was mutual, and for the purpose of abating a nuisance on the plaintiff's premises. The plaintiff replies, denying that any nuisance exists on his premises, and declares that the nuisance, if anywhere, is on Slosson's premises. Plaintiff also claims that if his private sewer is used by the defendants for such a purpose, he should receive a fair compensation for such use. Slosson claims that his action was pursuant to permission from the former occupant of plaintiff's premises. This allegation was, however, denied by an affidavit of that occupant. After some discussion, the matter was laid over, to give plaintiff opportunity to obtain further papers.

He then asked his leadership to inform the Society, "if not inconsistent with his duty," "whether there is any foundation for such a rumor!" The following is Lord LYONS' reply:

abstract: Our dispatches from Washington, while they indicate that the Government has indeed taken steps to stem the torrent of Disunion, also prove conclusively that these steps have not been taken a moment too soon. The last communication made by the South Carolina Commissioners to the President was returned by him -- one account says unopened, and another says without word or comment. This action of the President is considered by the Commissioners as insulting, and tantamount to a declaration of war. They, of course, do not recognize the fact that their State already occupies a position of hostility to the General Government. The plot mentioned in our dispatches yesterday, having for its object the organization of an armed force to take possession of the Capitol, and prevent the inauguration of Mr. LINCOLN, is more fully revealed every day. Gen. SCOTT, however, is actively engaged in counter movements, and the plans of the plotters will be circumvented. Capt. STONE, recently appointed to the Inspector-Generalship of the militia of the District, yesterday issued, his orders, through which the men under his command will be ready at a moment's warning.
lead_paragraph: Our dispatches from Washington, while they indicate that the Government has indeed taken steps to stem the torrent of Disunion, also prove conclusively that these steps have not been taken a moment too soon. abstract: Wm. R. Green vs. L Sherman. -- This was a motion to discharge the defendant from arrest. It appears from the statement of counsel that the defendant was engaged in business at Memphis, and came on here to purchase goods. It is charged by the plaintiff that the defendant made fraudulent representations to him, on the strength of which he sold to him certain bills of goods on credit; that on the goods arriving at Memphis, the defendant took the goods, delivered from that piece, sold them, and converted the proceeds to his own use.

abstract: Now that rumor is so busy with the alleged movements southward of United States troops and naval vessels, it may not be out of place to give a statement of the forces likely to be ordered for hostile service in South Carolina, should unfortunate circumstances render extreme measures necessary. If soldiers be required, Governor's Island, N.Y., Carlisle, Penn., and the Navy-yards will be the first places from which reinforcements may be taken.
lead_paragraph: Now that rumor is so busy with the alleged movements southward of United States troops and naval vessels, it may not be out of place to give a statement of the forces likely to be ordered for hostile service in South Carolina, should unfortunate circumstances render extreme measures necessary. If soldiers be required, Governor's Island, N.Y., Carlisle, Penn., and the Navy-yards will be the first places from which reinforcements may be taken. The 800 troops stationed at Fort Monroe, Fayetteville, N.C., Augusta, Key West, Banancos and Baton Rouge, would not be removed. The available men, then, for military duty are nearly as follows:

abstract: Mayor WOOD is not pleased with the Metropolitan Police, and makes no effort to conceal his dislike. On the contrary, he is anxious that all the world should know how immeasurably superior he considers his own management of the Old Municipal Police to have been, when contrasted with "the incapacity and mismanagement" of the present Metropolitan system. He thinks the General-Superintendent "sufficiently able and astute" in one breath, while in another every recom rience.

abstract: The Panama Railroad Company's steamship Columbus, Capt. RATHRUN, arrived at Panama on the 21st inst., from Central American parts. She brings dates from Guatemala to the 10th, Salvador to the 15th, Nicaragua to the 16th, and Costa Rica to the 18th December. The Columbus brought 1,264 ceroons indigo for Europe and the United States, hides, skins, coffee, vinegar, balsem, etc. The news is unimportant.

abstract: The following contracts were awarded Wednesday in the office of the Street Commissioner: Flagging, &c., in Tenth-avenue, from Fifty-fourth-street to Broadway, nine bids, awarded to John McGrane, at $6,191, time ninety days, sureties Saml. Cochran and Thomas Doyle, in $6,000 each. Regulating and grading Fifty-sixth-street, from Fifth to Sixth-avenue, eight bids, awarded to Jeremiah Crowley, at $4,762, time 104 days, sureties Edmund Connelly and Thomas Callaghan, in $2,000 each. Regulating and grading Fifty-seventh-street, from Eleventh-avenue to Hudson River, four bids, awarded to John G. Mastersen, at $2,864, time seven months, sureties Terence McGuire and Peter Mastersen, in $1,600 each. Regulating, &c., Forty-ninth-street, from First to Third-avenue, four bids, awarded to John McGrane, at $1,937 75, time thirty days, sureties John Doyle and Saml. Cochran, in $1,500 each. No award made for repairing and reglazing public lamps.

abstract: The funds on the 21st were dull and Consols further declined 1/3 cent., closing at 92 7/8@93 for account, ex-dividend. The markets generally were under the influence of the approaching holidays. The Exchange was to be closed from Saturday the 22d till Wednesday the 26th, owing to the intervention of Christmas. The demand for money in the discount market had become extremely heavy, owing to the three days suspension of business and the necessity for providing for bills falling due in that period. No business was done generally below the Bank rate, and the applications at the Bank were quite numerous.

abstract: The schooner Janet Kedstone, Capt. WM. CLARK left this port on Wednesday for Port-au-Prince, having on board fifty-six emigrants, who go out under the auspices of the Boston Bureau of Emigration, which has recently been organized by Mr. JAMES REDPATH, of Boston. Rev. H.H. GARNET is the agent in this City. The passengers are from Massachusetts, New-York, Pennsylvania and Canada. It is stipulated with the Haytian Government that each emigrant shall have a free passage, and on arrival in the republic, a farm of 16 acres of land. Each party carries out agricultural and household implements, and those who may be too poor to purchase these are supplied by the agent. These emigrants appear to possess intelligence and other qualities which must render them a valuable accession to the Republic, and open for them the road to success. Previous to sailing, after the passengers had assembled on board, they were addressed by Rev. Mr. GARNET and Rev. Mr. LEWIS, who also offered prayer for their safety and future success. The vessel was towed into the stream amid the cheers and expression of good wishes from their friends. The Janet Kedstone is a schooner of 200 tons register, and is fitted up with comfortable accommodations for the passengers.

abstract: The two branches of the Legislature, and a very large audience of citizens, assembled at the State House, between 12 and 1 o'clock to-day, to hear Gov. BANKS' valedictory address. It is an important document, giving a detailed review of the material, educational and inilitary progress of the State during the three years he filled the Executive chair. The assessed value of property of the State is $897,000,000. The enrolled militia numbers 155,3810 men.

abstract: Three men named Edward Brodie, Benj. F. Goodman and Wm. Walker, were arrested yesterday, charged with swindling Joseph Jackson, representing himself to be a pawnbroker at No. 111 Grands-treet, by inducing him to advance $10 on a medal which was represented to him to be gold, but which proved to have but about $4 worth of gold in it. The medal, it seems, purported to have been presented to Capt. S. Johnson as a token of esteem, by his officers in 1856. It was evidently made with intent to swindle, and it is stated that several pawnbrokers have been taken in by them. The outside was gold, but the inside was of some base metal. Two or three of the same kind of medal, and bearing the same inscription, were offered to the complainant, and this led him to suspect their genuineness. The matter was investigated before Justice STEERS, when it appeared that the complainant was not a licensed pawnbroker, and therefore incompetent to prefer the charge. The case was then dismissed, and the accused discharged.
lead_paragraph: Three men named Edward Brodie, Benj. F. Goodman and Wm. Two or three of the same kind of medal, and bearing the same inscription, were offered to the complainant, and this led him to suspect their genuineness. The matter was investigated before Justice STEERS, when it appeared that the complainant was not a licensed pawnbroker, and therefore incompetent to prefer the charge. The case was then dismissed, and the accused discharged.

abstract: WALLACK's THEATRE. -- There is no delusion more common with managers than that which suggests a cheerful entertainment for times of trouble and sore distress. If at the present moment a drama could be constructed in which were depicted the sternest features of ruin, it would undoubtedly meet with a prodigious reception. The coldest Winter is the best time for bringing out the "Sea of Ice;" there is nothing refreshing in the piece when the thermometer ranges above ninety. So with the dismal dish called "Pauline," the right moment is the one when mistrust prevails, and genuine smiles are as scarce as honest Cabinet Ministers. In the matter of fun your public requires to be poked in the ribs in a very circumspect manner, and the chances are about equally balanced at all times whether he will take it as a joke and laugh, or account it an affront and pass on. There is only one thing absolutely certain, and that is that the theory which suggests a light and cheerful piece in dull times is wrong. When affairs are wearing a perplexed look, managers would do well to furbish up their mimic horrors, for the public mind will be ready to receive them. A ghost story is never so delicious as when the surrounding gloom prevents our recognizing the faces of our friends.
lead_paragraph: WALLACK's THEATRE. -- There is no delusion more common with managers than that which suggests a cheerful entertainment for times of trouble and sore distress. The coldest Winter is the best time for bringing out the "Sea of Ice;" there is nothing refreshing in the piece when the thermometer ranges above ninety. So with the dismal dish called "Pauline," the right moment is the one when mistrust prevails, and genuine smiles are as scarce as honest Cabinet Ministers. In the matter of fun your public requires to be poked in the ribs in a very circumspect manner, and the chances are about equally balanced at all times whether he will take it as a joke and laugh, or account it an affront and pass on. There is only one thing absolutely certain, and that is that the theory which suggests a light and cheerful piece in dull times is wrong. When affairs are wearing a perplexed look, managers would do well to furbish up their mimic horrors, for the public mind will be ready to receive them. A ghost story is never so delicious as when the surrounding gloom prevents our recognizing the faces of our friends.

abstract: A book has been opened at the Head-quarters of the Republican Central Club, in this city, for the enrollment of volunteers to meet any demand which may be made by the Governor of the State for troops to aid in preserving the Union. The Company thus formed is to be known as "Company A, Union Volunteers." The roll has but just been opened and already contains the names of a considerable number of citizens without respect to party.

abstract: CORNERS' INQUESTS. -- Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest on Thursday at a house in One Hundred and Tenth-street, near Third-avenue, upon the body of MARY FINNEGAN, a child one year old, who died from burns received on the 31st ult, when her clothes caught fire from a stove. Verdict, "accidental death," The same Coroner held an inquest upon the body of ARTHUR DONNELLY, a native of Ireland, 37 years of age, who was suffocated by a bank of earth which fell upon him while he was at work in Fourth-avenue, near Forty-seventh-street....Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest at No. 152 West Seventeenth-street, upon the body of CATHARINE BRADLEY, a child 5 years old, who died from burns received by her clothes catching fire from a stove while she was alene in the room....Coroner SCHERMER held an inquest at No. 477 Cherrry-street, upon the body of PHILIP DILLON, an infant who, on New-Year's night, was accidentally suffocated while in bed with its mother. The same Coroner held an inquest at No. 130 Broome street, upon the body of BARBARA KLUO, a child six weeks old, who was suffocated by being overload by its nurse. A verdict of "accidental death" was rendered in each case.

abstract: The death of this nobleman is announced. JAMES ANDREW BROWN DALHOUSIE, Marquis of Dalhousie, was the tenth Earl of Dalhousie. He was born at Dalhousie Castle, near Edinbro', in 1812, and was therefore in the forty-eighth year of his ago. As Lord Ramsey, his title by courtesy, he was first educated at Harrow School, and then took his degrees at Oxford, in 1833. He contested, without success, the representation of Edinburgh, on Conservative principles, with Mr. ABERCROMBY subsequently Speaker of the House of Commons, and with Sir JOHN CAMPBELL, the present Lord Chancellor. By his frankness, and manly straightforwardness, however, he won golden opinions, not less from his adversaries than from his partisans. In 1837 he was returned to the House of Commons for the County of Haddington, and on the death of his father, in, 1838, he succeeded to the earldom of Dalhousie. In 1843 he was appointed Vice-President of the Board of Trade, and in 1845 President, with a seat in the Cabinet, resigning with the Ministry in 1846. In 1847, on the return of Lord HARDINGE from India, he was offered and accepted the Governor-Generalship, being the youngest man ever appointed to that responsible office. The Sikhs, shortly after his landing, broke out a second time into war. Under his management they were defeated everywhere. He then annexed the Punjaub, seemingly indifferent to public opinion as to that decisive step: Pegu, Bezar, and Nagpore, and lastly, Oude came under the same system of political acquisition; but while conquering and annexing, ho did not forget to develop the internal resources of the country. Railways, canals, and telegraphs were established; she sought to reform the administration of the civil and legal departments, and extended education and public works. In 1849 he was elevated to the dignity of a Marquis, receiving at the same time the thanks of both Houses of Parliament. He was a K.T., and Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports. The Marquis returned from his duties in the East, in shattered health, in 1855. Having no sons by his wife, his cousin, Lord PANMURE, is the heir of his Scottish titles.

abstract: The Southern Disunion Press persists in encouraging the belief among the people, that they have only to hold on a little while in their Disunion movement, and starvation will do its work among the people of the North. They believe that all our manufacturing establishments are entirely dependent on the Southern supply of cotton, -- that shipping cotton constitutes the great bulk of the business of our Northern cities, and that as soon as the laboring portion of all our Northern communities feel the pressure of secession in throwing them out of employment, they will rise in mobs and compel submission to the demands of the South.

abstract: The Court for the purpose of trying Col. CORCORAN, of the 69th Regiment, who is charged with disobedience of orders in refusing to parade at the reception of the Prince of Wales, was to have met at the Arsenal in White-street, at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon. At that hour there were present Brigadier-Gen. SPICER, Col. POSTLY, Judge Advocate MEAD, Col. GEO. W. MORELL, the complainant, Col. CORCORAN, the accused, and his counsel, RICHARD O'CORMAN, Esq., besides a room-full of spectators, mainly friends of the accused. Half an hour was lost in waiting for Col. PINCKNEY, the third member of the Court. Col. PINCKNEY at length arrived, and the record of proceedings already taken was read.

abstract: The Woman's Library will be found a pleasant place this Winter for those who avail themselves of its privileges. Many beautiful books have lately been added to its former handsome collection, among which are two splendid editions of Shakespeare, and other rare and valuable books, from BURTON's Library. Of the Shakespeares, one is the edition of JOHNSON & STEVENS, of 1778, in twelve large volumes, and the other is HANMER's (Oxford) edition of 1771. There is also BOYDEL's Plates of SHAKESPEARE, the most beautiful engravings illustrating the works of that great man ever executed. Another fascinating book is HOLBEIN's Court of Henry VIII. The ladies examining this curious volume, will get some new ideas as to the fashions of headdresses of the greatest beauties of the Court in those days, and will be surprised to find that bewitching creature, ANNE BOLEYN, with her head tied up in a dingy handkerchief, and looking, as Mrs. Crupp would say, "quite ornary." HOLBEIN was the great painter of HENRY VIII.'s Court; and the portraits in this book are perfect copies of those which hang upon the walls of Hampton Court Palace. But perhaps the most acceptable addition to the books of the Woman's Library will be the books of fashion, which will be imported direct from Paris every month, beginning with last December, for the benefit of those women engaged in various branches of millinery and dressmaking, whose means have prevented their access to the highest authorities in fashion, and whose opportunities for improvement in their business has been thereby cramped and delayed. The subscription price to the best magazines of fashion published in Paris is from $10 to $15 a year; and the Woman's Library has ordered nearly a dozen of the best, comprising those containing plates and new patterns for needlework and crotchet, as well as those for dresses, cloaks, mantillas, and millinery. Paper patterns accompany the magazines devoted to the latter, and the subscribers to the Library will be permitted to cut patterns from them. Thus they will have artistic rules to guide them, and may become finished artists in their work themselves. Would not the gift of a year's subscription ticket to the Library be acceptable to most not over-rich young women?

abstract: We have not as a people yet attained that degree of love for the beautiful which prompts us to demand from our Government, national or civic, free public galleries, and yet no people are so well and so liberally supplied with food for thought, for study and improvement through the medium of private enterprise, as ours. We have no public permanent collections -- all belong to private individuals, who gather the treasures of the old and new Worlds, either for their personal gratification or their own aggrandisement. At GOUPIL's the Third Annual Exhibition of French and Flemish Paintings is still open. It was to have been closed on the 1st of January, but so eager and extended has been the curiosity to see the pictures, that the proprietors have wisely concluded to remain with us for some little time. At no one time will our space permit us to give an extended or full review of the many beautiful works there exhibited, but it is with pleasure that from time to time we can call the attention of our readers to individual gems of the collection.

abstract: Our dispatches this morning add nothing of special importance to the actual movements of the Disunionists in the Southern States. In Georgia some of the Federal arsenals have been seized, and a mob in North Carolina, in defiance of the State authorities, was prepared to follow the example within that State. In Charleston there seems to be a very great eagerness to capture Fort Sumter, but the ways and means of accomplishing that object have not yet been devised. The reported change in the President's purposes towards disunion has created a fresh effervescence throughout the more violent of the Southern States, -- but it certainly can lead to nothing more serious than would have taken place without it. The general tone of feeling throughout the country has been immensely improved by the intelligence. The people everywhere feel inspired with fresh courage to confront whatever perils the future may have in store, when they have reason to hope that they will not be deserted by the very men to whom they have intrusted the guardianship of their honor and their rights.

abstract: The steam-tug R.L. Mabey, when coming up the Lower Bay yesterday morning, saw the schooner F.J. Brognard, of New York, ashore on the west bank, and abandoned. The men on the tug saw the captain and crew leave her, and land on Staten Island shore. They went to them, and offered to carry them back, and tow the vessel off the bank. The captain refused to have anything more to do with her. The tug then went to the schooner, and, after placing two men on board, took her in tow, and docked her at Pier No. 33 North River. She has her counter stove in about the rudder-hole, and is leaking badly. She is supposed to be from Philadelphia, and is loaded with coal.

abstract: While FRANCIS JOSEPH II., youngest and last King of Naples, continues to maintain in the face of universal remonstrance the hopeless ...
lead_paragraph: While FRANCIS JOSEPH II., youngest and last King of Naples, continues to maintain in the face of universal remonstrance the hopeless defence of Gaeta, the French Emperor persists in puzzling the world by giving him the quasi support of a fleet. Why should he lend a helping hand to the most unpopular phase of that old-fashioned absolutism which differs so much from, and which has been so inimical, to his own. After suggesting a Murat-Neapolitan rule -- a universal referee theory, and other explanations -- the journalists of all European nations seem, between the 20th and 22d ultimo, to have resolved that "It's a' a muddle." And, as if to puzzle them still more, we learn that at the last hour dispatches had been received from St. Petersburgh, "begging the French Government to continue to give the protection of its fleet to FRANCIS JOSEPH."

abstract: In a country addicted to home-flesh--as every Angle-Saxon country must be--the feats of the horsetamer are viewed with something more than favor.
lead_paragraph: In a country addicted to home-flesh -- as every Angle-Saxon country must be -- the feats of the horsetamer are viewed with something more than favor. Mr. RAREY, the most renowned of this class, and a man who is acknowledged to be without an equal, and so far as we know without a rival, having graduated in Europe, comes back to the land of his birth for the applause which should surely await him. His first "lecture," (for so it is properly called, inasmuch as its object is not merely amusement but instruction,) takes place to-day, at Niblo's Garden, commencing at 3 o'clock. The event will need, we are sure, no more than this simple mention. But we may add, as a circumstance of decided public interest, that Mr. RAREY has succeeded in securing a horse of due viciousness, and one who is likely to do full justice to his peculiar powers of persuasion. The animal, Joe Anderson by name, Is known extensively to those who frequent the road, his owner being Mr. LUFF, a hosteler of high fame in the up-town eastern side of the City. Joe is descended legitimately from the famous Messenger, and is supposed to be the only scion of that distinguished horse now in America. His antecedents are in the highest degree unsatisfactory. Mischievous treatment in early horsehood soured the natural sweetness of his disposition, and from the time when an accidental injury was inflicted on him with a pitchfork, he has never been known to do a kindly thing. For the last four years he has been allowed to have, his own way, and has taken advantage of the opportunity to inflict all the injury on his friends that was possible. It is said that among other feats he has killed two boys who were indiscreet enough to come within his reach. During the entire period he has never had a shoe upon his feet. His owner is is incredulous of Mr. RAREY'S powers, and will be satisfied if the redoubtable Joe can be subdued, oven with the grim hand of death. He is regarded as incorrigible, as a veritable Cruiser, and a blessed malcontent whom the public will relish hugely.

abstract: Rev. Dr. ADAMS, of the Madison-square Presbyterian Church, preached a discourse appropriate to the occasion, to a very large audience. He took a conservative view of the national difficulties, and argued that the object and aim of government was to promote the happiness and welfare of the people, and that legislation upon moral questions did come within the legitimate sphere of its duties, and was disorganizing in its tendency. The discourse, which occupied an hour in its delivery, is unavoidably crowded out.

abstract: On Sunday last Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER informed his congregation that the President of the United States had deemed it wise to recommend a ...
lead_paragraph: On Sunday last Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER informed his congregation that the President of the United States had deemed it wise to recommend a day of National Fasting, and the Governor of the State of New-York had issued a proclamation to the same effect ; and that, in conformity with the desires of those eminent authorities, he would have his church opened on Friday, the 4th, and he would improve the occasion by the delivery of a sermon suited to the times and the events which had made it necessary for the nation to mourn, confess and supplicate. As a natural consequence, despite the falling snow, the slippery pathway and the threatened storm, an immense number of people from this City and Brooklyn wended their way to Plymouth Church, and at 10 o'clock, one hour before service was to begin, the pews and aisles, the windows and doors, the pulpit stairs, and even the platform itself, were crowded to the utmost capacity, and hundreds were compelled to go away disappointed. Rev. Mr. CUYLER was in the pulpit with Mr. BEECHER, and we recognized in the audience the venerable Lyman Beecher, David Dudley Field, Charles L. Brace, Addison Burt, Pay-master Eldredge, of the United States Navy, and Rev. Mr. Ewer, late of San Francisco, and at present Rector of St. Ann's Church in this City.

abstract: A large Union meeting of our citizens was held at Citizens' Hall to-night. Owing to a misunderstanding of the object of the meeting great disorder prevailed at first. An attempt was made to hiss down Dr. A.H. GRIMSHAW, on the ground that he was a Republican, but he finally obtained a hearing, and made a Union speech. Resolutions were passed indorsing the course of the Legislature, and repudiating the Mississippi Commissioner and secession in any form.

abstract: FIRE IN JERSEY CITY.--Last night about 7 o'clock a fire occurred in a large two-story brick building on the corner of Greene and Bay streets, ...
lead_paragraph: FIRE IN JERSEY CITY. -- Last night about 7 o'clock a fire occurred in a large two-story brick building on the corner of Greene and Bay streets, Jersey City, occupied as a kerosene oil factory. An alarm was immediately given, but the fire igniting with some oil in the vats, the building in a few moments was enveloped in flames. There were a number of sheds used for storing oil and materials, to which the fire soon communicated, and before the Fire Department were fairly at work, the fire was under full headway. Through their exertions the principal portion of the oil and stock stored under the sheds was saved. The main building, together with the contents, was entirely destroyed. The building is said to have been owned by Messrs. KENNY & HALIDAY, and occupied by SHIFLAND, BROTHER & Co., and the loss was probably from $6,000 to $8,000. No one could be found to give definite information. Steam engine No. 8, of New-York, was present, and did good service. The origin of the fire was unknown.

abstract: He commenced his discourse with a reference to the unusual circumstances under which the congregation had been called together.
lead_paragraph: He commenced his discourse with a reference to the unusual circumstances under which the congregation had been called together. The Union which they loved was in jeopardy. The President, dispairing of all help which might be afforded by human counselers, called upon them to draw near to God, asking His interposition. They had responded to that call, and he need not tell them how deeply he entered into the spirit of the day. The seceding State was his birthplace -- the home of his mother and dearest kindred. Must not, then, his soul feel some sympathy for it. Here, now, was his home, and the birthplace of his children, and how could he feel otherwise than alarmed at the dread separation, which seemed to be impending. Let them look, then, together at the hopes vouchsafed of God's interposition in these dark days. In seeking a proper solution of the text they must recur to the age in which it was written. Rome was then the mistress of the world; her procurators and governors everywhere ruled her captured provinces; her officers and soldiers everywhere displayed the imperial standard, and commanded an unwilling obedience. Publicans were engaged in the thankless office of levying taxes upon the industry of the world, and sending them up to the Metropolis to swell the tide of wealth which flowed at the feet of the Caesars. The religion of the day was a superstitious idolatry, the immorality the most debasing and beastly that ever disgraced the world; the amusements, on the one hand licentious, and on the other cruel and inhuman; the bondage of the slave intolerable, the punishment of the prisoner barbarous; and while there was intelligence, learning, refinement in the better classes, we could scarcely conceive of a state of society so degraded, immoral and destructive to the best interests of religion and humanity, as the rule of despotic Rome. Here and there throughout that vast empire there was to be found little clusters of Christians who had given their hearts to the service of Him who had been crucified, adopting his precepts as the rule of life, and trusting to His promises as an unfailing source of happiness. Persecutions innumerable surrounded their path. To the dungeon and the cross thousands of them were marched, presenting a long catalogue of martyrs called to suffer and die for the sake of Jesus. What was their duty in their said condition? The great Apostle answering, said: "I exhort, therefore, first of all, supplications, prayers, and giving of thanks to be made for all men." The Christians prayed in faith, and the result was a great change, a great reform. Every evil, perhaps, was not reformed; there were still drunkards and debauchees, unfaithful public servants, cruel masters and rebellious slaves; but the Gospel triumphed, and the world was Christianized. And now was there not a much neglected duty brought before them as citizens of the great Republic -- and he asked that God might give them grace to enforce that duty and reduce it to daily practice. From the Capitol, from the great metropolis, from every quiet village and little hamlet, from the extreme North and South notes of alarm were daily wafted to our ears. They told us that the interests, cemented by the blood of our Fathers, rose in jeopardy; that the affections, the patriotism which had stood the best of more than three-quarters of a century; that men's hearts were quaking for fear, and that the future looked dark and ominous. Prejudice and passion seemed to have usurped the place of truth and reason, and in the present unhappy dilemma public men seemed to have lost the power of steering the ship of State out of the quicksands upon which she was in danger of being stranded. Under such circumstances it was the duty of Christians not to leave unemployed the peculiar weapons of their faith to avert the dangers which they feel and fear. We live under the most benignant Government that ever existed -- one which gave us civil and religious liberty, and protected our rights. Granted, that it had its evils, that bad men were sometimes in office, that things were permitted which we did not approve -- still, would we exchange it, with all its imperfections, for any other under the sun? Then, when these notes of alarm reached their ears, what should they, as Christians, do? They should do just what the Christians in Rome did under circumstances infinitely more unpropitious and forbidding. They should pray for the President, for Congress, for the Governor, the Legislature, for the Democrat, the Republican, for the Slaveholder and Abolitionist, for all sorts and conditions of men; for the Christian should have a heart large enough to carry them all with him in the arms of love to a throne of mercy. Let them then pray for the peace of Jerusalem, crucify every feeling which should be banished from the large heart of the patriot Christian, and look upon the whole people of our country as brethren. The more dire the confusion, the more earnestly should they pray, for he knew that He that stilled the tempest still heard prayer, and could produce peace out of discord, friendship out of hate, and, as the now threatening clouds began to disappear from our political horizon, would give us fresh assurances that "blessed is that people whose God is the Lord." That was the great hope of the Christian for the perpetuity of his country.

abstract: This building rapidly approaches completion. Certain of our cotemporaries have been pleased to criticise the decorations and tints of the brilliant circle, but as the coats of paint at that time were limited ...
lead_paragraph: This building rapidly approaches completion. Certain of our cotemporaries have been pleased to criticise the decorations and tints of the brilliant circle, but as the coats of paint at that time were limited to but one, it is fair to presume that a more accurate impression can be conveyed to the public after it is finished than was possible in its then crude and raw state. It is the intention of the managers to open the building on the 15th of January -- giving in the evening a grand concert, and in continuance of the opening, to have on the evening of the 19th a public ball. Too great praise cannot be awarded the conductors of this enterprise, who have from their own purses filled the empty corporate treasury -- have given valuable time without charge, and have displayed a public spirit most commendable in the furtherance of the work.

abstract: The organ of the Disunionists at Washington, misnamed the Constitution, is urging upon the Federal Government the duty of withdrawing its forces from, the forts in the Southern States. It can have no use for these forts, it argues, after the States shall have ceased to have any connection with the Federal Government. We begin to hope that the Constitution may have told the truth in saying that the President was not responsible for anything in its columns. At all events, we are disposed to give him the benefit of the doubt.

abstract: Of all the miscalculations upon which the rebellion at the South is founded, none is more erroneous than the estimate placed upon the ...
lead_paragraph: Of all the miscalculations upon which the rebellion at the South is founded, none is more erroneous than the estimate placed upon the military spirit and resources of the National Government. It has evidently been anticipated that the sentiment of the North -- cowardice, perhaps, might be the plainer term -- would shrink from a conflict which the South, with braggart fierceness, might challenge; or, if the challenge were accepted, that the present Executive, by its inertia, would give the start and every ground of vantage to the insurgents; or that, if the present Executive were disposed to act, it would find the Army indisposed to become the instrument of political correction. One after the other these delusions are disappearing. From the reluctance of Northern representatives to concede, under the direst pressure of Southern threats, any but the most just and reasonable grounds of compromise, it is clear that mere apprehension of an armed conflict with the South has no force upon public opinion here -- a conviction which has gathered unmistakable authenticity from the reception which the gallant act of Major ANDERSON meets from all classes of our population, without regard to previous partisan proclivities.

abstract: We find the following paragraphs in the Mercury: "The military movements are progressing rapidly all around us.
lead_paragraph: We find the following paragraphs in the Mercury: "The military movements are progressing rapidly all around us. The brave sons of Carolina, cheered by me encouragement of her equally courageous daughters, are earnestly and silently doing all that men can do towards putting our State in a position to defend herself against the world. For the present, we retrain from giving the particulars of the various works that are progressing. We will only say, for the benefit of anxious friends, that the gallant volunteers stationed at the various posts around us are, one and all, devoting themselves to fill the exigencies of a noble cause, and that they are, and will doubtless continue, in high spirits, and as comfortable 'as circumstances permit.'

abstract: FERRERO'S SOIREE DANSANTE.--Mr. FERRERO, the maitre de danse of Fourteenth-st., gives his third annual soiree dansante at the Academy of Music on the 17th instant.
lead_paragraph: FERRERO's SOIREE DANSANTE. -- Mr. FERRERO, the maitre de danse of Fourteenth-st., gives his third annual soiree dansante at the Academy of Music on the 17th instant. These entertainments of Mons. FERRERO are entirely unique in their character and are largely attended by our most fashionable citizens. From 5 P.M. until 9 the juveniles have exclusive possession of the floor, the sight of whom is something to be remembered. No Eastern picture is more suggestive of fairy land than the swarm of bright-eyed, lithe-limbed, graceful forms that float around the Academy to the sound of inspiring music, while the boxes, filled with beauty and fashion, and the reflected lights from innumerable jets, form a coup d'oeil which must be seen to be appreciated. After 9 P.M. the scene changes, and the "children of a larger growth" continue the dance until the "wee hours" of morning. The soirees are not public, but given to the present and former pupils of Mr. FERRERO and their friends, for whose benefit we call their attention to it that they may secure their tickets of admission are the stock is exhausted.
