abstract: How strikingly is this solemn declaration verified by the history of the past? The fulfillment of the prediction will be equally true in all coming time.
lead_paragraph: How strikingly is this solemn declaration verified by the history of the past? The fulfillment of the prediction will be equally true in all coming time. Reason alone forbids the belief that the declaration of the text can ever be falsified. Our nature and the circumstances in which that nature is developed and exercised make it impossible that it should be otherwise. Nations are but the aggregate of the individuals who compose them. What God requires of one in his individual capacity he demands of the whole in their associated character. He requires each accountable being to do justly, love mercy, and walk humbly before God, to look for honor in honoring him, and for prosperity in seeking his blessing. Hemakes the same requisitions of nations, and in case of disobedience is sure to visit with punishment. The law which governs nations is as inevitable as the law of gravity. This is written in the plainest language all over the history of the world. As nations have no existence as such in another world their retributions must be meted out and suffered in this. The wisdom, the justice and the perfection of God's government are strikingly illustrated in the fact that the great fundamental laws of our humanity and of our social being execute their own penalty when violated, vindicate themselves as certainly as any law of the physical universe. Their constant, because their natural tendency, is to punish wrong and reward the right. Up to a certain point we may appear to escape, in some instances, the results of our wrongdoing, but the appearance is always a delusion. Sin against God or man is always the seed of sorrow. The harvest may, in a measure, be gathered at the very time of sowing, or an interval may be allowed, to enable it to mature its results, and present them at once, with awfully accumulated force, and in the most crushing and destructive form. As in the individual human system, so in the great body politic, vices cut its sinews --injustice and impiety dig its grave. Under the just and inevitable operation of these great laws of our nature and of God, we find ourselves to-day involved in commercial disorder and treasonable guilt, excited and inflamed by plans and movements for civil revolt, threatened with fratricidal war, and in one portion of the country panic-struck and appalled by fears of a servile insurrection, whose horrors no imagination could conceive. We look upon all this to-day and see in it all the fulfillment of God's word and truth: "The nation and the kingdom that will not serve thee shall perish; yea, those nations shall be utterly wasted."

abstract: Two of our eminent City delegation to Albany have signalized their entrance on public life by giving notice of bills for the repeal of the laws restraining Sunday theatricals and rum-selling. They will need at least one hundred days to accomplish their object, so that the first day of the session was none too early for a beginning. It may prove a slight obstacle with the Legislature -- especially with the members elected by other than dram-shop votes -- that the operation of the laws in question has resulted in the suppression of seventy-five per cent, of crimes on Sunday, as compared with other days, and with the former regime of free Sunday sales and sports. An additional hindrance is quite likely to be found in the fact that, beyond the purlieus of the liquor-shops and lagerbier saloons, our whole City population are more than content with the present comparative peace and order of a decent Sunday, and will join hands with the people and legislators, from all other parts of the State, in the demand to let well enough alone. Even the Herald sees that "the antecedents of a majority of the Legislature would seem to make all such efforts (for repeal) unsuccessful."

abstract: The wisdom of the course that the Western Powers of Europe have pursued in their relations with China remains now to be tested.
lead_paragraph: The wisdom of the course that the Western Powers of Europe have pursued in their relations with China remains now to be tested. They have obtained a treaty in which all their demands are conceded; they have humiliated the Mandarin pride that so long and so obstinately resisted their policy; and they have avenged the wrongs, real or imaginary, that they ever suffered at the hands of Chinese authority. It may be thought that the sum paid for these privileges and victories is large and -- there being little honor to gain in a war against barbarians -- that the material advantages of free trade with China are not sufficiently great to outweigh the deplorable loss of life and great expenditure of money that have marked the campaign. But these drawbacks and disadvantages are merely temporary in their nature, and they would soon be forgotten, if the main object of the war shall be realized, and the fabulous trade of the conquered empire thrown open, in very deed, to the civilized world.
headline: {'main': 'The Peace in China.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Peace in China.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: It seems to be well established that an important feature of the secession movement is the seizure of the National Capital.
lead_paragraph: It seems to be well established that an important feature of the secession movement is the seizure of the National Capital. The Conspirators are quite right in supposingt that the possession of the seat of Government would give them a prodigious advantage in the consummation of their schemes. Gov. WISE is generally regarded as the author of the project, which was originally devised for the contingency of FREMONT'S election in 1856. Since that time the organization has been extended and perfected. Minute-men have been enlisted in Virginia and Maryland, and large bodies of Baltimore roughs and rowdies have been secured for the coup d'etat when the moment for its execution arrives. The military command of the enterprise is understood to be placed in the hands of the Texan Hanger, Major BEN MCCULLOCH, who has been for some time busy in the enrollment of his forces, the secret drill of such squads who could be drilled without fear of detection, and the survey and examination of the City with reference to judicious points of attack, and of subsequent defence against a northern invasion. The period which has been fixed for the actual enactment of the drama was the 15th of February, when the counting of the Presidential vote was to be interrupted and the constitutional declaration of Mr. LINCOLN's election prevented.

abstract: Messrs. Editors : It is the duty of every true man of the South who may happen to be in this distracted city at the present time, to give warning to the Southern States of the danger that impends over them.
lead_paragraph: Messrs. Editors : It is the duty of every true man of the South who may happen to be in this distracted city at the present time, to give warning to the Southern States of the danger that impends over them. The resignation of Gov. FLOYD has thrown the Department of War into the hands of men who breathe nothing but coercion against the South. Mr. Holt is the most violent coercionist in Mr. Buchanan's Cabinet, out-Heroding even Black in this particular, and fully as clamorous for a grand campaign against the South as Gen. SCOTT himself. There was a talk yesterday that SCOTT had been appointed Secretary of War. Such an appointment would have been received by the country in its true interpretation -- as a war appointment -- and the South would have known what to do in the premises. The appointment of Holt is the same thing, but it is the thing in disguise: for the country does not understand HOLT'S position or feelings. Holding the War Office ad interim, SCOTT will be the real Secretary, while he, agreeing with SCOTT, will be his willing agent and sponsor in all his measures of coercion.

abstract: South Carolina seems about to carry on her postal system on her own hook, and it becomes an interesting matter to study the probability ...
lead_paragraph: South Carolina seems about to carry on her postal system on her own hook, and it becomes an interesting matter to study the probability of her success in the enterprise. In order to do this, let us first see what the service in that State costs the Federal Government now, and what arc its advantages to the people who propose to cut themselves off from participation in the advantages of the Union. An examination of the figures of the Post-office-Department for the year ending June 30, 1859, gives us, side by side, detailed accounts of the postal debits and credits in each State of the Confederacy. The Department report shows the following items of cost of the service in South Carolina last year:

abstract: Warlike movements are still reported in the Southern States. A telegram from Mobile announces the seizure of the United States Arsenal ...
lead_paragraph: Warlike movements are still reported in the Southern States. A telegram from Mobile announces the seizure of the United States Arsenal at that place, in which were stored fifteen hundred barrels of powder, three hundred thousand rounds of musket cartridges, and other munitions of war, but only six stand of arms. It was also rumored that Fort Morgan had been taken possession of. Fort Pulaski, below Savannah, was occupied by the Georgian forces en the 2d inst., by order of the Governor. It appears also that the United States revenue cutter Dolphin was seized at that port, but that Gov. BROWN subsequently ordered her restoration to the Government. The dispatch published yesterday, relative to the besieging of Fort Sumter, as we expected, turns out to have been an exaggeration. A telegram from Charleston reports all quiet there. Meantime, another proof that the Administration, whatever may have been its course heretofore, now intends to enforce the Federal laws, is to be found in an order yesterday promulgated at Fort Leavenworth, as coming from Gen. SCOTT, that all the available forces at that post must hold themselves in readiness to move to Fort McHenry at a moment's warning.

abstract: Rev. Dr. RAPHALL delivered a discourse in the Synagogue, in Greene-street, yesterday. His text was the 5th and 6th verses of the 3d Chapter of Jonah.
lead_paragraph: Rev. Dr. RAPHALL delivered a discourse in the Synagogue, in Greene-street, yesterday. His text was the 5th and 6th verses of the 3d Chapter of Jonah. He commenced by saying: We meet here this day under circumstances not unlike those described in my text. Not many weeks ago, on the invitation of the Governor of this State, we joined in thanksgiving for the manifold mercies the Lord had vouchsafed to bestow upon us during the past year. But "coming events cast their shadows before," and our thanks were tinctured by the foreboding of danger impending over our country. The evil we then dreaded has now come home to us. As the cry of the prophet, "Yet forty days and Nineveh shall be overthrown," alarmed that people, so the proclamation, "the Union is dissolved," has startled the inhabitants of the United States. The President -- the chief Officer, placed at the helm to guide the vessel of the Commonwealth on its course -- stands aghast at the signs of the times. He sees the black clouds gathering overhead, he hears the fierce howl of the tornado, and the hoarse roar of the breakers all around him. An aged man, his great experience has taught him that "man's extremity is God's opportunity;" and conscious of his own inability to weather the storm without help from on high, he calls upon every individual "to feel a personal responsibility towards God," even as the King of Nineveh desired all persons "to cry unto God with all their strength" -- and it is in compliance with this call of the Chief Magistrate of these United States that we, like the many millions of our fellow-citizens, devote this day to public prayer and humiliation. The President, more polished though less plain spoken than the King of Nineveh, does not in direct terms require every one to turn from his "evil way, and from the violence that is in their hands." But to me these two expressions seem in a most signal manner to describe our difficulty, and to apply to the actual condition of things both North and South. The "violence in their hands" is the great reproach we must address to the sturdy fire-eater who in the hearing of an indignant world proclaims "Cotton is King." King indeed, and a most righteous and merciful one, no doubt, in his own conceit; since he only tars and feathers the wretches who fall in his power, and whom he suspects of not being sufficiently loyal and obedient to his sovereignty. And the "evil of his ways" is the reproach we must address to the sleek rhetorician who in the hearing of a God-fearing world declares "Thought is King." King indeed, and a most mighty and magnanimous one, no doubt, in his own conceit; all-powerful to foment and augment the strife, though powerless to allay. Of all the fallacies coined in the North, the arrogant assertion that "Thought is King" is the very last with which, at this present crisis, the patience of a reflecting people should have been abused. For, in fact, the material greatness of the United States seems to have completely outgrown the grasp of our most gifted minds: so that urgent as is our need, pressing as is the occasion, no man or set of men have yet come forward capable of rising above the narrow horizon of sectional influences and prejudices, and with views enlightened, just and beneficent to embrace the entirety of the Union and to secure its prosperity and preservation. No, my friends, "Cotton" is not King, and "Human thought" is not King. Adonai Melok. The Lord alone is King! Umalkootho bakol mashala, and His royalty reigneth over all. This very day of humiliation and of prayer, -- what is it but the recognition of His supremacy, the confession of His power and of our own weakness, the supplication which our distress addressee to His mercy? But in order that these supplications may be graciously received, that His supreme protection may be vouchsafed unto our Country, it is necessary that we should begin as the people of Nineveh did; we must "believe in God." And when I say "WE," I do not mean merely us handful of peaceable Union loving Hebrews,but I mean the whole of the people throughout the United Suites, the President and his Cabinet, the President elect and his advisers, the leaders of public opinion North and South, if they truly and honestly desire to save our country,let them believe in God and in His Holy Word; and then when the authority of the Constitution is to be set aside for a higher Law, they will be able to appeal to the highest Law of all, the revealed Law and Word of God, which affords its supreme sanction to the Constitution. After saying that there could be no doubt that the origin of the present quarrel between the two great sections of the Commonwealth was the difference of opinion respecting slaveholding, he placed the subject of his investigation under the three following heads:

abstract: In accordance with the recommendation of the President of the United States, yesterday was very generally observed in this City, and Brooklyn, and ...
lead_paragraph: In accordance with the recommendation of the President of the United States, yesterday was very generally observed in this City, and Brooklyn, and Jersey City, by the closing of business places and attendance at places of worship. Everywhere the day was spent quietly and soberly; and the churches in which services were held were more than usually well filled. Several of the religious denominations united their congregations, and met for prayer in one church. The reformed Dutch Churches assembled at the church in Lafayette-place, at noon, where prayers were offered up by Rev. Drs. DEWITT, HUTTON, HARDENBERGH, BETHUNE and Chancellor FERRIS. In the evening, Dr. BETHUNE preached in his own church, in Twenty-first-street, from the 14th chapter of Jeremiah, contrasting the troubles of the Israelites, at that period, with the dangers with which, as a nation, we were now threatened. In the City of Brooklyn there was also a large Union Prayer Meeting, at the First Presbyterian Church in Henry-street, at which Rev. Drs. STORRS, COX, EELS, ROBINSON and others, made short addresses. In Jersey City the places of business were mostly closed, and many prayer-meetings were held which were well attended. The following are some of the discourses delivered:

abstract: --The recent news from Peking proves conclusively how incontestible is the Chinese claim to being considered barbarians.
lead_paragraph: -- The recent news from Peking proves conclusively how incontestible is the Chinese claim to being considered barbarians. The treatment they bestowed upon the English prisoners was at once childish and brutal -- pulling their hair and whiskers, rubbing their heads in the dust before the feet of petty mandarins, forcing them to their knees, and subjecting them to kindred indignities. They evidently supposed they were establishing their own superiority when they forced the faces of their prisoners to the ground. They imagined that by literally making the unfortunate men bite the dust, they were humbling the power of England. This puerile mode of manifesting, their rage was, however, aggravated by absolute cruelties. The unlucky Messrs. PARKES and LOCH were not only thus insulted, but were tied with thongs so contrived as to cause them acute agony, were thrown into a cart, and then drawn rapidly for many miles over a rough road, while every jolt of the vehicle increased their sufferings. Meanwhile, the Celestial savages amused themselves by seizing their arms and legs, and pulling them, to see if it would hurt them. They were subsequently loaded with heavy chains, their ears were cuffed, they were thrust into a prison along with the commonest and vilest of even Chinese malefactors, and only brought out occasionally, to be subjected to new and more exquisite cruelties and ignominies.
headline: {'main': 'CHINESE BARBARITIES.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'CHINESE BARBARITIES.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We have already, in a previous article, stated our belief that the appointment would come to New-England, that Mr. LINCOLN's well-known sagacity and wisdom would lead to the selection of Hon. GIDEON WELLES, of this city and State, and it now affords us great pleasure to be able to say that, in all human probability, Mr. Welles will receive at the hands of Mr. Lincoln the appointment of Postmaster General. We are satisfied that no better man in all New-England could have been selected, as a reliable and judicious adviser of the President elect, while his eminent ability and great experience in public life particularly point to him as the man for the place.

abstract: Rumors have been current for several days that some of the idle steamers now lying up in our harbor would probably soon find employment in the honorable business of reinforcing Southern forts. The first steamer intended for this service -- the Star of the West -- is, without doubt, already on her way to Charleston with an efficient body of troops for the relief of the gallant Major ANDERSON. This steamer, which belongs to M.O. ROBERTS, and has been of late engaged in the trade to Havana and New-Orleans, was chartered a few days since by the Government, and, on Friday, was coaled with unusual dispatch, and got ready for sea. On Saturday she was cleared for Havana and New-Orleans, and late in the afternoon of the same day she proceeded apparently on her voyage.

abstract: It is always a thankless task to expose the weakness of any portion of our common country. But the extraordinary proceedings of South Carolina, and the equally extraordinary threats of other Southern States, render it necessary to examine the foundations on which they rest. The present disunion movement, when closely scrutinized, resolves itself into an attempted military coercion of the Federal Government into concessions which reason and argument have failed to command.
lead_paragraph: It is always a thankless task to expose the weakness of any portion of our common country. But the extraordinary proceedings of South Carolina, and the equally extraordinary threats of other Southern States, render it necessary to examine the foundations on which they rest. The present disunion movement, when closely scrutinized, resolves itself into an attempted military coercion of the Federal Government into concessions which reason and argument have failed to command. There are portions of the Southern people ignorant enough, or frenzied enough, to rush upon the execution of this endeavor without counting the cost. But there is, to say the least, a respectable minority in every Southern State who have no disposition to rush blindly over a precipice, and who will not object to an inquiry into their ability to maintain the war which an attempt to dissolve the Union will assuredly involve. And there is a very large class of persons at the North who will be strengthened in their loyalty to the Government by seeing how feeble, in all the essentials of effective hostility, its assailants are.

abstract: Ayer's Compound Extract Sarsaparilla. -- No one remedy is more needed in this country than a reliable Alterative, but the sick have been so outrageously cheated by the worthless preparations of Sarsaparilla abroad, that they are disgusted even with the name. Yet the drug cannot be blamed for the Impositions from which they have suffered. Most of the so-called Sarsaparillas in market contain little of the virtue of Sarsaparilla or anything else. They are mere slops -- inert and worthless, while a concentrated extract of the active variety of Sarsaparilla compounded with Dock, Stillingia, Iodine, etc., is, as it ever will be, a powerful alterative and an effectual remedy. Such is Ayer's Extract of Sarsaparilla, as its truly wonderful cures of the great variety of complaints which require an alterative medicine, have abundantly shown. Do not, therefore, discard this invaluable medicine, because you have been imposed upon by something pretending to be Sarsaparilla, while it was not. When you have used AYER's -- then, and not till then, will you know the virtues of Sarsaparilla. abstract: Philanthropists in all ages have been honored amongst their fellows. Merciful men! Those who feel kindly towards man and beast are considered worthy of honorable mention in the beatitudes of our Savior. Probably there is not a reader of this paper who has not often and often shuddered at witnessing the inhuman, the barbarous and wicked treatment of...
lead_paragraph: Philanthropists in all ages have been honored amongst their fellows. Merciful men! Those who feel kindly towards man and beast are considered worthy of honorable mention in the beatitudes of our Savior. Probably there is not a reader of this paper who has not often and often shuddered at witnessing the inhuman, the barbarous and wicked treatment of horses or cattle by fiends in human shape, and who has not burned with smothered indignation or boiled over with rage at some wanton act of cruelty manifested by a driver towards his mere noble brute. So prevalent had this system of cruelty to animals become, that States found it necessary to pass stringent laws concerning it, and Societies were formed in many of the larger cities, whose prime object and end were the prevention of cruelty to dumb animals.

abstract: In this Court, on Saturday, Justice QUACKENBUSH, OSBORN and BERNNAN, disposed of the Calendar as follows: None of the cases having any interest except to the parties concerned. Of thirty one persons charged with assault and battery, fourteen were discharged on account of non-appearance of witnesses, one was allowed postponement, four were remanded, three were fined, seven imprisoned, and two acquitted. Of twenty-one charged with larceny, seven remanded, twelve were imprisoned, and two acquitted.

abstract: The most important incident of the day is the appointment of Mr. SEWARD to be Secretary of State in the approaching Administration of Mr. LINCOLN. We believe it is quite certain that he has accepted the appointment. We assume it to be equally certain that he would not have done so, unless he had felt satisfied that the policy of the President would be in harmony with his own political opinions, and such as he could adopt without any sacrifice of his political position and his personal consistency.

abstract: The Boards of Aldermen and Councilmen will organize to-day, at noon, by the election of presiding officers, and our new Recorder and City Judge will, for the first time, take their seats upon the Bench of the Court of General Sessions. The Board of Aldermen will doubtless elect HENRY W. GENET to its Presidency, in place of WM. J. PECK, although Alderman TUOMEY had many friends in the caucus who would have been glad, had they been able, to secure his elevation. In the Board of Councilmen, MORGAN JONES will doubtless be reelected, his course during the past year having given general satisfaction to these interested, and his fairness in deciding questions of parliamentary law being acknowledged by enemies as well as friends. Of Recorder JOHN T. HOFFMAN and City Judge JOHN H. MCCUNN, we have fully expressed our opinions previous to the November election, and have now only to wait and watch their official action to see in how far their respective departments on the Bench will tally with their professional antecedents and reputations at the Bar. It is thought, and apparently with some good reason, that the Mayor will be utterly powerless over the Aldermen and Councilmen during the balance of his term -- Street Commissioner SMITH and City Inspector DELAVAN standing strongly intrenched in public confidence, and no changes in their Departments being contemplated. Register KEYSER has been in harness since the 1st of the month, and such members of the legal profession as have been brought in contact with him, express themselves fully satisfied. On the whole, we make no doubt that the machinery of our City Government in 1861 will be found to work more smoothly and with less offence, fewer sins, and less objectionable legislation than that of the year just closed. Ex-Judge ABRAHAM D. RUSSELL will hereafter devote himself to the same lucrative and large private practice in criminal cases, which he held before his election to the Bench.

abstract: The great theatrical event of the week or rather the great event at the theatre has been the appearance of Mr. RAREY, the horse-tamer, at Niblo's on Saturday afternoon, before an overflowing audience. A detailed report of the proceedings will be found in another column. Three horses were sub-...
lead_paragraph: The great theatrical event of the week -- or rather the great event at the theatre -- has been the appearance of Mr. RAREY, the horse-tamer, at Niblo's on Saturday afternoon, before an overflowing audience. A detailed report of the proceedings will be found in another column. Three horses were submitted to treatment, and the renowned Cruiser also made his first appearance before an American public. Joe Anderson, who was expected to have been the great feature of the lesson, scarcely did justice to his antecedents, and was completely eclipsed by a South American mustang -- a brave little brute, who fought like a hero and surrendered like one. Joe was not in good spirits; his journey from "up-town" on the previous day having exhausted much of his strength, and rendered him weak on his legs. It was scarcely expected that he would make as good a show as he did. Mr. RAREY will deliver his second lecture tomorrow evening, and expects by that time to be well supplied with vicious horses. He is especially anxious that the worst specimens only shall be brought to him.

abstract: SHOCKING ACCIDENT AT SPEYER'S BREWERY. On Saturday afternoon, while some masons were at work on one of the upper floors in SPEYER'S ;lager-bier brewery, at the corner of One Hundred and Ninthstreet and Ninth-avenue, a partition wall gave way, and buried JACOB MUSLER and another man named VOOEL. A quantity of grain stored in the adjoining...
lead_paragraph: SHOCKING ACCIDENT AT SPEYER's BREWERY. -- On Saturday afternoon, while some masons were at work on one of the upper floors in SPEYER'S ;lager-bier brewery, at the corner of One Hundred and Ninthstreet and Ninth-avenue, a partition wall gave way, and buried JACOB MUSLER and another man named VOOEL. A quantity of grain stored in the adjoining room rushed in through the broken wall and in a few moments the unfortunate workmen were covered to the depth of at least ten feet. They were extricated as expeditiously as possible, but before MUSLER could be reached he was suffocated. VOGEL's legs were both broken by the mass of bricks which fell upon him, and he was otherwise so shockingly injured that little hopes of his recovery are entertained. MUSLER's remains were taken to the Twenty-third Precinct Station-house, where Coroner SCHIRMER will hold an inquest upon them. The accident was caused, it is said, by the immense weight of the grain heaped against the wall.

abstract: "The fire-eaters are in the ascendant still, and nothing but dissolution will do, nor can I see anything to indicate any ray of hope for the maintenance of the Union. The feeling in private is fully as strong as in public, among the class who rule by noise, and none others are yet heard. Among the sober, sensible citizens, who feel with the South, yet are not politicians, and yet who believe in Slavery, the feeling is the same, as, witness the immense popularity of Dr. PALMER's Thanksgiving sermon. Here, as in a large city is always the case, there is a large element of protestants against the worship of the god Slavery, -- but they are silent -- and till the time for reaction comes, must keep silent. Among the Pro-Slavery men themselves, however, there are a few who feel the weight of the barbarism which must grow out of all this excitement; and, as one of them said to me the other day, with a sad voice, 'We have very few patriots among us, and we have not the men for the crisis.' Such men, although quite determined to go with the South wherever she goes, look to the future with anxiety and fear. They feel that the cause is not one to call out the noblest men, and that it never can command the respect or sympathy of the world, -- and they are terror-stricken at the outrages to common decency which are daily perpetrated all over the South, in the name of Southern safety.

abstract: Our dispatches from Washington indicate that the difficulty of fixing upon any plan for adjusting the national difficulties has not yet been overcome, though the efforts to that end are continued, and strong hopes are entertained in influential quarters that these efforts will finally be crowned with success. The Committee appointed by the caucus of the Border States, slave and free, agreed on Saturday, with but one dissenting voice, to a proposition very similar in its details to that of Mr. CRITTENDEN. This gentleman has expressed the belief that a satisfactory adjustment will yet be made through the mediation of the Border States, notwithstanding the fact that several of the most ultra Republicans express their opposition to any plan of compromise, believing that now is the time to test the strength of the Government. A caucus of Southern Senators was held on Saturday evening, to take into consideration the subject of secession, and the interests of those States proposing to secede. It is understood to have been the unanimous opinion, with but one exception -- Senator FITZPATRICK, of Alabama, -- that the States should secede separately. All tears of any attempt on the part of the Disunionists to seize the capital are now at an end, the promptness of Capt. STONE, the new Inspector-General for the District, having placed their success out of the range of possibility.

abstract: The excitement to-day is somewhat increased. THURLOW WEED, HAMILTON FISH, ERASTUS CORNING, ISAAC BELL, and other influential New-Yorkers have arrived. While they counsel moderation and conservatism, it is understood that they are unanimous for the preservation of the Union at any cost. WEED says he sees little probability that any satisfactory compromise will be arranged.

abstract: Alex. Mitchell vs. John Mackay et al. -- This action was stated in the TIMES Dec. 25. The Court has now rendered a decision declaring the sale of the fifty shares of the Pioneer Iron Company's stock fraudulent -- that the plaintiff is entitled to recover $1,250 and interest from Aug. 4, 1857, and $750 with interest from the commencement of the action; that the plaintiff is also entitled to recover $700 on account of the sale of the 400 shares of the Milwaukee and Mississippi Railroad stock; and that as to the other matters the defendants should have judgment, and that neither party is entitled to costs.

abstract: Gov. LETCHER'S message, alluding to the condition of the country, says all see, know and feel that danger is imminent, and all true patriots are exerting themselves to save us from impending perils. abstract: SUPREME COURT. -- CHRISTOPHER C. HOLMES and JOHN O'BRIEN, Plaintiffs, against JOHN McGINLEY, Defendant -- Summons for a money demand on Contract. -- To the defendant above named: You are hereby summoned and required to answer the complaint in this action, of which a copy is herewith served upon you, and to serve a copy of your answer to the said complaint on the subscriber, at his office, at No. 133 Nassau-street, in the City of New-York, within twenty days after the service hereof, exclusive of the day of such service; and if you fail to answer the complains within the time aforesaid, the plaintiffs in this action will take judgment against you for the sum of one hundred and forty-five dollars and fifty cents, with interest from the 6th day of January, 1860, besides the costs of this action. -- Dated Oct. 26, 1850.

abstract: The telegraph announces that Ex-Governor JOHN B. FLOYD, the absconding Secretary of War, has for the present taken up his residence in Richmond, Va., where, doubtless, he can place himself in closer correspondence than heretofore with the seceders and traitors, who already owe so much to his official connivance with their plans.
lead_paragraph: The telegraph announces that Ex-Governor JOHN B. FLOYD, the absconding Secretary of War, has for the present taken up his residence in Richmond, Va., where, doubtless, he can place himself in closer correspondence than heretofore with the seceders and traitors, who already owe so much to his official connivance with their plans. But we have to tell Mr. FLOYD that, if his object be to secure safety or oblivion, he must seek it further South, and in some State which has had less cause to understand his character and motives. His shameful prostitution of the public patronage of the Old Dominion, while he was its Governor, to subserve the private interests of his brother-in-law, General LEWIS, has not yet be a forgotten; nor his complicity in the frauds of certain New England and Virginian backs; nor his infamous collusion with Mr. RAND in the affair of erecting a monument to GEORGE WASHINGTON in the Capitol square of Richmond; nor the secret motives which made him so anxious that Mr. RAND should leave the State Capital with no pecuniary cause of complaint against the generosity of the Chief Magistrate of Virginia. All these things still live, and are matters of daily reference in the respectable circles of the Old Dominion -- a commonwealth so ancient and proud of her honor, not soon being able to forget the first Governor who indulged an ostentatious immorality, and whose official robes were sullied by only too many proofs of collusion with jobbery and organized default.

abstract: Erastus Genin vs. George W. Chadsey and Myron H. Decker. -- In the TIMES of the 27th of December, 1860, it will be remembered we gave a report of the above entitled cause, entitled "Another Trademark Case," "Live and Let Live," It was a motion for an injunction restraining the defendants from using the sign "Live and Let Live." From the facts, as they were then given, it appears that the plaintiff was the proprietor of an oyster-saloon at No. 214 Broadway. The defendant occupies the saloon No. 212 Broadway. Plaintiff alleged that for fourteen years his saloon had been known as the "Live and Let Live," and that his saloon has been for a long while known to the public by that sign. Defendant, whose saloon is next door, put up a sign of the same name and in the same style. The plaintiff charged that by the original appropriation of that name he had acquired exclusive right to use it, and that the use of it by the defendants tended to mislead the public and induce them to the belief that plaintiff's saloon was the original saloon known as the "Live and Let Live." The Judge having taken the papers on the argument of this motion, now decides that an injunction must issue restraining the defendants from the use of the sign as above described.
lead_paragraph: Erastus Genin vs. George W. Chadsey and Myron H. Decker. -- In the TIMES of the 27th of December, 1860, it will be remembered we gave a report of the above entitled cause, entitled "Another Trademark Case," "Live and Let Live," It was a motion for an injunction restraining the defendants from using the sign "Live and Let Live." From the facts, as they were then given, it appears that the plaintiff was the proprietor of an oyster-saloon at No. 214 Broadway. The defendant occupies the saloon No. 212 Broadway. Plaintiff alleged that for fourteen years his saloon had been known as the "Live and Let Live," and that his saloon has been for a long while known to the public by that sign. Defendant, whose saloon is next door, put up a sign of the same name and in the same style. The plaintiff charged that by the original appropriation of that name he had acquired exclusive right to use it, and that the use of it by the defendants tended to mislead the public and induce them to the belief that plaintiff's saloon was the original saloon known as the "Live and Let Live." The Judge having taken the papers on the argument of this motion, now decides that an injunction must issue restraining the defendants from the use of the sign as above described.

abstract: The Select Committee appointed for investigating the recent abstraction of Indian Bonds from the Treasury, arrived in this City yesterday morning and took up their quarters at the St. Nicholas Hotel. They immediately communicated with the United States District-Attorney, Ex-Judge ROOSEVELT, who was unable to attend their first meeting, at noon, in room No. 236 of that Hotel.
lead_paragraph: The Select Committee appointed for investigating the recent abstraction of Indian Bonds from the Treasury, arrived in this City yesterday morning and took up their quarters at the St. Nicholas Hotel. They immediately communicated with the United States District-Attorney, Ex-Judge ROOSEVELT, who was unable to attend their first meeting, at noon, in room No. 236 of that Hotel. At that meeting they passed a resolution to keep all the proceedings private until their termination, when they will issue a Report to be made public by the Press. In the meantime reporters are rigidly excluded, it being the opinion of the Committee that a publication of their proceedings from day to day would tend to embarrass the course of justice and prevent a full investigation of the frauds committed. District-Attorney ROOSEVELT did not reach the Hotel until late in the afternoon, and, as far as we could learn, no witnesses were examined, and the business was only preliminary.
headline: {'main': 'The Indian Bonds Abstraction.; THE COMMITTEE OF INVESTIGATION IN NEW-YORK.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Indian Bonds Abstraction.; THE COMMITTEE OF INVESTIGATION IN NEW-YORK.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Then the world was recently astonished by the remarkable permission to publicly discuss his measures, extended by the Emperor of France to popular representatives, a correspondent of the London Daily News declared that he had reason to believe that the French Government intended further liberal concessions.
lead_paragraph: When the world was recently astonished by the remarkable permission to publicly discuss his measures, extended by the Emperor of France to popular representatives, a correspondent of the London Daily News declared that he had reason to believe that the French Government intended further liberal concessions. The Minister of the Interior, PERSIGNY, had, it was stated, inspired the Emperor with a new domestic and international policy, which would soon be fully exposed. Certain it is, that after this reform there came, in quick succession, the same liberty of the Press, with promise of extension, and permission to Englishmen to travel passport free in France. Those doubting the sincerity or consistency of the Emperor in making these liberal concessions, are referred to that universally prophetic index, his earlier works, where all such measures are warmly advocated.

abstract: The January Term of this Court was opened yesterday by Judge LEONARD. The jury lists were called, excuses heard, and the Jurors discharged for the day. The District-Attorney then briefly addressed the Court in eulogy of the late Judge Kent, who had once presided over this Court, and moved to adjourn as a mark of respect for his memory. The Court remarked that such a course was eminently proper, and ordered an adjournment at once, to Tuesday morning at 10 o'clock.

abstract: To any dyspeptic sufferer, who requires a good laugh to put his blood into more active circulation, we recommend the moderate perusal of Mayor WOOD'S Message to the Common Council. It will be found a somewhat violent remedy, but if no more than three paragraphs be taken at one sitting, there can be no danger of bursting a blood vessel.
lead_paragraph: To any dyspeptic sufferer, who requires a good laugh to put his blood into more active circulation, we recommend the moderate perusal of Mayor WOOD'S Message to the Common Council. It will be found a somewhat violent remedy, but if no more than three paragraphs be taken at one sitting, there can be no danger of bursting a blood vessel. Taken, however, in homoepathic doses of one paragraph at a time, the document will prove a mild and perfectly harmless stimulant of seniles. It commences with what it terms a "prophetic quotation," in which there is no prophecy, -- and has for its bulk a string of "arguments," in which there is no logic. Every sentence of the fulmination is rife with suggestions in favor of violence, bloodshed and civil war; while in the concluding lines of this strange production, the Mayor announces that he is not "yet" prepared "to recommend the violence implied in these views!" The attempt of a demagogue is first made to inflame all the passions of the ignorant and needy to the highest point of exasperation; and then the mischief-maker, to protect himself, protests, with mock meekness, against the natural fruits of the seed he has just been sowing.

abstract: The arrival of the U.S. ship Dacotah, is the principal item of news in this, our unusually dull city. Your gun-boat, though reputed fast, had a long passage from Rio Janeiro. This is attributed to her little coal capacity. Indeed, the Dacotah is a failure so far as her man-of-war qualities are concerned. She rolls incessantly, rendering her battery totally useless, and making it next to impossible to lower her fighting bulwarks.

abstract: ITALIAN OPERA. We are not to be absolutely without opera this Winter, after all. M. MUZIO, who is well remembered and esteemed as an orchestral conductor, has taken a limited lease of the Academy of Music, and will opon that beautiful but unfortunate concern on the 21st inst., for a season of four weeks.
lead_paragraph: ITALIAN OPERA. -- We are not to be absolutely without opera this Winter, after all. M. MUZIO, who is well remembered and esteemed as an orchestral conductor, has taken a limited lease of the Academy of Music, and will opon that beautiful but unfortunate concern on the 21st inst., for a season of four weeks. The company will consist of Mme. COLSON, Signor BRIGNOLI, Signor SUSINI, and the other members of the late starring troupe. To this list may perhaps be added the name of a new prima donna, recently arrived from Brazil, but of whose antecedents we are entirely uninformed. It is said, however, that Mlle. ELENA, the lady in question, possesses a good voice, and if it be true she will need no better introduction. Under any circumstances, we may safely aanticipate a series of good Italian representations, with reliable singers, chorus, orchestra and conductor. Let us hope that Mr. MUZIO will be adequately supported by the public.

abstract: On Sunday evening a number of Eleventh Ward policemen made a demonstration against some petty gamblers, who conducted their operations in a lager-bier saloon kept by Jacob Letts, at No. 99 Willett-street. Not anticipating a visit from the officers, the gamblers were found absorbed in the game of bluff, and were easily taken prisoners. Justice BRENAN yesterday fined the offenders $1 each, and let them go. The proprietor of the place was required to furnish bail in the sum of $500, to answer. One of the prisoners, named John Galway, on his way from Essex Market to the Tombs, escaped from the custody of the police.

abstract: In our Washington dispatches, this morning, will be found a verification, by an authority which none will be disposed to question, of the reports which have reached us relative to the distressing condition of affairs in Charleston, and elsewhere in South Carolina, growing out of the stoppage of all business through the position of rebellion which that State has seen fit to assume towards the General Government. Com. SHUBRICK, who has just arrived from Charleston, states that the greatest anxiety and terror prevail there, enhanced by every fresh report of movements at the North. It is believed that a revulsion of feeling against the Disunionists must soon take place, unless Georgia speedily adopts a course to infuse new life into the secession movement, and give the already wavering people a new accession of courage.

abstract: The Eighth of January stands as one of the monumental columns in American history, and already its hero looms up in the legends of the Republic. The day and its man figure together in the public mind as the types of American independence and democracy, and their memory is one of the strong links that unite the South, the West and the North in the bonds of fraternal suffering and triumph.
lead_paragraph: The Eighth of January stands as one of the monumental columns in American history, and already its hero looms up in the legends of the Republic. The day and its man figure together in the public mind as the types of American independence and democracy, and their memory is one of the strong links that unite the South, the West and the North in the bonds of fraternal suffering and triumph. Such dates as this, the 4th of July, the 22d of February, the 22d of December, and so forth, are to us what the Fasti were to the ancient Romans -- they are inscribed on the tablets of the national memory and handed down to posterity to be preserved forever. Their history, thank God! still quickens the national pulse and strengthens its resolves; and as we descend into the struggles of the present hour, these great deeds of our ancestors fire us with emulation to do yet greater deeds which shall also be written on the Fasti of America.

abstract: Mr. RAREY'S second lecture took place last evening, at Niblo's Garden, inside and out. So great a gathering as was there assembled is a stronger proof of Mr. RAREY'S powers than the mere subjugation of Cruiser or Joe Anderson, or any other horse. The many-headed public, however, was by no manner of means "tamed all over" by what they witnessed, and before the end of the lecture grew vicious instead of quietly submitting and trotting home affectionately.

abstract: The correspondent of a cotemporary gravely denounces the rashness of attempting to send reinforcements to Fort Sumter by the Star of the West. The reason, because the vessel and its load would be wholly at the mercy of....
lead_paragraph: -- The correspondent of a cotemporary gravely denounces the rashness of attempting to send reinforcements to Fort Sumter by the Star of the West. The reason, because the vessel and its load would be wholly at the mercy of Fort Moultrie through its entire passage up the tedious ship channel; while it would only come within range of the guns of Fort Sumter during the last three and a half miles of its course. It is argued, therefore, that the ship might be knocked to pieces by the insurgents in the former fortress before it would be near enough to the latter to obtain protection.

abstract: The grand ball given, last evening, at the St. Nicholas Hotel by its public-spirited proprietors, under the management of a Committee of one hundred eminent citizens of all parties, was a splendid ovation to the memory of the hero of New-Orleans and of the battle which has made him and the day famous. The west dining-room of the hotel was the dancing hall, and there, at an hour as late as ...
lead_paragraph: The grand ball given, last evening, at the St. Nicholas Hotel by its public-spirited proprietors, under the management of a Committee of one hundred eminent citizens of all parties, was a splendid ovation to the memory of the hero of New-Orleans and of the battle which has made him and the day famous. The west dining-room of the hotel was the dancing hall, and there, at an hour as late as the etiquette of these days prescribes, -- an hour at which our progenitors were wont to break up their evening parties, -- a gay throng was assembled, and he dancing commenced. The ball-room was very tastefully decorated with American flags. It was thrown open for the first time as a Terpsichorean salon, and seemed to be exceedingly well adapted to the purpose. Unfortunately, the floor had just been waxed, and had an adhesiveness which interfered somewhat with many soles. It may be laid down as an axiom in affairs of the light, fantastic toe, that beyond a certain point in proportion as a dancing floor has been waxed, pleasure may be said to have waned. It was the only drawback of the evening's festivities, and was a very slight one. The music was by DODWORTH'S Band, and was, of course, excellent. The ladies, who, at-10 o'clock, when they began to thread the mazes, were not unduly numerous, an hour later with difficulty navigated -- there were so many of them. The scene was an exceedingly brilliant one. Among the distinguished gentlemen present were Hon. Daniel S. Dickinson, August Belmont, Augustus Schell, Richard Schell, Judge Daly, Judge Braby, Maj.-Gen. Sanford, Gen. Hali; Cols. Bostwick, Pinckney, Butterfield; Division-Engineer Morrell, Commodore Garrison, Recorder Hoffman, John E. Burrill and Udolpho Wolfe. The following letters were received by the Executive Committee:

abstract: The good work of purging the Federal Government of traitors makes steady and encouraging progress. We hear this morning that Secretary THOMPSON has resigned. His sympathy with treason and rebellion outweighs ...
lead_paragraph: The good work of purging the Federal Government of traitors makes steady and encouraging progress. We hear this morning that Secretary THOMPSON has resigned. His sympathy with treason and rebellion outweighs his fear of being regarded as a fugitive from justice, -- and he quits the Department in which occurred the late enormous robbery of bonds intrusted to his care. At any price the Government is well rid of him. If any Secessionists still linger around the council-board of the Union, we trust they will either resign or be relieved of duties which hey are incompetent properly to perform.

abstract: Suppose the crop of the South, the past year, had been in food wheat, corn, beef and pork as in the Northern and Western States, what would have been their position in the present crisis? Why, the foreign demand for it would have been more active than for cotton, while the ample means of support among ...
lead_paragraph: Suppose the crop of the South, the past year, had been in food -- wheat, corn, beef and pork -- as in the Northern and Western States, what would have been their position in the present crisis? Why, the foreign demand for it would have been more active than for cotton, while the ample means of support among themselves would have placed them in a position of almost entire independence of the North, and would, consequently, have made them impregnable. Under such circumstances, if we had command of the sea, they would have laughed at us from, their well-stocked granaries. With abundance of food, contentment could have been secured at home, while they would have abundant guarantees for the ultimate sale of all the surplus in the primary want of mankind -- that of food.

abstract: John H. Deyo, residing at No. 6 City Hall-place, made an affidavit before Justice WELSH, on Monday, charging, in substance, that he had of late been buying experience dearly at the House No.52 Lispenardstreet, kept by one Cooley Keese, and also at No.438-...
lead_paragraph: John H. Deyo, residing at No. 6 City Hall-place, made an affidavit before Justice WELSH, on Monday, charging, in substance, that he had of late been buying experience dearly at the House No.52 Lispenardstreet, kept by one Cooley Keese, and also at No.438- Broadway, of which Thomas McCann and Charles Williams are the presiding genii. His experience' consisted in the fact that he had hazarded his cash on certain games known as faro and roulette, which games the gentleman in question nightly induced himself and other unsophisticated persons to participate in, to the destruction of their morality and peace. Having thus become "played out" himself, he wanted those who had brought him to his present undesirable condition to be placed in the same category. The Magistrate, upon the strength of Deyo's representations, issued warrants for the arrest of Keese, George W. Brown, his dealer, McCann and Williams, and the Police of the Fifth and Fourteenth Wards respectively executed them. The visitors at Keese's place, to the number of eleven, were apprehended about 8 o'clock on Monday evening, and several hours later eight of the patrons of the other establishment were also placed in durance. Yesterday all the prisoners were arraigned before Justice KELLY, at the Tombs, and examined upon the charge. The hearing resulted, apparently, to the great gratification of a large audience of sporting men, in the discharge of all the accused, excepting the proprietors of the houses, on the ground that they had only been spectators of and not participants in the games. The others furnished bail in $1,000 each for trial. Several hundred dollars worth of ivory checks, cards, cues, and other gambling paraphernalia were seized, and are in custody of the authorities.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. The management of this establishment supplied its patrons, on Monday night, with a capital evening's fun, and this, too, without the slightest expenditure of novelty-for the burlesque...
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- The management of this establishment supplied its patrons, on Monday night, with a capital evening's fun, and this, too, without the slightest expenditure of novelty -- for the burlesque of "Mazeppa," although new here, scarcely comes under that head. Mr. JOE JEFFERSON was the spirit of the occasion, appearing in no fewer than three pieces. The first of these was the respectable, but not at all dull, comedietta, called "Lend Me Five Shillings," in which' the comedian's quick style of humor was seen to great advantage. The house was kept in a constant roar of merriment. Then came the burlesque of "Mazeppa," and lastly the screaming farce called the "Spitfire." It is only necessary to add a few words to this enumeration of good things. The burlesque has been freely altered from the London edition, and adapted to this locality by the usual references to Jersey and lager-beer. Quickened with this infusion of American wit, it is now, we suppose, a better work than it ever was before, and certainly sufficiently amusing to merit a long career. The puns with which the dialogue is studded are frequently admirable, and perplex the ear of the intellect to a degree which renders laughter or madness inevitable. The action, -- well it is not necessary to analyze the action, -- it is sufficient that it moves on the most improved style of rocking-horse. We have seldom seen a piece played with greater spirit. Mr. JEFFERSON was truly excellent, and danced his minuet and performed his daring act in the ring to perfection. The latter, by the way, is a new revelation, and a vast improvement on the old wicker-horse arrangement. It was so good, indeed, that the audience without any regard to the effort required in making it so, persisted in encoring it, or rather bringing the appl use to such a point that Mr. JEFFERSON had to beg to be excused from the overtaxing honor. Mrs. CHANFRAU supported Mr. JEFFERSON with great spirit, and achieved in consequence a decided success. Mr. J.H. STODDARD was very good in the burlesque, and also in the comedietta. Some of the minor parts were but indifferently studied; notably in in the case of Mr. DAVIDGE; otherwise they were well distributed.

abstract: Judge LEONARD, in opening his remarks, referred to the importance of the functions pertaining to the Grand Jury. While corruption had crept into other political bodies and branches of government, it was the pride of the Grand Jury system that no charge of...
lead_paragraph: Judge LEONARD, in opening his remarks, referred to the importance of the functions pertaining to the Grand Jury. While corruption had crept into other political bodies and branches of government, it was the pride of the Grand Jury system that no charge of such evil had ever been made against them. The jurors had been selected, not for their wealth or standing in society, but because they were men of approved character. The attention of the Jury was called to the fact that the Supreme Court and other tribunals in the City were not properly supplied with rooms for transacting their various business. The duties of these tribunals were of the highest importance, thousands of causes, involving property of the value of millions of dollars were settled therein, and in the Oyer and Terminer, the life and liberties of the citizen were often on trial.

abstract: President BUCHANAN has got rid of another clog to his Administration, in the person of Secretary THOMPSON, who resigned his position as head of the Interior Department yesterday. It is understood that his conditional resignation has been held in terrorem over the President for upwards of a week the final step being induced by the fact of reinforcements having been sent to Major ANDERSON on the Star of the West. Mr. THOMPSON ...
lead_paragraph: President BUCHANAN has got rid of another clog to his Administration, in the person of Secretary THOMPSON, who resigned his position as head of the Interior Department yesterday. It is understood that his conditional resignation has been held in terrorem over the President for upwards of a week -- the final step being induced by the fact of reinforcements having been sent to Major ANDERSON on the Star of the West. Mr. THOMPSON insists that the President pledged himself that no troops should be sent to the South without his knowledge, and it now appears that yesterday morning he first learned of the fact of the movement of troops to Fort Sumter. Report says that high words passed between the President and the retiring Secretary.

abstract: There was ample supply of stock yesterday. About 3,000 head were on sale at Forty-fourth-street, and at least 200 or 300 more expected for to-day's market. With the exception of a single animal or two, which would class as premium, and a few lots of good beeves, the cattle were generally of ordinary quality -- quite inferior to the offerings one week ago. Trade was dull, and prices fully 1/4c. B lb. lower than last week -- some sellers thought 1/2c. There were enough left over for late buyers, and a dragging market is anticipated before the close to-day, with a further decline in prices. A very few choice animals brought 10c., but good beeves were to be had at 9c., and medium bullocks at 8c.

abstract: That millennium, which prophet and priest of a Liberal turn, have long and wearily predicted for Mexico, seems at last to have dawned. Our news, brief as it reads, is to the utmost exciting and gratifying. The Constitutional Army, ...
lead_paragraph: That millennium, which prophet and priest of a Liberal turn, have long and wearily predicted for Mexico, seems at last to have dawned. Our news, brief as it reads, is to the utmost exciting and gratifying. The Constitutional Army, whose advance upon the capital has been slow certainly, but, as the result proves, eminently guarded and circumspect, seems to have been anticipated in its approach by a sortie of MIRAMON, who on the 22d of December encountered his enemy, and after a contest, of which we lack particulars, sustained a fatal rout, and fled alone to the City. Staying only long enough to pack his portmanteau and portmonnaie, and perhaps to secure the company of his wife, he resumed his flight on the 24th. Christmas witnessed the entry into the capital of the triumphant Liberals, and, in all probability, the close of the war.
headline: {'main': 'The Liberal Triumph in Mexico.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Liberal Triumph in Mexico.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A grand banquet, in honor of the memory of ANDREW JACKSON, in connection with his renowned victory at New-Orleans, forty-six years ago, attracted nearly all the brothers of the Tammany Society, with many of their friends, to Tammany Hall last night.
lead_paragraph: A grand banquet, in honor of the memory of ANDREW JACKSON, in connection with his renowned victory at New-Orleans, forty-six years ago, attracted nearly all the brothers of the Tammany Society, with many of their friends, to Tammany Hall last night. The affair had been gotten up in great haste, Mr. BROWN, the landlord and caterer, having only received his instructions on Sunday night, but, nevertheless, in all respects it was perfect, and the large room presented a magnificent appearance. The decorations were very appropriate, and at the same time less profuse than has been usual, at Tammany, on similar occasions. In front of the balcony, which has usually been the reporters' gallery, but which was last night occupied by the band, was a framed likeness, in oil, of Old Hickory, the hero of the day, surmounted by a Cap of Liberty, and in large letters the name of "WASHINGTON." Beneath the portrait was suspended a framed copy of the "Declaration of Independence," while on either side, were the names of JEFFERSON, MADISON, MONROE, and WRIGHT. Around the Hall, at regular intervals, were hung the arms of the original thirteen States, with two oil portraits of WASHINGTON, and one each of POLK, CLAY and LAFAYETTE. One of the portraits of WASHINGTON, immediately behind the Grand Sachem's chair, was draped with the American flag. The following, in large letters, on wide spaces of canvas attached to the wall, nearly filled up one end of the room:

abstract: The annual renting of pews in Plymouth Church took place last evening. There was a larger number of people in attendance than on any previous year, the bidding was more spirited, and from ten to twenty per cent, more was realized in premiums than at any previous sale; and what, perhaps, may be considered as indicating the increasing popularity of the Pastor more than any other one circumstance, is the fact that before 11 o'clock every pew in the house was sold, and each one at a premium ranging from $1 to $160. At previous sales there has always been a few pews eft on hand at the close, and generally a large number have been sold at the valuation placed upon them oy the Trustees, without premium.

abstract: THE ACCIDENT AT SPEYERS' BREWERY -- A VERDICT OF CENSURE. -- Coroner SCHIRMER on Monday commenced an inquest upon the body of JACOB MUSLER, a mason, who was killed on Saturday at Speyers' Lion Brewery in One Hundred and Ninth-street, near Ninth-avenue. MARTIN VOGEL testified that he was at work in the Brewery, which is unfinished, and that about noon on Saturday the masons went to the malt floor, on the second story, to eat their dinner. A few minutes afterwards the foreman called to them from below to "come away." Deceased descended by one of the ladders and witness followed. When witness had got about half way down he heard a crashing noise, the grain from above poured upon him and the ladder was broken by a falling beam. A plank fell on witness, who was knocked down and nearly suffocated by the grain, but Mr. SPEYERS and the workmen rescued him. Deceased was found soon afterwards at the foot of the ladder suffocated and covered by grain to the depth of ten feet. Mr. SPEYERS testified that his Brewery was in process of construction, and that Mr. LOUIS BURGER, the architect, had full power to do everything to insure its stability and safety. Coroner SCHIRMER and the Jury examined the premises, which demonstrated that the immediate cause of the accident was the falling of a partition wall, which formed part of the old building. A number of iron pillars which rested on this wall, as supports to the floor above, were found to have been forced into the brick-work by the weight of the grain. Dr. BOUTON made an examination of the body of deceased, and finding no marks of violence, gave an opinion that death had resulted from suffocation. The Coroner, having been unable to secure the attendance of certain witnesses, adjourned the investigation until yesterday afternoon. At that time the case was again opened, and a large quantity of testimony was given with reference to the construction of the building. The jury, after due deliberation, returned the following verdict: "We find that deceased came to his death from suffocation, by having been covered with barley, in the malt-house of Speyers' Lion Brewery, Jan. 5, 1861, in consequence of the falling of the malt floor, occasioned by the use of a defective wall in the rebuilding of said brewery. Further, we would censure LOUIS BURGER, the architect and superintendent of said brewery, for culpable carelessness in allowing the use of said wall."

abstract: DEATH FROM EXPOSURE -- THE AUTHORITIES CENSURED. -- Coroner JAMES H. O'DONNELL, of Hudson City, held an inquest on Monday evening on the body of John GAYNOR, one of the oldest stage-drivers in Hudson County, who was found lying dead in a barn in Newark-avenue, Hudson City. It appears that deceased,' who was of intemperate habits, had been wandering about the streets in a destitute condition, and the authorities were notified of the fact, but neglected to render him any aid. The jury rendered a verdict that deceased came to his death from intemperance and exposure; and censured the authorities for neglect, in not providing for him -- they having been notified of his situation.
lead_paragraph: DEATH FROM EXPOSURE -- THE AUTHORITIES CENSURED. -- Coroner JAMES H. It appears that deceased,' who was of intemperate habits, had been wandering about the streets in a destitute condition, and the authorities were notified of the fact, but neglected to render him any aid. The jury rendered a verdict that deceased came to his death from intemperance and exposure; and censured the authorities for neglect, in not providing for him -- they having been notified of his situation.

abstract: The Message of Gov. LETCHER, of Virginia, has been briefly sketched by telegraph. After a few introductory remarks by way of impressing upon the legislators the importance of their responsibilities in the present crisis, he addresses him elf to the discussion of our Federal Relations. The country, he says, is torn by dissension; -- the vile spirit of faction shows itself on all sides. Confidence is destroyed; the ties of brotherhood have been severed, and though living under the same Constitution the sections seem to be as hostile, each to the other, as if their citizens belonged to unfriendly Governments. Under such circumstances it is hardly possible for a Government to live; but it is useless to look at the past, for in the present, if it is improved, the ties of affection may be recruited, and the fires of patriotism rekindled, and if this is done a bright and glorious future is still before us. Gov. LETCHER then alludes to our progress as a nation. From an original area of 549,615 square miles our country has expanded until it covers 1,602,000, exclusive of the Mesilla Valley, embracing 78,000, and the Indian Territory, embracing 187,000 square miles. Our power, influence, agricultural and manufacturing wealth have increased beyond all expectation. No people was ever blessed as we have been, and if the judgments of men were consulted the Union would yet be saved from overthrow. Yet all see and feel that the danger is imminent, and if the country is saved at all it must be by wisdom, prudence, and patriotism, aided by Divine Providence.

abstract: The Board of Education for 1861 convened at the Hall of the Board, corner of Grand and Elm streets yesterday at 5 P.M. Fourteen new members appeared: Jeremiah Fitzpatrick, (Opp.;) Wm. Smith, (Dem.;) Thomas Kennedy, (Dem.;) C. Godfrey Gunther, (Dem.;) Patrick Ford, (Dem.;) Samuel B.H. Vance, (Opp.) With the exception of those names the Board stands as it did last year. The Democrats have six majority this year. Last year the Board was equally divided.

abstract: The Seventh Regiment, long ago, won for itself a name; it has now also a local habitation. Its new Armory was yesterday thrown open for the inspection of the public, and during the day a great many ladies and gentlemen visited it. In the evening, the friends of the regiment, especially the fair, whom none but the brave deserve, flocked thither in throngs, placing themselves at the clemency of the inclement weather that they might examine the much-talked of edifice. They were amply repaid for their trouble. The new Armory is undoubtedly the finest one appropriated to the use of volunteer soldiers in the world. The Regimental band was in attendance, and the hours of the evening floated away upon its delightful music like a period of short-lived ecstacy.

abstract: To-night, at the annual meeting of the Plymouth Church Society in Brooklyn, is to be reopened the matter of building a new church for Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER. For three years this subject has hung fire--proving the exception to the prompt and business like action of this Society in all mundane and financial affairs.

abstract: Yesterday morning Inspector Carpenter was called upon at Police Head-quarters by the senior member of a firm of prominent shipping merchants engaged in the Southern trade, who desired to make a complaint against Mrs. Barker, one of the guests at the St. Nicholas Hotel. The gentleman stated that the fair one on Sunday last called at his residence and presented a letter of introduction to his wife which purported to have been written by a very intimate personal and mercantile friend of his at Savannah, Ga. The epistle set forth the merits of the lady, who had come North on a visit, representing her to be possessed of all womanly virtues, worthy of their highest regard, and an ornament to the best society. As soon as the gentleman was apprised of the fact he told his wife that no expense should be spared to make the fair Southerner's sojourn in the City agreeable. The next day he personally paid his respects to Mrs. Barker at the hotel, and found that her appearance and manner fully verified all that had been stated in the letter of introduction. After an agreeable interview he went to his place of business, and not many hours passed before he there received a note from the lady, requesting the loan of sixty dollars until such time as she should receive a remittance from home, as unfortunately her pocket had been picked of $200. The cautious merchant, before loaning his cash, deemed it the part of prudence to telegraph to his friend in Savannah to ascertain if the lady was "all right," The answer astonished him. It set forth that she was an impostor, who had just fled from Savannah, after coming the confidence game over a gentleman there to the tune of $500. The merchant went home, and examined, for the first time, the letter of introduction, which he found bore no resemblance to the handwriting of his friend, from whom it purported to have come. He therefore laid the facts, at the earliest moment, before the authorities. Detective King was sent to take the fair deceiver into custody, and he soon brought her to headquarters. She wept bitterly, and appeared to feel her condition keenly; but the police say her tears are of the crocodile kind, and that she is an old stager, whose principal exploits heretofore have been confined to shoplifting in this City and Boston. She is detained in custody for the present.

abstract: Our advices from Charleston are of the most startling character, and indicate most unequivocally the intention of the authorities of South Carolina to precipitate a collision with the Federal Government. The steamship Star of the West, which recently left this port with reinforcements for Major ANDERSON, arrived off Charleston Harbor yesterday morning, and, on endeavoring to enter, was fired upon by the South Carolinians on Morris Island, and also from Fort Moultrie. Some twelve or fifteen cannon shots were fired at her -- with what effect is not known -- when she again put to sea. Subsequently, Lieut. HALL, of Fort Sumter, visited Charleston with a flag of truce, and had an interview with Gov. PICKENS and his Council, which lasted some two hours. The nature of his communication is not known, but it was intimated that it was of the most threatening character. The course to be pursued by the commander of the troops on board the Star of the West, is, of course, now a matter of conjecture, but he will probably keep the steamer off the harbor, out of harm's way, until he receives instructions. Meantime a telegram from Norfolk informs us that the Brooklyn, which has been in readiness for several days, put to sea last evening with sealed orders, and the supposition is that she has also gone to Charleston. What course will be pursued when she arrives there, remains to be seen.

abstract: THE SNOW STORM. -- Early yesterday morning there were indications of a storm, the wind blowing moderately from the Northeast. Toward noon snow began to fall, and it continued to fall all day and during the evening. Notwithstanding the storm, the Sound steamers took their departure at the usual hour. The steamer Star of the South, for Savannah, departed at the usual hour, but probably anchored below. The steamship Nashville was detained. She is to leave at 9 o'clock this morning. The snow storm will probably detain inward bound vessels and steamers.

abstract: The public will be gratified to learn that there is at last a prospect of having the office, of City Chamberlain placed on a secure and acceptable footing. Senator MANIERRE has introduced a bill making the Chamberlaincy in fact, what it already is in theory, a bureau of the Finance Department, with power in the Comptroller to appoint the Chamberlain and to designate in what bank the City and County funds shall be lodged. The bill also provides that the Chamberlain shall give sureties in the sum of $400,000 for the faithful discharge of his duties; and that, while the Comptroller may suspend him for alleged malfeasance or misfeasance, the Chamberlain shall not be removed except after charges of misconduct against him have been certified to the Governor of the State by the Comptroller -- it becoming then the duty of the Governor to call on the Chamberlain for his defence, and to dispose of the case thereupon without delay, by either approving or disapproving the sufficiency of the Comptroller's charges.
lead_paragraph: The public will be gratified to learn that there is at last a prospect of having the office, of City Chamberlain placed on a secure and acceptable footing. abstract: ARREST OF A BURGLAR. -- Some time during Tuesday night, Mr. WM. PAYNE's shoe-store, in South Bergen, was broken open, and robbed of a large quantity of tools, some stock and fixtures -- in all valued at about $50. About 3 o'clock yesterday morning, officers JORDON and ROSE took into custody, near the Jersey City ferry, a German having several bundles in his possession, which were subsequently identified as the stolen property. The prisoner gave his name as JACOB RUTH. He was committed by Recorder TILDEN for trial.

abstract: A letter received a day or two since by a gentleman of this City from a lawyer in Charleston, gave a very gloomy statement of the condition of affairs in that City. He said that there were a large number of respectable, wealthy and influential persons there who were, like himself, thoroughly opposed to the whole secession movement, but that they were utterly overborne and silenced by the mass. No man dare avow such a sentiment there, no matter what his standing or position. He had himself already paid $2,500, which had been exacted as a contribution towards the expenses of the movement, and there was every prospect that these exactions would grow heavier and more frequent. The condition of affairs, he said, was perfectly awful, -- such as he had never expected to see in this country. The mob had complete control, and the conservatives were paralyzed.

abstract: It seems to be conceded that the Congressional atteofmpts to compromise our sectional difficulties, have failed. We are not surprised at this, -- nor do we regard it as at all conclusive against a friendly adjustment of the pending controversy. Those attempts have failed because they have not been made by the proper parties, nor in the proper spirit, nor at the proper time. They have been contests rather than compromises, -- struggles of the South to secure concessions from the North, -- rather than endeavors to detect and acknowledge faults and short-comings on both sides, and to arrive, by frank and friendly inquiry, at some mutual basis of future union and good-will. The South, as represented in these efforts, has assumed throughout, that the North was to shoulder all the blame of the existing condition of affairs, -- and that the only open question was how far the North was willing to retreat from the position it has hitherto occupied on this subject. In short, the course taken by the South in these movements for compromise has seemed too much like a part of the secession movement, -- like one branch of the general scheme of coercing the North, -- the diplomatic negotiation by which the fruits of the terror inspired by actual disunion were to be gathered.
