abstract: In spite of all that has been said and written on the subject of Slavery, there is still a deep-seated, popular delusion in these Northern latitudes as to the condition of the Southern States, which, it seems, will yield to no array of facts and figures which the most ingenious statists can bring to bear. We all admit the particulars, when brought to our attention, but we adhere to our preconceived ideas.
lead_paragraph: In spite of all that has been said and written on the subject of Slavery, there is still a deep-seated, popular delusion in these Northern latitudes as to the condition of the Southern States, which, it seems, will yield to no array of facts and figures which the most ingenious statists can bring to bear. We all admit the particulars, when brought to our attention, but we adhere to our preconceived ideas. The word South has immemorially been suggestive of large plantations, stocked with negroes; and, whatever the census returns may say to the contrary, Northern people are prone to believe that every proprietor is a nabob, surrounded by hundreds or thousands of black menials. The public has been told that in 1850 there were 347,525 slaveholders in the country, and immediately the conclusion is arrived at that there are as many wealthy and accomplished gentlemen, who while away their life in elegant hospitality, or diversify its monotony by engaging in politics.

abstract: Some months ago a gigantic negro, known as John Body, alias Johnson, fled from Catskill, Greene County, N.Y., to avoid the legal consequences of having nearly killed a man named James Agner, who in some way had excited his rage. Constables from Greene County had frequently been to the City in...
lead_paragraph: Some months ago a gigantic negro, known as John Body, alias Johnson, fled from Catskill, Greene County, N.Y., to avoid the legal consequences of having nearly killed a man named James Agner, who in some way had excited his rage. Constables from Greene County had frequently been to the City in search of the fugitive, but he managed to elude them, and not until Wednesday night was his arrest effected. He was found by Officer McCleary, of the Fifth Precinct Police, playing first fiddle at a dance-house in Laurens-street, near Canal, and yesterday he was sent to Catskill. Johnson is described as a very bad fellow, and a few years ago he was arrested on suspicion of having murdered Jane Brandon, a young colored damsel to whom he had been paying his addresses. Her body was found in the river near Catskill, but no evidence against the accused could be obtained, and he was set at liberty.

abstract: In this Court, yesterday, before Judge LEONARD, the case of Selover, convicted of ticket-swindling, was brought up. Mr. Clinton also appeared and asked that the sentence might be delayed, on the ground that Selover was an eyewitness to a homicide in the trial of which Mr. Clinton was counsel.

lead_paragraph: We have at last full reports of what took place when the Star of the West attempted to enter Charleston Harbor. She was fired upon from Morris Island and Fort Moultrie. Maj. ANDERSON then demanded from Gov. PICKENS permission for her to enter, backing it with a threat to open his guns upon any battery that might fire upon her. Gov. PICKENS refused permission, and Maj. ANDERSON decided to refer the matter to "Washington, Lieut. TALBOT being dispatched thither as a special messenger.

abstract: In the Message transmitted by the President to the Senate of the United States on last Wednesday, we find in a single phrase the key unlocking many secrets of Mr. BUCHANAN'S later policy tire partial explanation and apology for nearly all his former short-comings with reference to the question of secession.
lead_paragraph: In the Message transmitted by the President to the Senate of the United States on last Wednesday, we find in a single phrase the key unlocking many secrets of Mr. BUCHANAN's later policy -- the partial explanation and apology for nearly all his former short-comings with reference to the question of secession. "Time," writes the President, "is a great conservative power" -- an axiom one of the clearest in itself, in certain limited aspects, but capable of infinite mischief when perverted by designing advisers into the plea and excuse for passivity, while the treason in which they were participants was being extended and organized. "Do nothing," said COBB. "Let the evil cure itself. Time is a great conservative power." And the same plea, we may well imagine, was urged by FLOYD as an excuse for not sending the necessary reinforcements to Fort Moultrie. "Time is a great conservative power," whispered the President to himself; and, with a conscientious desire to avoid bloodshed, the dulcet sophistry of this phrase was accepted for much more than it is worth.
headline: {'main': "The President's Message.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The President's Message.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The news which we publish this morning fully confirms the accounts telegraphed from Charleston relative to the Star of the West, which appeared in the TIMES of yesterday. The result of the communication between Major ANDERSON and Gov. PICKENS on the subject was, that a messenger was dispatched by the former to Washington, to receive...
lead_paragraph: The news which we publish this morning fully confirms the accounts telegraphed from Charleston relative to the Star of the West, which appeared in the TIMES of yesterday. The result of the communication between Major ANDERSON and Gov. PICKENS on the subject was, that a messenger was dispatched by the former to Washington, to receive special instructions as to the course to be pursued in the future. The messenger will probably reach Washington to-night. Meantime, however, another cause of excitement has arisen in Charleston. Intelligence yesterday reached there that the sloop-of-war Brooklyn was on the way to aid the Star of the West to enter the harbor and land the troops at Fort Sumter. This caused the greatest commotion, and steps were immediately taken to resist her approach. The determination was to fire upon her, when it was understood that Fort Sumter would take part in the proceedings, and the expectation entertained in Charleston was that a general action would be fought. Our telegram from Charleston states that the steamship Marion has been purchased for the use of the State of South Carolina; but a dispatch to SPOFFORD, TILESTON & Co., of this City, states that she was seized, with no intimation of any design to pay for her. The events transpiring at Charleston created the greatest excitement in Washington to-day.

abstract: Col. JEFFERSON DAVIS made a speech in the Senate yesterday which throws more light upon the condition of his own mind, than on the state of the country. He seems to have been profoundly astonished to find that this is a Government of force, as well as of consent,...
lead_paragraph: Col. JEFFERSON DAVIS made a speech in the Senate yesterday which throws more light upon the condition of his own mind, than on the state of the country. He seems to have been profoundly astonished to find that this is a Government of force, as well as of consent, -- that we have an army and navy, -- ships and forts and guns, and men who dare to use them when the necessity arises. He had reposed on the belief that a Government of consent means a Government, -- in which force is unknown, -- which each State and each person may obey or disobey at pleasure. Col. DAVIS evidently supposed that secession was to be a peaceable pastime, -- that Southern States could stay in the Union, or go out, and stay out or come back again at their sovereign will and pleasure.

abstract: In the matter of the application of Daniel Devlin. A motion came on before this Court on the return of an order to show cause, issued under the following circumstances. It will be remembered that in May, 1860, Mayor Wood appointed to the office...
lead_paragraph: In the matter of the application of Daniel Devlin. -- A motion came on before this Court on the return of an order to show cause, issued under the following circumstances. It will be remembered that in May, 1860, Mayor Wood appointed to the office of Chamberlain of the City Mr. Nathan C. Platt. During the recent absence of the Mayor, from the City, the President of the Board of Aldermen, acting as Mayor, removed him with the concurrence of the Board and appointed in his place Mr. Daniel Devlin. On the 6th of January, 1861. Mr. Devlin obtained an order to show cause requiring Mr. Platt to deliver up all books and papers appertaining to the office, which order was made returnable on the 10th. At the opening of the motion Mr. Whiting, as one of the counsel for Mr. Platt, served upon the Judge a writ of certiorari, which he had just obtained from Judge Barnard, removing the hearing of the cause to the Chambers of the Supreme Court. On the service of the order the Judge remarked that he knew of no authority vested in a Judge of the Supreme Court to issue such a writ to him, and unless sufficient authority was shown he should not regard it, but proceed in the cause. Mr. Whiting, appealing for Mr. Platt, argued that the writ of certiorari was good and valid, and authorized by law, and operated as a stay of proceedings. He also took objection to the order which had been served on Mr. Platt, on the ground that it did not show upon its race that facts sufficient had been stated to counter jurisdiction; that no affidavit had been served with it, and they were left entirely ignorant of the facts on which the order had been granted, and had nothing to show cause against. The counsel then asked for time to answer the complaint, saying that he had relied upon the writ of certiorari, but seeing the disposition of the Judge to disregard it, they should have time to answer.

abstract: The meeting held at Baltimore on Thursday night seems to have been a genuine Union meeting.
lead_paragraph: The meeting held at Baltimore on Thursday night seems to have been a genuine Union meeting. The thousands who were present attended because they were for the Union, -- not for Slavery first, and for the Union as a secondary and incidental matter. The speakers, men of national reputation and character, spoke for the country, -- for Government, for law and civilization, -- for the Union and the Constitution as indispensable to the welfare of Maryland, and not as useful merely for the preservation and extension of Slavery. The tone of the meeting was sound and self-reliant. Its appeal was to Maryland, -- to her people, -- not mainly to the North nor the Federal Government. The State of Maryland is in danger, because the UNION is in danger: and her own people, -- those whose welfare is indissolubly bound up with that of the Union, -- who see nothing but ruin and devastation if this great fabric of constitutional Government is broken up, were summoned to rally to the rescue and plant themselves like adamant in the path of those who menace it with destruction.

abstract: A letter received in Washington from a distiaguished gentleman now in Charleston status that the condition of affairs there is heart rending. No business whatever is doing, and the merchants anticipate a speedy and general bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: A letter received in Washington from a distiaguished gentleman now in Charleston status that the condition of affairs there is heart rending. No business whatever is doing, and the merchants anticipate a speedy and general bankruptcy. Those of them who can get away are endeavoring to so arrange their affairs as to get as much of the remains of their property out of South Carolina as they can, as soon as possible, in order to escape the current and impending extra taxation, exactions under peril on the pretence of voluntary contributions, &c. Sickness prevails to an alarming extent among the armed bands who control agairs there on the mob principle. The Convention itself legislate tender terror of those bands; and beef sells for thirty-five cents per pound there, in view of the fact that the supply of provisions in the city is almost exhausted.

abstract: The controversy between South Carolina and the Government is now brought to a direct and decisive issue.
lead_paragraph: The controversy between South Carolina and the Government is now brought to a direct and decisive issue. The PRESIDENT must now decide whether reinforcements shall go to Maj. ANDERSON at Fort Sumter, or whether the Government shall yield to the prohibition of GOV. PICKENS and relinquish the attempt. The decision is one which involves great responsibility, as it may determine the fate of the country for years to come. It will undoubtedly be given after full consideration of the grave consequences which it involves; -- but we can perceive no room for doubt as to its character.

abstract: A very pretty domestic comedy was enacted in New-Orleans a few days since. Mr. Ward, of Cincinnati, a well to do grocer, lost his wife, and after much searching, found her at a boarding-house in New-Orleans, where she was abiding with her paramount, a former clerk in Mr. Ward's store.
lead_paragraph: -- A very pretty domestic comedy was enacted in New-Orleans a few days since. Mr. Ward, of Cincinnati, a well to do grocer, lost his wife, and after much searching, found her at a boarding-house in New-Orleans, where she was abiding with her paramount, a former clerk in Mr. Ward's store. While Mr. Ward was waiting for his apparently repentant wife to gather together her duds and return home with hun, the couple actually succeeded in cloping a Second time, calling into requisition the carriage in which the injured husband had come to the boarding-house. Very wisely he concluded to pay her little board bill, for which the clerk strangely although neglected to provide, and left for Cincinnati a wiser and a little poorer man.

abstract: Besides the general dearth, and consequent suffering for food in Kansas, considerable distress and anxiety have overtaken small farmers there on account of the liability of having their little farms taken from them on account of their inability to meet the interest and principal upon mortgages, which were made at times when prospects were good. A gentleman is now in this City, from Kansas, for the purpose of raising three or four thousand dollars in order to relieve a number of persons in that State whose property is liable to be taken from them, thus rendering themselves and families homeless. He brings notes secured by mortgage on real estate largely exceeding the amount in value of the sums required for their release. The securities appear to be undoubted, and affords an opportunity for those who feel disposed, for a fair consideration, to confer a lasting benefit upon some sixteen worthy persons, without which timely assistance they must lose the avails of years of labor. Those wishing information on the subject are referred to CHARLES W. ELLIOT, NO. 31 Pine-street, New-York.

abstract: IN SELLING SEWING-MACHINES. -- Mr JOSEPH THORN has been arrested by the United States Marshal, and lodged in Eldridge street jail, for violating an injunction by selling sewing-machines. On motion of GEORGE GIFFORD, Esq., an attachment was granted by Judge SMALLY, in the United States Court, against the defendant, for selling sewing-machines, in violation of an injunction issued against him, on the patents owned by the Grover & Baker Sewing-Machine Company, and the Wheeler & Wilson Manufacturing Company, and known as the sewing mamachine feed patents. Violating the order of Courts is rather a serious matter, as it renders the offender liable to punishment by fine and imprisonment.

abstract: Now that the excitement attending holidaysales and Christmas gift-books is over, the publishing trade shows its sympathy with the disturbed state of politics and the money market by the absence of new announcements and a general tendency to hold back books, already far advanced, until a more favorable time.
lead_paragraph: Now that the excitement attending holidaysales and Christmas gift-books is over, the publishing trade shows its sympathy with the disturbed state of politics and the money market by the absence of new announcements and a general tendency to hold back books, already far advanced, until a more favorable time. Meanwhile it is satisfactory to know that the large enterprises commenced before the prevailing depression -- as the fine library editions of Lord Bacon's Works, Macaulay, Milman's Latin Christianity, Hallam's Works, APPLETON's New American Cyclopedia, LITTLE & BROW's British Poets, &c., &c., are all meeting with fair and liberal support -- a fact that proves the general development of a taste for books of a superior class, and that only a glimpse of sunshine is needed to encourage our publishing houses to follow up these with many similar undertakings, of which the plans are now in consideration.

abstract: Gov. LETCHER introduced Messrs. ANTUN F. HOPKINS and F.M. GILMER, the Alabama Commissioners, to the Virginia Legislature, in a brief message, dated Jan. 7. He speaks of the importance of the crisis; says that all the South wants is an equal right with the North in the Territories, the enforcement of the Fugitive Slave law, and that a stop should be put to the agitation of the Slavery question. These points he thinks that the North might concede without compromising her dignity. He recommends the Legislature to hear the Commissioners calmly, and weigh dispassionately the views which they represent.
lead_paragraph: Gov. LETCHER introduced Messrs. ANTUN F. HOPKINS and F.M. GILMER, the Alabama Commissioners, to the Virginia Legislature, in a brief message, dated Jan. 7. abstract: One of the chief arguments for secession in the seaboard cities of the South is the expectation of great advantages they are to derive from the inauguration of a Free-Trade policy. Now we respectfully submit that these political economists have lost sight of one highly important element which will do much to upset their calculations we mean the drawback or remission of duties on bonded goods, when re xported to foreign States.
lead_paragraph: One of the chief arguments for secession in the seaboard cities of the South is the expectation of great advantages they are to derive from the inauguration of a Free-Trade policy. Now we respectfully submit that these political economists have lost sight of one highly important element which will do much to upset their calculations -- we mean the drawback or remission of duties on bonded goods, when re xported to foreign States. This simple provision will take effect in South Carolina and other seceding States so soon as their foreign condition is ackowledged, and will retain the trade in foreign goods within its present channels.

abstract: George B. De Forestal et al. vs. Heman J. Redfield. Pedro A. De Aguirre vs. The Same. -- These actions were tried and decided together. They were both brought to recover back an alleged excess of duties levied by the defendant, then Collector of this Port, upon goods imported by the plaintiffs in the years 1853, 1854, 1855 and 1856, from Porto Rico. Their invoices were made out giving the value of the goods in what 16 called the Macuquino currency, and, as they claimed, duties should have been levied upon their value, estimating $112 1/2 of that currency at $100 of our currency.

abstract: The second's and third volumes of this great historical epic, embrace a series of events of almost unsurpassed interest. They cover the period
lead_paragraph: The second and third volumes of this great historical epic, embrace a series of events of almost unsurpassed interest. They cover the period extending from the close of the sixth to the close of the eleventh century, a period which witnessed some of the chief internal and outward revolutions in the history of the Papacy -- a period which commenced with the Pontificate of GREGORY the Great, (I.,) under whom the Roman See began to exercise a virtual temporal sovereignty, and including that of the Great GREGORY, (VII.,) or HILDEBRAND, under whom it consolidated its spiritual power. The several scenes, as they pass before us, are such of absorbing interest. The rise and spread of Western monasticism, with the life of the founder of that Benedictine order to whose learned labors both sacred and secular literature is so largely indebted -- the rise of that gigantic system of fanaticism and imposture which, bursting forth from the Arabian deserts, carried the religion of ISLAM from the banks of the Euphrates to the banks of the Guadalquiver, wresting some of the fairest portions of the earth from the dominion of Christianity -- the reconversion of Britain to the faith which had been trampled out by the idolatrous hordes of Saxon invaders -- the iconoclastic contests which issued in the final sundering of the Western Church from its connection with the Eastern Empire -- the splendid reign of CHARLEMAGNE -- the humiliation of the Papacy and its subjugation to the Princes of Germany -- and finally, the accession of HILDEBRAND,and the energetic acts by which he broke the yoke of German power, reformed the abuses of the Church, and asserted and made good its supremacy over the mightiest secular Potentates. These are some of the topics which in these volumes are treated with a fullness of knowledge and a breadth, though not always accuracy or elegance of style, characteristic of their eminent author. At the present day, when the foundations of the Papacy seem to be giving way; when questions of vital interest are clustering about the destiny of the See of Rome, the history of its varying fortunes in the past, of the successive steps by which it built up the colossal structure of its power -- a survey of the principles on which its wide and enduring sway has rested, must, to every thoughtful mind, be invested with tenfold interest. We commend, therefore, with emphasis to the reading public, this elegant edition of one of the great historical works of our times -- a work which unites English soundness of judgment with continental depth of research and fullness of learning, and which under the guidance of a Christian scholar, conducts us through both the political and moral history of Mediaeval Europe.

abstract: The Louisville Journal has some new revelations regarding the Knights of the Golden Circle. It says that this association, as at present organized, originated in Alabama under the auspices of Mr. YANGEY, the whole purpose being the dismemberment of the Union. Even in Kentucky, the Journal asserts, this oath-bound and traitorous conclave has been organized, and is constantly gathering in scores, if not hundreds of young, reckless, impulsive spirits, who, with hearts inflamed by misrepresentation and ill-understood facts, and with little care for aught else than excitement and adventure, are prepared for anything that will minister to the gratification of their passions.
lead_paragraph: The Louisville Journal has some new revelations regarding the Knights of the Golden Circle. It says that this association, as at present organized, originated in Alabama under the auspices of Mr. YANGEY, the whole purpose being the dismemberment of the Union. Even in Kentucky, the Journal asserts, this oath-bound and traitorous conclave has been organized, and is constantly gathering in scores, if not hundreds of young, reckless, impulsive spirits, who, with hearts inflamed by misrepresentation and ill-understood facts, and with little care for aught else than excitement and adventure, are prepared for anything that will minister to the gratification of their passions.

lead_paragraph: We have at last a united UNION ADMINISTRATION. Mr. BUCHANAN has finally purged his Cabinet of Secessionists, and has now no man in his Council Chamber whose fidelity to the Constitution he has any reason to distrust. Gen. Dix, of this City, takes the Secretary ship of the Treasury in place of Mr. THOMAS, who succeeded the fugitive Disunionist, Mr. COBB. This is a most excellent appointment. Gen. DIX is one of the purest and most upright of the public men of the country. He has been, and still is, an earnest Democrat, and has gone even beyond the line of his own estimate of justice in concession to the demands of the South. But he has no sympathy with secession, and will never consent to the disgrace or destruction of the Federal Union.

abstract: Amid the various political, commercial and social topics which engross our attention at this time, it behooves us not to forget the claims of the poor. Winter, with its home
lead_paragraph: Amid the various political, commercial and social topics which engross our attention at this time, it behooves us not to forget the claims of the poor. Winter, with its home comforts, its gayeties, its holidays, has ever its shadow creeping stealthily beside it, the gaunt, pinched form of Poverty. And again arises the ever-recurring question, "What shall we do for the poor?" We cannot give indiscriminately to every case that applies to us, else we may be supporting the vicious at the expense of the deserving; we may be adding to the miser's hoard, instead of placing food in the poor man's mouth. These are important considerations to those who give, as well as to those who receive. For the indigent of our great cities consist of two classes -- those who cannot, and those who will not labor. For the former class -- those who from sickness or accident are rendered unable to help themselves, and those who by providential causes are rendered so destitute that their labor is insufficient to maintain them, it is a pleasure as well as a privilege to provide. The support of such, irrespective of their personal character, is a moral obligation imposed by by every instinct of reason and sound political economy upon the community where they dwell. As regards the latter class, however, those who have the ability, but not the will to labor, their own indolence or vice is clearly the cause of their suffering, and that "if a man will not work neither shall he eat," is alike the judgment of revelation and common sense. These acknowledged facts present themselves to the minds of all who are called upon to bestow charity, and should never for a moment be lost sight of.
headline: {'main': 'The Duty of Providing for the Poor.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Duty of Providing for the Poor.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Of the recent biographical works which have issued from the press in increasing numbers both in this country and in England, none has equal interest at the present moment, to Americans, with this of Gen. QUITMAN.
lead_paragraph: Of the recent biographical works which have issued from the press in increasing numbers both in this country and in England, none has equal interest at the present moment, to Americans, with this of Gen. QUITMAN. It is the life of a man of spirit and ability, a brave soldier, and of considerable eminence as a politician. He was a man of the North as well as of the South. He gave to the latter his heart and soul in the maturity of his life; but he belonged to the former by birth and family, and the early years which shape the man were passed in the education and society of the Northern States. His biography touches the extremes of two modes of living, one severe in training and discipline, the other lax and openhanded, facile both for enjoyment and action. Nowhere, within our knowledge, can the distinctive influences of the North and the South be more readily traced than in the career of this gallant soldier.

lead_paragraph: We joined the crowd on Saturday afternoon, and were swept by the human tide to the door of the temple of the god of the hour. abstract: Having carefully examined the report made by Capt. McGOWAN, of the steamship Star of the West, in relation to his recent unsuccessful attempt to reach Fort Sumter with reinforcements of men and munitions, we are
lead_paragraph: Having carefully examined the report made by Capt. MCGOWAN, of the steamship Star of the West, in relation to his recent unsuccessful attempt to reach Fort Sumter with reinforcements of men and munitions, -- we are compelled to regard failure of his mission as mainly attributable to want of firmness and loss of judgment in himself at the critical moment. Had he obeyed the instructions given him by the charterers of the ship -- had he not utterly lost his presence of mind under the practically harmless fire of the Cummings Point Battery, -- Major ANDERSON would, long ere this, have had two hundred additional men under his command, and all the supplies needed for standing a protracted siege. We speak on information which we regard as perfectly reliable, and propose to direct public attention to some few of the salient errors in Capt. MCGOWAN's course.

abstract: We observe that Messrs. WATTS SHERMAN, ROYAL PHELPS, and other influential citizens, have preferred a written request to Rev. Dr. RAPHALL that he would
lead_paragraph: -- We observe that Messrs. WATTS SHERMAN, ROYAL PHELPS, and other influential citizens, have preferred a written request to Rev. Dr. RAPHALL that he would repeat his Fast Day Sermon, proving that Slavery was tolerated and approved under the Jewish dispensation, -- and encouraging the inference that American Slavery is a divine institution. We have not the slightest disposition to interfere with any intellectual pursuits in which these gentlemen find recreation and delight at this period of civil commotion; but we should like to know what special public service they expect to render the country, by stimulating and sustaining this line of argument. Do they deem this a proper time to undertake the conversion of the great mass of our community to this extreme doctrine on the subject of Slavery? They can scarcely be ignorant of the fact that the pressure of this ultra position by the South has contributed very largely to that extreme exasperation of the public mind, which is now working out its legitimate fruits.

abstract: FATAL STREET ENCOUNTER On Friday afternoon Coroner SOHIRMER took the ante-mortem deposition of ROGER LAFTUS, a native of Ireland, 20 years of age, who lay at the point of death in the New York Hospital in consequence of a wound in his arm, received on New-Year's Eve, in an affray at the corner of Worthstreet and Broadway. LOFTUS made affidavit to the
lead_paragraph: FATAL STREET ENCOUNTER. -- On Friday afternoon Coroner SOHIRMER took the ante-mortem deposition of ROGER LAFTUS, a native of Ireland, 20 years of age, who lay at the point of death in the New York Hospital in consequence of a wound in his arm, received on New-Year's Eve, in an affray at the corner of Worthstreet and Broadway. LOFTUS made affidavit to the effect, that on the evening in question, he was standing at the place designated, conversing with CATHARINE CARE, a young woman of his acquaintance, when he accidently came in contact with a man named MICHAEL JOSTEN who was passing by. JOSTEN immediately turned upon him and without listening to an apology stabbed him in the left arm. A Fifth-ward policeman, who had by this time reached the scene of the affray, at once arrested JOSTEN, who was locked up to await the result of the deponent's injuries. The woman CARR was also apprehended and detained as a witness of the affray. On Saturday morning LOFTUS died, and yesterday Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest upon the body, at which evidence was elicited putting a different complexion upon the case. CATHARINE CARE deposed that about 10 o'clock on New-Year's Eve she was standing with MICHAEL JOSTEN at the corner of Worth-street and Broadway, when the deceased, ROGER LOFTUS, came staggering up along. He jostled against JOSTEN in a violent manner and the latter turned and grappled with him. In the struggle both slipped and fell, and LOFTUS having recovered his feet attempted to kick his antagonist Witness then took a penknife from her pocket and stabbed LOFTERS in the left arm. She had no intention of doing him a serious injury, but merely desired to keep him from kicking JOSTEN. Very soon Policeman came up and arrested all of them. The Jury upon this testimony rendered a verdict as follows: "That deceased died from exhaustion, produced by a stab-wound at the hands of CATHARINE CARE given while MICHAEL JOSTEN was engaged in a fracas with deceased." Coroner SCHIRMER examined CATHARINE in the prescribed way, and in reply to his questions she said: "I am a native of Ireland, 19 years of age, residing at No. 67 Sullivan-street. I inflicted the wound, and JOSTEN had no knife in his possession when the stabbing occurred." She was committed to the Tombs to await the action of the Grand Jury, and JOSTEN was sent to the House of Detention for witnesses.

abstract: The Washington Constitution contradicts the report that the South Carolina Commissioners left Washington without paying their rent and other household expenses. As the Constitution has become the recognized organ of the Secessionists, it is probably good authority on the mooted point. It has taken the judicious precaution, however, of sustaining its own statements by the additional testimony of JAMES WORMLEY, whom it indorses as a "highly respectable colored man," and who was "engaged by the Commissioners to supply their table."

abstract: CARD FROM CAPT. KENNEDY OF SHIP MEDWAY. -- The Br. ship Medway, Capt. Kennedy, from Bombay, arrived 6th inst. at which time we omitted to mention the following: Capt. Kennedy wishes to express his obligations to the (commanding officer of U.S. steamer Sumter, for the assistance he received from him at St. Helena, when getting ship under way. The Medway anchored at St Helena Oct. 31, in the dark, and in bringing up gave the war steamer a foul berth; the water was deep, 23 feet.) and the commanding officer of the Sumter very kindly veered cable, and allowed the M. to lay until next day, and when she commenced to heave up her anchor, he sent a cutter's crew to assist in getting her under way. The M. could not have got away without assistance, as she was close to the Sumter and a Spanish ship had come in, and overlaid her own anchor.

abstract: The Constitution says that since the resignation of Hon. P.F. THOMAS there is "no Southern man, properly so called, in the Executive Council." What does the President's late organ consider a Southern man, "properly so called?" What are his essential qualifications? Must he be a Disunionist? Must he advocate the surrender of United States forts, arsenals, Custom-houses, Navy-yards, and other property to men who are in arms for the overthrow of the Federal Government? If these things are essential to the definition, we may well congratulate the country and the President on the fact of which the Constitution complains.

abstract: BILL. -- We trust that our State Legislature will lose no time in giving us a solution of the difficulties we now labor under with regard to the City and County funds. Ex-Chamberlain PLATT, it is said, has in so far acknowledged the decision of the Common Pleas as to surrender the books, papers and accounts of his late office to Mr. DANIEL DEVLIN; but in the more important matter of paying over to his alleged successor in office the balances of City and County moneys now in his hands, and amounting to over four millions of dollars, the late Chamberlain still remains refractory. This is most clearly a case in which the Legislature should step in to relieve the City of its embarrassments, and the bill introduced by Senator MANIERRE contains, in our judgment, all the provisions and clauses required by the important and delicate nature of the office in dispute. It very properly lodges the appointing power of the Chamberlaincy-Bureau in the Head of the Finance Department; while carefully guarding against any undue subsequent control of the actual money-guardian of the City and County, by limiting the power of removal to the Governor after charges of malfeasance or misfeasance shall have been made and proved against the Chamberlain by the Comptroller. This is one of the few cases in which State legislation for the City would be hailed as a boon by the honest and intelligent of all parties.

abstract: -We copied some days since from the Albany Atlas and Argus, an extract of a speech said to have been made by Mr. LINCOLN in 1858, in which he denounced those States which withheld from the negro the right of suffrage. We
lead_paragraph: -- We copied some days since from the Albany Atlas and Argus, an extract of a speech said to have been made by Mr. LINCOLN in 1858, in which he denounced those States which withheld from the negro the right of suffrage. We proved that the extract must be a forgery, unless Mr. LINCOLN had directly and distinctly contradicted himself -- for we quoted from his speeches the most explicit declarations which language could frame, of hostility to the admission of negroes to the right of suffrage.

abstract: We notice that a bill has been introduced in the State Assembly to reduce the rate of interest exacted by pawnbrokers a most excellent measure, but one little likely to pass.
lead_paragraph: -- We notice that a bill has been introduced in the State Assembly to reduce the rate of interest exacted by pawnbrokers -- a most excellent measure, but one little likely to pass. It can only have in its favor the very poorest classes of our citizens, and those who understand and sympathize with their sufferings and wrongs, -- while against any ameliorative legislation, the powerful and wealthy combination of the three-ball money-lenders stand arrayed, their lobby agents in the field every session, and their unholy profits liberally employed to prevent the poor from receiving any substantial redress.

abstract: At about 12 o'clock Saturday night, Offier CASLER, who was on duty in the office of the Deputy Inspector of Police, in the basement of the City Hall,
lead_paragraph: At about 12 1/2 o'clock Saturday night, Offier CASLER, who was on duty in the office of the Deputy Inspector of Police, in the basement of the City Hall, heard a man enter the passage-way leading to the office, and went to the door to see who the visitor was. He there found a man -- who gave his name as JAMES MARTIN -- in a somewhat excited condition, who was in search of the Police Office. Officer CASLER asked him to walk in, which he did. Upon entering the office he said that he had murdered his child, and he had come to "give himself up to the law." As the man made a respectable appearance, the officer told him that he did not look as though he would do anything of that kind, whereupon MARTIN drew a bloody razor from his pocket and exclaimed, "Yes I have, and that is what I did it with." He grabbed MARTIN's hand and found that too covered with blood. MARTIN then told him that he resided on Bergen near Powers-street, and that jealousy caused him to commit the deed. He also said that he had had a quarrel with his wife and killed the child out of spite. He subsequently said that he did not know why he killed the child -- that he loved it dearly. The officer locked him up and then 'visited his home. Upon rapping at the door, Mrs. MARTIN opened it. He asked her if the child was injured. At first she denied all knowledge of any injury having been done, but the officer pressing into the room and insisting upon examining for himself, Mrs. MARTIN acknowledged that the child was dead, and took the officer to the bed where it lay. He gave directions not to disturb the body and subsequently notified the Coroner.

abstract: The steamship Star of the West, Capt. McGOWAN, returned to this port on Saturday morning from Charleston harbor, after an abortive attempt to land 200 troops and four officers at Fort Sumter, who had been sent for the reinforcement of that garrison.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Star of the West, Capt. MCGOWAN, returned to this port on Saturday morning from Charleston harbor, after an abortive attempt to land 200 troops and four officers at Fort Sumter, who had been sent for the reinforcement of that garrison. These troops were put on board the Star of the West at 8 o'clock on Saturday evening, January 5th, while the steamer was lying-to above the Narrows. The embarkation was conducted with all the secrecy possible, but the nature of the expedition soon became known -- Southern agents being on the alert, and telegraphing the facts to Charleston early on Sunday.

abstract: The bill before the Legislature requires that a vote shall be taken at the time of the election of delegates to the Convention, to determine whether the action of the Convention shall be submitted to the people or not. abstract: Our latest dispatches from Charleston announce that the Brooklyn sloop-of-war had arrived off that port, but that she had made no attempt to enter. She was last seen off Cape Romain by the steamer Nashville, which has arrived at Charleston from this City. Major ANDERSON had a visit on Friday
lead_paragraph: Our latest dispatches from Charleston announce that the Brooklyn sloop-of-war had arrived off that port, but that she had made no attempt to enter. She was last seen off Cape Romain by the steamer Nashville, which has arrived at Charleston from this City. Major ANDERSON had a visit on Friday from the South Carolina Secretaries of War and State, who went down to Fort Sumter under a flag of truce. Mr. GOURDIN, a member of the Secession Convention, also visited the Fort on Saturday. The exact object of these visits was not known in Charleston, and the most absurd rumors were afloat in reference to them. They resulted, however, in the departure for Washington of Col. HAYNE on the part of the State, and Lieut. HALL on the part of Major ANDERSON, -- the former, as was understood, with an ultimatum for the Government, and the latter for instructions. No intimation has been received in Washington of the nature of their mission; though, contrary to the spirit of the advices from Charleston, our correspondent telegraphs that there is no probability that the Government will now readopt the temporizing policy. On the contrary; it is believed that the attempt to reinforce the garrison at Fort Sumter will soon be renewed, and with such appliances as must render success certain.

abstract: The South Carolina Secretaries of War and State went, yesterday, to Fort Sumter under a flag of truce. There is great excitement, and all sorts of rumors are afloat as to their object, but nothing certain is publicly known. The Secretaries remained two hours at Fort Sumpter. It is believed the visit was not hostile.

abstract: Skating is a species of sport combining amusement with exercise, which has legions of lovers and few maligners. That man we have yet to meet who will not assent to the assertion that boys, girls and grown children, like champagne and congress water, are improved by being placed upon the ice. Ice taken internally is a tonic. Ice spurned by the steel-shod sole is not less so. It gives tone to the entire system. It stiffens the sinews and summons up the blood. It recreates the mind unstrung with too much toil, and to far forth, usurps the function of "Nature's sweet restorer." We are made better by it in body and, by that very fact, in mind. The skater, on the frozen field at Central Park, enacts a miniature drama of life in a theatre of his own. Life intensified, liberty and the pursuit of happiness are his inalienable rights. The placards inscribed "Danger," and the Policemen of the pond, guard him sufficiently from difficulties in which, unassisted, he would be pretty sure to involve himself; but within certain bounds he may cut as many capricious capers as suit his fancy. As long as he obeys the power that rules over his little world, reads the Scripture, so placed that he who skates may read, and takes heed, all will go well with him -- and we to him that heeds not. Several of the thousands of people who, on Saturday, made the blue ice black and their red hoses blue, skating on the Central Park Pond, suffered from disregarding what was written for them and preached to them. One malignant male, who would persist in skating on the ladies' pond unaccompanied by ladies, was arrested, and three, who hazarded their lives by placing themselves beyond "danger," were suddenly baptised in the faith of the true believers. All day and all the evening, till 10 o'clock, the skaters "skeeted" and the sliders slid. A great many of the softer sex indurated themselves skating, in the cold keen air, upon the sheet of ice specially provided for their accommodation. In the evening the ice was illuminated with calcium lights, and the scene was picturesque and worthy of being painted.

abstract: It frequently happens that the wisdom of particular movements can be tested only by their success or failure in accomplishing the object sought, Mr. SEWARD'S speech, in its general tenor, does not require this vindication.
lead_paragraph: It frequently happens that the wisdom of particular movements can be tested only by their success or failure in accomplishing the object sought, Mr. SEWARD's speech, in its general tenor, does not require this vindication. Its main object is to set forth the advantages, the necessities of the Union to the people of the United States, and the vast calamities to them and to the world which its destruction would involve. That this is done with consummate ability and power, no one who reads the speech will have any doubts, -- or if he has, a second reading will dispel them. It is eminently compact in its style, comprehensive in its scope, and statesmanlike in its tone. Mr. SEWARD takes very little note of those considerations which make the Union of more importance to one section than to another. He presents only those which commend themselves to the general judgment of the whole country. He bases his appeal on the universal sentiments of national ambition, love of liberty, and pride of public character which pervade the whole people and make them loyal, if anything can, to the Constitution which has given them such free and such vigorous development. His speech is addressed to the People of the United States, -- showing how they must all suffer if the Union is destroyed, -- and not to the North or South as sections having any distinct and separable interest in its preservation.
headline: {'main': "Mr. Seward's Speech.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Mr. Seward's Speech.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The meeting of the Bar, for the purpose of paying a tribute to the memory of the late Judge KENT, was convened in the General Term room of the Supreme Court, on Saturday afternoon. At an early
lead_paragraph: The meeting of the Bar, for the purpose of paying a tribute to the memory of the late Judge KENT, was convened in the General Term room of the Supreme Court, on Saturday afternoon. At an early hour the room became quite crowded with the members of the profession, both old and young. At the hour appointed for calling the meeting to order, E.L. Fancher, Esq., arose and moved that Hon. D.P. Ingraham be called to the Chair. The motion being seconded, was unanimously carried. The gentleman proposed as Vice-Presidents the names of Hon. Judge Daly, Hon. Murray Hoffman, Hon. Judge Betts, Daniel Lord, Esq., and several others.

abstract: Shortly after dark last evening, a young man, named EUGENE TOUCEY, employed as a waiter in a Broadway saloon, while passing through the City Hall Park, on his way to his place of business, was accosted by a half a dozen youths, who clustered around him, and demanded his money. He refused to give them anything, at which they became angry, and commenced to beat him, when he shouted loudly for the Police. Officer NIEF, of the Third Ward, heard his cries, and ran to aid him, but the ruffians became aware of his approach and ran away. Before they left, however, one of them drew a dirk-knife, and made a lunge at TOUCEY's breast, but he warded the blow with his left arm, which was terribly cut, the blade having passed directly through it. The Officer conveyed him to the Station-house, whence, after his wounds were dressed, he was taken to the New-York Hospital.

abstract: Considerable excitement was occasioned in the Seventeenth Ward last evening by the discovery, shortly before 8 o'clock, of the dead body of a murdeied man on the sidewalk in the Bowary, between Stanton and Rivington streets. The policeman who
lead_paragraph: Considerable excitement was occasioned in the Seventeenth Ward last evening by the discovery, shortly before 8 o'clock, of the dead body of a murdeied man on the sidewalk in the Bowary, between Stanton and Rivington streets. The policeman who first saw the deceased supposed him to be a drunken man, but in attempting to arouse him he found that his shirt, coat and other garments were saturated with blood, and his body quite cold. A litter was at once procured, and the remains were conveyed to the Station-house at the corner of Fifth-street and First avenue, where the Police-Surgeon examined them. Upon the left breast a wide and deep wound was found, evidently made with a dirk-knife, penetrating to the heart, and without doubt producing death, but what interval elapsed between the infliction of the violence and the decease of the victim can only be conjectured, as the freezing weather doubtless dissipated the natural heat of the body soon after the wound had been given.

abstract: A business meeting of the pew holders in Plymouth Church was held on Thursday evening in the lecture room, for the special purpose of electing three
lead_paragraph: A business meeting of the pew holders in Plymouth Church was held on Thursday evening in the lecture room, for the special purpose of electing three Trustees in place of those whose terms of office expired on the 1st inst., and also to transact such other business as might be legitimately brought before them for consideration. The old Trustees were reelected, with the exception of one, who declined because his business makes it necessary for him to be absent from the City most of the year, and therefore he could not discharge the duties pertaining to the office of a Trustee in a proper manner. On the last ballot for Trustee one vote was cast for Major ANDERSON, the announcement of which by the tellers was received with a round of applause.

abstract: Our Mexican correspondence this morning gives very full and interesting details of the complete victory which has at last crowned the efforts of the Liberal and Constitutional party of that country. They have completely routed the army of MIRAMON and have full possession of the city and the Government We trust we may now hope for a more rational and stable administration of affairs in Mexico than it has enjoyed hitherto.
lead_paragraph: Our Mexican correspondence this morning gives very full and interesting details of the complete victory which has at last crowned the efforts of the Liberal and Constitutional party of that country. They have completely routed the army of MIRAMON and have full possession of the city and the Government We trust we may now hope for a more rational and stable administration of affairs in Mexico than it has enjoyed hitherto.

abstract: In the President's Message, and in some of the speeches in the Senate, the power of the President to coerce obedience to the laws and Constitution of the United States has been denied.
lead_paragraph: In the President's Message, and in some of the speeches in the Senate, the power of the President to coerce obedience to the laws and Constitution of the United States has been denied. It is the fashion, in certain quarters, to consider the Government of the United States a feeble Government, but when it is seen that the President, when necessary, may place himself at the head of the whole land and naval force of the United States, and all the militia of the States, to execute the laws, and to preserve, protect, and defend the Constitution of the United States, his powers and his duty will be found ample for the present emergency.
headline: {'main': 'The Powers of the President and his Duty.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Powers of the President and his Duty.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Special Committee to investigate the action of the Commissioners for the erection of the new bridge at Harlem, met yesterday and had a protracted session.
lead_paragraph: The Special Committee to investigate the action of the Commissioners for the erection of the new bridge at Harlem, met yesterday and had a protracted session. All of the Committee were present, as were G. W. SMITH, Esq., Street Commissioner, and one of the Commissioners -- Messrs. MCLEOD MURPHY and MCALPINE, Civil Engineers, and a large lobby composed principally of assistants or employes on the work. The table of the chamber was strewn with maps, plans, law books, official coast surveys, &c, and it was evident that business was intended. Mr. Street-Commissioner SMITH was first called to testify, and he gave evidence as to his connection and meetings with the Commissioners. The original plan submitted by Mr. MCALPINE met his decided objections, as it necessitated a change of grade of the streets on the New-York side of the bridge, which would involve the necessity of a vast expenditure to property owners in the vicinity of the bridge and to the City, and it was subsequently modified to the plan under which the existing contracts were formed.

abstract: What must that people be," exclaimed some philosopher, "whose god is a monkey?" What must those Virginians be, we may add, who make a hero of FLOYD? He has been feasted, we see, at...
lead_paragraph: "What must that people be," exclaimed some philosopher, "whose god is a monkey?" What must those Virginians be, we may add, who make a hero of FLOYD? He has been feasted, we see, at Richmond, -- honored like a man who has rendered some distinguished service to his country, -- by the dignitaries of that ancient State and such private citizens as they could persuade to join in their ovations. The Lieutenant-Governor and Attorney General of Virginia must have exhausted their resources of rhetorical whitewash in vain attempts to cover up and conceal the black spots of dishonesty resting on the character of their guest. But as to the still blacker and more damning stains of treason, perjury to his official oath, and connivance with traitors there was no whitewash thought necessary. The avowal of these offences, rather, was FLOYD's distinctive claim to recognition, and the honors of the banquet; it was because he had aided the Disunionists in their schemes to overthrow the Union, that his delinquencies and manifold infamies in the pecuniary line deserved to be forgotten. Such is the present standard of public morals in the State that was the birthplace and home of WASHINGTON.

abstract: -- Col. J. B. F. Russel died very suddenly in Chicago on Jan. 3. He entered the army as a cadet in 1814, from Boston, Mass., where he was born; was appointed Second-Lieutenant of the Artillery in 1818; in 1821 was transferred to the Fifth Infantry; was Assistant Quartermaster from 1828 to 1830, and in April, 1830, was promoted to a Captaincy. In 1832 he went to Chicago with his command and engaged in the Black Hawk War, under Gen. Scott. Subsequently he was stationed at Fort Brady, Sault Ste. Marie, Fort Spelling and Fort Crawford; and in 1837 he superintended the removal of the Indian tribes of Wisconsin beyond the Mississippi. By real estate speculations in Chicago, where he took up his residence after resigning his command, he acquired a large property. His wife and one child, who survive him, reside in Brooklyn.

abstract: CITY MORTALITY. -- The City Inspector reports the death of 425 persons during the week ending on Saturday, Jan. 12, viz.: 104 men, 86 women, 128 boys and 107 girls -- being an increase of 48 on the preceding week, and a decrease of 77 on the deaths during the corresponding week in 1860. abstract: In this Court yesterday, before Judge LEONARD, in the case of Freidrich Freund, who was sentenced on Saturday to imprisonment for life, in a conviction of arson, Mr. Morrison, the assigned counsel, yesterday, in accordance with the recommendation of the jury to the mercy of the Court, drew up a petition to the Governor for a commutation of sentence to seven years' imprisonment.
lead_paragraph: In this Court yesterday, before Judge LEONARD, in the case of Freidrich Freund, who was sentenced on Saturday to imprisonment for life, in a conviction of arson, Mr. Morrison, the assigned counsel, yesterday, in accordance with the recommendation of the jury to the mercy of the Court, drew up a petition to the Governor for a commutation of sentence to seven years' imprisonment. This was signed by the Court, and is in the hands of the Clerk for the signature of the jurors. On the verdict rendered, the Court had no discretion but to sentence for life. But as the prisoner was not a hardened, bad man, and was over 60 years of age, a lenient course on the part of the Governor was deemed by Court and jury as only the part of humanity.

abstract: As Lord ELGIN'S chair entered the gate the troops presented arms, and the Bands played "God save the Queen." His chair was carried to the front of the dais, when Prince KUNG advanced to receive him, accompanied by all the Mandarins.
lead_paragraph: As Lord ELGIN's chair entered the gate the troops presented arms, and the Bands played "God save the Queen." His chair was carried to the front of the dais, when Prince KUNG advanced to receive him, accompanied by all the Mandarins. A cold bow from Lord ELGIN and all anxious, hesitating salutation from Prince KUNG, and Lord ELGIN passed at once to his seat and sat down, motioning KUNG to take the one on his right, which is considered the lowest. A table stood in the middle of the space, in front of which the boxes containing the convention and treaty were placed.

abstract: Prince KUNG was requested to have some private palace at once prepared for Lord ELGIN'S reception, and the Prince of I's was hamed, as being in a conventent situation.
lead_paragraph: Prince KUNG was requested to have some private palace at once prepared for Lord ELGIN'S reception, and the Prince of I's was hamed, as being in a conventent situation. It is a building of vast extent; the outhouses alone could accommodate 3,000 soldiers with case; but the palace and gardens were in not much better condition than the other buildings visited. Three hundred Chinese workmen were, however, set to work, and it is surprising how much they can do in a few hours towards making a place look habitable and comfortable. But the state of decay of the public buildings as well as private, even when owned by one of the greatest and richest Princes of the Empire, like the Prince of I, gives a melancholy impression for the future of China.

abstract: Thomas W. Alexander, an individual of soldierly appearance, was tempted to indulge his taste for strong drink on Sunday night, and soon presented anything but a martial and dignified appearance.
lead_paragraph: Thomas W. Alexander, an individual of soldierly appearance, was tempted to indulge his taste for strong drink on Sunday night, and soon presented anything but a martial and dignified appearance. Indeed he made the mud-gutter his couch, and while seeking "tired Nature's sweet restorer," his reveries were rudely interrupted by one Francis Roberts, an habitual violator of the Eighth Commandment, who seized his gold watch, valued at $50, and ran. The thief's flight was intercepted by officer Zieger, of the Twenty-first Ward, who found the watch in his possession. He was arrested, and taken yesterday morning before Justice CONNOLLY, who committed him for trial in spite of Alexander's disinclination to prosecute, as he was very anxious to depart immediately for Mexico, where he could indulge his warlike propensities. To secure his attendance as a witness, he was sent to the House of Detention, No. 88 White-street.

abstract: Judge SMALLEY delivered an important charge to the Grand Jury in the United States Circuit Court, yesterday, on the law of high treason.
lead_paragraph: Judge SMALLEY delivered an important charge to the Grand Jury in the United States Circuit Court, yesterday, on the law of high treason. He told them that the seizure of United States property and firing on the United States flag by persons owing allegiance to the United States, constituted high treason by levying war; that no State could absolve citizens from their allegiance to the General Government; and that neither South Carolina nor any other State could legally protect citizens of other States in waging war against their Government. He laid down the legal definition of treason, and declared it to be the duty of all good and true citizens to do everything in their power to suppress rebellion, expose treason and bring traitors to justice.

abstract: In the analysis of Southern society, attempted by us in the TIMES of yesterday, we stated the number of slaveholders contained in the eight highest grades, as classified in the census report.
lead_paragraph: In the analysis of Southern society, attempted by us in the TIMES of yesterday, we stated the number of slaveholders contained in the eight highest grades, as classified in the census report. It will be remembered that there were only two men in the South, in 1850, who owned so many as one thousand slaves; only nine who owned so many as five hundred, and under one thousand; fifty-six who owned three hundred to five hundred; 187 who owned two hundred to three hundred, and 1,479 who owned one to two hundred -- in all 1,733 who owned one hundred slaves or more. This insignificant number of men constitute the real "South" of which we hear so much, with its large plantations, tilled by hundreds of slaves. Their aggregate ownership is less than 300,000, and if we add the next wealthiest class, comprising 6,196 persons who own fifty to one hundred slaves each, the whole number of large proprietors will be 7,929, owning together about one hundred and fifty thousand slaves. This is less than one-fourth of the whole slave population of the South in 1850, which amounted to 3,204,313 souls.

abstract: THE INDIAN TRUST FUND ROBBERY. -- "Occasional" writes to the Philadelphia Press: "A curious fact connected with the Indian Trust Fund robbery, and going to show that Gov. FLOYD long meditated obtaining possession of these bonds, is contained in the Congressional Globe of the last session of the Thirty-fifth Congress, from which it appears that an amendment was introduced in the Senate to the Indian Appropriation bill, disconnecting the whole Indian Bureau from the Interior Department, and placing it under the charge of the War Department. I am informed that Gov. FLOYD showed great anxiety to have this amendment adopted by the House of Representatives, and was present in that body during its consideration urging his friends to support it, but, principally through the opposition of Hon. JOHN B. HASKIN, it was lost. The suspicions of Mr. HASKIN that the Secretary of War desired to have this Indian Bureau placed under his care for no good purpose, are clearly shown in his remarks on the occasion. The Secretary of War, defeated in obtaining control of the bureau, turned his attention to, and succeeded in having his nephew, BAILEY, appointed clerk, in charge of the Trust bonds, under the Interior Department. This accomplished his evidently long-cherished design of possessing the power to use the bonds for his own purposes. The Special Committee which has been appointed to investigate the case, are expected to return from New-York at an early day, and the developments they will make, it is believed, will show that the whole machinery of the Government has been perverted by certain of Mr. BUCHANAN's Cabinet, to enable their friends to plunder the Government.

abstract: The six hundred troops quartered at Fort Columbus, on Governor's Island, are daily drilled, and are being prepared for active service should they be called for. A considerable portion of them are raw recruits, but they are fast being broken in and will make efficient soldiers. Yesterday they were congratulating themselves at being in snug quarters during the prevailing severe storm. They appear very observant of every movement which indicates an intention to draft them into active service, -- a feeling being prevalent in the garrison that they will, sooner or later, be required to proceed to Southern forts. The two hundred troops who returned on the Star of the West are still retained in a separate organization, and drilled together.

abstract: The man who was found murdered shortly after 7 o'clock on Sunday evening, upon the steps of the building No. 205 Bowery, has been identified as JOHN SEXTON, a native of Ireland, 26 years of age, residing at the corner of Washington and Canal streets.
lead_paragraph: The man who was found murdered shortly after 7 o'clock on Sunday evening, upon the steps of the building No. 205 Bowery, has been identified as JOHN SEXTON, a native of Ireland, 26 years of age, residing at the corner of Washington and Canal streets. Corner SCHIRMER, yesterday afternoon, opened an inquest and took the testimony of several witnesses, in whose company the deceased had been up to a late hour previous to the time when his lifeless body was discovered by the police, but their statements failed to fix suspicion upon any one. It was shown that deceased had been on a drinking bout, commencing at a late hour on Saturday night, and that he was in a semi-intoxicated condition when his acquaintances last saw him alive. He is represented to have been of a violent temper, and quarrelsome when under the influence of liquor. One of the witnesses testified that on Saturday night while intoxicated, deceased made a wanton assault upon himself and his (witness) brother, with whom he was on the best of terms, and the next day, when partially sober, he made a most abject apology for his misconduct. Edward Doyle, a young butcher, employed at Clinton Market, had been drinking with the murdered man on Sunday afternoon, and it was in his company that he was last seen. He is in custody as a witness and his testimony will be given to-day. The evidence furnished statements of deceased having caused unhappiness in the domestic relations of a butcher, named Sheridan, with whom he boarded at the time of his death, but the developments were of a very vague character. The following testimony was given:

abstract: The programme for the establishment of the southern Confederacy is understood to be alraady perfected, and some of the details are given in our Washington dispatches. Georgia, it is expected, ...
lead_paragraph: The programme for the establishment of the southern Confederacy is understood to be alraady perfected, and some of the details are given in our Washington dispatches. Georgia, it is expected, will have declared herself out of the Union by Saturday next. When this event shall have happened, delegates from South Carolina, Alabama, Florida, Mississippi and Georgia will assemble at Milledgeville, in the latter State, to take steps to establish a Provisional Government, and elect a President and Vice-President pro tempore, provide for an army, and initiate other defensive measures. It is the intention, also, to dispatch Ministers immediately to Foreign Powers, to negotiate treaties. It is possible that the States mentioned may be left alone in this movement, as indications are not wanting that their precipitate action will not be followed by either Louisiana or Texas, upon both of which States the immediate Secessionists have counted. The latest dispatches received in Washington are to the effect that the Disunionists will be badly beaten in Texas, and that in Louisiana the cooperationists stand decidedly the best chance of success.

abstract: Coroner SCHIRMER, yesterday, continued his investigation at the Seventeenth Ward Station-honse of the circumstances attending the murder of JOHN SEXTON on Sunday night last. The evidence elicited does ...
lead_paragraph: Coroner SCHIRMER, yesterday, continued his investigation at the Seventeenth Ward Station-honse of the circumstances attending the murder of JOHN SEXTON on Sunday night last. The evidence elicited does not shed the slightest light upon the case, but goes far toward relieving EDWARD DOYLE, the young man in whose company the deceased was last seen, from suspicion. JAMES CRAIG, an actor, who has been mentioned in connection with the case, yesterday called upon Capt. TURNBULL and yielded himself into custody. There is no cause watever of suspicion against him. Following is the testimony:

abstract: The public mind is becoming very impatient at the state of affairs in the South. The repulse of the Star of the West, bearing rein
lead_paragraph: The public mind is becoming very impatient at the state of affairs in the South. The repulse of the Star of the West, bearing reinforcements to Fort Sumter, and her precipitate retreat from the fire of the Disunionists, have seriously stung the pride of the country: -- and the silence and utter inactivity of the Government at Washington over this most direct and flagrant defiance of its authority, create general disgust and indignation. It looks as if vacillation at head-quarters had been succeeded by imbecility, -- as if the Government had made up its mind to make no further efforts to stem the tide of rebellion, but leave everything to take care of itself. This does not suit the temper of the American people. It is difficult to perceive its wisdom, and quite impossible to reconcile it with that sense of honor and self-respect which is the life and soul of every nation.

abstract: The market opened yesterday very much as on the previous Tuesday. The number of cattle, 3,000, the quality and the prices being about the same. The small supply of animals on hand in the morning led to some competition among buyers, especially among those looking for the best grades, which were scarce. Ten cents lb for the estimated dressed weight, was the ruling price at first; but continued fresh arrivals on delayed trains diminished the eagerness of purchasers, though the entire business of the day was unusually large for Tuesday's preliminary markets. Some expected lots were still behind last night, and a fair supply is looked for to-day with easy rates. Those having cattle in the delayed trains were much disappointed in not being able to take advantage of the first day's better market.

abstract: As Detective Wilson was passing through Sullivan-street, about 12 o'clock, on Monday night, he observed two men dodging in an erea way, and suspecting that they were thieves, he stopped to watch their actions. One of them happened to see him, and picking up a club from the ground he approached in a threatening manner. Wilson warned the man to keep at a respectable distance or he would shoot him, but his words were disregarded, and fearing that he would get a severe beating, he drew his revolver and fired. The ball took effect, for the man uttered a cry of pain and ran off. Wilson immediately went to the Fifteenth Ward Station-house, near which the occurrence happened, and procured assistance, under the impression that the wounded man would be found lying upon the sidewalk. Upon reaching the place, however, the person was not visible, but he was found after a protraced search at his residence No. 226 Sullivan-st. It then transpired that his name was George Taylor, that he was a person of respectable character, until recently employed as a porter at A.T. Stewart & Co.'s, and that he had got into the somewhat equivocal position in which he was seen by the Detective through an unfortunate indulgence in intoxicating drink. Dr. Clements was called in to see Taylor, but he was unable to find the ball, which had entered his breast and apparently glanced around the body. It is not thought that the wound will prove fatal. During yesterday afternoon the brother of the wounded man called upon Justice DUSENBERRY, who is temporarily presiding in Justice CONOLLY's place at Jefferson Market Police Court, and prayed that a warrant might be issued for Wilson on a charge of felonious assault. The Magistrate, however, refused to issue a warrant, thus leaving the inference that the officer was justified in using his weapon.

abstract: We have not the pleasure of knowing Messrs. HAYNE, MANIGAULT and PICKENS, of South Carolina, but are sorry to find any three unknown gentlemen reduced so low that Ex-Secretary FLOYD should think it necessary to vouch "for their honesty and integrity." They are "good men," says FLOYD in his late speech at the Richmond banquet; "they are great men;" -- and thus are three reputations utterly blasted and withered in root and branch, merely to furnish an ornament, possibly, for the postprandial eloquence of our late Secretary of Civil War! What deadly wrong could the three persons named have committed against Ex-Gov. FLOYD to justify this fell malignity of approbation? Are they not Secessionists as much as he is -- one of them the Secession Governor of South Caroliana? and should not this fact in itself, have sufficed to shield them from the moral leprosy of his praise? That they should be regarded by all conservative, national and Union-loving men as traitors, was bad enough: but that their ideas of "honesty and integrity" should be loose enough to meet FLOYD's views, is something we confess ourselves not to have been prepared for.

abstract: By a citizen of New-York, recently arrived from Savannah, where he has resided since the middle of November last, we receive additional accounts of the secession fever, and the condition of the city. ...
lead_paragraph: By a citizen of New-York, recently arrived from Savannah, where he has resided since the middle of November last, we receive additional accounts of the secession fever, and the condition of the city. Our informant witnessed the capture of Fort Pulaski, together with the preliminary movements. Three hundred and fifty volunteers from the city, able-bodied men, and mostly rather young, were taken down the river by a small steamboat, making two trips for the purpose. Besides muskets, they were armed with three or four six-pound field pieces, besides other smaller pieces -- for cannister -- making seven in all. Landing upon the wharf next the Fort, they were preceded by an officer who entered, and in place of the stars and stripes, raised a flag bearing as emblems the lone star, the cotton-bale, and the rattlesnake. Meanwhile, the garrison abandoned the Fort. It consisted of three persons only, -- one man and two women, -- an old watchman, his wife, and his daughter.

abstract: Application of Commissionres of Apprasial of Central Park Extension.-This proceeding was stated in the TIMES, Jam 8. It is an application on the ...
lead_paragraph: Application of Commissionres of Apprasial of Central Park Extension. -- This proceeding was stated in the TIMES, Jam 8. It is an application on the part of the Commissioners of Appraisal, appointed by the Supreme Court, at the instance of the Central Park Commissioners on the 13th of July, 1859, to have their report confirmed. This report awards the amount due to parties for lands taken for the extension between the Fifth and Sixth avenues and One Hundred and Sixth and One Hundred and Tenth streets; and it is alleged that while it was represented to the Legislature at the time of the passage of the act authorizing the extension, that the total expense of the extension would be but $300,000, yet the Appraisers awards the sum of $1,500,000, which is double the value of the property taken. That the Commissioners, while they considered it desirable to extend the Park if the land could be purchased at the cost first estimated, did not consider it desirable to do so at the increased expense made necessary by the award of the Appraisers, and therefore by resolution of the Board, they discontinue these proceedings.

abstract: Several gentlemen have arrived in this City within a few days who have, for a long time past, been engaged in trade at Charleston. One of these ...
lead_paragraph: Several gentlemen have arrived in this City within a few days who have, for a long time past, been engaged in trade at Charleston. One of these kept a provision and grocery store. A demand was made upon him for an exorbitant sum to sustain the State authorities. He offered them State Stocks, but they would accept only a moderate amount of these securities, and finally they removed by force about one-half of all the goods from his store. He did not dare to remonstrate, but he quietly sent his slaves to Richmond, Va., and, between two days, packed up the remainder of his property and left the State. His case, he says, is only a sample of multitudes of others. It is no uncommon thing to notice the closing of stores, when an inspection, of the premises reveals the fact that all the merchandise has been re moved.
