abstract: The consequences which have immediately followed the election of a Republican President have probably taken the South as well the North by surprise. Loud threats of secession had been so habitually used that they were generally classed among the exaggerations of American party warfare. There was undoubtedly some affectation both in the sinister forebodings of the Democrats and in the obstinate incredulity of the Republicans; but it was only in South Carolina, and one or two adjacent States, that the disruption of the Union was seriously contemplated. The authors of the movement probably formed a small minority even in Charleston itself, but they have taken advantage of a moment when the Pro-Slavery orators had committed themselves too far to recede. South Carolina has practically thrown off the Federal authority, and the remaining Cotton States seem about to adopt a similar course. The older slaveholding communities are agitated by conflicting uncertainties, wishing at the same time to cling to the Union and to extort impossible concessions from the Northern States. The Republicans are evidently perplexed by their triumph, and their Democratic opponents see in the unexpected fulfillment of their own predictions the imminent ruin of their party, through the secession of their slaveholding allies. The election of Mr. Lincoln is in itself only an imaginary or symbolic grievance. The President has no initiative in Federal legislation, nor is it in his power to interfere with local rights of property. The ostensible points in dispute are the right of possessing slaves in the Territories, and the unconstitutional acts by which some Free States have rendered the Fugitive Slave law inoperative. Both questions lie within the competence of the Supreme Court, which has uniformly interpreted the Constitution in accordance with the pretensions of the slaveowners. The President has no means of influencing the decision except by the nomination of partisan Judges to vacancies which may occur on the Federal Bench, but the Southern States resent the discovery that a majority of the entire population is opposed to the extension of Slavery. A reconciliation seems hopeless if the the Unum is only to be preserved on the conditions suggested by Mr. Buchanan in his Presidential Message. The New-England States might, perhaps, repeal the laws which they have passed in defiance of the Constitution; but it is absurd to expect that the Republicans will turn their victory into a defeat by acknowledging the abstract right of property in slaves, or by legislating in accordance with the decision of the Supreme Court in favor of Slavery in the Territories. The prospect of the maintenance or restoration of the Union must de derived from more general considerations, which have hitherto been obscured by party passions. The States which meditate secession have as yet by no means realized the establishment of an inland frontier with strangers, and perhaps enemies, on the other side. The evils of which they complain can only be aggravated by the abdication of the hold over their confederates which they derive from the Constitution and from their alliance with the Democrats of the North. Separation will convert every Free State into a safe asylum for fugitive slaves, and, if a partition of the Territories is effected, the Southern Confederacy will only obtain the portion which must from situation and climate necessarily have fallen to its share. Mr. BUCHANAN was right in thinking, if not in saying, that it is impossible to coerce a seceding State, because American institutions involve no provision for the government of a conquered province. The pride of belonging to a great nation, the habit of union, and the convenience of unrestricted intercourse, will probably induce the Slave States to devise some attainable compromise, if only time is given to negotiation and reflection. The feelings, and perhaps the interests of England, are on the side of continued Union. The free commerce which might be opened at Charleston or New-Orleans would fail to produce cordial relations with a Confederacy which would be pledged to promote the indefinite extension of Slavery, even if it were not tempted to revive the Slave-trade.

abstract: We understand that Ex-Councilman KERRIGAN, who has been engaged for some weeks in raising companies of men in this City, for service against the Federal Government, has returned within a day or two from South Carolina, which he visited for the purpose of concerting some effective plan of operations with the Disunionists of that State. What plans were matured it is impossible, of course, to say. But we have reason to believe that promises were made, which are to be fulfilled by movements in this City, upon which it will be prudent for the Federal authorities and the Grand Jury to keep an eye.

abstract: At starting we find both Consols and the bank bullion at the lowest points of the last twelve months, and the rate of discount more than twice as high as on the 1st of January, 1860. These,however, are not ...
lead_paragraph: At starting we find both Consols and the bank bullion at the lowest points of the last twelve months, and the rate of discount more than twice as high as on the 1st of January, 1860. These,however, are not material considerations. In the face of the decline in the bank bullion the remedy of a fresh advance in the rate of discount is simple, and the mercantile world have at length learnt that, so far from a full rate of interest being injurious to business, it operates, when resulting from natural circumstances, to the benefit of the legitimate trader, by bringing down all the unsound speculators who are playing with the means of other people. But there is apparently no reason to anticipate any prolonged increase of pressure in the money-market. Although rates may remain high for some time, there are three millions at the credit of our account in China, and two millions have been dispatched to America, which are likely to create a remarkable influence on our interchanges with that country during the next few months. There is scarcely a single point to which we have remittances to make for installments of loans, and in India it seems at last to have been discovered that there are limits within which it is expedient, for the preservation of credit, to confine the system of draining the London market. By this time a large part of the grain importations rendered requisite by our own deficiency must have been paid for, and, although the ability of the United States to continue sending us large quantities at prices considerably below those now prevalent is usually underrated, and will probably be found much greater than has yet been supposed, the movement is not, under any circumstances, likely to do more than prevent money from becoming particularly abundant. The Turkish loan having been a failure in London, no outgoing will take place in that respect, while, if the whole should be subscribed in France, a not insignificant part of the proceeds will find their way to this country in liquidation of balances due to us from Constantinople.

abstract: In his instructions to the Grand Jury of the United States Court, on the subject of high treason, Judge SMALLEY is at once a sound expositor of Constitutional law and of public opinion. There is no reason whatever to entertain doubt upon either point. ...
lead_paragraph: In his instructions to the Grand Jury of the United States Court, on the subject of high treason, Judge SMALLEY is at once a sound expositor of Constitutional law and of public opinion. There is no reason whatever to entertain doubt upon either point. It is sufficient to understand that the penalties of treason are the only legal securities against the overthrow of the Federal Government; and that a neglect to enforce them places the whole costly machinery of its administration in the hands of any body of daring conspirators whose knowledge of the impunity assured them may invite to acts of active hostility, to understand the absolute necessity of putting these laws in force, or of admitting our Federal system to be too weak and worthless to deserve preservation. The convictions of a vast majority of the American people are evidently founded upon this impression. It is, of all things, most desirable to avoid such conflict between local interests, and passions, and national obligations, as may bring the highest of political crimes into, existence; but the moment such conflict is clearly inevitable, equally inevitable is the stern duty of applying all constitutional and legal agencies to the cure of the popular distemper. The nature of these agencies Judge SMALLEY has very explicitly defined.

abstract: WALLACK'S THEATRE. -- At this season of the year it is always good managerial policy to produce a "sensation" piece -- by which we mean a piece wherein the accidental calamities of life, rather than its ordinary characteristics, are attempted to be delineated. Guided by a sound knowledge of the requirements of our public, Mr. WALLACK has fallen readily into the proper track, and has given us a sensation piece in "Pauline," and another in the "Lady of St. Tropes." The last-mentioned work was produced yesternight, and maybe recorded as a success. It is taken, as its name indicates, from a French melodrama, and has already found several English dresses. At one of the London theaters it is even now in the enjoyment of what is called a "run." The version produced at Mr. WALLACK'S is said to be by a gentleman of Boston, and we take it, a faithful rendering of the original. In the first and second acts it is somewhat wordy, and abounds in narratives which consume time and retard action; in the latter portions it is spirited and eminently effective. It can hardly be doubted that the experienced pen of the manager will detect much that can be readily excised, and we are sure that liberality in this respect will be well bestowed.

abstract: The American Exchange Fire Insurance Compauy Dexter B. Britton impleaded.--This is an appeal to the General Term of this Court from a judgment entered at a trial term thereof on the 16th day of October, 1860, held by Justice Bosworth. The facts of the ...
lead_paragraph: The American Exchange Fire Insurance Compauy Dexter B. Britton impleaded. -- This is an appeal to the General Term of this Court from a judgment entered at a trial term thereof on the 16th day of October, 1860, held by Justice Bosworth. The facts of the case as they appeared on the trial are as follows: The plaintiffs were constituted a corporation under the general act of 1853, in February, 1859. Upon filing their charter with the Comptroller, that officer, pursuant to the statute, appointed the defendant, John Raymond and Royal Chamberlain, as Commissioners, to examine the assets of the Company, and certify whether the capital named in the charter had been paid in good faith, and was the property of the Company in its own right. The Commissioners having made the requisite examination, certified, under oath, that the capital of the Company had been paid in good faith and was their property, and having made out the necessary papers, gave them to an officer of the Company, who dispatched a messenger with them to the Comptroller to obtain that officer's official certificate necessary to authorize the Company to commence their business. On the next day the Commissioners presented a bill to the Company for services rendered, amounting to $300. The Company objected to the bill as exorbitant, and declined to pay it, but on being told by the defendant that if the bill was not paid he should inform the Comptroller of the non-payment, the Company paid it under protest, and this action was brought to recover the same. At the trial a judgment for the whole amount was entered for the plaintiffs. The defendant now appeals to the General Term of this Court on the following points:

abstract: At 8 o'clock last evening the Academy of Music was first opened to the public. An immense audience was lathered within its walls. We noticed among ...
lead_paragraph: At 8 o'clock last evening the Academy of Music was first opened to the public. An immense audience was lathered within its walls. We noticed among those present Commodore STRINGHAM, of the United States Navy, Rev. Dr. STORES, Rev. Dr. CUYLER, and other members of the clerical profession.

abstract: The good people of Charleston are agitating a question only second in importance to that famous one so long since bruited: Who struck Billy Patterson? They are anxious to discover who fired the first shot at the Star of the West. An ovation awaits the gentleman as soon as his name is announced. Many claimants of honor have presented themselves, but the question of to whom it rightfully belongs, seems as yet involved in doubt. It is likely, from present indications, that this act of gunnership will go down to posterity muffled in a mystery like to that which envelops the authorship of Junius.

abstract: A meeting, ostensibly of workingmen of the City, opposed to the "Republican Party," who, according to the advertised call for the gathering, are "rushing us into the horrors of civil war, by refusing to give the South her just rights ...
lead_paragraph: A meeting, ostensibly of workingmen of the City, opposed to the "Republican Party," who, according to the advertised call for the gathering, are "rushing us into the horrors of civil war, by refusing to give the South her just rights under the Constitution, setting up the Chicago Platform, instead of the ruling of the Supreme Court, as its proper interpretation, thus overthrowing the Constitution and Union at one blow," was held, last night, at Brookes' Hall, No. 361 Broome-street. It was not held in the "Hall" itself, -- that was appropriated by the devotees of the dance, and the feet of the Terpsichorean worshippers gave Marshal RYNDERS many occasions to roll the ball, which he probably would not otherwise have thought of. The meeting was held in a room beneath the hall, used as a drill-room by the "Governor's Guard, Sixth Regiment, New-York State Militia," and was somewhat incommodious for a grand demonstration for any political party whatever, but quite large enough for the Working Men's Anti-Republican in-aid-of-South Carolina-Party, which assembled there last night, which was composed mainly, and indeed almost entirely, of the rough-spun sons of the Celtic Isle.

abstract: -- A couple recently went all the way from Dover, N.H. to Portland, Me., to find a Unitarian clergyman to unite them in bonds matrimonial. On reaching Portland they inquired for Mr. Moore, and as they did not state the denomination to which the clergy man of that name whom they desired to find belonged, were introduced to the pastor of a Congregational Church, who performed the ceremony without making any inquiries into the religious belief of the parties concerned. Great was their mortification and perplexity when they ascertained that they had stumbled upon the wrong Mr. Moore, and that their journey had been made for nothing.

abstract: The past twenty years have witnessed three instances of industrial progress on so grand and rapid a scale as to be without a parallel in history. These are given in Russia, in our own far West, and in the English settlements in Australia. As regards the latter, it is interesting to know that the population of Victoria alone has, within a quarter of a century, risen from 170 to 530,000 souls. During this time Government has realized nearly eight million pounds sterling by the sale of the colony lands, all of which has been expended in local improvements. On 200,000 acres of settled land there is property valued at nearly seventy millions of pounds. Last year there was raised two million five hundred thousand pounds worth of cereals and vegetables, with an export of wool, tallow, hides and cattle to the value of very nearly four million pounds. The gold export of 1859 was about nine million pounds.

abstract: An interesting company of homeless and orphan children left the City yesterday afternoon with Mr. C.C. TRACY. The Children's Aid Society, notwithstanding the hard times, and the business depression consequent on the national troubles, continue unceasingly their work of saving the poor children of New-York from the distress and wretchedness, the inevitable results of orphanage and the desertion of these little ones. A poor widow, with three fine children of tender age, accompanied the party. The children varied in age from infancy to fourteen years. They were quite a family party, and well fenced by good and warm clothing against the severity of the season.

abstract: The question of the City Chamberlaincy is becoming more and more involved with each day that passes. Ex-Chamberlain PLATT, ...
lead_paragraph: The question of the City Chamberlaincy is becoming more and more involved with each day that passes. Ex-Chamberlain PLATT, finding that the summary process of the Court of Common Pleas had compelled his surrender of the books, papers and accounts of his late office to his successor, has now very ingeniously shifted the contest to an affair in which the Park Bank is the defendant, and with which the late Chamberlain has no ostensible connection. The Park Bank refuses to transfer the millions of public money now in its custody to the Broadway Bank until authorized and ordered to make the change of deposit by a warrant which shall have attached to it the signatures of the Comptroller, Mayor and Clerk of the Common Council; and in this refusal, there can be no doubt that the Park Bank is, apparently, if not actually, sustained by Section 22 of the amended City Charter.

abstract: THE DEATH OF Mr. HEIL.-Coroner JACKAMN yesterday closed the inquest upon the body of J. F. HEIL, keeper of a lodging-house and restaurant, at No.420 Broome-street, who was found dead a few days since upon the floor of his bedroom with his throat cut. From the fact that a host-mortem...
lead_paragraph: THE DEATH OF Mr. HEIL. -- Coroner JACKAMN yesterday closed the inquest upon the body of J. F. HEIL, keeper of a lodging-house and restaurant, at No.420 Broome-street, who was found dead a few days since upon the floor of his bedroom with his throat cut. From the fact that a host-mortem examination, made by Dr. JOHN BEACH, resulted in showing the presence of mineral poison in large quantities, in the stomach of deceased, the Coroner deferred the investigation, with the object of making a chemical analysis. This having been done, the poison was found to have been arsenic, and evidence was obtained making it probable that deceased had voluntarily taken it, with the view of destroying himself, but as it did not take immediate effect, he cut his throat. Deceased had, for some time previous to his death, lived unhappily with his wife, and that was undoubtedly the cause of his having committed suicide.

abstract: In 1859 the value of duty-paying goods imported into the States south of Maryland was $13 014,000, which equaled about five per cent. of the total imports into the country. The duties collected thereon, at the average rate paid by all the imports, was $2,602,800. The population of these States was about ...
lead_paragraph: In 1859 the value of duty-paying goods imported into the States south of Maryland was $13 014,000, which equaled about five per cent. of the total imports into the country. The duties collected thereon, at the average rate paid by all the imports, was $2,602,800. The population of these States was about 11,000,000; the rate of import per head, consequently, was about $1 20 -- of duties paid, about 24 cents. The value of importations of duty-paying goods into the Northern States, including Maryland, the same, year, was $246,000,000; the duties paid thereon about $47,000,000. The value of imports into these was about $13 per head, assuming the population to have been 19,000,000. The duties were very nearly $2 50 per head. The ratio in value of importations of duty-paying goods into the Northern States per head, and of the revenues paid to the Government, were ten times as great as into the Southern States.

abstract: -- In view of the probably near assault upon Fort Sumter, the failure of the Star of the West to land her reinforcements becomes more and more a subject of general regret. In regard to the responsibility for that failure, we have made still further inquiry into the facts of the case and find them to be substantially as already stated. It is quite true, however, that Capt. MCGOWAN had no revenue flag on board, -- so that his failure to hoist one on approaching the Fort was not his fault. At the same time the charterer of the vessel supposed that one had been sent on board, -- as he had ordered it to be procured, and did not learn until the steamer's return that this had not been done.

abstract: The Supervisors met yesterday at 12 o'clock M., when they organized for the year. All the members were present. Mr. SMITH ELY was first called on to preside. a ballot was then taken for permanent President, and resulted for WILLIAM R. STEWART, 11; for blank, 1. The Democrats, it appeared, although entitled to the office, preferred to give it to Mr. STEWART again, who is a Republican.

abstract: PUGNACIOUS NEIGHBORS--DEATH FROM VIOLENCE.--On the 24 of November last, a quarrel occurred at the tenement house No. 241 First-avenue, between Mrs. WESTON, one of the occupants, and two sisters, named HONORAH McCARTY and CATHARINE McCLAIN, who had just been married and were also keeping house in the premises in question.
lead_paragraph: PUGNACIOUS NEIGHBORS -- DEATH FROM VIOLENCE. -- On the 24 of November last, a quarrel occurred at the tenement house No. 241 First-avenue, between Mrs. WESTON, one of the occupants, and two sisters, named HONORAH McCARTY and CATHARINE McCLAIN, who had just been married and were also keeping house in the premises in question. The women commenced hostilities in the forenoon, but without coming to a settlement they were separated by their friends. A few hours later the belligerent sisters resumed active demonstrations by knocking furiously at the door of Mrs. WESTON'S room. The husband of the latter opened the door to learn what might be the matter, when one of the women, it is said, struck him a blow on the head with a hatchet, which rendered him insensible. He was taken to Bellevue Hospital, and placed under the care of the House Surgeon, Dr. PAYNE, who at first did not think that his injury was of a fatal character. Lately, however, his symptoms have become unfavorable, and on Tuesday he died. The women were arrested soon after the commission of the assault, and required to give bail to appear and answer. Coroner JACKMAN yesterday investigated the case and took testimony of a somewhat conflicting character. It was not positively shown that either of the accused inflicted the violence upon the deceased, though the inference that one of them did could not be stronger. Dr. PAYNE testified that he made a post-mortem examination of the body, finding a large abscess in the brain, quite remote from the wound, and in his opinion death was caused by the abscess, which was the result of the injuries. A verdict was given to the effect that the deceased died from violence at the hands of some unknown person, but the Coroner determined to hold Mrs. MCCARTY and Mrs. MCCLAIN in bonds of $500 each as witnesses. The deceased was 54 years of age, and a native of Ireland.

abstract: There are one hundred cases of suicide officially registered in New-York and Brooklyn for the bygone year. This, of course, can form but an approximate of the number of persons who have been really guilty of felo de se during that period, as it includes merely those cases in which death has resulted, or in which legal proceedings were taken; while of the large number recorded as ...
lead_paragraph: There are one hundred cases of suicide officially registered in New-York and Brooklyn for the bygone year. This, of course, can form but an approximate of the number of persons who have been really guilty of felo de se during that period, as it includes merely those cases in which death has resulted, or in which legal proceedings were taken; while of the large number recorded as "found drowned," probably two-thirds at least were voluntary suicides; and a still larger number, doubtless, are unknown and unregistered, save by Him from whose luminous glance nothing is concealed. Indeed, the total number of suicides during the year must exceed, no man can say how much, those that are actually known.

abstract: Ex-Gov. MOREHEAD, of Kentucky, has written a letter to some gentlemen in New-Orleans, declaring it to be his settled conviction that the precipitate dissolution of the Union by separate State secession, would be a severer blow to Slavery than all the Abolitionists of ...
lead_paragraph: Ex-Gov. MOREHEAD, of Kentucky, has written a letter to some gentlemen in New-Orleans, declaring it to be his settled conviction that the precipitate dissolution of the Union by separate State secession, would be a severer blow to Slavery than all the Abolitionists of the North could inflict in the next twenty years. He can go a good deal further than this, and be perfectly right. The dissolution of the Union, -- whether effected by separate secession or by cooperation, -- inflicts a death-blow upon Slavery. No future event is more certain than this.

abstract: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Jan. 16. Col. HAYNE Called on the President last even ing, and was politely received. He stated verbally and fully the purpose of his mission, which was to demand the unconditional withdrawal of the garrison of Fort Sumter. The President heard him through patiently and attentively, but without the slightest intimation as to what his own views were.

abstract: Mr. Henry Livingstone, a middle-aged man of respectable appearance, who plumes himself upon his lineage and family connections, was apprehended on Tuesday evening by Detectives Slowey and Sease, on a warrant charging him with having defrauded Messrs. Warnock Co., hatters and furriers, No. 519 Broadway, of two wolf-skin robes valued at $40.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Henry Livingstone, a middle-aged man of respectable appearance, who plumes himself upon his lineage and family connections, was apprehended on Tuesday evening by Detectives Slowey and Sease, on a warrant charging him with having defrauded Messrs. Warnock Co., hatters and furriers, No. 519 Broadway, of two wolf-skin robes valued at $40. The fraud was perpetrated about a year ago, the prisoner having selected the property, and directed that it should be left at Mr. Treadwell's boarding house in Fifty-second-street. Accordingly the robes were dispatched there by an errand-boy, who delivered them to a member of Treadwell's family, by whom he was told that Livingstone was not at home, and he must call again for the money. The youth told his employer what had occurred, and the latter becoming impressed with the idea that they were to be the victims of a confidence game, determined to discover if their suspicions were well founded. A member of the firm, therefore, called at Treadwell's house and asked for the money, but was coolly informed that Livingstone did not live there, and that no package had been left for him. Messrs. Warnock consequently obtained a warrant for the swindler's arrest, but the officers were unable to find him until yesterday. In the interval, seven or eight complaints for transactions of a similar character have been lodged against him at the Police Courts, and among them is one from the proprietors of the drug-store at the Fifth-avenue Hotel, from whom he is said to have obtained $20 worth of medicines. The landlord of Gardner's Hotel, Park-place, also alleges to have lost the price of the prisoner's board and lodging for a few days. The officers yesterday searched the house in Fifty-second-street, and found the two robes which had been procured from Messrs. Warnock, in the possession of the man Treadwell, who was arrested as an accomplice with Livingstone in the theft. Both prisoners are detained at Head quarters pending a hearing before a Police Magistrate......Another adept in the practice of artful dodging was arrested in the Eighth Ward on Tuesday night. He is a young man named Gilbert Morris, of prepossessing manner, but whose distinguishing characteristic is a gift of gabbling. The complainants against the prisoner are numerous, and yesterday an army of them presented themselves before Justice QUACKENBUSH, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, to initiate proceedings against him. He operated mainly in silk goods, and his victims are sufferers generally to the extent of $40. There was nothing original in Morris' mode of swindling. His plan was the old one of calling at a store, selecting a piece of goods, and directing that it should be sent to his residence, where he would be in waiting to receive and pay for it. Having obtained the package from the messenger he would tell that individual to wait while he went up stairs for the money, instead of doing which, however, he would leave the premises by another door -- a corner building with a side entrance being necessary to make the dodge successful; The house No. 609 Broadway, corner of Houston street, was a favorite place of the prisoner's, and there, under the name of Sheffield and various other aliases, he had often played his game. Among the merchants who have received his attentions are Messrs. Uosdell, Pierson & Lake; Arnold, Constable & Co.; Jackson & Co.; Strang, Adriance & Co., and Joseph Balter, of Sixth-avenue, while still others are expected to make themselves known.

lead_paragraph: Justice SPEER, of Bergen, commenced an inquest, yesterday afternoon, at Greenville, on the body of Mr. JoHN S. TUTTLE, of that place, who died on Friday last, under circumstances which led to the impression that his death was caused by poison. Mr. TUTTLE had been treated, for several months, by his family physician for a pulmonary disease, but through the advice of a friend was induced to apply to Dr. L. ELSBERG, of No. 153 West Fifteenth street, New-York. Mr. TUTTLE received a prescription; and applied to a druggist in Greenwich-street to have it put up. The druggist, after looking at the prescription, and consulting one or two others in the store, declined to make it up. The deceased procured the medicine at a store in Jersey City, and on the following day commenced to take it as directed; but instead of improving he grow worse, and on the fourth day was very ill, suffering severe pains in his stomach, bowels, kidneys and entire body. The family physician was called in, but could render no relief, and the patient died on the following day, previous to which he requested that a post-mortem be made, and an inquest be held on the body. The following is the evidence:

abstract: ATTEMPT TO BURN A TENEMENT-HOUSE. -- At about 1 o'clock yesterday morning some fiend set fire to a tenement-house, occupied by a large number of colored persons, at the corner of Tillary and Canton streets. The fire was discovered in time to prevent much damage. It is supposed that this incendiary attempt grew out of the late killing of SHIRLEY by RICKS, a colored man.

abstract: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Jan. 16. Col. HAYNE called on the President last even ing, and was politely received. He stated verbally and fully the purpose of his mission, which was to de mand the unconditional withdrawal of the garrison of Fort Sumter. The President heard him through patiently and attentively, but without the slightest intimation as to what his own views were.

abstract: We are glad to learn on authority, which we regard as perfectly reliable, that the Park Bank is in a position to pay over, at a moment's notice, every dollar belonging to the City and County of New-York, provided that its legal adviser shall first be satisfied of the sufficiency of the warrant on which said funds may be called for. In our remarks on this subject, we have not intended at any time to impeach either the ability or the readiness of the Bank to meet all demands that might be made upon it. Indeed, in an article of yesterday we stated that under existing laws the Bank could not do otherwise than refuse payment of the City moneys upon any other warrants than such as may be drawn in strict conformity to law.

abstract: The members of the Board of Supervisors-- a body composed of Republicans and Democrats in equal numbers--have agreed unanimously in awarding to the Metropolitan Police system an indorsement of the highest and most substantial character.
lead_paragraph: The members of the Board of Supervisors -- a body composed of Republicans and Democrats in equal numbers -- have agreed unanimously in awarding to the Metropolitan Police system an indorsement of the highest and most substantial character. By a full vote of the Board, had yesterday, the Police Commissioners are authorized and directed to add four hundred men to their present force, -- the Supervisors thus answering and pushing aside, in a very practical manner, the cloud of misrepresentations and slanders contained in the Mayor's veto of the proposed addition to our Police. It certainly can be straining nothing to assert, that had such earnest Democratic partisans as Supervisors PURDY, TWEED, ELY, BRIGGS, ROCHE and CONNER not felt perfectly satisfied with the management of the Metropolitan Police, they would have "cried aloud and spared not," while denouncing the iniquity of an organization which happens to be controlled by Republican officers, though not directed to Republican ends.

abstract: IMPORTANT MILITARY MOVEMENT. -- The Board of Officers of the Second Regiment, Hudson Brigade, Col. GREGORY Commander, at their last meeting appointed a Committee to devise means to increase the numbers and efficiency of the Brigade. They have addressed a communication to the Board of Officers of the First Regiment, Major BOHNSTEDT acting commandant, to cooperate with them, it is proposed to ask of the present Legislature the passage of such amendments to the Militia law as would be most likely to increase the inducements for joining the organized militia, and to place the Brigade on a better footing -in fact, on a thorough war footing. One of the amendments proposed to be asked for, is a law similar that in New-York by which a person belonging to the infantry, is exempt from $500 taxation on real estate and a person belonging to the cavalry from $1,000 taxation. It is understood that this proposition will be favorably entertained by the first Regiment and a united effort will be made to carry out the objects above stated in order that the Hudson County Brigade, in peace or war, may stand first in the State.
lead_paragraph: IMPORTANT MILITARY MOVEMENT. -- The Board of Officers of the Second Regiment, Hudson Brigade, Col. abstract: Our dispatches from Washington this morning are important. The President, it will be seen, yesterday mustered courage to send to the Senate his nomination of Mr. HOLT as Secretary of War, and that body considered it in Executive Session. The debate upon it was understood to be very personal and acrimonious, but although the nomination has not yet been confirmed, there is little doubt that it will be to-day, as a strenuous effort of the Secessionists to have it referred to the Military Committee failed by a sufficiently decicive vote. The nomination of Mr. MCINTYRE as Collector at Charleston still hangs in the Committee on Commerce. Col. HAYNE, the Commissioner from South Carolina, yesterday completed his communication in accordance with the request of the President, and will probably present it to-day. What disposition will be made of it by Mr. BUCHANAN remains to be seen. It is rumored very strongly that he is again getting uncertain in his policy towards the Disunionists, and that in consequence of this fact there was some very plain conversation in Cabinet meeting yesterday. The latest reports from the South received in Washington are deemed of an encouraging nature.
lead_paragraph: Our dispatches from Washington this morning are important. The President, it will be seen, yesterday mustered courage to send to the Senate his nomination of Mr. HOLT as Secretary of War, and that body considered it in Executive Session. The debate upon it was understood to be very personal and acrimonious, but although the nomination has not yet been confirmed, there is little doubt that it will be to-day, as a strenuous effort of the Secessionists to have it referred to the Military Committee failed by a sufficiently decicive vote. The nomination of Mr. MCINTYRE as Collector at Charleston still hangs in the Committee on Commerce. Col. HAYNE, the Commissioner from South Carolina, yesterday completed his communication in accordance with the request of the President, and will probably present it to-day. What disposition will be made of it by Mr. BUCHANAN remains to be seen. It is rumored very strongly that he is again getting uncertain in his policy towards the Disunionists, and that in consequence of this fact there was some very plain conversation in Cabinet meeting yesterday. The latest reports from the South received in Washington are deemed of an encouraging nature.

abstract: In this Court yesterday, before Judge LEONARD, the trial of Simon Katz, indicted for arson, was proceeded with, this being the fourth day. The testimony was all closed on the previous day, and Mr. Clinton now summed up at great length to the jury. As the proof of the crime charged against the prisoner depended almost solely on the testimony of Louis Katz, to contradict whom the defence had introduced many witnesses, the counsel confined his remarks principally to a discussion of the testimony impeaching Louis, and be claimed that the statements of a crowd of witnesses should be sufficient, at least, to raise a doubt of the truth of a single boy's story, told to spite the prisoner. If such reasonable doubt were raised, the prisoner should have the benefit of it and be acquitted.

abstract: ANNIVERSARY OF FRANKLIN's BIRTHDAY. -- The members of the New-York Typographical Society celebrated, last night, at their rooms, No. 3 Chambers street, the 155th anniversary of the birthday of BENJAMIN FRANKLIN, Mr. MILLER in the Chair. The large room was completely filled, and ladies were among the audience. The proceedings were of a social and varied kind, commencing with a performance on a grand piano, after which songs, glees and other vocal entertainments, were the order of the evening. The principal feature, however, was an able address by Mr. BAKER, descriptive of his travels in Europe a year ago, especially in England, and more particularly in the British metropolis, the portion whereof which was most interesting to his auditors, being his account of the visits he paid to the various priming-offices of London. Mr. BAKER was very felicious in his remarks, and greatly applauded on resuming his seat. The evening was most pleasantly passed, and if the enthusiastic cheers which followed every Union sentiment in song and speech, are indicative of the feelings of the printers of this City, their Southern brethren may expect little sympathy and less assistance from them.

abstract: CHARGES OF TREASON TO BE INQUIRED INTO. On Wednesday last the United States Grand Jury, upon the strength of Judge SMALLEY's charge respecting the law of treason, applied to the United States District-Attorney, requesting him to issue a subpoena,...
lead_paragraph: CHARGES OF TREASON TO BE INQUIRED INTO. On Wednesday last the United States Grand Jury, upon the strength of Judge SMALLEY's charge respecting the law of treason, applied to the United States District-Attorney, requesting him to issue a subpoena, directed to JAMES E. KERRIGAN, to appear before them to answer touching his knowledge of any movements, military or otherwise, which are now on foot in this City, or elsewhere in this district, or which are in contemplation, for "giving aid and comfort" to the enemies of the Government. Judge ROOSEVELT issued the summons accordingly, and it was placed in the hands of the United States Marshal. Deputy DE ANGELIS, generally esteemed a vigilant and efficient officer, was intrusted by the Marshal with the summons, but up to a late hour yesterday the instrument had not been served. Subpoenas for other parties, who are either charged with treasonable proceedings, as defined by Judge SMALLEY, or who are supposed to be cognizant of such acts, have been issued, and it is understood that there is a settled purpose to make diligent inquiry into the whole subject, with a view to prevent the further manufacture and sale of arms and munitions to the Secessionists, as well as to put on their guard any inconsiderate persons who are in danger of incurring the terrible penalties attached to the crime of treason. The recent visit of Mr. KERRIGAN to South Carolina, with the rumored intention of lending cooperation to the Secessionists, and offering the assistance of a New-York volunteer corps, is understood to be the ground on which the Grand Jury have called him to appear before them.

abstract: Last night, in continuation of the inauguration of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, a grand ball was given, which, in every way, save one, was a success. The decorations of the building, though well designed and erected, did not harmonize with the peculiar tinting of the walls, and very greatly marred the effect of the scene. A huge canopy overspread the stage in the form of a tent, in which were all the stripes, but not one of the stars of our National flag -an omission which reflects greatly upon the patriotic foresight of the decorator. Upon the floor of the house were two floral bowers, upon the tops of which were, respectively, a lyre and a harp, while the interiors were filled with huge baskets and bouquets of the choicest hot-house flowers. NOLL's ochestral band furnished the music, which was, as it always is, good.

abstract: The Paris Moniteur says Lord COWLRY confined himself on New-Year's Day to presenting to NAPOLEON the respects and congratulations of the Diplomatic Corps, in whose name he spoke. The Emperor replied: "I thank you for the wishes which you have expressed to me. I regard the future with confidence, being convinced that the friendly understanding between the Powers will maintain peace, which is the object of my desires."

abstract: Some curiosity exists as to the forms at present adopted at the Charleston Custom-House for clearing vessels. We have been shown the clearance papers of a vessel just arrived from Charleston, which throw some light upon this subject. The blank forms supplied by the Treasury Department to the Collectors at all ports of entry are still in use at Charleston, but the words, "in the eighty-fifth year of the independence of the United States of America" are struck out with a dash of the Collector's pen, and in their place are interlined with a pen the 'words "eighty-fifth year of the sovereignty and independence of the State of South Carolina!" The clearance papers are signed by W.F. COLCOCK, Collector, and JOHN LAURENS, Naval Officer.

abstract: The offer to Gov. MORGAN, by Major-Gen. SANDFORD, of the services of the First Division of the New-York State Militia has been variously discussed. It will be seen from the correspondence between the MajorGeneral and Gov. MORGAN, the offer was made in
lead_paragraph: The offer to Gov. MORGAN, by Major-Gen. SANDFORD, of the services of the First Division of the New-York State Militia has been variously discussed. It will be seen from the correspondence between the MajorGeneral and Gov. MORGAN, the offer was made in conformity with the unanimous wish of the Division Board of officers, and that the organized, uniformed and disciplined troops of this Division, constituting sixteen regiments, include over seven thousand men, officers, non-commissioned officers and privates. The uniformed militia of this division, now enrolled, amount to upwards of 85,000 men. Of these, a large number have served their term in various regiments, and are liable to be called into service in case of insurrection and invasion. It is believed that the uniformed corps could be easily increased to 16,000 men.

abstract: Gov. CURTIN was inaugurated at Harrisburgh on Jan. 15, as the telegraph has already announced. The first portion of his inaugural address is devoted to the discussion of local topics. Then passing to the consideration of national affairs, he says that no one who knows the history of Pennsylvania, and understands the opinions and feelings of her people, can justly charge her with hostility to other States. On the other hand, she feels the deepest interest in their welfare, and recognizes her constitutional obligations to them in their broadest extent. There is nothing in Mr. LINCOLN's life or declarations to justify the apprehension that his Administration will be unfriendly to the local institutions of any of the Southern States.None but the feelings of kindness and conciliation have been entertained by the constitutional majority which elected him, and nothing whatever has occurred to justify the excitement which has blinded a part of the people and is precipitating them into revolution. After remarking on the loyalty of Pennsylvania and her sons to the Constitution and laws, Gov. CURTIN said:

abstract: The store of Messrs. Fishers & Co., importers and dealers in lace goods, No. 69 Worth-street, was visited by burglars on the night of the 17th of November last, and robbed of laces valued in the aggregate at $4,000. The thieves forced an entrance to the premises through the scuttle on the roof, but they must have become frightened while conducting their operations and left in a hurry, from the fact that next morning a large quantity of goods were found packed in bundles ready for removal. A careful examination of the store afforded no clue by which the identity of the offenders could be established, and the Detective Police who took the case in hand foresaw that much difficulty would be experienced in tracing out the perpetrators of the burglary. Sergeant Dickson, with Officers Farley and Eustace, however, undertook the task, and after two months' time spent in investigation they have succeeded in accomplishing it. The officers commenced operations by diligently inquiring of persons in the neighborhood of the store whether any suspicious characters had been loitering about the premises on the night of the robbery. Finally they received information which led them to suppose that two well known burglars, named George Smith and John Campbell were the guilty men, as their personal appearance corresponded with a description of two fellows who had been lounging about a grocery near. Messrs. Fishers & Co.'s establishment. A few days afterwards the suspected individuals were traced to a boarding-house in Sullivan-street, where Campbell had lately engaged board. Upon inquiry of the landlady, it was ascertained that her newly-arrived guest had brought with him two apparently well-filled trunks, which were pointed out to the officers. The officers felt confident, therefore, that they were on the track of the thieves, but having no authority to open; the trunks, they determined to keep quiet until morning, when, after procuring a search-warrant they would return and make an examination. In the morning, however, when the officers went back to the boarding-house they learned that Campbell had been there and taken the trunks away. For a week or two the officers could obtain no information of Campbell or of the property, but notwithstanding the fact of their having been baffled they were not discouraged. An untiring search finally resulted in tracing Campbell to Albany, whither he had taken the laces for the purpose of disposing of them. Farley then learned that a man who has often been arrested for receiving stolen goods, had followed Campbell to that place, undoubtedly with the object of becoming the purchaser; consequently he also went up to the capital to watch the turn of events. Through some mischance, however, the receiver, to whom the detective is well known, happened to learn that the latter had come up to Albany, and, suspecting the cause of his visit, the bargain was not consummated. Subsequently, the goods were sent down to Yonkers, and the Police again lost sight of them for a time. A few days ago, however, the Officers regained their clue, and having traced the trunks to a house in Yonkers where they had remained two days, it was found that thence they had been removed to a respectable boarding-house in Bleecker-street. On Wednesday the officers went to the house in question, and were fortunate enough to recover the long-sought trunks. Upon breaking them open, it was found that they contained about $2,500 worth of laces, all of which have been since identified by Messrs. Fishers & Co. as belonging to them, the burglars having neglected to remove the trade-marks. It transpired also that the property had been brought there by Smith, one of the suspected men, who was subsequently arrested. Upon searching him, samples of the goods were found in his possession, and Justice KELLY yesterday committed him, pending an examination. Campbell, the alleged confederate of Smith, was apprehended a few days since, charged with assault and battery, and having been convicted at the Court of Special Sessions, is now serving a term of imprisonment at the Tombs. He will be arrested on the charge of burglary as soon as his sentence shall have expired.
lead_paragraph: The store of Messrs. Fishers & Co., importers and dealers in lace goods, No. 69 Worth-street, was visited by burglars on the night of the 17th of November last, and robbed of laces valued in the aggregate at $4,000. The thieves forced an entrance to the premises through the scuttle on the roof, but they must have become frightened while conducting their operations and left in a hurry, from the fact that next morning a large quantity of goods were found packed in bundles ready for removal. A careful examination of the store afforded no clue by which the identity of the offenders could be established, and the Detective Police who took the case in hand foresaw that much difficulty would be experienced in tracing out the perpetrators of the burglary. Sergeant Dickson, with Officers Farley and Eustace, however, undertook the task, and after two months' time spent in investigation they have succeeded in accomplishing it. The officers commenced operations by diligently inquiring of persons in the neighborhood of the store whether any suspicious characters had been loitering about the premises on the night of the robbery. Finally they received information which led them to suppose that two well known burglars, named George Smith and John Campbell were the guilty men, as their personal appearance corresponded with a description of two fellows who had been lounging about a grocery near. Messrs. Fishers & Co.'s establishment. A few days afterwards the suspected individuals were traced to a boarding-house in Sullivan-street, where Campbell had lately engaged board. Upon inquiry of the landlady, it was ascertained that her newly-arrived guest had brought with him two apparently well-filled trunks, which were pointed out to the officers. The officers felt confident, therefore, that they were on the track of the thieves, but having no authority to open; the trunks, they determined to keep quiet until morning, when, after procuring a search-warrant they would return and make an examination. In the morning, however, when the officers went back to the boarding-house they learned that Campbell had been there and taken the trunks away. For a week or two the officers could obtain no information of Campbell or of the property, but notwithstanding the fact of their having been baffled they were not discouraged. An untiring search finally resulted in tracing Campbell to Albany, whither he had taken the laces for the purpose of disposing of them. Through some mischance, however, the receiver, to whom the detective is well known, happened to learn that the latter had come up to Albany, and, suspecting the cause of his visit, the bargain was not consummated. Subsequently, the goods were sent down to Yonkers, and the Police again lost sight of them for a time. A few days ago, however, the Officers regained their clue, and having traced the trunks to a house in Yonkers where they had remained two days, it was found that thence they had been removed to a respectable boarding-house in Bleecker-street. On Wednesday the officers went to the house in question, and were fortunate enough to recover the long-sought trunks. Upon breaking them open, it was found that they contained about $2,500 worth of laces, all of which have been since identified by Messrs. Fishers & Co. as belonging to them, the burglars having neglected to remove the trade-marks. It transpired also that the property had been brought there by Smith, one of the suspected men, who was subsequently arrested. Upon searching him, samples of the goods were found in his possession, and Justice KELLY yesterday committed him, pending an examination. Campbell, the alleged confederate of Smith, was apprehended a few days since, charged with assault and battery, and having been convicted at the Court of Special Sessions, is now serving a term of imprisonment at the Tombs. He will be arrested on the charge of burglary as soon as his sentence shall have expired.

abstract: The resolutions of the Joint Committee of Twenty-six, adopted here yesterday by the Bell and Douglas Mass Conventions, were to-night ratified with acclamation by several thousand citizens of Louisville. The principal speaker was Hon. JOSHUA F. BELL. That patriot and orator reiterated the sentiments of his speech before the Conventions, and was loudly cheered throughout.

abstract: John Schillhaus vs. John Culver. -- The plaintiff in this action is a manufacturer of lager-bier, and on the 15th of June last, had a quantity stored in his cellar at No. 196 Stanton-street Plaintiff now alleges that the defendant carelessly erected a vault which he used for the reception of offal, &c., against the wall of his cellar upon the adjoining premises; and upon the said 15th of June, through the improper construction of the vault, the water, filth. &c., came through the wall and destroyed the plaintiff's beer, besides doing other damage to the plaintiff, for which he now asks judgment for $2,200.

abstract: The Committee of Thirty-three has closed its labors. Mr. CORWIN has submitted the majority report, advising the enactment of certain measures of concession to Slavery, by means of which he thinks the Union may be preserved. Messrs. WASHBURNZ and TAPPAN, two of the minority, make a report, the object of which is to prove that all the complaints of the South are utterly groundless, and that the Union is not to be preserved by conceding unjust demands or sacrificing principle, -- but only by a conviction, on the part of all sections, that it is essential to their prosperity.

abstract: Our readers will remember that, a few weeks since, Rev. abstract: Ex-President TYLER presents his views of the crisis, in a long communication to the Richmond Whig. Assuming that the Constitution is only a compact, he claims that any State has a right to secede for cause. Were this not so, he says, "the States would occupy the same position, and none other, to the Government of the United States that each county or town occupies to the Government of a State. The uprising of a county against the State would be unqualified rebellion, and all concerned in it would be guilty of high treason. * * No matter what the evil complained of, no redress is left but out-and-out rebellion, and each and all engaged in such rebellion have entered into it with halters around their necks, to be used, unless the rebellion proves successfully the consolidated Government at its will and pleasure." The remedies which the Constitution provides for redressing wrongs are unavailable against an overwhelming sectional majority, and the Supreme Court, Mr. TYLER thinks, will have its character materially modified by Mr. LINCOLN. But the right to secede which is new resorted to after a long course of forbearance on the part of the South, should be regarded as a means of perpetuating rather than imperiling the existence of the Government, for if acknowledged it must operate to restrain the conduct of majorities and officials. Mr. TYLER then considers the consequences resulting to the seceding States from their exercise of this right. It would be better that a full adjustment of all the responsibilities to which each member of the political partnership is liable, should be made before the act of separation, but as this is not practicable, all that each State which secedes can do is to declare her readiness to assume her portion of the public debt, and her determination to have her share of the public domain and other property. The trade and commerce of each State are under its exclusive control, and revenues collected in its ports are subject to its own orders. In discussing the effect which this withdrawal of one or more States will have on the rest, Mr. TYLER is disposed to regard the Constitutional compact in the light of a mercantile partnership, and to argue that the States which do not secede are absolved from their obligations to one another, and that the best thing they can do is to set about the reconstruction of the Government. As well might North Carolina and Rhode Island have laid claim to the public property because they refused to abandon the "Perpetual Confederation" when it was merged into the present Union, as those who cling to this compact refuse to give those who repudiate it their share. A reconstructed Confederacy based on ample guarantees, Mr. TYLER asserts, would command public confidence after it was once in motion.

abstract: It is surprising that so little attention is given by the Press to the numerous evidences of a strong Union sentiment in the South. Unfortunately, those who counsel peace and moderation are not heard in revolutionary times, though they may be in a large majority; while every noisy declaration in favor of rebellion is heralded over the country on the wings of lightning. The conservative Press of North Carolina is filled from week to week with resolutions of Union meetings of the people, in which it is declared that no cause exists for a dissolution of the Union. But news of this kind fails to awaken a sensation, and is for that reason rarely dignified by the notice of those having charge of the telegraph wires in the Southern States; and even those further North seem to give the preference to the machinations of traitors over the protests of honest and patriotic citizens.
lead_paragraph: It is surprising that so little attention is given by the Press to the numerous evidences of a strong Union sentiment in the South. Unfortunately, those who counsel peace and moderation are not heard in revolutionary times, though they may be in a large majority; while every noisy declaration in favor of rebellion is heralded over the country on the wings of lightning. The conservative Press of North Carolina is filled from week to week with resolutions of Union meetings of the people, in which it is declared that no cause exists for a dissolution of the Union. abstract: government, because without the enforcement of the laws the Union could not continue. But that reme dy did not meet the existing state of things. They could not, under any provision of the Constitution, enforce the law against a seceding State. The law was applicable to individuals, and to enforce the law against the individual you must have judges and juries, and you must proceed against him, according to the Constitution, in the State where the crime was committed. It was clear, therefore, that they could not enforce the law against an individual in South Carolina, for no jury would bring in a verdict of guilty upon any indictment found at this juncture and under present circumstancesstances. It was true there was a general domain for the enforcement of the laws, but however true as an abstraction, however necessary at all tunes and imperative it might be on the Government to enforce them, it was impracticable and impossible, as welll as wholly unsuited to the occasion. The question then was, what was the duty of the Admnistration and of Congress? It was one of pacification and reconstruction; a duty which must undeubtedly to committed to the next Administration, and the country must therefore await an appeal to the people. But what, in the meantime, is to be done? As yet no practical remedy had been devised, and State after State was going out of the Union. All the votes taken in the different crisis committees tended to strengthen the indication that a remedy from these sources is cut of the question. The dominant party have shown an indisposition to make those concessions indispensable to a reunion. Their bounden duty, then, was to preserve the status quo, and to preserve the existing state of things as nearly as possible -- to avoid the employment of coercion. But to do this it was essentially necessary to their policy that a like purpose and spirit should animate their Southern friends It would not do for the South to protest against coercion, while at the same time they seized the arms, arsenals, fortresses, navy-yards and ships that come within their reach and power. To act thus was not and could never be peaceable secession-that would not be preserving the status quo. It was a declaration of war; and when sovereign States make war they could not cry peace, nor call for protection against coercion. The constitutional compact was a compact between equal sovereign States, and when, therefore, a sovereign State did an act, whether by law or treaty, or by grant on parchment, ceding unalterably apiece of territory, large or small, whether for the purpose of erecting on it a fortress, or fort, or Custom-house, or city, or town, that State could not recall that cession nor unmake the grant. That was cut of the question. Such a proposition was monstrous in law, in morals and politics, and was utterly untenable and indefensible. He hoped the South, therefore, would not force an issue of war in defence of this incontrovertible right, and in discharge of the imperative and paramount duty of occupying and keeping those fortified places provided for the common defence of the country. It was on this point alone the whole danger of collision was to be dreaded-on this only civil war can happen, and on this position the first battle may be fought. It cannot be said by the South that the seizure of the forts had been made for the purpose of protection. Remember, the course of events in South Carolina in her Convention, convened for the purpose of taking steps to secede, met with no interference from any quarter -- no interference from the Executive or from Congress. That Convention was held -- the ordinance of secession was passed, and they met with no interference with the act -- none whatever. No army or naval forces were sent for the purpose of coercion. But what had the Legislature of South Carolina done? They organized an army, and yet there was no interference with that hostile act from any quarter. The act of secession, from its inception to its consummation, was rendered as complete and perfect as human agency could make it, and not the slightest interference was asserted or attempted by the Executive or legislative departments. Through all these acts there was no show of coercion. The transfer of sixty men from one fort to another, however, simple as it was, gave rise to unfounded apprehensions, not only in one Stale, but throughout that whole section of the country. The mere transfer of a handful of men, not under instruction to menace or attack anybody, was assumed to be a warlike measure on the part of the Federal Government What next? An unarmed vessel approaches the harbor of Charleston, bearing dispatches and provisions and men to a place within the unquestionable jurisdiction of the Federal Government of the United States. From its masthead is displayed the American flag, and as she approaches and is within sight of a fortification of the General Government -- the o fficial character of the vessel being well known -- the authorities of South Carolina opened a fire from their guns upon her, defenceless as she was, and compelled her to return and abandon the legitimate and peaceful character of her mission. That was an act of war, of unqualified and flagrant war; and had such an act been done by another Government or authority, by any foreign Power whatever, it would have aroused theire of every man in the nation; and have elicited from every patriot heart a loud and earnest protest, and a demand for an immediate appeal to all the measures necessary to repel the insult and avenge the outrage. It was an act of war. But, eternal thanks to the moderation and noble magnanimity of gallant Major ANDERSON it was not so regarded by him. He remembered it was an act done by his fellow countrymen, by men excited and milled by the apprehension of force to be employed against themselves, and aroused to blind zeal by their own anomalous political condition. In retaliation of that net of war, Major ANDERSON might have laid Charleston in ashes, and civilization and history would have approved the act. He emphatically announced his conviction that no man, looking at the responsibility of Major ANDERSON, could honestly lay his hand upon his heart and condemn him for such a vindication of the honor and the lights of a flag which his sword and his life were pledged to maintain. But this was not done, and he thanked heaven for it. If is had been done is would have been impossible to reconstruct the Confederacy, which now seemed the only peaceful escape from their difficulties. In view of mere coercion, he would repeat that they could not recruit a regiment in New-York to march over the frontier to any State for the purpose of coercion against a people in the exercise of their legitimate and holy rights. Never -- never! But the men of New-York would march in untold thousands anywhere to protect the honored flag of the Union, and to defend and maintain its glory and renown in any event, or in any emergency where it was necessary to do so. He would call attention once more to the great and grave distinction between an issue where force is employed against a sovereign State to compel its abandonment of any political act within her legitimate jurisdiction, and an appeal to arms in defence of the indisputable right and jurisdiction of the United States, when that jurisdiction had been ceded by the act of the seceding State. Reference had yesterday been made (by Mr. GARNETT) to the probability of a hostile visit from the armies and navies of France and England for the purpose of interfering with our jurisdiction. This very probability showed it would be worse than madness to surrender the fortified places, which alone could enable them to assert and maintain that jurisdiction. Whatever might be the views of gentlemen as to a peaceable secession, however they might meet the exigencies of the times, they had yet their political position to maintain as a great commercial nation. The elements of that commercial greatness was in the North and West, and not in the South. They had absolute duties to perform for self-defence, and these ports and fortified places are indispensable to the protection of their position as a commercial and maritime nation, and as a means of self-defence against those very eventualities which accession roust necessarily bring with them. The possession of these fortified places became more important with secession an accomplished fact than when secession was never dreamed of. There was no possibility of foreign intervention without secession; with secession it was almost inevitable. On all these considerations it was their absolute duty to hold those places; nay more, it was madness on the part of those who sincerely deprecated war to seize and to attempt to hold them. Their statute books were full of precedents to justify their regaining possession of them. In 1811-12 Congress, by a large majority, into which Southern men entered, determined to take possession of the country west of the Mississippi and of Florida, and of the Territories adjoining, because their possession was essential to our political safety and to our territorial protection; and therefore all the statesmen of the South were committed to the recognition of the right of the Government to hold those fortified places, at all risks and under all circumstances. The history of this, as well as of all great countries, was full of precedents for this course of action, whatever may be the issue of events-whether happily by conciliation and justice to the South we may and an honorable and fraternal solution of our difficulties, or whether unhappily we blindly drift into alienation, war and irrevocable separation--the great commercial interests of this country require, the destiny of American civilization demands that the political and territorial control of this continent, from the mouth of the Hudson to the mouth of the Mississippi, from the Atlantic to the Pacific seas, shall remain where it now exists -- in the hands of the Government of the United States. In all the partisan issues between the South and the Republican Party the people of the City of New-York are with the South, but when the South makes an untenable issue with our country, when the flag of the Union is insulted, when the fortified places provided for the common defence are assaulted and seized, when the South abandons its Northern allies for English and French cooperation, then the loyal and patriotic population of that imperial City are a unit for the Union.
lead_paragraph: government, because without the enforcement of the laws the Union could not continue. But that reme dy did not meet the existing state of things. They could not, under any provision of the Constitution, enforce the law against a seceding State. The law was applicable to individuals, and to enforce the law against the individual you must have judges and juries, and you must proceed against him, according to the Constitution, in the State where the crime was committed. It was clear, therefore, that they could not enforce the law against an individual in South Carolina, for no jury would bring in a verdict of guilty upon any indictment found at this juncture and under present circumstancesstances. It was true there was a general domain for the enforcement of the laws, but however true as an abstraction, however necessary at all tunes and imperative it might be on the Government to enforce them, it was impracticable and impossible, as welll as wholly unsuited to the occasion. The question then was, what was the duty of the Admnistration and of Congress? It was one of pacification and reconstruction; a duty which must undeubtedly to committed to the next Administration, and the country must therefore await an appeal to the people. But what, in the meantime, is to be done? As yet no practical remedy had been devised, and State after State was going out of the Union. All the votes taken in the different crisis committees tended to strengthen the indication that a remedy from these sources is cut of the question. The dominant party have shown an indisposition to make those concessions indispensable to a reunion. Their bounden duty, then, was to preserve the status quo, and to preserve the existing state of things as nearly as possible -- to avoid the employment of coercion. But to do this it was essentially necessary to their policy that a like purpose and spirit should animate their Southern friends It would not do for the South to protest against coercion, while at the same time they seized the arms, arsenals, fortresses, navy-yards and ships that come within their reach and power. To act thus was not and could never be peaceable secession-that would not be preserving the status quo. It was a declaration of war; and when sovereign States make war they could not cry peace, nor call for protection against coercion. The constitutional compact was a compact between equal sovereign States, and when, therefore, a sovereign State did an act, whether by law or treaty, or by grant on parchment, ceding unalterably apiece of territory, large or small, whether for the purpose of erecting on it a fortress, or fort, or Custom-house, or city, or town, that State could not recall that cession nor unmake the grant. That was cut of the question. Such a proposition was monstrous in law, in morals and politics, and was utterly untenable and indefensible. He hoped the South, therefore, would not force an issue of war in defence of this incontrovertible right, and in discharge of the imperative and paramount duty of occupying and keeping those fortified places provided for the common defence of the country. It was on this point alone the whole danger of collision was to be dreaded-on this only civil war can happen, and on this position the first battle may be fought. It cannot be said by the South that the seizure of the forts had been made for the purpose of protection. Remember, the course of events in South Carolina in her Convention, convened for the purpose of taking steps to secede, met with no interference from any quarter -- no interference from the Executive or from Congress. That Convention was held -- the ordinance of secession was passed, and they met with no interference with the act -- none whatever. No army or naval forces were sent for the purpose of coercion. But what had the Legislature of South Carolina done? They organized an army, and yet there was no interference with that hostile act from any quarter. The act of secession, from its inception to its consummation, was rendered as complete and perfect as human agency could make it, and not the slightest interference was asserted or attempted by the Executive or legislative departments. Through all these acts there was no show of coercion. The transfer of sixty men from one fort to another, however, simple as it was, gave rise to unfounded apprehensions, not only in one Stale, but throughout that whole section of the country. The mere transfer of a handful of men, not under instruction to menace or attack anybody, was assumed to be a warlike measure on the part of the Federal Government What next? An unarmed vessel approaches the harbor of Charleston, bearing dispatches and provisions and men to a place within the unquestionable jurisdiction of the Federal Government of the United States. From its masthead is displayed the American flag, and as she approaches and is within sight of a fortification of the General Government -- the o fficial character of the vessel being well known -- the authorities of South Carolina opened a fire from their guns upon her, defenceless as she was, and compelled her to return and abandon the legitimate and peaceful character of her mission. He remembered it was an act done by his fellow countrymen, by men excited and milled by the apprehension of force to be employed against themselves, and aroused to blind zeal by their own anomalous political condition. He emphatically announced his conviction that no man, looking at the responsibility of Major ANDERSON, could honestly lay his hand upon his heart and condemn him for such a vindication of the honor and the lights of a flag which his sword and his life were pledged to maintain. But this was not done, and he thanked heaven for it. If is had been done is would have been impossible to reconstruct the Confederacy, which now seemed the only peaceful escape from their difficulties. In view of mere coercion, he would repeat that they could not recruit a regiment in New-York to march over the frontier to any State for the purpose of coercion against a people in the exercise of their legitimate and holy rights. Never -- never! He would call attention once more to the great and grave distinction between an issue where force is employed against a sovereign State to compel its abandonment of any political act within her legitimate jurisdiction, and an appeal to arms in defence of the indisputable right and jurisdiction of the United States, when that jurisdiction had been ceded by the act of the seceding State. abstract: There was a sound of revelry last night, and the Metropolis had gathered there its children, and the chandeliers shone bright o'er dawning women and incipient men. A gentleman of some literary repute a few years since opened a description of a ball with lines somewhat similar to the above, but the appreciative observer will mark the added beauties which present themselves in the present version. The occasion of the revelry was a soiree dansante given by Prof. FEBRERO, and the scene was in the Academy of Music. The Academy was not built for a ball-room, but it answers a very good purpose, and loses less money when put to this use than in the legitimate operatic line. The soiree dansante of last evening was a Prince's ball in miniature. The inevitable Policemen were in attendance; the carriages relied to the doors, debarked their fairy freight and departed; gossamer visions flitted past the guests whose tickets only entitled them to stand on the steps, and buried themselves from sight in the vestibules. The attendance was not quite so large as at the Prince's Ball, but this may be attributed to the unpleasantness of the walking, the lower price of the tickets, and the fact that plenty could be obtained. Two other points of dissimilarity were visible: the floor was not so contrived as to break down in the middle of the first dance, and the Master of Ceremonies was different. In other respects the affairs were much the same, if we except the age of the ladies attending. It was a pleasure last evening to see the inchoate-powers of society go through the languid luxury of the Lancers, and the whirling witcheies of the waltz. To see the youthful Adolphus lead the budding Caroline through the mazes of a difficult dance with as much a plomb as though a state of easy unrest were his normal condition. But greater still was the pleasure of marking the countenances of the parents of the Adolphs and Carolines. Those whose dancing days were haply long time past, sat in a state of swaying satisfaction, and, watching the tripping feet of their children, danced all their dances o'er again. From the hour of 5 to 9, the children held high carnival; after that hour they kindly surrendered the floor to Adolphs and Carolines of more mature age. The last aspirants for Terpsichorean honors came in greater numbers and more elaborate costume, but the fist had the best of the dance, so far as apparent enjoyment was concerned. When hearts and feet are both light and bound together in unison, as is mostly the case in childhood, we have a fair illustration of what is meant by the poetry of motion. Hearts wax heavy and joints become stiff as years grow; adults dance from duty, while children dance because they cannot help it. And so we give the palm of last evening to FEBRERO's younger pupils. It is out fair to say that the band throughout the performance discoursed most excellent music.
