abstract: The Springfield Republican narrates the experience of Mr. JOHN D. MCKNIGHT, who has just returned from Georgia, where he attempted to collect bills for the clothing-house which he represented. He describes the excitement as intense throughout the State, and had numerous narrow escapes from falling a victim to the suspicions of the Fire-Eaters. He came to this city by the steamer State of Georgia, on its last trip from Savannah. Among his fellow-passengers was a Nova Scotian, resident for years in Savannah, who was only a few evenings before waited upon by the "Owls," one of his own employes heading the ruffianly gang. He saved his life by showing pluck and loaded weapons, but he seized the earliest moment to escape. Another was a Northern man, officer in the Savannah Blues, and it would have been his turn next day to go to Fort Pulaski; he fled without settling up his affairs, and, like the first-named, was glad to get off thus well. The passengers now began to relate the horrors they had seen in their several localities. One had seen three unoffending Northern men shot down like dogs; and all agreed that the half had not been told of the frenzy and madness of the Southern people. Mr. MCKNIGHT says he would not go through another such week of terror and espionage for five thousand dollars!

abstract: That intelligent and instructive body who, for the past five days have been holding secret meetings at the Capitol, this afternoon came forth and stated that we were no longer members of the great Confederacy of America, but a distinct and independent Sovereignty; that Alabama, the rich and river-traced, now belongs, and is accountable only to herself.
lead_paragraph: MONTGOMERY, Friday, Jan. 11, 1861.

abstract: The Grand Jury yesterday morning brought in an indictment against Nathaniel Courier and seventeen others, being the crew of the brig Bonita, for being voluntarily engaged on board the brig while engaged in the Slave-trade. Also, an indictment against Gordon Lafitte for manufacturing counterfeit coin.
lead_paragraph: The Grand Jury yesterday morning brought in an indictment against Nathaniel Courier and seventeen others, being the crew of the brig Bonita, for being voluntarily engaged on board the brig while engaged in the Slave-trade. Also, an indictment against Gordon Lafitte for manufacturing counterfeit coin.

abstract: The steamer Marion, Capt. ADKINS, vice Capt. SAM. WEITING, arrived at this port yesterday morning, from Charleston, S.C., with some 350 tierces of Rice and a quantity of Cotton. The Marion came out of Charleston Harbor through Maffit's or Sullivan's Island Channel, the approach to the main ship channel having been obstructed by the sinking of three or four vessels on the bar, to prevent the entrance of vessels.
lead_paragraph: The steamer Marion, Capt. ADKINS, vice Capt. SAM. WEITING, arrived at this port yesterday morning, from Charleston, S.C., with some 350 tierces of Rice and a quantity of Cotton. abstract: The "Allocution of Pope PIUS IX.," delivered recently to a conclave of his Cardinals, is a very curious and instructive document. Poor old Pope, he sees the world all tumbling into chaos about his head! "Cruel events" fill the heart of him, and of his "venerable brothers," with anguish.
lead_paragraph: The "Allocution of Pope PIUS IX.," delivered recently to a conclave of his Cardinals, is a very curious and instructive document. Poor old Pope, he sees the world all tumbling into chaos about his head! "Cruel events" fill the heart of him, and of his "venerable brothers," with anguish. It is no longer, he is fain to confess, a question of the temporal sovereignty of the Priest-Prince of Rome; he feels that his spiritual dominion is fast vanishing into thin air.

abstract: Mr. HOLT was yesterday confirmed as Secretary of War by the Senate, by a vote of 38 to 13, after a stormy secret session of about four hours. During its continuance Mr. CRITTENDEN unexpectedly made a speech, in which he severely upbraided the Southern members who voted against his resolutions on Thursday, and thus defeated them. He declared that Kentucky occupied such a position in the Union that it was of vital importance to her that it is should be preserved, and that it must be preserved at all hazards. The speech is represented to have made a decided sensation among the Secessionists. Col. HAYNE, notwithstanding announcements to the contrary, has not yet sent in his communication to the President, and does not intend doing so before Monday. It is asserted that the tone of the document is likely to be quite moderate. Possibly a still longer delay might result in a further access of moderation.

abstract: Elizabetha Dietz vs. Frederick Dietz. This action was brought to obtain a divorce a mensa et thorn on the ground of alleged inhuman treatment. The parties were married at Hoboken on the 12th of July, 1860. The defendant is a lithographer and at the time specified in the pleadings was in the employ of Conrad Fatzer, of this City.
lead_paragraph: Elizabetha Dietz vs. Frederick Dietz. -- This action was brought to obtain a divorce a mensa et thorn on the ground of alleged inhuman treatment. The parties were married at Hoboken on the 12th of July, 1860. The defendant is a lithographer and at the time specified in the pleadings was in the employ of Conrad Fatzer, of this City. The cause of their difficulty appears to be a yellow dog, the property of the defendant. The plaintiff testifies that she and her husband went out for a walk on the 12th of August, 1860, and on returning home found the dog on the bed. The plaintiff then told him that the housekeeper had said they must not keep a dog as it would be apt to frighten the children in the house. The defendant, as alleged, thereupon struck his wife twice on the nose and once on the cheek, which caused her to fall insensible on the floor. On the 20th of August, 1860, while they were alone together, he told her he would sirike her so that she could send him to the Tombs. Attempting to put his threat into execution, she opened the door of the room in which they were, when he dropped the stick of wood with which he had attempted to strike her. These two acts are alleged as the cause of action. The plaintiff having closed his testimony, the Court remarked that a general impression seemed to prevail that an action of this kind could be supported by but one or two acts of cruel treatment. It was but justice to the public generally to inform them that it could not. That the uniform character of decisions, both in England and in this country, have held that such an action must be sustained by repeated and continuous acts of cruelty. That the wife should not seek on slight provocation to dissolve that sacred tie which binds her to her husband for life, for better or worse. The Judge then remarked that the present case presenting no feature which would warrant him in granting a separation between the parties, the complaint was dismissed.

abstract: WEDNESDAY EVENING. It was announced today, by electric telegraph, that the Bank of France, overcoming their long hesitation in face of the strong action taken by the Bank of England, have raised their rate of discount from 4 to 5 per cent. This measure may, perhaps, trouble French trade, but it is the only one possible under the circumstances.
lead_paragraph: From the London Daily News, Jan. 3.

abstract: As we are now called on to face the alternative of secession, it becomes important to inquire as to the dangers to which it may expose the trade of the Gulf of Mexico. The preconcerted movement of the States border... will never expose itself to a lawless mob or to the danger of being seized by a needy State.
lead_paragraph: As we are now called on to face the alternative of secession, it becomes important to inquire as to the dangers to which it may expose the trade of the Gulf of Mexico. The preconcerted movement of the States bordering it, undoubtedly connived at by the retiring Secretaries, shows the importance they attach to the command of that great basin, both as a means of protection and defence, and to enable them to carry on with impunity one great object of secession -- the Slave-trade.

abstract: On the evening of Jan. 15, a large audience assembled in St. Lawrence Hall, Toronto, C.W., to hear an address by Hon. GERRITT SMITH, on the case of ANDERSON, the fugitive slave, whose surrender has been demanded by the United States Government.
lead_paragraph: On the evening of Jan. 15, a large audience assembled in St. Lawrence Hall, Toronto, C.W., to hear an address by Hon. GERRITT SMITH, on the case of ANDERSON, the fugitive slave, whose surrender has been demanded by the United States Government. Mr. SMITH was received with the heartiest applause. He had made two trips to Toronto within the last three weeks he said, to share his sympathies with his poor brother, the prisoner ANDERSON, who is in danger of being burned at the stake. If they asked why he, a foreigner, should meddle with their affairs, he would reply that he felt a personal concern in the disposition which should be made of ANDERSON.

abstract: Reports from Pensacola, received through dispatches from New-Orleans, indicate that the Governor of Florida has determined to risk a collision with the Federal forces at Fort Pickens, unless that fortification shall be speedily surrendered to the State authorities. He has already assembled a force of two thousand men in the vicinity, and Major CHASE, Commander of the State troops, has telegraphed to the Mayor of New-Orleans for two thousand additional men, the avowed purpose being an attack upon the fort. Troops are also constantly arriving from Mississippi and other points. The Pensacola pilots have been notified not to pilot United States vessels into the harbor on pain of death, and the steamer Wyandotte is reported as lying at the entrance of the harbor, with the families of the United States officers on board, out of coal and supplies, -- she not being permitted to enter. The Florida forces had twenty-five heavy guns mounted at the Navy-yard, and it was believed that Fort Pickens could be taken with a loss of not more than three hundred men. The latest account, however, expresses some doubt as to there being any fighting, the prevalent belief being that the officer in command of the fort would surrender. It is of course impossible to surmise how well this belief may be founded. Our dispatches from Washington assert that efforts are being made there to prevent the catastrophe of a collision, though great apprehensions are entertained that it will occur.

abstract: Sarah M. Sanford vs. The Mayor, The plaintiff is the owner of certain lots in Seventyseventh-street in this City, upon which, in 1858, she was assessed for regulating that street, in the sum of $2,641,52, with some interest. She handed the matter over to her husband, as her agent, who, supposing the assessment could be collected, paid it, taking a receipt therefor on behalf of his wife, the owner. ...
lead_paragraph: Sarah M. Sanford vs. The Mayor, The plaintiff is the owner of certain lots in Seventyseventh-street in this City, upon which, in 1858, she was assessed for regulating that street, in the sum of $2,641,52, with some interest. She handed the matter over to her husband, as her agent, who, supposing the assessment could be collected, paid it, taking a receipt therefor on behalf of his wife, the owner. At that time it was supposed that the proceedings in the regulation of the street were perfectly regular and valid; but subsequently, as alleged, the plaintiff ascertained that the assessment was illegally and fraudulently managed, in that, first, the contract for doing the work was not awarded to the lowest bidder; and, secondly, in that the agreement was altered after the bid was accepted, in such a manner as to give the contractor, for the work done, $46,149 13, instead of $26,406, the amount of his bid, as appeared by the assessment roll and other papers. The plaintiff alleges that certain papers and records of the matter have been abstracted from the Street Department, and for the purpose of concealing fraud.

lead_paragraph: The second concert of the fourth season of this popular and most successful society was given on Saturday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The building was literally jammed, not a seat being left without an occupant. "No reserved seats" was the rule, and in consequence a large crowd gathered at the doors by 7 o'clock, at which hour they were opened, and the people rushed in. The private boxes were not thrown open to the public until about 3/4 o'clock, when a most amusing scramble for places ensued, and apparently the best of feeling did not prevail, particularly amongst those who couldn't crowd in and those who did get in, only to find their dresses torn and their toilettes much disarranged. A complacent boy, half a dozen school girls, and a couple of young dry-goods clerks occupied one box, and the others, with the exception of one reserved for the Directors, were filled with probably the most singular appearing people ever seen in any similar position.

abstract: The annual report of the City Inspector for 1860, prepared for the Common Council, is a very lengthy document, and contains much that is of importance to the public. The returns show that during the year there were 4,241 marriages, 12,454 births, and 22,710 deaths. With the exception of an epidemic which prevailed during the Summer months, in the form of scarlet fever, the City has been unusually healthy.
lead_paragraph: The annual report of the City Inspector for 1860, prepared for the Common Council, is a very lengthy document, and contains much that is of importance to the public. The returns show that during the year there were 4,241 marriages, 12,454 births, and 22,710 deaths. With the exception of an epidemic which prevailed during the Summer months, in the form of scarlet fever, the City has been unusually healthy. The number of emigrants arrived during the year was 104,900; the per centage of those remaining in the City after their arrival could not be accurately ascertained, but it is estimated at fifty per cent. In aiming at the average rate of the mortality of the City, the means for a correct estimate were placed within reach, through the census recently completed. These returns show a population of 814,254. The mortality of the past year having been 22,710, shows an apparent increase in the mortality over 1859 of 1,005; but when the increase of the population for that period is taken into account, we have an actual decrease in our death list. The data for comparing the mortality of this City with London, Paris, and other European cities, is very imperfect; but so far as could be estimated, the difference between this City and London and Paris, is not great; and as compared with most of the large cities of Europe, shows a decided superiority. In making comparative tables, there is an important element which operates to the disadvantage of New-York, from which both of the cities named are in a measure exempt; and that is, the large emigration which yearly visits us, and is composed in the main of the poverty and wretchedness of Europe, among which the mortality is very great. The average rate of the mortality of this City between the native born and foreign population is, the City Inspector says, best illustrated by the following statistics, taken from the registration records of his office:

abstract: In this Court, on Saturday, before City Judge McCUNN, Simon Kinney, who had previously pleaded guilty to a low degree of forgery, in passing a counterfeit bill, was called up for sentence. The prisoner, like Cincinnatus, had formerly followed the plow, and subsequently "gone down to the sea in ships, and done business on the great deep." The Court determined that the prisoner should be relieved for a short time from the toils of his earlier and the perils of his later avocation, and committed him to the cherishing care of the Penitentiary Warden for the next nine months.

abstract: The Academy of Music will open to-night for an experimental season of opera, under the auspices of the Italian artists. MERCADANTE's famous work, "Il Giuramento," will be produced, with COLSON, ADELAIDE PHILLIPS, BRIGNOLI and FERRI, in the caste. The music of this opera is as fluently graceful and pleasing as any that belongs to the modern Italian school, and we shall be greatly mistaken if it does not achieve a success. Although this is scarcely the right season to enter upon an expensive and hazardous undertaking, it is, we believe, a fair one for musical purposes. In the way of opera we have never been poorer than now. For many months our energies have been wasted on the experiment of giving Italian music without Italian artists, and it has failed. Latterly, we have even been without this ordinary resource. Our theatres are crowded; there seems to be no scantiness of money for the purposes of amusement, and several successful concerts during the past week have demonstrated the fact that our public wants music. Under these circumstances we are disposed to anticipate a good season for the associated artists, especially as it is apparent that it will be conducted with energy. We trust for the sake of our most elegant and refined amusement that the public will lend its aid to the undertaking. A great deal depends on the success of the experiment; it will determine probably whether or not we are to have a vigorous Spring campaign. At any rate, with new operas, good singers, fine orchestra and an able conductor like Signor Muzio we ought to be moderately content. There will be a brilliant house to-night.

abstract: Artists in this City cannot complain of the times. Of all luxuries they are most indulged in at present. Within the past month there have been several sales of collections of paintings, at which the prices obtained, were absolutely refreshing. Private studios are extensively patronized, and public galleries are paying well. Fifteen years since, it was considered an evidence of artistic appreciation if a family preserved the parental portraits, a few colored engravings and, possibly, one or two dingy oil-paintings, besides the crotcheted sampler and the black paper profiles of Revolutionary grandsire and his matronly help-mate. Now there are few families of even moderate wealth who do not own one or more master-pieces, foreign or native; landscapes of familiar scenes; portraitures, varying vastly in tone, color and quality, from those now sent to the garret, and engravings, photographs and pencillings by the portfolio. New-York, Philadelphia and Boston are the prominent patrons of the fine arts -- New-York, of course, vastly in the van.

abstract: When DE QUINCY put in a plea in favor of Judas Iscariot, he simply pushed to an ultra application a tendency of historical Criticism which has become very marked during the present age. Bizarre in its extreme illustrations, the disposition to submit the old verdicts passed on characters and lives to reconsideration under the light of a new dispensation, nevertheless justifies itself as a very genuine and generous prompting. In a certain
lead_paragraph: When DE QUINCY put in a plea in favor of Judas Iscariot, he simply pushed to an ultra application a tendency of historical Criticism which has become very marked during the present age. Bizarre in its extreme illustrations, the disposition to submit the old verdicts passed on characters and lives to reconsideration under the light of a new dispensation, nevertheless justifies itself as a very genuine and generous prompting. In a certain mood of the mind, indeed, a judgment whereto an age has set its seal assumes somewhat of the character of Fate; and it is wise not to deal lightly with these secular verdicts. But it remains to add that we also have our right of sentence. For many things are not to be judged of except at a certain perspective, and for characters this is sometimes very long. Amplitude of time -- that sets everything right. And it is certainly very sublime that each age is, as it were, a Court of Appeal, where the solemn process of rehearing, confirming, reversing, ever goes on -- Justice, in the long run, surely bringing round its revenges.

abstract: There is not a week passes that we do not chronicle more or less deaths in this City by poisoning. Now it is a suicide "laboring under temporary insanity," or something else, who poisons himself -- now we hear of poison "given by mistake," or otherwise -- now dispensed "by the carelessness of the druggist" -- and again administered with murderous intent. There is thus not far short of a hundred deaths in this City, from poison alone, inscribed in the Coroner's books for the last year; and six or eight have already occurred in the few passing days of the present year. Does it ever occur to anybody that there is a joint responsibility for a large number of these murders, and that sometimes a considerable share of it may rest, in the eye of heaven if not of the law, on the heads of those who, with such fatal facility, furnish the means of destruction to any man, woman or maniac who may have the pence necessary to pay for it? Probably the idea is not new to the public; at all events, it has been emphasized sufficiently in the TIMES to have started some such train of thought, even if the almost daily record of facts did not suggest it.

abstract: The speech recently delivered by Ex-Governor JOHN B. FLOYD, at Richmond, Va., is of a character which should not be allowed to pass unscourged into oblivion. It may be regarded as the monumental speech of the treasonable movement for the disruption of the Union. It was spoken by the right man, to the right audience, in perhaps the right place; and to all the revelations of perjury and treachery therein made, those who remain faithful to the Union, the Constitution and the enforcement of the laws, are entitled, as to so many indisputable proofs against the traitorous advisers who recently had seats in the Cabinet.

abstract: COLUMBIA COLLEGE. -- A reunion of the Alumni and Undergraduate members of the Philolexian Society was held in their rooms on Friday evening, the 18th inst. Notwithstanding the inclemency of the weather the hall was crowded to its utmost capacity. After an introductiory address by the President, ABRAHAM SUYDAM, A.B., an oration, in behalf of the Alumni, was read by HERBERT B. TURNER, A.M. Mr. EDWARD MITCHELL followed with an oration in which he spoke upon the past and present state of the Society and its future prospects. A poem was next delivered by Mr. WM. A. RICE, and elicited rounds of applause. The prizes which had been offered for the greatest excellence in elocution and composition were then competed for. Speeches were made by Messrs. C.B. Mitchell, Spencer, Atwill, Hegeman, Turner, Adams and Rice, and a goodly number of essays were submitted to the judges. Mr. J.H. SIDDONS, Professor of Elocution in the College, read some extracts from English authors, after which speeches of encouragement and advice to the members were made by President KING, Prof. NAIRNE, Judge MITCHELL and others, who spoke of the usefulness of the Society, and the advantage which the students had derived from it during the sixty years for which it had been connected with the College. The meeting was protracted until a late hour, when all retired well pleased with the exercises of the evening.

abstract: Within a week past, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, two culprits have been convicted of the crime of arson, and sentenced to State Prison for life. While the successful issue of the public prosecutor's efforts to bring these criminals, of a most dangerous class, to justice, will increase the public feeling of security, by furnishing dreadful warning to those whose interests or inclination might tempt them to commit the offence, it illustrates, at the same time, the benefits which result to public justice from applying the "division of labor" principle to the duties which public officers have to discharge. To such an extent does the self-governing spirit of the English Common law prevail with us, that the prosecution of criminal offenders against the peace and safety of the public, is left to a great extent, if not entirely, in the hands of private individuals, who may volunteer or not, as they choose, to bring an offender to justice. The District Attorney is only bound to prosecute such cases as are officially brought before him, either by a Magistrate or the Grand Inquest of the county, -- neather of whom have authority to go beyond such matters as private individuals may volunteer to bring before them. The punishment of criminals, therefore, like the election of upright rulers, and the enactment of sound laws, depends in a great degree on the honest disposition of the community at large.

abstract: There are few leaders of the newspaper literature of the day who are not familiar with the name of that eccentric, brilliant', impulsive woman, known as LOLA MONTEZ. AS a danseuse, an actress, a politician, a courtezan, a lecturer, a devotee, she has occupied a large space of the public attention for many years, both in this country and in Europe. Her career, so strangely erratic, so wonderfully checquered, came to its end on Thursday last. After a lengthened period of suffering, during which the knowledge of her approaching end quickened her to renewed preparations to meet it, she breathed her last tranquilly, the victim of a paralytic complaint which defied the medical skill of New-York. Her funeral took place on Saturday, and was attended with no other demonstration than that of affectionate lamentation for one who was known to be kindly in her actions to others, and who, in the latter days of her life, succeeded in winning the esteem and regard of a wide circle of friends.

abstract: The Secession movement is passing into its second stage. The first flush of feverish excitement is passing off. Even South Carolina no longer considers herself equal to maintaining a separate existence and begins to lean on a future Confederacy of Slave States. Virginia, Tennessee, Kentucky and Georgia are looking in the same direction. Separate State secession is beginning to be regarded as only a preliminary step. The one thing absolutely needful to success in destroying the present Union is the formation of a new one. Until that is done disunion is incomplete. RECONSTRUCTION is the indispensable task, which the Southern seceding States have immediately before them.

abstract: On Saturday last orders were issued to the members of a number of military companies in this City and in Brooklyn, to hold themselves in readiness to repair to their several armories, prepared for service, on hearing the alarm signal from the City Hall bells. The orders state that no immediate call for active service is anticipated, and that it is to be understood as merely precautionary. It is believed that the orders were
lead_paragraph: On Saturday last orders were issued to the members of a number of military companies in this City and in Brooklyn, to hold themselves in readiness to repair to their several armories, prepared for service, on hearing the alarm signal from the City Hall bells. The orders state that no immediate call for active service is anticipated, and that it is to be understood as merely precautionary. It is believed that the orders were issued in consequence of the reports of the secret organization here of military companies composed of men who sympathise with the Secessionists at the South, and who might be inclined to disturb lawful meetings of citizens in this City and in Brooklyn.

abstract: A great deal of excitement was occasioned in the Twentieth Ward, on Saturday forenoon, by the rumor that a woman had been brutally murdered at a shoemaker's shop in the basement of 171 West Twenty-ninth-street. Officer IRVING was dispatched to investigatethe circumstances of the case, and he found the deceased -- an Irishwoman named MARY ANN LOVE - lying upon the floor, with marks of violence upon her face, and her fingers were mutilated as though they had been gnawed by rats. Two men, named SAMUEL LOVE, brother of the deceased, and PETER BRADLEY, one of his friends, were found in a drunken sleep in the room where the body lay, and suspicion at once pointed to them as being the murderers. Coroner JACKMAN was notified of the matter, and in the afternoon he held an inquest upon the body, conducting the proceedings at the Twentieth Ward Station-house. The testimony showed that BRADLEY and LOVE are shoemakers -- the former hiring the shop where the occurrence happened, and the latter having bench-room there, obtaining his work from down-town stores. The deceased, who was an unmarried woman, about 39 years of age, had been, until about tour weeks since, at service in the country, but having lost her place, she took up her residence with her brother, and both of them slept in a small, dirty room, partitioned off at the back part of the cobbler's shop. BRADLEY boarded elsewhere. On Friday the deceased and both of the men had been drinking freely, and their carousal was continued until a late hour, much to the annoyance of the neighbors. The shop not having been opened at a late hour on Saturday morning the neighbors suspected something wrong, and on searching the place they found the woman dead and the men in the condition above stated. It was also shown that the deceased and the prisoners had been quarreling while in their cups, and the face of each exhibited severe scratches which, doubtless, had been given during the fight. Dr. JOHN BEACH made a post mortem examination of the body, and was of opinion that the woman died from intemperance, as he could trace no connection between the marks of violence exhibited by the body, and the cause of death. The case was submitted to the jury, who returned the following verdict: "That the deceased came to her death by intoxication, and that she had been killed by violence." This paradoxical production the Coroner refused to accept,and six wise men were sent back to reconsider it. After a short time spent in deliberation, they reappeared with the following: "That deceased came to her death by intemperance, hastened by violence at the hands of PETER BRADLEY." The Coroner thereupon committed the accused to answer any action which may be taken against him by the Grand Jury. He stated in his examination that he was 20 years of age, and a native of Ireland. In reference to the charge, he said that he had no knowledge of having use I violence toward the deceased, but that he had saved her once or twice from being abused. SAMUEL LOVE and PATRICK MCCRUDDEN were also held by the Coroner as witnesses in the case.

abstract: The Tribune, a day or two since, suggested a compromise of the Slavery controversy quite unique in its character, to say the least. It had the merit of being quite certain to exasperate the South, and to encounter the stern hostility of the North,--and thus was in perfect harmony with the Tribune's position, that no compromise on this subject can ever be made.
lead_paragraph: The Tribune, a day or two since, suggested a compromise of the Slavery controversy quite unique in its character, to say the least. It had the merit of being quite certain to exasperate the South, and to encounter the stern hostility of the North,--and thus was in perfect harmony with the Tribune's position, that no compromise on this subject can ever be made. Our neighbor proposes the purchase of the slaves in Delaware and Maryland, together with those of the States west of the Mississippi, including Louisiana, by the Federal Government. It is supposed that these States now contain about 600,000 slaves, and that the owners would do well to sell them for $100,000,000. We think that our cotemporary underrates both the number of the slaves and the price the owners would be willing to take for them. But supposing these points adjusted, why select these particular States as the objects of Federal bounty? Does the Tribune contemplate the secession of the remaining States? Nothing could be more abhorrent to them than this policy of surrounding them with a cordon of emancipated slaves. The South cries aloud against being inclosed by States filled with free white men, and the impression which must be made upon them by the proposition to hem them in by emancipated slaves, may be more easily imagined than described.

abstract: When Russia came out of the Crimean war, it was, according to the views of the Western World, in a very mangled, tattered, shabby condition; very much out of pocket, very much in debt. She had been thrown, a la Falstaff, among all the dirty linen, into the horse-pond of disgrace.
lead_paragraph: When Russia came out of the Crimean war, it was, according to the views of the Western World, in a very mangled, tattered, shabby condition; very much out of pocket, very much in debt. She had been thrown, a la Falstaff, among all the dirty linen, into the horse-pond of disgrace. But those who knew her well doubted this extreme misery, and examination soon revealed that if she had been ducked, it had been with the luck of the Arab who, when thrown into the Nile, came up with a fish in his mouth! She had availed herself of a war with France and England to quietly and unobservedly acquire on the Amoor a territory worth six times as much as was lost by the expenses of the war and the partial cession of Bessarabia; and whose value, as necessary to her future schemes, was literally incalculable.

abstract: The Brooklyn Navy-yard was last evening the scene of unusual excitement, on account of an order issued by Commander FOOTE to have the entire force put under arms and held in readiness to act immediately. The one hundred marines remaining there were accordingly mustered, under command of Captains REED and DOUGHTY and with loaded muskets occupied the guard-house at the gate.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn Navy-yard was last evening the scene of unusual excitement, on account of an order issued by Commander FOOTE to have the entire force put under arms and held in readiness to act immediately. The one hundred marines remaining there were accordingly mustered, under command of Captains REED and DOUGHTY and with loaded muskets occupied the guard-house at the gate. On board the receiving ship North Carolina the guns were placed in position and shotted for immediate use, and every officer was ordered to be on the alert. In the Wallabout, and near the Navy-yard, several boats made their appearance shortly after dark, filled with policemen. Simultaneously with these ominous preparations at the Navy-yard, the military of Brooklyn in strong force were observed to be gathering at the new armory and also at the new arsenal, and crowds of wondering citizens assembled, anxious to know the cause of the sudden military display. During the evening it became known that there were apprehensions of an attack upon the Navy-yard by an organized force, with the intention of holding it in the interest of those favoring the Southern Secessionists. Portions of the Thirteenth, Fourteenth and Twenty-eighth Regiments, of the Fifth Brigade, numbering over three hundred men, responded to the call of Major-Gen. DURYEA, and held themselves in readiness to cooperate with the forces at the Navy-yard for resisting the apprehended attack. The movement was made at the request of Mayor POWELL.They remained under arms until a late hour of the night, and were then dismissed for the present. The force at the Navy-yard was kept under arms until all apprehension of an attack had passed. To-day a full battery will be placed on board of the North Carolina, and howitzers will be put in position to sweep every approach to the grounds. Strict military orders will be enforced, and every precautionary measure will be adopted to guard against surprise. It is impossible of course, at the present time, to say how much necessity may exist for these precautions.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--MRRCADANTE's celebrated opera of " Il Giuramento," was produced here last night, and, being accepted with great favor, inaugurated brilliantly the new season undertaken by the associated Italian artists, And to this season we would direct particular attention. It has been commenced under circumstances generally regarded as unfavorable to its commercial prosperity.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--MRRCADANTE's celebrated opera of " Il Giuramento," was produced here last night, and, being accepted with great favor, inaugurated brilliantly the new season undertaken by the associated Italian artists, And to this season we would direct particular attention. It has been commenced under circumstances generally regarded as unfavorable to its commercial prosperity. The times are admittedly out of joint, and fashionable people, it is said, are more scared -- and perhaps more hurt -- than any other. But whilst recording these facts we must remember that they have led to the formation of a company thoroughly economical in its personnel -- so economical indeed that the principal artists are prepared to take nothing if that is the share a liberal public awards to them for much enterprise and effort. In the best of times it is objected that we cannot afford to pay the high salaries demanded by artists; in the worst of times we may, however, be able to pay nothing. So, on the whole, the prospects of the company seem to us to be good. If the season is a failure it will only show that New-York cannot support an opera at any price, and that the career of the Academy of Music is ended.

abstract: The North American Review for the current quarter begins with an article headed as above. The history and statistics of this important staple are given in a brief but clear account, derived mainly from ELLISON's Handbook, the latest authority on the subject. It is, indeed, a wonderful history.
lead_paragraph: The North American Review for the current quarter begins with an article headed as above. The history and statistics of this important staple are given in a brief but clear account, derived mainly from ELLISON's Handbook, the latest authority on the subject. It is, indeed, a wonderful history. No other product of human labor -- no other element in the commerce of the world -- has played so momentous a part. In less than a half century the manufacture of cotton has quadrupled the wealth and power of Great Britain. In the same short period its culture in the United States has changed the current of events and controlled our national politics. Among the causes which have conspired to bring our country to its present critical condition, cotton stands preeminent. The change which has taken place in Southern opinion and feeling as to the nature and tendencies of Slavery, and the entirely altered tone of Southern language on that theme, began with the rising prospects of cotton, and have kept pace with the progress of that great staple. Such a change very naturally awakened the jealousy and called forth the remonstrances of the North. The purposely irritating assaults of the Abolitionists, and even the milder comments of those who could not but condemn the institution, while they deprecated all interference with it, reacted on the Southern mind, and by a process perfectly natural, drove it still further in the wrong direction.

abstract: "Devil with devil damned, firm concord holds!" " For ourselves," says the Charleston Mercury of Thursday last, " we look to the Abolitionists for the deliverance of the South." When the Mercury reads the speech of WENDELL PHILLIPS, which we publish this morning, it will see that it has substantial ground for its reliance.
lead_paragraph: "Devil with devil damned, firm concord holds!" " For ourselves," says the Charleston Mercury of Thursday last, " we look to the Abolitionists for the deliverance of the South." When the Mercury reads the speech of WENDELL PHILLIPS, which we publish this morning, it will see that it has substantial ground for its reliance. There is not a Disunionist in Charleston so eager for the overthrow of the Constitution, and the destruction of the American Union, as this man, -- the head and front of Abolitionism in the Northern States. He hails disunion as the signal of deliverance for the four millions of slaves. He welcomes it as the rupture and utter repudiation of the unholy bargain of 1787. He has no words to express his joy at the reckless courage with which South Carolina has set fire to the American Union, utterly heedless of what gives him the keenest delight -- the certainty of her own destruction.

abstract: Andrew Stevens vs. The New-York Consolidated Stage Company.--This is an appeal from a judgment rendered at a trial term of this Court against the defendants.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Stevens vs. The New-York Consolidated Stage Company.--This is an appeal from a judgment rendered at a trial term of this Court against the defendants. The action was brought to recover damages for alleged negligence on the part of defendants servants, in upsetting the plaintiff just as he was get ting out of one of the defendants' stages. It is alleged that, on that occasion, the driver started forward before the plaintiff had firmly planted his feet upon the pavement, and that in consequence the plaintiff was precipitated from the step, and thrown with violence upon the pavement, of which he suffered seriously. Upon the trial of this cause, there were several prepositions presented by defendants' councel to the Judge, upon which to charge the jury, all of which the Court refused to charge. It appears that, previous to this accident, the plaintiff had been suffering from a complication of diseases, among which were epilepsy and softening of the spine. Among the questions presented, was whether the sickness of the plaintiff alleged in the complaint, was caused by the injuries he received by the fall, or by previous existing disease. Decision reserved.

abstract: For some time past an old gentleman, known as Mr. James Whiting, has been stopping at one of the firstclass hotels at Philadelphia, where, by his engaging manners and plausible conversation, he made many influential acquaintances, and invested himself with all the importance of unlimited wealth. Among those who gave him their confidence was Mr. A.H. Little, an extensive dealer in silk goods, at No. 325 Marketstreet.
lead_paragraph: For some time past an old gentleman, known as Mr. James Whiting, has been stopping at one of the firstclass hotels at Philadelphia, where, by his engaging manners and plausible conversation, he made many influential acquaintances, and invested himself with all the importance of unlimited wealth. Among those who gave him their confidence was Mr. A.H. Little, an extensive dealer in silk goods, at No. 325 Marketstreet. Mr. Whiting expressed his desire to purchase a valuable estate belonging to Mr. Little, and negotiations were entered upon with that object in view. While these were pending, the old gentleman incidentally remarked that he had determined upon making his wife and daughter each a present of a gold watch and guard-chain, and would like Mr. Little to recommend him to a trustworthy jeweler. That gentleman complied without hesitation, particularly as he had a very worthy friend in that branch of trade, who kept an establishment in the upper purl of the same building where he (Mr. Little) conducted his own business. The name of the jeweler is Mr. Jas. Watson, and under the influence of a personal introduction from Mr. Little, he let Whiting have two gold watches and three chains, valued in the aggregate at $670, taking in payment a check drawn by the later upon the Girard Bank, Philadelphia. It was after banking hours when the transaction took plane, but early the next morning the check was sent to the bank for payment, when it transpired that there were no funds there credited to Whiting, nor had there been any. Mr. Little was informed of the matter, and, loth to believe that the venerable stranger had been doing wrong he went to his hotel for an explanation. But he could not find him, and, after searching several days, he reluctantly made up his mind that he was the dupe of an imposter. In his mortification, he determined to spare no pains to affect Whiting's apprehension, and came to New York to look for him. Arriving at Jersey City by the 10 1/2 o'clock train on Sunday night, he took the ferry boat, and was fortunate enough to final on board the very person for whom he searched. Officer Clark, of the Third Ward, was, therefore, notified, and took Whiting prisoner. He will be sent to Philadelphia for trial. Not the least fortunate part of the arrest was the fact that the watches and chains were all found in the prisoner's possession.

abstract: Information that an attack was anticipated reached the police authorities in this City about 4 o'clock in the afternoon. Superintendent KENNEDY was out of town, and the duty of disposing the police in the emergency developed upon Commissioner BOWEN and Inspector CARPENTER. A plan of operation was promptly decided upon, and through the instrumentality of the telegraph it was almost immediately in process of execution.
lead_paragraph: Information that an attack was anticipated reached the police authorities in this City about 4 o'clock in the afternoon. Superintendent KENNEDY was out of town, and the duty of disposing the police in the emergency developed upon Commissioner BOWEN and Inspector CARPENTER. A plan of operation was promptly decided upon, and through the instrumentality of the telegraph it was almost immediately in process of execution. The Harbor Police boats, fully manned with armed crews, and commanded by Capt. TODD, were ordered to rendezvous at Wallabout Bay. A force or one hundred patrolmen, from various wards, under the command of Capt. HELME of the Eighth Precinct and Drill Sergeant WAUGH, was concentrated at Head-quarters, ready to march at a moment's notice. One of the Catharine Ferry-boats was chartered to transport this force to the Navy-Yard, and at 8 o'clock information was telegraphed from the Fourth Precinct that the boat was in readiness for that purpose. The men were immediately formed in marching order, and were to have taken up their quarters on the boat, where they were to remain until warned by a preconcerted signal from the Yard that their services were necessary.

abstract: Mobile is a city sui generis. With a population less than 30,000, it ranks third in the amount of its exports among the ports of the United States. Surrounded by a sterile country, its business is almost exclusively with agricultural products. With extensive pine forests all around it, producing the most valuable lumber, and large quantities of turpentine, its exports of lumber are constantly diminishing, and those of naval stores are insignificant.
lead_paragraph: MOBILE, Wednesday, Jan. 9, 1861.

abstract: A special dispatch from Springfield, Ill., to the Republican says that Congressman KELLOGG arrived there on Saturday night, and is in conference with Mr. LINCOLN. His object is supposed to be in reference to a compromise of the national difficulties. It is believed that the Republicans, with Mr. LINCOLN'S sanction, will propose holding a National Convention, and the restoration of the old Missouri line to California.

abstract: In this Court yesterday, before Judge MCCUNN, the trial of Jose Varona, indicted for forgery, which occupied the Court during most of last week, was concluded late in the day. Several witnesses were called by the prosecution in rebuttal of the testimony introduced by the defence relative to the character of some of the witnesses for the people, but beyond this the testimony, yesterday, did not go. Judge Whiting, for the defence, summed up at great length, and Mr. Anthon closed for the people. The Court then charged the Jury, who, at a late hour, had not rendered a verdict.

abstract: COTTON The market yesterday (Monday) opened with a brisk inquiry, but it was checked by the further advance in the Bank discount. The sales of the day were about 10,000 bales, including 1,500 on speculation and for export at last Friday's rates. This morning the market has been very quiet, and it is computed that the sales will not exceed 3,000 or 4,000 bales.

abstract: Governor's Island has been again reinforced by recruits. On Friday night a detachment, consisting of drafts from Buffalo and Rochester, arrived in town, but owing to the stringent rules in force at the barge office, were obliged to lodge in the City till Saturday morning, when they reported themselves to Major HOLMES. There are now 730 men, all told, on the Island, and if many more arrive a considerable number of hands must be detached.

abstract: We see that some unscrupulous partisans of the Federal Union are contributing to the American newspapers stories of the joy expressed by Englishmen traveling in the United States, at the prospect of the Constitution collapsing. Not a word of this ought to be believed. The view of all Englishmen, whose opinion is worth taking is almost exactly expressed by Mr. HALE. They know perfectly well that the Americans are applying the political discoveries of the English race under the only forms which are probably suited to their circumstances. None of us are likely to be deluded by the empty compliment implied" in a Southern cry for a return to monarchical government. In some of its ideas, particularly those on the subject of slavery, the English people are more advanced than the American; and it is no flattery to be told that a slaveholding community considers a monarchy likely to be more conservative of its institutions than a republic. Besides, every one among us who can observe, will vehemently doubt whether the Southern monarchy would have much that is constitutional about it. When a majority, consisting of men equal among themselves, gets into a violent fright about the supposed designs of a minority, we have European experience to show us to what sort of protection they are apt to fly. If the Southerners ever take a king to reign over them, it is not a constitutional monarchy but a military despotism which they will probably establish. Great as are the political aptitudes of the English race, it has always shown that its love of liberty was in some danger from its love of gain. Cupidity has often made Englishmen and Americans tyrants -- who knows but that, if it be allowed to get the upper hand, it may yet make them slaves?
lead_paragraph: We see that some unscrupulous partisans of the Federal Union are contributing to the American newspapers stories of the joy expressed by Englishmen traveling in the United States, at the prospect of the Constitution collapsing. Not a word of this ought to be believed. The view of all Englishmen, whose opinion is worth taking is almost exactly expressed by Mr. HALE. They know perfectly well that the Americans are applying the political discoveries of the English race under the only forms which are probably suited to their circumstances. None of us are likely to be deluded by the empty compliment implied" in a Southern cry for a return to monarchical government. In some of its ideas, particularly those on the subject of slavery, the English people are more advanced than the American; and it is no flattery to be told that a slaveholding community considers a monarchy likely to be more conservative of its institutions than a republic. Besides, every one among us who can observe, will vehemently doubt whether the Southern monarchy would have much that is constitutional about it. When a majority, consisting of men equal among themselves, gets into a violent fright about the supposed designs of a minority, we have European experience to show us to what sort of protection they are apt to fly. If the Southerners ever take a king to reign over them, it is not a constitutional monarchy but a military despotism which they will probably establish. Great as are the political aptitudes of the English race, it has always shown that its love of liberty was in some danger from its love of gain. Cupidity has often made Englishmen and Americans tyrants -- who knows but that, if it be allowed to get the upper hand, it may yet make them slaves?

abstract: The call for a Convention is more doubtful on account of disagreement as to time. One party is for hasty, and the other for deliberate action. abstract: James F. Whiting, who was arrested on Sunday evening, on a charge of having defrauded a Philadelphia jeweler to the extent of $670, turns out to be an old acquaintance of the Police, noted for his expertness in swindling by means of various "confidential" devices. He was taken to Police Head-quarters, yesterday, for the purpose of having a photograph taken, and Detective Keefe recognized him as an escaped convict from Clinton Prison, who was sentenced in 1856 for a robbery committed at Saratoga Springs. Whiting, who there was known as A.M. Kingsland, had taken board with his family at Congress Hall, and during the time of his residence at that hotel, Gen. Robert Halsey, of Utica, who was also a guest of the establishment, lost $14,000 in cash under circumstances which left no doubt of the prisoner's guilt. He was arrested and tried for the offence, with a confederate named William Henderson, and having been proved guilty, each was sentenced to Clinton Prison for a term of nine years and six months. In April last, however, Whiting managed to obtain a suit of citizen's clothes, and, disguised as a visitor, he escaped from prison. Detective Keefe told the prisoner that the circumstances of his past life were pretty well know to the police, and after a while he admitted that he was the person whom he was taken for. Since he escaped from prison, Whiting has been successfully engaged in various swindles, and from his own statements he has accumulated about $20,000. He is a very fine-looking man, possessing great conversational powers, and altogether he is a very prepossessing person. His right name is supposed to be Thompson, though his aliases are said to have been as numerous as his misdeeds. The Warden of Clinton Prison was notified of the arrest, and to-day the fugitive will be sent to his former quarters.

abstract: The excitement occasioned by the rumors of yesterday, and the extraordinary steps taken to protect the property of the Government from attack or injury, attracted more than the usual number of persons to the yard yesterday, evidently from the most patriotic motives. A slight inspection was sufficient to assure every one that the Navy-Yard is perfectly safe in present hands. The officers generally appear never to have entertained serious apprehensions that the insane project of seizing this naval station would be attempted; but the course of events in other parts of the country was deemed sufficient cause for being prepared for emergencies.

abstract: Company K, Second Regiment, United States Artilery, consisting of 44 rank and file and 4 officers, reached this City last evening via the Hudson River Railroad, en route to Fort Hamilton, which for a long time past has been without a garrison. This Company is commanded by Capt. H.A. ALLEN, and comes from Pittsburgh Barracks, Lake Champlain, where it has been stationed during the past 21 months. Capt. ALLEN received marching orders on Saturday afternoon last, and on Monday, at 3 o'clock P.M., the Company left quarters and took the railroad for this City. Owing, however, to various unlooked-for detentions upon the road, it did not arrive here until after 6 o'clock. Having partaken of supper at TRACY & EMERY's restaurant, the men embarked on the tugboat Pope Catlin at the barge-office pier, and were transported to Fort Hamilton. They are a fine-looking corps.

abstract: The elder MATHEWS recorded as a peculiarity of the American people, that they do everything and expect everything to be done, in about twenty minutes. We carry this impatience and restless eagerness into public affairs. Any great movement must be consummated at once or we grow weary of it. The Tribune, some time since, stated that the Russian project of emancipation, -- involving an entire reconstruction of Russian society, -was beginning to be a bore: -- it had been on the carpet two years, and was still incomplete. The project of recreating Italy is regarded in very much the same light. Because NAPOLEON did not on the instant, at the close of a sixty days campaign, instantly decree the existence of a tree, united, independent Italian nation, he is suspected of hypocrisy and flagrant treason to the cause of nationalities.

abstract: This Society is dependent for the greater part of its support upon unsolicited contributions, which are sent in, in smaller or larger sums, from this City and from every part of the country. In times of great public excitement, and in the more momentous national troubles, the enterprises of daily charity are naturally overlooked. The business depression, moreover, falls most heavily on those from whom most of the support of benevolent societies come. The consequence is, that in the midst of Winter, with the usual and, perhaps, even a greater number of poor children dependent upon them, the Trustees of the Children's Aid Society are extremely cramped for means to carry on their various and important enterprises for the needy and ignorant children of the City. They fear even that some of these most needful charities to those who suffer most in distressed times -- the poor and homeless little ones of the streets -- must be given up, unless more liberally aided by the public.

abstract: Certainly the last man in the world who might have been expected to rap the Secessionists over the knuckles was Mr. JOHN MITCHEL; and for this very reason, perhaps, he has felt bound to do it, and has done it with a will. The charm of inconsistency is one which this gentleman appears utterly unable to resist; and having preached in this country for several years the omnipotence of King Cotton, and its ability to subdue all other interests to its royal demands, -- we should take it, perhaps, as but natural to find him now preaching, while in France, that cotton is but a very small affair after all; and that the English markets can be supplied with all, and more than all they need and at cheaper rates than ever heretofore, from "the magnificent alluvial vallies of Central China." Thus Mr. MITCHELL speaks in his last letter from Paris, dated the 15th of December, and addressed to the Charleston Mercury:

abstract: The Mayor, &c., of New-York, vs. The Parker Vein Steamship Company et al. -- At a trial term of this Court, a judgment of $3,350 was rendered against the defendants, under the following circumstances: The defendants, it appears, run a line of steamers between this City and the City of Baltimore. On the 1st of May, 1854, the defendants leased of the plaintiffs the wharf known as No. 13 North River, for the use and occupation of vessels of more than five tons burden, which lease dated from that day, and was to continue in force to the 1st of May, 1855. By a separate lease dated the same as those before set forth, they further leased of the plaintiffs the Pier No. 12 North River, at the foot of Albany-street, at a stipulated rent. Each of these leases, it appears, contained a covenant that, if the rent was behind for the space of ten days after the dates on which payment was to be made, the Comptroller might cause a notice to be served on the defendants declaring the lease null and void, and that the service of such notice should be conclusive evidence that the defendants had failed to perform their agreement, and that the plaintiff should have the immediate right of reentry upon the said premises as if no such leases were in existance, and that the defendants should be liable for rent to that time. It appears that such notice was served on the 11th of September, 1854. Two of the defendants in this action, Jewett and Mali, thereupon made and executed to the defendant a bond under seal, conditioned for the payment of the rent. They having failed to comply with the condition of their bond, and the rent not being paid, this action was brought against the lessees as well as the obligers. The defendants admit the claim, but set up that after the defendants entered into possession of Pier No. 13 they made temporary erections and fixtures thereon, and that at the termination of the leases the plaintiffs prevented them from removing said fixtures, but converted them to their own use. The defendants therefore claim that the value of these fixtures should be allowed as a counter-claim. The Court below having held that this was not properly the subject of a counter-claim, an appeal was brought upon this ground alone. The principal point taken by the defendants in support of this position are: First, That the counter-claim set up is within subd, 1, sec. 150 of the Code, because it arises out of a contract on which the plaintiff sues; the right asserted by that contract, being involved in and implied by that contract. That the counterclaim arises out of the transaction set forth in the complaint, viz; the lease, the possesion, the incidental election of fixtures, the interference with the outgoing tenants, and the appropriation of their fixtures.
lead_paragraph: The Mayor, &c., of New-York, vs. The Parker Vein Steamship Company et al. -- At a trial term of this Court, a judgment of $3,350 was rendered against the defendants, under the following circumstances: The defendants, it appears, run a line of steamers between this City and the City of Baltimore. On the 1st of May, 1854, the defendants leased of the plaintiffs the wharf known as No. 13 North River, for the use and occupation of vessels of more than five tons burden, which lease dated from that day, and was to continue in force to the 1st of May, 1855. By a separate lease dated the same as those before set forth, they further leased of the plaintiffs the Pier No. 12 North River, at the foot of Albany-street, at a stipulated rent. Each of these leases, it appears, contained a covenant that, if the rent was behind for the space of ten days after the dates on which payment was to be made, the Comptroller might cause a notice to be served on the defendants declaring the lease null and void, and that the service of such notice should be conclusive evidence that the defendants had failed to perform their agreement, and that the plaintiff should have the immediate right of reentry upon the said premises as if no such leases were in existance, and that the defendants should be liable for rent to that time. It appears that such notice was served on the 11th of September, 1854. Two of the defendants in this action, Jewett and Mali, thereupon made and executed to the defendant a bond under seal, conditioned for the payment of the rent. They having failed to comply with the condition of their bond, and the rent not being paid, this action was brought against the lessees as well as the obligers. The defendants admit the claim, but set up that after the defendants entered into possession of Pier No. 13 they made temporary erections and fixtures thereon, and that at the termination of the leases the plaintiffs prevented them from removing said fixtures, but converted them to their own use. The defendants therefore claim that the value of these fixtures should be allowed as a counter-claim. The Court below having held that this was not properly the subject of a counter-claim, an appeal was brought upon this ground alone. The principal point taken by the defendants in support of this position are: First, That the counter-claim set up is within subd, 1, sec. 150 of the Code, because it arises out of a contract on which the plaintiff sues; the right asserted by that contract, being involved in and implied by that contract. That the counterclaim arises out of the transaction set forth in the complaint, viz; the lease, the possesion, the incidental election of fixtures, the interference with the outgoing tenants, and the appropriation of their fixtures.

abstract: Drawn out by the announcement that this most original and eccentric of all Evangelists would relate a portion of his life experiences at Clinton Hall on Monday evening, a multitude went thither. They saw much the manner of man that one skilled in drawing mental portraitures would have limned from Dr. CARTWRIGHT's reputation, -- a sturdy, square-built, square-shouldered man, looking as though he had both the mind and the muscle, when occasion required the exertion, to hold a sinner down, and force him to hear the Gospel whether or no. His face is rugged and bronzed by exposure to seventy five winters, the features strongly marked with the square chin and firmly arched mouth that always go to indicate determination. A humorous twinkle about the deep-set eyes, a bushy head of hair, arranged apparently more with a view to celerity than to elegance, and you have an idea of the famous PETER CARTWRIGHT. He looks very much like an honest, straightforward going old farmer; an old farmer to whom you'd give half the road, if you met him going to mill, without a moment's hesitation, and yield the whole if he insisted very strenuously upon having it; a farmer, withal with whom you'd never think of getting the upper hand in making a bar gain.

His face is rugged and bronzed by exposure to seventy five winters, the features strongly marked with the square chin and firmly arched mouth that always go to indicate determination. A humorous twinkle about the deep-set eyes, a bushy head of hair, arranged apparently more with a view to celerity than to elegance, and you have an idea of the famous PETER CARTWRIGHT. He looks very much like an honest, straightforward going old farmer; an old farmer to whom you'd give half the road, if you met him going to mill, without a moment's hesitation, and yield the whole if he insisted very strenuously upon having it; a farmer, withal with whom you'd never think of getting the upper hand in making a bar gain.

abstract: Matters remain in statu quo so far as the City and County funds are concerned. The Park Bank recognizes Mr. DEVLIN as City Chamberlain, so far as the books and papers and vouchers are concerned, and pays promptly all warrants drawn upon the Chamberlain for ordinary disbursements, and the balance in the custody of the Bank is being rapidly diminished. The warrant "properly" drawn for the transfer of the general balance, has not yet been presented.

abstract: MOVEMENTS OF MRS. LINCOLN. -- On Saturday last Mrs. LINCOLN, wife of the President elect, visited the Navy-Yard, accompanied by Com. STRINGHAM and a small party of friends. The North Carolina and the chief points of interest about the yard were visited. Mrs. LINCOLN was received everywhere with the greatest courtesy. Last evening Mrs. LINCOLN occupied a private box at the Academy of Music. It was soon known throughout the house, and she was the observed of all observers. A large number of ladies and gentlemen the entered the box were presented to Mrs. LINCOLN by Hon. EDWARDS FISK.

abstract: The present is an age of magazines. A few centuries since and the public taste craved prolixity; now it seems inclined to recognize brevity as the soul of literature. The truth is that amid the hurry and bustle of the day people have very little time to devote to the much-of-one thing that goes to make a book; they infinitely prefer the little-of-everything to be found in periodicals. We import the magazine mania from England, but it manifests itself with us under a different phase. The rule governing the conduct of periodicals is reversed; there it is the editors of newspapers who are impersonal; here it is of the magazine. The leading luminaries of the literary world, in England, are accustomed to revolve in monthly orbits; each fashions for himself a sphere, and covers it with his prestige. Thus, in taking up the Cornhill you grasp THACKERAY by the hand; in All the Year Round you walk arm in arm with DICKKNS; in our Harper's, Knickerbocker or Atlantic, on the other hand, you are introduced to a roomful of litterateurs; they are very pleasant gentlemen to know; you nod cordially to them all, and bow yourself out of their presence, with the consciousness of having spent a pleasant evening, yet half inclined to regret that you had not met some man towering above the others, to give individuality to the group.

abstract: The ship Pampero arrived at this port on Monday from San Francisco, whence she sailed in September last, and, soon after her arrival, JOHN SIMPSON and WM. BUTLER, two of her crew, gave information at the Harbor Police office of a murder alleged to have been committed on board by FREDERICK HENDERSON, the third mate. The name of the victim was FRANCIS GOLDSMITH, and the sailors stated that, as the vessel gas passing out of the harbor of San Francisco, an attack was made upon him by HENDERSON, who was offended at something which he had done. After knocking him down from the top galiant-forecastle to the deck, he stamped upon him until life was almost exact. Before the pilot left the ship the man died, and his body was wrapped in a blanket and sent ashore in the pilot-boat --a certificate from the captain as companying it, to the effect that deceased had come to his death by a fall from aloft. As soon us the vessel arrived here, HENDERSON came ashore in a steamboat and made his escape. The police are searching for him, but the probabilities are that he has left the City.

abstract: The Brooklyn military were dismissed at 12 o'clock, night before last, by order of their commandant. Gen H.B. DURYEA. Yesterday they were not under arms, but the men have been instructed to hold themselves in readiness to respond to a sudden call at any time. They obeyed that of Monday night with great alacrity, and notwithstanding the difficulty which necessarily attended the convocation of citizen soldiery on such short notice, the ranks of the several regiments were quite full at an early hour in the evening. There are a little more than 1,500 men under Gen. DURYEA's command. No orders in contemplation of an outbreak have been issued to the troops in New-York City. Reports to the contrary, whichhave been published, are erroneous.

abstract: Yesterday morning a terrible encounter took place at Astley's Amphitheatre. An under-groom, named SMITH, was litterally throttled to death by one of the lions which play so prominent a part in the holiday entertainments at that favorite place of amusement. The lions, three in number, are confined in a cage at the back of the stage. When the night watchman left the theatre yesterday morning a few minutes before 7 he reported "all right." Shortly afterwards SMITH, the deceased, entered the place and found the lions prowling about. They had torn off a heavy iron bar which crossed the front of their cage, and then burst open the door. SMITH was alone, and, not being familiar with the animals, he attempted to escape into an adjoining stable yard. His situation was a frightful one, and most men would have acted precisely as he did under the circumstances; but the probability is that if he had stood his ground boldly his life would have been saved, unfortunately, one of the lions -- that which is known by the name of Havelock -- caught sight of his retreating figure and instantly sprang upon him. It seized him by the haunches, pulled him to the ground, and then fixed its teeth in his throat. Death must have been almost instantaneous; but, as SMITH was found a good deal cut and bruised at the back of the head, it is supposed that the lion, after bury big its fangs in his throat, dragged him about and dashed his head against the ground. It seems, in fact, to have worried him, though the wounds inflicted by the brute are neither so numerous nor so severe as might have been expected. There were no cries for help, but a sort of shuffling noise was heard by a man in the stable yard. He suspected what had occurred, and did not venture to open the door through which SMITH had endeavored to escape; but he gave the alarm, and in a few minutes was joined by several grooms and others Connected with the theatre. They were all, however, too much afraid to enter the place, and nothing was done to ascertain the fate of SMITH until the arrival of CROCKETT, the lion conqueror, to whom the animals belong. As soon as he reached the spot he passed through the door alone, none of the others daring to follow. The body of SMITH was lying upwards a few feet from the door, and Havelock was crouching over it as a hungry dog hangs over a piece of meat. CROCKETT immediately threw the animal off, and dragged the body into the yard; It was still warm, but life had been extinct for some time. A surgeon was sent for, but of course he could render no assistance. CROCKETT lost no time in securing the lions. They allowed him to capture them easily enough. Even Havelock did not offer any resistance, and the other two, which had taken no part in the terrible scene with SMITH, seemed rather afraid than otherwise. In a few minutes all three were back in their cage again, and last night they went through their usual performances before a crowded audience. SMITH was unmarried. There will, of course, be an inquiry into the circumstances which attended the unhappy man's death.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning a terrible encounter took place at Astley's Amphitheatre. An under-groom, named SMITH, was litterally throttled to death by one of the lions which play so prominent a part in the holiday entertainments at that favorite place of amusement. The lions, three in number, are confined in a cage at the back of the stage. When the night watchman left the theatre yesterday morning a few minutes before 7 he reported "all right." Shortly afterwards SMITH, the deceased, entered the place and found the lions prowling about. They had torn off a heavy iron bar which crossed the front of their cage, and then burst open the door. It seems, in fact, to have worried him, though the wounds inflicted by the brute are neither so numerous nor so severe as might have been expected. He suspected what had occurred, and did not venture to open the door through which SMITH had endeavored to escape; but he gave the alarm, and in a few minutes was joined by several grooms and others Connected with the theatre. abstract: OPERATIC. -- The greatest social event of the Nineteenth Century -- according to competent Brooklyn authority -- occurred last night, when the Academy of Music was opened for the legitimate purposes of its foundation. The attendance was very good, showing that there is at least a fair degree of sympathy with the undertaking, and, in consequence, a reasonable prospect of its success. By 8 o'clock -- the time of commencement house presented a very animated appearance, and the curtain rose on some poorly painted scenery, representing the opening scene of "Il Giuramento." It was apparent before the end of the overture that the house was a splendid success in every acoustical point of view, and this, too, in spite of admirable reasons for the contrary. Mr. MUZIO's orchestra gained not only strength, but what is far more desirable, quality of tone in the fine, delicate and rapid resonances of the building. The overture -- which, by the way, was an introduction from another opera, "Joana d'Arco" -- was excellently rendered and much applauded.

Mr. MUZIO's orchestra gained not only strength, but what is far more desirable, quality of tone in the fine, delicate and rapid resonances of the building. The overture -- which, by the way, was an introduction from another opera, "Joana d'Arco" -- was excellently rendered and much applauded.

abstract: Our dispatches from Washington this morning are very interesting. The South Carolina Commissioner, Col. HAYNE, still remains inactive, so far as any communication with the Government is concerned, but appears to be spending his time quite agreeably in attending dinner parties. He is stated to have received a telegram from Gov. PICKENS yesterday, which represents the most amicable relations as existing between the Charlestonians and Major ANDERSON. Another special messenger has been dispatched by the President to Pensacola, to communicate with the commander of Fort Pickens. It is understood that the instructions sent are to the effect that a collision must be avoided by all honorable means. There are now no fears of a collision, as, according to declarations made yesterday by the President, such a catastrophe will not be likely to take place during the remainder of his Administration.

abstract: On Tuesday afternoon, Mr. Austin A. Turner, lithographer at No. 553 Broadway, was introduced to Patrick Burns and Robert Kehoe, whom he encountered in the bar-room of the Carleton House. The toast to "a better acquaintance" was repeatedly honored, and, after a time, the three went over to Parmelee's, under the St. Nicholas Hotel, where they took several additional drinks. While standing at the bar, Kehoe, it is alleged, suddenly snatched a diamond pin, valued at $200, from Turner's scarf, at the same time striking him a violent blow in the face. The assault was continued by Burns, and while Turner was receiving a beating from him, Kehoe left the place. As quickly as he could, the victim of bar-room acquaintances made the matter known to Officer Sickles, of the Eighth Ward, who arrested the alleged robber and his confederate, but the jewelry was not recovered. Each of the prisoners were required by Justice QUACKENBUSH to furnish bail in $1,000 for trial.
