abstract: Never for many years can the United States be to the world what they have been. Mr. BUCHANAN'S Message has been a greater blow to the American people than all the rants of the Georgian Governor or the "ordinances" of the Charleston Convention. The President has dissipated the idea that the States which elected him constitute one people. We had thought that the Federation was of the nature of a nationality; we find it is nothing more than a partnership. If any State may, on grounds satisfactory to a local Convention, dissolve the union between itself and its fellows; if discontent with the election of a President or the passing of an obnoxious law by another State, or, it may be, a restrictive tariff, gives a State the "right of revolution," and permits it to withdraw itself from the community then the position of the American people with respect to foreign Powers is completely altered. It is strange that a race whose patriotic captiousness when in the society of Europeans is so remarkable should be so ready to divide and to give up the ties of fellow-citizenship for a cause which strangers are unable to appreciate. Still stranger is it that a Chief Magistrate, who would have plunged the world in war rather than a suspicious craft should be boarded by English officers after it had displayed the Stars and Stripes, or would have done battle against despots for any naturalized refugee from Continental Europe, should, without scruple and against the advice of his own Secretary of State, declare the Federal Union dissolved whenever a refractory State chooses to secede.
lead_paragraph: Never for many years can the United States be to the world what they have been. Mr. BUCHANAN'S Message has been a greater blow to the American people than all the rants of the Georgian Governor or the "ordinances" of the Charleston Convention. The President has dissipated the idea that the States which elected him constitute one people. We had thought that the Federation was of the nature of a nationality; we find it is nothing more than a partnership. If any State may, on grounds satisfactory to a local Convention, dissolve the union between itself and its fellows; if discontent with the election of a President or the passing of an obnoxious law by another State, or, it may be, a restrictive tariff, gives a State the "right of revolution," and permits it to withdraw itself from the community then the position of the American people with respect to foreign Powers is completely altered. It is strange that a race whose patriotic captiousness when in the society of Europeans is so remarkable should be so ready to divide and to give up the ties of fellow-citizenship for a cause which strangers are unable to appreciate. Still stranger is it that a Chief Magistrate, who would have plunged the world in war rather than a suspicious craft should be boarded by English officers after it had displayed the Stars and Stripes, or would have done battle against despots for any naturalized refugee from Continental Europe, should, without scruple and against the advice of his own Secretary of State, declare the Federal Union dissolved whenever a refractory State chooses to secede.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Miss ISABELLA HINKLEY may congratulate herself on having achieved one of the most successful debuts ever won in this City. For one may safely say that in the large audience assembled last evening there was not one who failed to recognize in her initial effort all the prominent indications of a great fuure. Miss HINKLEY, of whom we have already distantly spoken in these columns, reechoing the applause that greeted her in Brussels, is a native of Albany; she has studied in Europe; appeared there successfully, and now returns to the land of her birth to reap the rewards of industry and triumph. Her voice is a soprano of the best class, unusually full, large and dramatic, for the kind called legere, and especially brilliant and exquisite in the upper register. Her manner of producing tone is defective, leading frequently to a peculiar style of mouthing, which is known as churchey, and which in a small room is effective, but in a large theatre intolerable. It is, however, a minor defect in comparison with her positive merits. And foremost amongst the latter we would direct attention to the really remarkable clearness with which all her passages are conceived and executed. A scale is of course a scale, whoever may sing it. Your mechanic will run through it like a column of figures, but your true artist presents it as a chain of pearls, each link giving to its fellow a borrowed light. It is not our purpose to overrate Miss HINKLEY in this comparison, but simply to hint that she possesses the true art temperament; -- the sensitiveness which instinctively rejects every thing mechanical, and soars effectively or otherwise on its own pinions. This, be it remembered, is the rarest of all gifts, and covers a greater multitude of musical sins than can be laid to the charge of the present debutante. In the agreeable but slightly hackneyed role of Lucia, Miss HINKLEY has a fair scope for the exercise of her powers, and especially for the display of certain niceties of execution in which she is perfect. But whilst cheerfully awarding her a very emphatic success, and hailing her as the best gifted of the many American debutantes we have had of late, we are sure that we shall yet see her to greater advantage. Her physique and her voice alike point to a higher range of feeling than that elicited by the lovelorn heroine of DONIZETTI'S work. The applause last evening was vehement. Miss HINKLEY may consider that her name has been honorably inscribed on the role of popular favorites.

abstract: THE ALLEGED MURDER ON THE SHIP PAMPERO. -- The report given by us yesterday, in relation to the alleged murder of a sailor on board the ship Pampero, while coming out of port from San Francisco, appears to have been unjust toward Capt. WM. LESTER, the commander of that vessel. He certified to the death of the sailor, GOLDSMITH, precisely as it was reported to him at the time by the second mate -- that he fell from the topgallant forecastle. This statement was corroborated by three witnesses, then on the vessel, who took the body ashore to the Coroner in San Francisco. It was not until he reached this port that Capt. LESTER knew anything about the charge of murder against his third mate, or that he was in any way implicated in GOLDSMITH'S death. This information was brought to him by the Harbor Police themselves, after the third officer and most of the crew had left the ship. Had he known that such a charge was to be preferred against the mate he would most assuredly have detached him. Instead of the Pampero's having just arrived, as reported by the Harbor Police, she has been two weeks is port.

abstract: Our readers have probably observed that a bill was a few days ago introduced into the Legislature to prevent Gas Companies from making any charge for gas-meters, and we understand the New-York, Harlem, and Manhattan Companies, in anticipation of this measure, have announced their intention to discontinue these obnoxious exactions on the 1st of February next. After that date, therefore, we presume all meter-rents in this City will be abolished, and the Companies will furnish these instruments free to consumers. This is the plan adopted by the Gas Companies in several populous cities in England, and the change, though tardy, is just. In the present state of public feeling here, the concession could not be withheld. It is imperatively demanded, and will be hailed with satisfaction by every consumer.

abstract: LIVERPOOL COTTON MARKET, 11th. -- The Brokers' Circular reports: Sales of the week, 57,000 bales, including 8,500 to speculators, and 4,000 to exporters. The market opened with an upward tendency, but became dull in consequence of the advance in Bank rates. The arrival of the Etna with favorable advices from America caused a reaction, and the market closed at last week's full prices with an advancing tendency. The sales on Friday reached 12,000 bales, including 4,000 to speculators and exporters, the market closing active at the following authorized quotations:

abstract: Lord PALMERSTON, in a speech at Southampton, had referred to the situation of affairs in America. He said that there was too much reason to fear that the Union, which had conduced to so much prosperity and happiness, was in danger of disruption. He expressed a fervent hope that whether the Union was maintained or dissolved it would be accomplished by amicable means, so that the world might be spared the afflicting spectacle of a hostile conflict between brothers.

abstract: A private letter from a reliable source, dated at St. Augustine, Florida, January 15, states that the Coast Survey schooner Dana, in charge of F.W. DORR, had been seized by the "authorities" while that officer was absent on an expedition in connection with his duties. The vessel had been temporarily left in the custody of a citizen of that place. It has already been mentioned that the steam-tender Firefly, belonging to Lieut. FONTLEROY'S surveying party, together with the schooner Petrel, under the direction of Assistant C.O. BOUTWELL, which have been doing the triangulation on the Coast of South Carolina for two or three years, have been seized at Charleston.

abstract: It is already clear that, with the progress of events, the Federal Government and the Northern States are gaining rapidly in confidence and strength, while the secession movement is daily growing weaker and weaker in everything that gives permanence and dignity to great political revolutions. The Government of the United States is not, as the seceders fondly hoped and expected, to be dissolved by the refractory conduct of one, two or three, or even fifteen of its members; nor has one of its attributes or functions thus far been weakened or effaced. It retains all the prestige of legitimacy, upon which loyalty is based, and which is its warrant for prompt and efficient action. It is the Government, or the direct representation of that, under which all our great deeds have been achieved, and which have consecrated the fields of Bunker Hill, Saratoga and Yorktown. Under its fostering care the most marvelous progress the world has yet seen, in population, wealth, social comfort, mechanical invention, political science, and in the charities and humanities of life, has been made. Beyond all question, some of the Northern States present examples of the most perfect commonwealths ever yet wrought out, testifying to the value of free institutions, and the capacity of man for self-government.
lead_paragraph: It is already clear that, with the progress of events, the Federal Government and the Northern States are gaining rapidly in confidence and strength, while the secession movement is daily growing weaker and weaker in everything that gives permanence and dignity to great political revolutions. abstract: The correspondence between Governors CURTIN, of Pennsylvania, and HICKS, of Maryland, is published. Gov. CURTIN, as the first official act of his administration, wrote to Gov. HICKS, introducing to him the Commissioners recently sent from Pennsylvania congratulating him on the firm and manly resistance with which he has opposed the efforts which, have been mad? to swerve him from the paths of duty, and tendering him assurances of all the aid that anearnest sympathy and an active cooperation in whatever measures of just conciliation may be proposed, can give him. Gov. HICKS replies, that though a slave holder, with Southern sympathies, he is ready to sacrifice life and fortune to perpetuate the Union. He had a full and free, but informal conference with the Commissioners, Messrs. PALMER, BALL and MCMICHAEL, and assured them that the people of Maryland, though strongly opposed to Mr. LINCOLN, did not intend to resist his inauguration; but, on the contrary, would assist in it, if necessary. He was also informed by the Commissioners, to reply to inquiries, that the people of Pennsylvania entertained no design of making a military display at Washington on the 4th of March.
lead_paragraph: The correspondence between Governors CURTIN, of Pennsylvania, and HICKS, of Maryland, is published. Gov. CURTIN, as the first official act of his administration, wrote to Gov. HICKS, introducing to him the Commissioners recently sent from Pennsylvania congratulating him on the firm and manly resistance with which he has opposed the efforts which, have been mad? to swerve him from the paths of duty, and tendering him assurances of all the aid that anearnest sympathy and an active cooperation in whatever measures of just conciliation may be proposed, can give him. Gov. HICKS replies, that though a slave holder, with Southern sympathies, he is ready to sacrifice life and fortune to perpetuate the Union. He had a full and free, but informal conference with the Commissioners, Messrs. PALMER, BALL and MCMICHAEL, and assured them that the people of Maryland, though strongly opposed to Mr. LINCOLN, did not intend to resist his inauguration; but, on the contrary, would assist in it, if necessary. He was also informed by the Commissioners, to reply to inquiries, that the people of Pennsylvania entertained no design of making a military display at Washington on the 4th of March.

abstract: Our reports from Charleston are interesting. The South Carolina Legislature will adjourn probably on Friday or Saturday, when the Sovereign Convention will assemble again. The Senate yesterday passed a tax bill, which increases the rate of taxation throughout the State twenty per cent. A boat manned by three men, approaching the battery on the beach at Sullivan's Island, coming with muffled oars from the direction of Fort Sumter, was hailed by the sentries, and no response being give, was fired upon. The boat returned with one man, it is said, badly wounded. Some think the object of the men in the boat was to desert; others that they hoped to be able to pass the sentries unobserved and spike the guns of the battery.

abstract: The Bank of France have this day adopted a measure which is without parallel in the history of the institution. They have raised the rate of discount 1 per cent. in one day.
lead_paragraph: The Bank of France have this day adopted a measure which is without parallel in the history of the institution. They have raised the rate of discount 1 per cent. in one day. Their charge, which was advanced from 4 1/2@5 1/2 cent, on the 2d inst., is now raised to 7, or the same as that of the Bank of England. This decision implies that the Council are determined at present to follow a correct principle. The course pursued will be far more efficacious than the poor palliative involved in making foreign purchases of gold at an artificial price. It is only by a sound policy that the contingency of a suspension of specie payments can be avoided, upon these grounds the news has been received here with satisfaction, notwithstanding the prospect of competition against our Bank for gold which it develops. The fact that both Banks are now carrying out a conservative action must tend to promote confidence. There is room to fear, however, that unfavorable effect will be produced on French trade.

abstract: Last night the capacity of the Brooklyn Academy of Music was tested to the full. Mr. RARET having advertised that he would give a Horse-Lecture at 7 1/2 o'clock on Wednesday evening, was undoubtedly delighted on receiving information, Wednesday morning, that tickets had been issued in sufficient quantities to guarantee the crowding of the entire auditorium, and that it would be unwise to sell any more. As at Niblo's, the plan was adopted of reserving the entire body of the house, and leaving the two upper tiers for the occupancy of the earliest comers, the strongest pushers and the most pertinacious squeezers. At 6 1/2 o'clock the unreserved seats, the aisles, the stalls, the tops of the pillars, and the sills of the windows were filled, and when the curtain rose there was no standing or sitting room without an occupant.

abstract: The long and manifold troubles of our State Democracy in reference to the rival Democratic organizations of this City, again threaten to be revived in aggravated form by the call for a Democratic State Convention, to consider the position of the country and the duty of the Democratic Party of the State of New-York in this crisis of our national history. There are not a few amongst the "Unterrified" who charge all the blame of the present political distractions upon, the very gentlemen of the State Central Committee who have been most active in issuing the call for this Convention, -- their averment being that, had it not been for the bitter personal hostility of Messrs. PETER CAGGER, SANDFORD E. CHURCH, and others of a like stripe, the claims of Ex-Governor HORATIO SEYMOUR would have been cheerfully acknowledged by the Democratic representatives of the South; and the nomination of such a man as SEYMOUR: -- his friends contend -- would have been equivalent to an election.
lead_paragraph: The long and manifold troubles of our State Democracy in reference to the rival Democratic organizations of this City, again threaten to be revived in aggravated form by the call for a Democratic State Convention, to consider the position of the country and the duty of the Democratic Party of the State of New-York in this crisis of our national history. lead_paragraph: Major George Middleton, of Syracuse, died in that city on the evening of Jan. 19, at the age of 91 years. He was claimed to be the senior member of the Masonic fraternity in the United States. It is said that the Major was present at the Fort Griswold massacre in Connecticut, when Col. Ledyard and most of his garrison were massacred in cold blood, after their surrender to the British under the command of the traitor Arnold.

abstract: The Tammany General Committee met last evening at Tammany Hall, the principal business being to fill vacancies in Primary Committees for the election of delegates to attend the Convention to assemble in Albany on the 31st of January. The contested seats from the Eighth and Sixteenth Wards occupied the great part of the evening. The rival partisans of DELEVAN and of COHEN, of the Eighth, and of MACKINTYRE of the Sixteenth Ward, were present in strong force, and as discussion grew warmer, the opposing parties began to interfere with each other's physiognomies, and organs nasal and visual were slightly damaged on both sides. District-Attorney WATERBURY dispatched a note to the Second Ward Station-house, which brought up Sargeant KELLY and a posse of police, who surveyed the scene and restored quiet. Afterwards Superintendent KENNEDY made his appearance to assure himself that all was right. An equal portion of delegates in favor of EMANUEL HART and of the Mckintyre ticket were admitted from the Sixteenth Ward as a compromise. In the Eighth Ward the Delevan ticket entire was admitted, and the Second Ward dispute was decided by the admission of the Union ticket.

abstract: NARROW ESCAPE. On Tuesday night last a barge took fire at the dock foot of Gold-street, and the vessel was sunk in the slip. At the time it went down ...
lead_paragraph: NARROW ESCAPE. On Tuesday night last a barge took fire at the dock foot of Gold-street, and the vessel was sunk in the slip. At the time it went down it careened, and carried down with it Mr. SIMPSON, Assistant Engineer of the Fire Department, and Mr. MONTROSE, Foreman of Hook and Ladder Company No 1. The night was one of the coldest of the season, and Messrs. SIMPSON and MONTROSE were rescued with the greatest difficulty. When taken out they were covered with ice, and were more dead than alive, but after administering proper restoratives they recovered sufficiently to walk home.

abstract: Our City Police are acting with commendable vigor in preventing the shipping of arms to the rebellious States. As a matter of ...
lead_paragraph: Our City Police are acting with commendable vigor in preventing the shipping of arms to the rebellious States. As a matter of course, they sometimes make mistakes, as when they seized muskets on Wednesday destined for South America. But the owners promptly made their appearance and claimed their property, and highly commended the vigilance of the authorities, although it had subjected them to some temporary inconvenience. But where the arms seized were really intended for hostile purposes, the owners do not call for them. They are in no hurry to bring themselves needlessly within the penalties of the law of treason.

abstract: It cannot be denied that New-York has always been and is still lamentably deficient in dwellinghouses for people of moderate incomes. For the man ...
lead_paragraph: It cannot be denied that New-York has always been and is still lamentably deficient in dwellinghouses for people of moderate incomes. For the man of wealth there is abundant accommodation; for the poorest clases some attempts -- wretched and often disgraceful, it is true, but still some attempts -- have been made; but the existence of any medium between these two extremes of poverty and wealth seems to have been entirely ignored by our building speculators. Thousands of families of the highest respectability in New-York are, therefore, driven to all the annoyances and discomforts of boarding-house life, or banished to the remotest outskirts of the City, inconveniently far from their daily business, because no one has yet understood the necessity of supplying their demand in some central and convenient locality.

abstract: The Autobiography of Dr. Alexander Carlyle, minister of Invernesk, published by TICKNOR FIELDS, is about as interesting a book of the kind as has met our observation for sometime.
lead_paragraph: The Autobiography of Dr. Alexander Carlyle, minister of Invernesk, published by TICKNOR FIELDS, is about as interesting a book of the kind as has met our observation for sometime. Notwithstanding the many ponderous platitudes which are annually palmed off upon the public, we have an especial fondness for autobiographies. When wearied with set speeches and squared stories, there is a pleasant relief in throwing one's-self at the feet of an intelligent old gentleman, and gathering the narratives which tremble on the lips of garrulous age. The same feeling of relief is experienced when we turn from the stately march of history to the easy flow of personal reminiscences. To get at the real characters and habits of the celebrities of any period, you must consult with one of their cotemporaries. The premeditated Lives, prepared by judicious friends, are very uncertain guides. You meet the object of your curiosity dressed for dinner, as it were; or in the formal attitude which people generally assume when intending to have their portraits taken. They have their company-look on. And you turn disappointedly away, wishing that you could meet them in their, every-day guise, hob-a-nob with them in their familiar haunts, and know what manner of men they actually are. We would give more for an autobiography of BEN JOHNSON than for all the elaborate lives of him and his cotemporaries that could be written.

abstract: We publish in full this morning the charge of the new City Judge to the Grand Jury, delivered in the General Sessions yesterday.
lead_paragraph: We publish in full this morning the charge of the new City Judge to the Grand Jury, delivered in the General Sessions yesterday. Many of the suggestions which it contains might, under other circumstances, be deemed simply a formal announcement of intentions never honestly entertained. Experience has taught the public hitherto, in many instances, to regard the semblance of law and justice which the criminal Bench has afforded, as only a cloak for concealing the violation of every principle of justice which interest of self or party might demand.

abstract: MY DEAR EDITOR: I hope you have not forgotten a letter written you by JERUBHA ANN BROWN she that was a Gonsobre. She asked your advice about ...
lead_paragraph: MY DEAR EDITOR: I hope you have not forgotten a letter written you by JERUBHA ANN BROWN she that was a Gonsobre. She asked your advice about seceding from her Lord and Master. Well, she has actually been and done it! I never heard anything so ridiculous in all my born days. We are all so scandalized,I tell you! And then the brazen example she has set the women folks about here is a shame and a sin. She was a church member, too, and in good standing, as far as we knew. Why, that woman has not only seceded from her husband -- a good, vigorous, noble man, handsome, too, with no fault towards her, except a blind eye to her carryings on, and a gentle rein over her, made, as you may say, of silken cobweb; but she has taken away the children as lawless as you please -- but that ain't all, dear RAYMOND, she actually insisted upon his yielding her her full income, just as if she was living with him -- and she got so enraged fit nothing, that one day in her mad pranks she cut holes in his trowsers, and spoilt one of his best suits -- a suit that he wore on general training day, and looked mighty handsome in, too! And, I do say, that was the unkindest cut of all. I always knew she was awful proud -- why, the pride and vanity of that one little woman was a sin to behold! She was so lazy that she kept as many as four helps to wait upon her alone! She never pretended to pay her bills, and when her old man let her have money for the house, she appropriated it all to herself! The main folly of all is, that she actually plumes herself that she is now sitting upon a pinnacle of greatness, and that we women-folks are going to recognize her as doing something lawful and proper -- to say nothing of the glorification she thinks men folks are going to grant her; it is so ridiculous that I am near about down sick about it.
headline: {'main': 'A Recent Case of Secession.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Recent Case of Secession.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: HABITS OF COUNT CAVOUR. This distinguished statesman has been dangerously ill, and at one time the ruiner gained currency that he was dead. His complaint, for which he was twice bled, was not of an apopleptic nature, as was at ...
lead_paragraph: HABITS OF COUNT CAVOUR. -- This distinguished statesman has been dangerously ill, and at one time the ruiner gained currency that he was dead. His complaint, for which he was twice bled, was not of an apopleptic nature, as was at first feared, but an inflammation of the digestive organs. Great fears, however, are entertained that his health will give way before his intense and incessant occupation, strong appetite, luxurious living, plethoric habits, and want of bodily exercise. He is always up and at work at 5 o'clock in the morning. From 9 till 6 1/2 in the afternoon he directs all the business of his own department, and takes a general survey of those of his more helpless colleagues. Then follows dinner, his only meal in the 24 hours, and none of the lightest. He uses no carriage, but a walk from his private residence in the Via Cavour to the Ministerial offices in the Piazza Castello is but poor relaxation. The activity of the man's mind is immeasurable. He neglects nothing, forgets nothing; no scheme of policy or diplomacy is too high, no mean detail or particular is too commonplace for him. He has an eye for everything; he trusts few men, and these generally obscure but able individuals of his own choice and creation. He writes most of his letters with his own hand. He writes a plain and distinct round French hand, with lines wide apart -- a hand of which strength and decision would not, on a first inspection, seem to be the most obvious characteristics. A whole volume might be written about the expression lurking beneath every line of the half good humoredly, half sarcastically smiling mouth. It is the smile of a man who has early found out "how little wisdom it takes to govern the world," and whose noble heart has prompted him to rule over it for its own greatest advantage.

abstract: The speech of Mr. ETHERIDGE, of Tennessee, is one of the noblest and boldest proclamations of devotion to the Union ever pronounced in Congress. It stirs the blood in ...
lead_paragraph: The speech of Mr. ETHERIDGE, of Tennessee, is one of the noblest and boldest proclamations of devotion to the Union ever pronounced in Congress. It stirs the blood in every American heart to hear a man from the South thus declare his determination to stand by the flag of his country in spite of the rebels and traitors who are striving to drag it into the dust. Mr. ETHERIDGE, like Mr. CLEMENS, of Virginia, is a Southern man, representing a Slave State, sympathizing to some extent with the complaints and apprehensions of the Slave interest. He has never been a Republican, nor has he any sympathy with the distinctive principles and purposes of the Republican Party. But he is more of a patriot than a partizan, and he loves his country better than any section or fraction of it.

abstract: The Dragoon Corps at West Point, which was ordered a few days ago to repair to the National Capital, is on its way thither by this time. They take six ...
lead_paragraph: The Dragoon Corps at West Point, which was ordered a few days ago to repair to the National Capital, is on its way thither by this time. They take six pieces of cannon, of which four are formidable field pieces, and two are howitzers, and seventy-eight splendid horses.

abstract: DEMILT DISPENSARY. At the annual meeting of the Managers of the Demilt Dispensary, held on the 21st inst., the Managers were elected for 1861.
lead_paragraph: DEMILT DISPENSARY. -- At the annual meeting of the Managers of the Demilt Dispensary, held on the 21st inst., the Managers were elected for 1861. The annual report, besides an appeal for additional support, gave the following facts in relation to the usefulness of the institution: "The whole number of new patients healed by this Dispensary, during the year 1860, was 27,378. The number vaccinated was 2,682. The number of prescriptions dispensed was 50,074. The receipts of the Treasure were -- from donations, $1,493; from New-York City. $500; from rents, 1,808 52; other sources, $11 25, Total, $3.812 77. The expenses of the Dispensary were $4,196 45, showing a deficiency of $383 63. The Dispensary owes, in addition, the sum of over $700 for salaries, medicines and supplies. The Managers assure the subscribers and the public that the affairs of the Dispensary are managed with care and fidelity upon the part of the medical staff and apothecary, and that the most rigid economy consistent with the efficient working of the Dispensary is practiced by the Board of Managers."

abstract: Brig A. Blanchard, of Boston, previously reported ashore on Napeaguet Beach, L.I., is full of water to her lower deck. As far as can be seen, she is apparently ...
lead_paragraph: Brig A. Blanchard, of Boston, previously reported ashore on Napeaguet Beach, L.I., is full of water to her lower deck. As far as can be seen, she is apparently but little injured, but her cargo will be nearly a total loss. The car go between decks is now being discharged, but will not amount to much. There is $6,000 insurance on the vessel in New-York offices, and the cargo is said to be fully insured, but it is not known whether in New-York or Boston.

abstract: The London Times greatly overrates the importance of the President's Message. It ...
lead_paragraph: The London Times greatly overrates the importance of the President's Message. It thinks the United States cannot "for many years" overcome the effect of that document. We think they have survived it already. Indeed, the President himself has almost entirely recovered from its effects. Before the Message crossed the Atlantic, the Times thought that the Federation was "of the nature of a nationality," -- clothed with all the attributes of a permanent and responsible Government. Now, it finds that it is only a partnership, from which any State may withdraw at pleasure. Let the Times console itself, and fall back upon its first impressions. Mr. BUCHANAN's Message has not turned the current of history, nor changed the nature of logic or of constitutional law. We have still in Government, -- capable of making contracts, and able to keep them. We have still a Union, -- consisting of just as many States as it ever had, -- and while in the course of a few days it will have one more, the Times may rest reasonably confident it will never haveany less.
headline: {'main': 'The Union Not Dissolved.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Union Not Dissolved.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: On the 20th of December last, in the night time, the house of Mr. Philip Sink, No. 440 Third-avenue, was broken into, and the burglars carried away $23 worth of clothing, belonging to Paulina Behli, the servant girl. While the burglars were ransacking the building Paulina discovered them and attempted to secure their apprehension, but they turned upon her and stabbed her in the head with a cold chisel, after which they escaped. On Wednesday night the same rogues made another attempt to break into the premises. Officers Rooney and Clark, of the Twenty-first Ward, found one of them upon the roof of a stable adjoining Mr. Sink's house, and the other was in the yard below. At sight of the officers they tried to escape, but were not successful, and a quantity of burglar's tools were found upon them. The prisoners names are Charles Wentworth and James Robinson, and both were identified by Paulina Behli as the individuals who had assaulted her and stolen her clothes. Justice CONNOLLY committed the burglars for trial.

abstract: A curious contest is troubling the Board of Supervisors of the city of Rochester. A native ...
lead_paragraph: A curious contest is troubling the Board of Supervisors of the city of Rochester. A native chemist had the stomach of a man supposed to have been poisoned committed to him for analysis, a short time since, and having completed his work sent in a quite moderate bill. The Supervisors did not see it in that light, and refused to allow it. Another individual has been poisoned in the vicinity, and the Coroner called upon the same chemist for an analysis, which he refused to make. The Coroner then threatened to bring the stomach to this City for examination, but the Supervisors have an idea that the chemists here demand pretty good compensation for work which they perform, and say they will not allow such a course to be taken. The matter remains in abeyance.

abstract: A letter received in Boston, dated at St. Augustine, Jan. 14, says that the secession flag was hoisted ...
lead_paragraph: A letter received in Boston, dated at St. Augustine, Jan. 14, says that the secession flag was hoisted at that place on the 12th inst, saluted by the firing of great guns, small arms and crackers. Four cannon have been taken from the fort, and placed in position on the banks of the river, ready to bid defiance to an invading force. The United Stales schooner Dana was in port, commanded by a Mr. DORR. He had been ordered to surrender her, but declined, stating, however, that she should not be taken to sea.'

abstract: Hon. VAN. R. RICHMOND, State Engineer and Surveyor, has just completed his report on the Canals of the State. The whole number of persons employed ...
lead_paragraph: Hon. VAN. R. RICHMOND, State Engineer and Surveyor, has just completed his report on the Canals of the State. The whole number of persons employed in the Engineer's Department on Dec. 31, 1860, was 62, and the total expenses were $80,657 86, of which $75,839 22 were for engineering proper. The estimiated cost of the work remaining to be done on the 1st day of January, 1861, to complete the unfinished Canals according to law, is $700,000; of which $357,975 99 is to be expended on the Erie Canal enlargement, the balance being divided between the enlargement of the locks on the Champlain Canal, the Black River Canal and Improvement, the Genesee Valley Canal and Extension. A comparison with the estimate of last year shows that this amount exceeds that then made by $47,097 87, of which $41,917 39 is for work not contemplated when the estimates were made. The fifteen per cent. retained by the laws of 1854, amounts to $176,122 33; of which $104,844 00 was on the contracts for the enlargement of the Erie Canal; $35,370 72 on those for the enlargement of the Oswego Canal. The balance is divided between the improvements on the Cayuga and Seneca, the Black River and the Genesee Valley Canals.

abstract: Police Station-houses are of multifarious use.
lead_paragraph: Police Station-houses are of multifarious use. The prime intent of their erection is, as their name implies, the furnishing of a depot for the temporary holding of the Municipal Police. But while this is the prime object of their erection, there has gradually arisen a custom' which bids fair in time to more than equal in importance the original design. We refer to the nightly lodging of destitute and homeless persons.

abstract: A public joke at P.T. BARNUM'S expense is not an every-day luxury, P.T.B. for many years having had the laugh on the other side. But at length ...
lead_paragraph: A public joke at P.T. BARNUM'S expense is not an every-day luxury, P.T.B. for many years having had the laugh on the other side. But at length the Prince of Showmen has been shown a trick that he did not know before, and the hero of the occasion has been, as is very usual on such occasions, a son of the Emerald Isle. It seems that BARNUM, a few days ago, was in a great hurry to be shaved, and entered his ordinary place of tonsorial resort under the Park Hotel; but all the operatives were engaged, and one other customer -- a great brawny Irishman, just landed, and with a beard and head requiring very extensive attention -- stood between the exhibitor of the "What-is-it?" and his turn as "next." "I am in a hurry, my good man!" said PHINEAS T., addressing Pat; "and if you give me your "turn I will pay for what you want done here." "All right," responded the delighted Irishman; and the showman was soon shaved and on his way to keep his engagement, merely saying as he left the door to the proprietor of the saloon, "Do what this man wants," pointing to the exile of Erin, "and charge it to me." No sooner was he gone than PATRICK took off his "trusty," and a thick cotton neck-tie, at the same time asking the barber, "Now tell me all you do?" "Why, Sir," responded the tonsorial operative, "we shave, cut and curl hair, shampoo and bathe." "All right, then," said PAT; "Do all them things to me. Sorra wan of me knows what they mane, but as he said he'd pay for them, just do them all, an' God bless you!" The barber saw the joke and did as requested, putting the big Irishman through all the processes, and bringing him out so pleasantly altered that he scarely knew himself. We leave our readers to imagine 'BARNUM's face next morning, when the proprietor of the saloon handed him a bill -- " For shaving irishman 10 cents, cutting his hair 25 cents, curling it 25 cents, shampooing it 25 cents, and bathing Irishman 25 cents -- total for Irish man $1 10." BARNUM at once acknowledged the com -- gave a receipt for the maize; but he is after the Irish exile, and swears, if he catches him, that he will place him check-by-jowl between the "What is it?" and the Aztec children.

abstract: The work of examining the qualifications of the candidates for the Police force is going on daily at the office of the Police Commissioners. About one ...
lead_paragraph: The work of examining the qualifications of the candidates for the Police force is going on daily at the office of the Police Commissioners. About one hundred have thus far been found duly qualified and sworn into office, and as many more have been rejected as not coming up to the required standard. A large majority of the new appointees bear Irish names, which, in the absence of other explanation, would seem to indicate superior mental and physical qualifications on the part of Ribernia's sons. The examination is very rigid, and many are the dodges resorted to by the candidates to pass the ordeal. They are required to read and write, and to stand five feet eight in their stocking feet The test of the first qualification was, for awhile, decided by their ability to read a sign on the opposite side of the street to the Commissioners' office, but this had to be abandoned after a short trial, as it was found that the candidates bad got wind of the fact, and those who were not able to spell out the sign had sought the aid of their more gifted friends, and committed it to memory. Those who can read, and yet lack the required stature, sometimes resort to other dodges not less artful. One candidate, after taking off his boots and being measured, was found to reach the exact height required, but on a closer inspection he was discovered to have concealed under the soles of his feet, inside his stockings, two folded newspapers, thereby adding to his height, and at the same time confirming his literary claims. Notwithstanding his ingenuity, however, the man was rejected.

abstract: The Governor of Georgia is determined, it seems, that there shall be no doubt about his treasonable intentions towards the Federal Government. Yesterday ...
lead_paragraph: The Governor of Georgia is determined, it seems, that there shall be no doubt about his treasonable intentions towards the Federal Government. Yesterday at the head of seven hundred State troops, he demanded the surrender of the Arsenal at Augusta, which demand -- opposition on the part of the few United States troops stationed there being out of the question -- was complied with.

abstract: A snow-storm of the ancient type set in yesterday morning at 5 o'clock, the wind blowing fresh from E.N.E. Throughout the day the snow continued, ...
lead_paragraph: A snow-storm of the ancient type set in yesterday morning at 5 o'clock, the wind blowing fresh from E.N.E. Throughout the day the snow continued, and at 2 o'clock there was a fall of some six inches, giving good promise of sleighing. At 4 o'clock the temperature grew milder, and the snow turned to rain, dashing all hopes of sleigh rides, and rendering travel more uncomfortable, for both man and beast, than it has been known since last Winter. Considerable delay in the arrivals of trains was caused by the storm. There have been but few arrivals from sea. Pilots who have come in report the wind outside the hook from E.N.E., and blowing a gale. The ship Liverpool, Capt. KEARNEY, from London, is near the Middle, in the Lower Bay, with both anchors down, and 75 fathoms of chain out to each. There is another ship in the Bay, outward bound. The British brig Boomerang, of Dundee, 92 days from Newcastle, short of provisions, was towed up to the City from the Lower Bay.

abstract: The snow storm of Thursday appears to have been more severe on the Harlem Railroad than anywhere else. All along the road the snow has drifted more or less, in some places the drifts reaching to the top of the cars. Between Hillsdale and Millerton the snow ...
lead_paragraph: The snow storm of Thursday appears to have been more severe on the Harlem Railroad than anywhere else. All along the road the snow has drifted more or less, in some places the drifts reaching to the top of the cars. Between Hillsdale and Millerton the snow is said to be from eight to ten feet high, and packed so hard that it was impossible to proceed without digging through. A gang of between one and two hundred men were at work all yesterday with picks and shovels, between these villages.

abstract: ANOTHER EXCITEMENT. Information was received at the Police Head-quarters last evening that a large quantity of powder had been shipped on board of schooner (suposed to be the Bergen) for a Southern port. The powder, according to the rumor, ...
lead_paragraph: ANOTHER EXCITEMENT. Information was received at the Police Head-quarters last evening that a large quantity of powder had been shipped on board of schooner (suposed to be the Bergen) for a Southern port. The powder, according to the rumor, was taken from the Union stores, near the foot of Degraw-street. The Police made a pretty thorough search of the river front between Fulton Ferry and Gowanus Bay, but up to a late hour last night the powder had not been found. It would have been seized under the Fire law.

abstract: The United States Grand Jury met yesterday, and after a brief consultation, adjourned without examining any witnesses. They meet again on Monday, when it is understood they will have before them certain parties prominently engaged in the purchase of arms, and in their shipment to Southern ports. The Police have their eyes on steamboats and Railroad cars by which arms are shipped from manufactories in Connecticut and elsewhere, and they have orders not to relax their efforts for the seizure of all war munitions found on their way South. Threats of retaliation from the South, Mr. KENNEDY says, will not influence him in the discharge of his duty. While acting with caution, he intends to permit no surreptitious shipment of arms or munitions through this District which he has reason to believe are destined for the States now in open rebellion against this Government. Orders have been issued to have the seizure mace without delay, so that there is not likely to be another escape like that of the steamer Montgomery.

abstract: MELANCHOLY SUICIDE OF A YOUNG MAN. Coroner O'KEEFE held an inquest yesterday, at No. 183 Third-avenue, upon the body Of STEPHEN AUGUSTUS PERINE, a native of this State, 24 years of age, until recently a clerk in the Register's office, who committed suicide by taking prussic acid.
lead_paragraph: MELANCHOLY SUICIDE OF A YOUNG MAN. -- Coroner O'KEEFE held an inquest yesterday, at No. 183 Third-avenue, upon the body Of STEPHEN AUGUSTUS PERINE, a native of this State, 24 years of age, until recently a clerk in the Register's office, who committed suicide by taking prussic acid. The father of deceased testified that since his son had been unemployed he had contracted debts which he was unable to pay, and his misfortunes had a very depressing effect. During the last few days of his life his dejection had increased to such an extent that it was feared he would go crazy, and a proposition was under consideration to place him in a Lunatic Asylum. On Thursday morning, after breakfasting, deceased went to his room, and in a short time his father heard a singular noise proceeding from the apartment. Going thither, he found the young man lying on the bed in the agonies of death, and two vials, which had contained prussic acid, beside him. Physicians were sent for, but his death occurred before they reached the house. Doctor CHARLES GALLAGHER testified to having made a post-mortem examination of the body, and finding prussic acid in the stomach in sufficient quantity to produce death. Mr. PERINE has left a wife and child.

abstract: George F. Clayton, residing at No. 283 West Twenty-fourth-street, yesterday caused the arrest of Arthur Wesley, a real estate agent at No. 402 Fourthavenue, on a charge of swindling him out of $100.
lead_paragraph: George F. Clayton, residing at No. 283 West Twenty-fourth-street, yesterday caused the arrest of Arthur Wesley, a real estate agent at No. 402 Fourthavenue, on a charge of swindling him out of $100. The complainant alleged before Justice KELLY that the accused wanted to borrow the sum mentioned, and agreed if he would let him have the amount to give him a situation as clerk at $7 per week, and also furnish security on certain furniture and fixtures. After obtaining the money Wesley refused to carry out the agreement in any of its particulars. He was required to give bail to answer the charge.

abstract: Gen. BARRIOS, President of Salvador, was on his way to visit President CARRERA, of Guatemala. He is accompanied by his wife, 50 soldiers, and 21 officers and attendants. President BARRIOS is very uneasy ...
lead_paragraph: Gen. BARRIOS, President of Salvador, was on his way to visit President CARRERA, of Guatemala. He is accompanied by his wife, 50 soldiers, and 21 officers and attendants. President BARRIOS is very uneasy and ambitious, and it is said wishes to inveigle President CABRERA into an alliance with him, the object being to conquer the two States of Honduras and Nicaragua, Guatemala to annex Honduras, and Salvador to annex Nicaragua. But BARRIOS is getting so unpopular at home that it was generally expected a revolution would break out in his State as soon as he left it. That the people have not risen against him must be attributed to the fact that he keeps a large army, and pays his soldiers before anybody else except himself. To show how sharp the President is after the "dimes," it is only necessary to say that he has several times been caught at smuggling through his own Custom houses. Once, some boxes, said to contain Government arms,&c., were found filled with costly silks and other goods, upon which the tariff is very high.

abstract: The Herald, which is the organ and agent of the Disunionists for the North, is very indignant at the Police for interfering with the shipment of arms and munitions of war to those States which are waging war upon the Federal Government.
lead_paragraph: The Herald, which is the organ and agent of the Disunionists for the North, is very indignant at the Police for interfering with the shipment of arms and munitions of war to those States which are waging war upon the Federal Government. It denounces this proceeding as a "high-handed outrage," and suggests that the offending Policemen are "indictable for robbery." On that point the Police may very safely rely on the verdict of a jury. Whether they have full technical warrant of law for these seizures of arms or not, they may trust, with full confidence, to the patriotism of their fellow-citizens for support in the discharge of an imperative duty.

abstract: The secession movement in its magnitude and rapidity took the North completely by surprise. It was natural it should be so.
lead_paragraph: The secession movement in its magnitude and rapidity took the North completely by surprise. It was natural it should be so. We went into the Presidential contest with all the earnestness which questions of the deepest moral significance and material welfare could impart. But however much we might wish to confine Slavery within its present limits, or expel from power the FLOYDS, THOMPSONS and COBBS, -- names which must forever stand as synonyms of official incompetency, baseness and treachery, and who well nigh subverted the fair fabric of our Government, and have disgraced and humiliated us in the eyes of the world, -- yet respect for law was the paramount sentiment, and if we had been beaten, we should like good citizens have submitted to the result, and commenced training for a new contest. The idea of displacing the constituted authorities in any other than a legal way, or of not yielding prompt obedience to whomsoever might have been elected, was not so much as thought of. We had no other objects than those presented by the issue; no aims but a well-ordered Government under which to cultivate the arts of peace. We had no provinces to annex, no new confederacies to form, no institutions to propagate, save in the line of our industries.

abstract: The Toronto Leader announces in the most positive terms that "it is the intention of the English Government to acknowledge the independence of the Southern Confederacy as soon as it is formed." We do not believe a word of it.
lead_paragraph: The Toronto Leader announces in the most positive terms that "it is the intention of the English Government to acknowledge the independence of the Southern Confederacy as soon as it is formed." We do not believe a word of it. We do not believe the Leader has any such authority, or that the English Government has any such intention. There has never yet been an instance in which a Canadian newspaper made the earliest announcement of the plans and purposes of the English Government. Nor has there ever been an instance in which the British Government announced its policy towards any nation, in advance of its coming into existence. The whole story is a canard. It is an humble attempt of our Canadian cotemporary to imitate the Herald. That sensation agent of secession has been busy for weeks in making the same announcement. It has proclaimed over and over again the determination of the British Government to side with the South. But nobody gives the slightest heed to its solemn assertions. They are set down as on a level with its reiterated statements, commenced nearly a week ago, that Col. HAYNE has sent in his written demands on behalf of South Carolina to the President --and that the President is "shut up in his library" preparing a reply; when no such paper has even yet been written by Col. HAYNE.

abstract: Peru. and Lima, its Capital, have been more than ordinarily tranquil the past fortnight, the Government seeming to be considerably less bellicose as respects its two enemies, Ecuador and Bolivia, and the Capital not having been treated to a single assassination, or an attempt to murder the President. Only think of it a whole fortnight of peace in Peru!

abstract: Recent events tend to initiate the barbarians into the mysteries of Oriental living. Of the Chinese Emperor, every one, even those of his own chamber, stand in the greatest imaginable awe, and on no pretext does any one ever address him save with the use of all his grand and glorious titles. It is the etiquette in the Chinese Court for the Emperor's physician to apply the same titles to his diseases as to himself and accordingly they talk of "His High and Mighty Stomach-ache," "His Imperial and Godlike Dyspepsia," and "His Eternal and Never-ending Diphtheria,"

abstract: A triple treat was promised by advertisement to such as would have faith enough to attend at Clinton Hall last evening and pay two and a-half dimes for the privilege, viz. the presence of the Union Volunteers in Zouave uniform, a lecture by F.J. TUCKER, Esq., at 7 o'clock, and a statement from a citizen of New-Orleans. The expectant audience (which ...
lead_paragraph: A triple treat was promised by advertisement to such as would have faith enough to attend at Clinton Hall last evening and pay two and a-half dimes for the privilege, viz. the presence of the Union Volunteers in Zouave uniform, a lecture by F.J. TUCKER, Esq., at 7 o'clock, and a statement from a citizen of New-Orleans. The expectant audience (which could easily have been accommodated on a Sixth-avenue car) was disappointed in all these promises. The fierce Zouaves were non est. the New-Orleans gentleman failed to appear, and Mr. TUCKER tardily presented himself to fulfill his part of the performance. Mr. TUCKER is a slim, dapper, ruddy-cheeked young gentleman, apparently of the age of the "jolly little saileur boy," and rather addicted to the Bombastes style of oratory than to the Demosthenic. Emulating the example of his immortal predecessor, Daniel Tucker, Esq., who, it will be remembered, came too late to get his supper, Mr. TUCKER came too late, and indeed, seemed somewhat tuckered out in the effort of his imposing entrance. The lecture consisted mainly of a compilation of the history of secession, and was interspersed with the highly original and instructive information that our forefathers -- WASHINGTON, WEBSTER and CLAY -- were great men; that the memory of DOUGLAS ought to be consigned to eternal infamy; that South Carolina ought not to secede; that the Union ought to be preserved; that Major ANDERSON is a hero, and that JAMES BUCHANAN, Esq., of Washington, D.C., is not doing his duty.

abstract: It strikes us that with a view to possible contingencies. Congress will do well to make provision for putting the Navy on an effective footing. Under any circumstances this important ...
lead_paragraph: It strikes us that with a view to possible contingencies. Congress will do well to make provision for putting the Navy on an effective footing. Under any circumstances this important branch of the public service ought to receive constant attention and support. But it is just now especially necessary. If the Southern States persist in their project of secession, we shall have use for the Navy. We shall need it not only for the protection of our important forts and for the enforcement of our revenue laws, but to prevent lawless aggressions of Southern fillibusters upon nations with whom we are at peace. It will become more than ever our duty to protect the friendly nations of Central America, Mexico and Cuba against the reckless adventurers who will swarm from Southern ports, in the hope to conquer new regions for the development of the peculiar institutions of the new Confederacy.
headline: {'main': 'Provide for the Navy!', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Provide for the Navy!', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A letter to the Chi cago Tribune, dated Springfield, (Ill.,) Jan. 22, says: "A Committee of three members of the Legislature of Indiana arrived to-day. They are instructed to invite Mr. LINCOLN to take Indianapolis on route when he goes to Washington. Mr. LINCOLN'S reply was ...
lead_paragraph: A letter to the Chi cago Tribune, dated Springfield, (Ill.,) Jan. 22, says: "A Committee of three members of the Legislature of Indiana arrived to-day. They are instructed to invite Mr. LINCOLN to take Indianapolis on route when he goes to Washington. Mr. LINCOLN'S reply was that he had finally decided on the route he would take, but would let them know in the course of two weeks. This delegation is composed of Messrs. R.A. CAMERON, D.C. BRANHAM and WALTER MARCU.

abstract: The Burns Club of this City, gave its annual dinner in commemoration of the birth of ROBERT BURNS, at the Fifth-avenue Hotel, last evening.
lead_paragraph: The Burns Club of this City, gave its annual dinner in commemoration of the birth of ROBERT BURNS, at the Fifth-avenue Hotel, last evening. It was the One Hundred and Second Anniversary of the event, and the countrymen of the poet gathered to the number of nearly one hundred and fifty, to do honor to it. At a little before 8 o'clock they marched in procession from the reception-room to the dining-hall, and sat down to "the canty" board "where cronies meet," which Messrs. HITCHCOCK, DARLING & Co. -- whom not to know argues a good dinner unknown -- had caused to be spread bountifully. Besides all the usual delicacies of the season, there were others, not usual on all such occasions, that were particularly seasonable. There was Scotch haggis, Scotch whisky, and genuine Scotch hilarity. The decorations were elegant and opposite. At the head of the banquet-room hung a portrait of BURNS, in a rich, carved frame, and draped with the various Clan Tartans, the St. Andrew's, St. George's and American flags.
headline: {'main': 'THE BIRTH-DAY OF ROBERT BURNS.; Dinner of the Burns Club Toasts, Songs and Speeches.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE BIRTH-DAY OF ROBERT BURNS.; Dinner of the Burns Club Toasts, Songs and Speeches.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Rochester Express, of Jan. 25, announces the conclusion of a singular lawsuit. The action was brought for the recovery of two sermons, which the plaintiff, Rev. J.R. PAGE, lost some two years since near the village of Perry, and which afterwards came into the hands of the defendant, Rev. J.B. WENTWORTH. Both clergymen resided in Perry, and were gentlemen of standing and influence in their respective denominations. The profession of the parties, as well as the circumstances of the case, contributed to give a wide publicity to the suit. By the report of the Referee, Mr. LAPHAM, of Canandaigua, the plaintiff obtains judgment for the restoration of the sermons, which was what he sought by the suit; and the two sermons are adjudged to have a pecuniary value of at least $50, -- s sum sufficient to impose the entire costs upon the defendant. The costs will not be far from $200.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. Mr. CHARLES DILLON, an English actor of high repute, made a sudden and unexpected appearance at this Theatre on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. Mr. CHARLES DILLON, an English actor of high repute, made a sudden and unexpected appearance at this Theatre on Thursday. The night was extremely inclement, and the attendance in consequence more complimentary to the actor than remunerative to the management. Mr. DILLON selected for the occasion a play long since made familiar to New-Yorkers, "Belphegor" by name, it is one of the very best pieces of its class, and the version played by Mr. DILLON struck us as being fuller and more able than the one we have naturalized on this side of the Atlantic. The gentleman's performance was of course the principal feature of interest, and in expressing our surprise at its great excellence, we shall but if echo the general feeling. Of late, we have not been accustomed to receive the best of talent from our English friends, but rather an inferior and greatly over-rated sort, which we could very readily dispense with. Mr. DILLON brought with him the usual quack hand-bills containing the opinions of the English Press, and was therefore justly viewed with suspicion by the initiated in such matters. A preparation so ridiculous was in his case assuredly unnecessary. Talent is not so plentiful here that we can afford to question it about its antecedents, and where exhibited so unmistakably as by Mr. DILLON, these need be no fear of the result. This fine artist's success was one of the most distinct we have ever placed on record. In the affecting scenes of the first act be was really superb, and this, too, without the slightest straining after effect. Mr. DILLON is natural to a point, but one degree removed from affectation; he does nothing in the usual way -- which in stage matters means the conventional way -- but trusts to the instant suggestions of a powerfully emotional nature. His voice is by no means pleasant, and is impeded with a noticeable lisp; yet these very defects are converted into excellencies by the realism of his style. The whole performance was characterized by originality and power, and under favorable circumstances would secure for the piece a long run. We trust that Mr. DILLON will have another opportunity of appearing before our public.

abstract: Among the great elements developing into the active life of cotemporary history, John Chinaman must not be forgotten.
lead_paragraph: Among the great elements developing into the active life of cotemporary history, John Chinaman must not be forgotten. The youngest of our readers can recall the time when the first exodus of these eccentric Orientals into the Western world and civilized service look place, and the oldest remember no emigration so extensive as theirs promises to become. Extremely industrious, docile and temperate, the Chinese coolie is certainly capable of being useful, while as regards the supply, it is self-evident that the swarming millions of the Flowery Kingdom are capable, without diminution, of supplying the world with labor. And there are indications that France, at least, is about to make a vigorous effort on a grand scale, to fill her Algerine and cotton-producing provinces with these extremely cheap operatives.

abstract: KENTUCKY, which holds the ashes of HENRY CLAY, stands by the Union! Her Legislature refuses to secede, or to call a Convention to consider the propriety of such a step. She stands by the Constitution, and will seek the redress of whatever wrongs she suffers, under its authority and on the basis of its guarantees, rather than by destroying it and trusting to the chances of civil war.

abstract: It was just as well for the credit of our City Inspector that he had not (as he says) the "official data of the mortality of London for 1860," before he made out his report on the health of the City for the past year, as it must have modified very materially his statement that "the difference of mortality either way (between New-York and London) cannot be very great."
lead_paragraph: It was just as well for the credit of our City Inspector that he had not (as he says) the "official data of the mortality of London for 1860," before he made out his report on the health of the City for the past year, as it must have modified very materially his statement that "the difference of mortality either way (between New-York and London) cannot be very great." For, while the mortality of New-York shows an increase for the year of 1,085 over 1859, in London, on the other hand, notwithstanding the far greater increase of population, there is the most remarkable absolute decrease. In each successive quarter of the year the effect of the energetic measures of the medical officers of health has shown itself in a great diminution of the deaths. To mention only the last half of 1860: in the quarter ending Sept. 29, the deaths were less by 3,094 than in the corresponding period of the previous year, while in the last quarter of the year they were less by 1,109 than the corrected average mortality for a corresponding period during the ten previous years.
headline: {'main': 'Health of New-York and London.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Health of New-York and London.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: When recently the public ear was shocked by the report of a murder in Twelfth-street, perpetrated with every circumstance of brutality, and while as yet even conjecture failed to point at the probable assassin, we expressed the opinion that the inherent character of the act was inconsistent with any other supposition than that it was the work of a lunatic.
lead_paragraph: When recently the public ear was shocked by the report of a murder in Twelfth-street, perpetrated with every circumstance of brutality, and while as yet even conjecture failed to point at the probable assassin, we expressed the opinion that the inherent character of the act was inconsistent with any other supposition than that it was the work of a lunatic. The subsequent arrest of ALFRED BUCHANAN, a half idiotic youth, and the facts elicited on an investigation by the Coroner, reduced that opinion to a moral certainty; to which on Saturday the verdict of a Jury in the highest criminal Court in the State added the sanction of a legal decision.

abstract: EDWARD CORNING, for many years one of our most prominent and upright merchants, and President of the Hardware Trade Association, died on Saturday afternoon, at his residence in Brooklyn. Few men of his age could be taken away from us who would be more missed. His counsels were at all times based upon the strictest construction of Christian duty; his life was active in the channels of business, and fruitful in the nobler paths of life, while he was noted at home and abroad for liberality, love of justice and spotless integrity. He has held many prominent and official positions in this City and in Brooklyn, in all of which he merited and received the commendation of his constituents. As a member of Plymouth Church, he was distinguished for his piety, his zeal in the cause of his Master, and his desire for the good of others. His funeral services will be held in Ply mouth Church on Thursday afternoon.

abstract: HIGHWAY ROBBERIES ARRESTS. PETER FLAHERTY, M.J. WHITE and D.L. WELSH, carpenters, residing in Grand, near Third-street, were arrested at an early hour yesterday morning by the Police of the Fifth Precinct, at the instance of PETER B. ROSS, of No. 253 Second-street, New-York, who alleges that the parties above named attempted to rob him by the use of violence, on Saturday night last, while he was passing through Grand-street.
lead_paragraph: HIGHWAY ROBBERIES ARRESTS. PETER FLAHERTY, M.J. WHITE and D.L. WELSH, carpenters, residing in Grand, near Third-street, were arrested at an early hour yesterday morning by the Police of the Fifth Precinct, at the instance of PETER B. ROSS, of No. 253 Second-street, New-York, who alleges that the parties above named attempted to rob him by the use of violence, on Saturday night last, while he was passing through Grand-street. The accused were committed to await an examination....JOSEPH, WILLIAM and MARY BOGERT were arrested Saturday night by Officer LEICH, of the Ninth Precinct, on complaint of PETER LYNCH, who says that they robbed him a few nights ago of a pistol and $2 in money. The complainant resides in Flatbush, and at the time referred to, he was passing through Classon-avenue, on his way home. Upon reaching Sackett-street, the parties named, assisted by one or two other persons, whose names he does not know, laid violent hands upon him and took the money and property named from his person and then permitted him to depart. The accused were committed for trial.

abstract: There is a very general demand for some measures of Compromise in order to save the Border States. Men who hold in disgust and ...
lead_paragraph: There is a very general demand for some measures of Compromise in order to save the Border States. Men who hold in disgust and horror the flagrant and baseless treason of the Gulf States, insist that the Border States may be saved to the Union by concessions on the part of the North, -- and that every consideration of duty to them and to the Country demands that these concessions should at once be made. "Is not the Union worth so much as this?" is the pertinent and forcible question with which they press their requisition.

abstract: The usual Monday performance at the Academy of Music will not take place to-night, in consequence of a ball, for which the house has been sub let.
lead_paragraph: The usual Monday performance at the Academy of Music will not take place to-night, in consequence of a ball, for which the house has been sub let. We say the usual performance, because whilst we have a season we naturally expect one on Monday, as well as Wednesday and Friday, but there seems a strong probability that we shall not long boast of having a season at all. The attendance last week, notwithstanding much musical and artistic attraction, was so discreditably small, that the associate artists are undoubtedly justified in closing the doors on any night they choose, and it is rumored that they will assuredly do so if the next night or two does not afford them greater encouragement. In the meantime, our friends on the other side of the East River are warming to the operatic muse, and showing by liberal attendance and kindly appreciation, that they do not regard the erection of a handsome building as the only thing that is necessary to the permanent success of their undertaking. It seems indeed at present as though Brooklyn would take the lead in supporting Italian opera, and New York sink into the condition of a mere dependence, a place where one or two performances may perhaps be given at certain favorable periods of the year. There can be no apology for the miserable neglect with which our Fourteenth-street establishment is treated. Hard though the times may be, they are certainly no worse in New-York than in the City of Churches. It is the disposition that is wanting here. Our Academy, with its legions of free-admissionists, is no longer a pet toy with the classes for whom it was erected, and the general public has never been reconciled to the restrictions with which it is hampered in regard to seats and stockholders privileges. It seems to be "played out." Our Brooklyn friends are of course jubilant over their novelty, and will for several seasons cheerfully support a good company and an enterprising management. These, it seems to us, they have fully secured in the present organization. The best of ourtstablished favorites are COLSON, PHILLIPS, BRIGNOLI, SUSINI and FERRI; the most promising of debutantes is Miss HINCKLEY; the ables tof Italian opera conductors is Mr. MUZIO; the politest of managers, Mr. GROW. To this competent list must be added the name of Signorina ELENA, a young prima donna who is said to possess every qualification for success, and who will shortly make her debut in a new opera. The second performance of "Il Giuramento" was so dismally attended on Friday night that we can scarcely hope it will interest a large class of our readers to announce that " Il Trovatore" will be played to-morrow evening. Still for the benefit of the stockholders, the press, and especially of Miss HINKLEY, who is to make her second appearance as Leonore, we announce the fact. A larger community will learn with pleasure that VERDI's agreeable opera of the "Sicilian Vespers" will be given to-night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and to hear that there will be three performances at the latter establishment and two at the Four-tenth street one, during the present week. Thus have the mighty fallen.

abstract: The Sixth Annual Anniversary of the New-York Woman's Hospital was held at the Hospital, No. 83 Madison-avenue, on Saturday last, at 12 o'clock, Hon. JAMES W. BEEKMAN presiding. Rev. Mr. MONTGOMERY opened the proceedings with prayer. Mrs. DOREMUS read the Treasurer's Report, showing the receipts of the hospital for the year just past to have been $8,511 36, its disbursements $8,958 08, and the unpaid bills $726 88.
lead_paragraph: The Sixth Annual Anniversary of the New-York Woman's Hospital was held at the Hospital, No. 83 Madison-avenue, on Saturday last, at 12 o'clock, Hon. JAMES W. BEEKMAN presiding. Rev. Mr. MONTGOMERY opened the proceedings with prayer. Mrs. DOREMUS read the Treasurer's Report, showing the receipts of the hospital for the year just past to have been $8,511 36, its disbursements $8,958 08, and the unpaid bills $726 88. Dr. SIMMS then read the Report of the Executive Committee, from which it appeared that the limited pecuniary embarrassments of the Institution, compared with those under which it has labored heretofore, is mainly due to the increased number of paying patients, to the increased price of their board, to the Treasurer's systematic collection of the board dues in advance, and to a legacy of $500 left by Hon. BENJAMIN F. BUTLER to the State Woman's Hospital, and loaned by the Board of Governors to the New-York Woman's Hospital. The patients however, are mostly persons dependent upon the precarious earnings of a husband or a parent, or upon their own little earnings or savings, and owing to the severity of the times they fear that it will be impossible for many to pay this Winter at all, and indeed there are some who are already alarmed, on this acccount. Instances of this kind are stated in the Report, and one instance is mentioned of a patient who has hitherto paid regularly, but who now, from want of means, is no longer able to do so, and who has been transferred to the Free Ward of the Hospital, and there retained. The executive Committee fear that there will be a falling off from the receipts of the institution during the ensuing Winter, growing out of this cause. During the past year 130 patients have been admitted, of whom 99 have been discharged, 41 permanently relieved, 52 perfectly cured, 2 deceased, and 4 incurable. The rest are still in the Hospital. The increased amount of donations of goods, provisions, &c., during the past year, has in some measure made up for the lack of pecuniary donations. The share of the institution in the State appropriation to charitable institutions in New-York City has been lost, and the reserved fund, being the remains of $10,000 donated by the State several years ago, will not be more than enough to pay the next quarter's rent. There are at present in the Hospital 132 patients -- 17 paying and 15 free. The out-door patients still continue to come on Fridays in great numbers, to receive gratuitous treatment. The report contained, also, a list of the donations received by the institution, and which were of many and various kinds.

abstract: Officer Randall, of the Third Ward, yesterday arrested two boys, named John McDermott and John Dignon, whom he found in Mr. Wm. S. Napier's fruit-store, No. 247 Fulton-street. The rogues had entered by forcing the basement door, and McDermott first explored the premises, leaving Dignon to watch against a surprise. He returned from the place, reporting that be could find nothing but fruit, and advised his confederate to make a search, hoping he would meet better success. Dignon had made his investigations, and was ascending the cellar steps on his return, when the police appeared, at night of whom McDermott, who was holding the cellar door, slammed it down and ran. He was captured after a short race, and upon returning to the store, the officer found the other lad lying helpless at the bottom of the cellar steps, having been struck on the head by the door when his confederate slammed it down. Justice KELLY committed the prisoners for trial

abstract: Mr. RAREY has capped the climax and closed his performances for the present. For several weeks past he has stirred up, with a very long pole, the equine circles of this metropolis, from which he has extracted fame and money.
lead_paragraph: Mr. RAREY has capped the climax and closed his performances for the present. For several weeks past he has stirred up, with a very long pole, the equine circles of this metropolis, from which he has extracted fame and money. He deserves both, and no's got 'em. With deep regret, everybody, "rich men, poor men, beggar men and thieves," read that on Saturday afternoon Mr. RAREY would bid farewell to the Niblonian boards and go to parts unknown. As a natural consequence, despite the snow, the ice, and the "inclemency of the weather," all creation went to see him. The house was fuller than ever before, the people more anxious than ever before, and Mr. RAREY's pockets were distended more than ever before.
