abstract: On the 10th of January the Lord Mayor of York entertained a large number of gentlemen. In the course of a speech delivered in reply to the toast of Her Majesty's Ministers, Sir C. WOOD said: It is not a little surprising that on the other side of the Atlantic, while in Italy different nations are struggling for liberty by unity, a great and free nation is abusing its liberty in order to effect a separation. It seems to me too early at present to look forward to what the issue of the strife may be. All I can say at present is to express a fervent hope, that among a nation of kinsmen, allied by blood and by every feeling with us, their soil may not be polluted with civil war and intestine commotion. [Cheers.] Thank God from this country we have long removed the stain and crime of Slavery and the Slave-trade; and we in this country May well be proud that we took no small part in effecting the triumph -- a triumph as it was to humanity and every good feeling, and profitable to ourselves, as we may see by the example of those counties who have not done so. It was in the last century we returned one of the greatest champions of abolition for years, Mr. WILLERFORCE; and it was on the last occasion on which the united county sent members to Parliament, I myself took part in on election when we sent one of the last and ablest champions who struck the last blow against the enemy, in the person of HENRY BROUGHAM. [Cheers.]

abstract: Last Christmas Eve, JOSEPH SUTCLIFFE, steward of the schooner William and Mary, lying at the foot of Thirty-fifth-street, North River, went ashore with another of the crew, for the purpose of making purchases. While passing through Thirty-ninth-street, ...
lead_paragraph: Last Christmas Eve, JOSEPH SUTCLIFFE, steward of the schooner William and Mary, lying at the foot of Thirty-fifth-street, North River, went ashore with another of the crew, for the purpose of making purchases. While passing through Thirty-ninth-street, on their way back to the vessel, and when near Tenth-avenue, a number of ruffians attacked and robbed them, leaving SUTCLIFFE almost dead upon the sidewalk, but not injuring his companion to such a degree as to prevent his crawling away from the place and finally reaching the vessel. In the course of the night, SUTCLIFFE, still insensible from the blows of his assailants, was found by two policemen, and conveyed to Bellevue Hospital, where he received medical attention. His injuries, however, proved of a fatal character, his skull having been broken, and, after lingering several days in an unconscious condition, he died. The Coroner's investigation failed to discover the names of the murderers, but enough testimony was obtained to afford the police a basis for further inquiry. A few days after the inquest had been closed Officer IRVING, of the Twentieth Ward, apprehended five men, suspected of implication in the murder, one of whom, JEREMIAH FLYNN alias Blueskin, was positively identified by SUTCLIFFE's companion. These persons were all committed to prison by one of the Police Justices, and the officer continued his investigations with the object of securing indisputable evidence against them. A few days since he was informed that JOHN MCVEY. a lad twelve years of age, knew something about the matter, and during an interview with the boy, he made a statement to the following effect, not, however, without having first exhibited a great deal of reluctance to say anything:

abstract: On Saturday afternoon a carman named SPELLMAN conveyed two barrels marked "J.W. WARD, Newark, N.J.," to the Jersey City Ferry, and requested the freight agent to have them forwarded.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday afternoon a carman named SPELLMAN conveyed two barrels marked "J.W. WARD, Newark, N.J.," to the Jersey City Ferry, and requested the freight agent to have them forwarded. Such a sickening stench proceeded from them, however, that the agent refused to accept them as freight, and upon questioning the carman he was told that they had come from the Homoeopathic Medical College, at the corner of Third-avenue and Twentieth-street. Suspecting that they contained human remains, the agent sent word to the Coroner's office, and had them taken to the Third Ward Station-house. Coroner SCHIRMER afterwards had them opened, and they were found to contain the flesh of a human being in an advanced stage of decay, besides two dead dogs, a dead cat and a mass of other corruption. The barrels were removed to Bellevue Hospital dead-house, where an inquiry with reference to the matter will be held to-day.

abstract: The recent visit of His Royal Highness, the Prince of Wales, was productive of a decided sensation amongst the artists of the Provinces, and of the United States.
lead_paragraph: The recent visit of His Royal Highness, the Prince of Wales, was productive of a decided sensation amongst the artists of the Provinces, and of the United States. Hardly had his royal feet touched the Canadian shore, when the residence of the Governor-General was besieged by representatives of the illustrated papers, who desired photographs of the Prince and of his suite, that they might be reproduced in wood-cuts for the next week's paper. Each and every daguerrean artist, every photographer, and all the lithographers in the country, bothered, pestered, perplexed and waylaid the attendants of the future King, that through their influence his English born, but Teutonic fashioned countenance, might attract the passers of their gallery windows. The entire party were taken at least forty times prior to their advent into this Confederacy. Standing, sitting, grouped, singly, on foot, on horseback, and in carriage of state, in every conceivable way, shape and manner, were these regal visitors compelled to gaze, with winning smile, at the round glass mouth of the camera. The same fate awaited him and them in the land of the free and the home of the brave. Gazing pensively at the roaring Niagara; attired in velvet coat, short pants and high boots, upon the game-crowded prairies; dressed "to kill" in the gorgeous saloon of BRADY, shedding the sympathizing tear at Mount Vernon, or biding with Mayor HOWARD, of Portland, at the very hour of his departure, the same merciless class pursued him, and seizing a favorable opportunity, have sent him, his clothes and his surroundings, into every city, town and village of this vast Republic. Nor was this all; the limners have painted him, the carvers have sculped him, and the draughtsmen have crayoned him.

abstract: The Louisiana State Convention, on Saturday, passed the ordinance of secession, in the same terms in which it was originally reported from the Special Committee of Fifteen, to whom the duty of preparing it had been intrusted.
lead_paragraph: The Louisiana State Convention, on Saturday, passed the ordinance of secession, in the same terms in which it was originally reported from the Special Committee of Fifteen, to whom the duty of preparing it had been intrusted. The vote on its passage stood, 113 for to 17 against it. A delay ordinance, proposed to be substituted for the Committee's report, was voted down on Friday by a large majority. It was the evident intention of the leaders in the Convention to discountenance delay in every possible manner, and the final action was pressed with almost indecent haste. As an evidence of a determination to disregard even the wishes of the people of the State, it is only necessary to say that a proposition to submit the ordinance to the popular vote was voted down, 84 to 45. The resolution accompanying the ordinance, declaring the right of free navigation of the Mississippi and its tributaries by all "friendly powers," was passed unanimously. The Convention then adjourned to meet again in New-Orleans on the 29th. Six States have now declared their connection with the Union dissevered -- South Carolina on the 20th of December, Mississippi on the 9th of January, Florida and Alabama on the 11th, Georgia on the 19th, and Louisiana on the 26th.

abstract: The examination in the case of Buchanan, the Twelfth-street murderer, then proceeded. lead_paragraph: The examination in the case of Buchanan, the Twelfth-street murderer, then proceeded. When the prisoner came into Court, the most affectionate greetings were exchanged between him and his mother, and other female relatives who were in attendance. He and they were moved to tears. The prisoner, during the examination, sat with the listless appearance of a little child, constantly changing his position as if fatigued with sitting. On Friday, while he was waiting for the examination to commence, he sat beside the prisoner Hochreitter, who had just been sentenced to prison for life, on a conviction of murder, and buried himself in extracting the handkerchief from the pocket of the latter prisoner, who, discovering the depredation, checked its progress with an apparent feeling that he was suffering "insult aided to injury." A few minutes later, when one of the officers of the Court passed before Buchanan with his handkerchief visible from his pocket, the prisoner manifested a strong propensity to lay hold of the tempting linen.

abstract: Coroner JACKMAN yesterday commenced an investigation at Believue Hospital, with reference to the decomposed human remains which, on Saturday, came into possession of the police. Dr. ISAAC M. WARD,
lead_paragraph: Coroner JACKMAN yesterday commenced an investigation at Believue Hospital, with reference to the decomposed human remains which, on Saturday, came into possession of the police. Dr. ISAAC M. WARD, one of the Professors at the Homoeopathic College, corner of Twentieth-street and Third-avenue, testified that the remains had been taken from the College at his order, for interment at a farm belonging to him near Newark, N.J. He had requested the janitor to collect the refuse matter from the dissecting-tables and pack it carefully in barrels for that purpose. The janitor carried out the order, and desiring to get rid of several cats and dogs, which had been subjects of physiological experiments, he took the responsibility of throwing them in the barrels with the human remains. The Coroner postponed further examination into the matter until to-day, and in the interval he intends to consult the District-Attorney in reference to the disposition of the remains.

abstract: We have an offset for one of the seceding States at all events. KANSAS is at last a member of the Union. After a struggle without precedent in its character she has at length been admitted into the Confederacy. The House yesterday concurred in the amendment of the Senate and the bill became a law. If this had been done two years ago we might have been saved from the embarrassments and perils that now involve the country. Kansas has been kept out of the Union because she was not a Slave State. Every expedient which reckless ingenuity could devise has been resorted to from time to time to prevent her admission unless she would come in as a Slave State. All have proved unavailing, and she is at last a member of the Federal Union.
lead_paragraph: We have an offset for one of the seceding States at all events. KANSAS is at last a member of the Union. All have proved unavailing, and she is at last a member of the Federal Union.

lead_paragraph: On the 11th of last December, Capt. George F. Lemon, well-known as Captain of one of the steamboats plying to Long Branch, N.J., was arrested on a charge of seduction, the complainant being Mrs. Ophelia Taylor, widow of Joseph L. Taylor, formerly Street Commissioner. Justice Welsh took the affidavit in the case at Mrs. Taylor's house, having been summoned thither by a note bearing the complainant's own signature. The Magistrate found her in a very weak condition, having three days before given birth to twins, whose paternity she charged upon the Captain. Yesterday, however, Mrs. Taylor appeared at the Tombs and made the following affidavit, contradicting the main features of her previous statement, and upon the strength of it the complaint against Capt Lemon most likely will be dismissed:

lead_paragraph: The case of the United States against Capt. Samuel Brooks, of the British steamship Kangaroo, charged with bringing over, in May last, an excess of 200 passengers over and above the number she is permitted to take under passenger regulations, came up for examination yesterday before the United States Commissioners' Court. The only witness examined was Capt. J. Caffey, from the Custom House, who assisted in measuring the ship's passenger space.

abstract: Capt. SAMUEL G. REID died at his residence, in this City, yesterday afternoon, after an illness of three days, in the 77th year of his age. Capt. REID was in command of the privateer brig General Armstrong, which was attacked in the neutral port of Fayal, just at the close of the last war with England, by three English vessels of war. The action was very severe, and was conducted with signal gallantry and Skill by Capt. REID. He was an officer of great bravery, and a gentleman highly esteemed for private worth.
lead_paragraph: Capt. SAMUEL G. REID died at his residence, in this City, yesterday afternoon, after an illness of three days, in the 77th year of his age. Capt. abstract: We have at last received some definite information relative to the mission of Col. HAYNE to Washington. He was instructed by Gov. PICKENS, it seems, to demand the surrender of Fort Sumter to the State authorities of South Carolina, but at the instance of Southern Congressmen, delayed doing so until he could receive further instructions. It transpired in Executive Session of the South Carolina Legislature, yesterday, that he will be again instructed peremptorily to demand the surrender of the Fort -- the alternative being an immediate attack upon it.
lead_paragraph: We have at last received some definite information relative to the mission of Col. HAYNE to Washington. He was instructed by Gov. PICKENS, it seems, to demand the surrender of Fort Sumter to the State authorities of South Carolina, but at the instance of Southern Congressmen, delayed doing so until he could receive further instructions. It transpired in Executive Session of the South Carolina Legislature, yesterday, that he will be again instructed peremptorily to demand the surrender of the Fort -- the alternative being an immediate attack upon it.

abstract: The Constitution of South Carolina, which has never been abrogated or altered, provides that the legislative authority of the State is vested in the Senate and House of Representatives. Without an amendment of the Constitution no laws can be passed by any body of men, except the Legislature, which can have force as laws. "The State of South Carolina," as an organized State, can speak only through the regular departments of the State Government. The act of secession and all the so-called acts of the late Secession Convention are, in no proper sense, the acts of South Carolina -- much less are they the acts of the legislative power of the State.
lead_paragraph: The Constitution of South Carolina, which has never been abrogated or altered, provides that the legislative authority of the State is vested in the Senate and House of Representatives. abstract: The New-Orleans Della, of the 20th narrates the particulars of an outrage perpetrated at Galveston, Texas, on the 15th inst. The steamer Texas, Capt. FOWLER, arrived at Galveston on the day previous, having on board as freight fifty-one boxes of cavalry equipments. Capt. REDWOOD, of the Lone Star Rides, learned this, and, having called together his company, demanded the surrender of the boxes. This was refused by Capt. FOWLER, when the men, in accordance with his orders, boarded the steamer, rigged the gangway, and put the equipments on shore, where they were taken charge of by the Committee of Safety. After they had been detained for three days, orders were given for their reshipment, it having been ascertained that they were designed for the frontier.
lead_paragraph: The New-Orleans Della, of the 20th narrates the particulars of an outrage perpetrated at Galveston, Texas, on the 15th inst. The steamer Texas, Capt. abstract: The funds had been steady, but on the 15th they became dull and heavy, and Consols declined 1/4 cent., closing at 91 1/3 @ 5/8 for MONEY, and 91 3/2 @ 7/8 for account. The heaviness was caused by a report that the Bank of France was still losing Gold, and that a further rise in the rate of discount there was contemplated. It was also said that the Bank of England was taking some considerable amounts of Money on loans of Stock.

abstract: A few days since one of the gallant soldiers of South Carolina made his appearance in our streets, wearing his military cap with the new insignia of the new nation, and carrying his right arm in a sling in consequence of a wound received in the war of independence. He seemed quite proud of his military character, and his scars of service, and lost no opportunity of extolling the bravery of South Carolina and the justice of her cause to his foreign relations in this region of the earth. He ingenuously confessed, however, when questioned as to his wound, that it was not received in any actual engagement, -- but that he broke his arm by falling from a powder keg, by the aid of which he was climbing into his bunk, after a bit of a spree among the volunteers of Fort Moultrie. He had come North on a furlough, and for surgical advice, and was eagerly looking forward to the time when he could be restored to active duty under the rattlesnake flag of the Palmetto State.
lead_paragraph: A few days since one of the gallant soldiers of South Carolina made his appearance in our streets, wearing his military cap with the new insignia of the new nation, and carrying his right arm in a sling in consequence of a wound received in the war of independence. He had come North on a furlough, and for surgical advice, and was eagerly looking forward to the time when he could be restored to active duty under the rattlesnake flag of the Palmetto State.

abstract: A concert given at Baltimore the other night to the Independent Greys of that city, by the Marine Band of Washington, was enlivened by a significant episode not promised in the programme. A lady residing there writing to a friend in this City thus describes it: "I don't know that I ever in all my life witnessed such an exciting scene. The last piece on the programme was the Constitutional Quadrilles, but they omitted it and played the Marseillaise hymn, which, they say, is the melody now adopted by the South Carolinians, and left out our national airs entirely. But the audience hissed in such a manner that they were obliged to come back, and when "Hail Columbia, "The Star Spangled Banner" and "Yankee Doodle" were struck up one after the other, I thought the house would have come down with the cheering. Nearly every man. woman and child arose and waved their hats and handkerchiefs, and I never felt so patriotic in all my days."
lead_paragraph: A concert given at Baltimore the other night to the Independent Greys of that city, by the Marine Band of Washington, was enlivened by a significant episode not promised in the programme. A lady residing there writing to a friend in this City thus describes it: "I don't know that I ever in all my life witnessed such an exciting scene. The last piece on the programme was the Constitutional Quadrilles, but they omitted it and played the Marseillaise hymn, which, they say, is the melody now adopted by the South Carolinians, and left out our national airs entirely. But the audience hissed in such a manner that they were obliged to come back, and when "Hail Columbia, "The Star Spangled Banner" and "Yankee Doodle" were struck up one after the other, I thought the house would have come down with the cheering. Nearly every man. woman and child arose and waved their hats and handkerchiefs, and I never felt so patriotic in all my days."

abstract: In this Court yesterday, before Judge McCUNN, counsel for James Shepherd, indicted for arson, stated to the Court that the prisoner had now been in prison three years and a half. He had once been tried, and...
lead_paragraph: In this Court yesterday, before Judge McCUNN, counsel for James Shepherd, indicted for arson, stated to the Court that the prisoner had now been in prison three years and a half. He had once been tried, and the Court of Appeals had unanimously ordered the reversal of the decision made at the trial, declaring that there were not facts enough to raise even a probability of the prisoner's guilt. This was eight months ago, since which time counsel had been knocking at the District-Attorney's Office and demanding a trial, but in vain. The prisoner was chafing under a groundless imprisonment, and anxious for a trial of the issue. Although the Court could not compel the District-Attorney to proceed to trial, it might notify that officer that unless the prisoner were brought to trial at a given time, he would be discharged. The motion was now made that such a course be taken. The Court took a memorandum of the application, and promised an early decision thereon.

abstract: Col. HAYNE, it seems by our Washington dispatches, is disposed to discredit the truth of the telegram from Charleston, published yesterday morning, to the effect that he would be instructed by Gov. PICKENS to demand peremptorily the sur render of Fort Sumter.
lead_paragraph: Col. HAYNE, it seems by our Washington dispatches, is disposed to discredit the truth of the telegram from Charleston, published yesterday morning, to the effect that he would be instructed by Gov. PICKENS to demand peremptorily the sur render of Fort Sumter. The truth of the matter, however, cannot be known until he receives his dispatches from the Governor, which will probably be to-day. The mission of the Brooklyn continues to be the great topic of conjecture. There seems to be little doubt in some quarters that her appearance off Pensacola would be the signal for hostilities, and threats to this effect are not wanting on the part of the Disunionists. There appears now to be some doubt, however, as to her errand being of a hostile character.

abstract: Mr. BUCHANAN has recently vetoed a little private bill, which had twice passed both Houses of Congress, after full and fair discussion.
lead_paragraph: Mr. BUCHANAN has recently vetoed a little private bill, which had twice passed both Houses of Congress, after full and fair discussion. The reason given by the President for withholding his signature from this bill is, that the loss sustained by the beneficiaries, for which Congress sought to indemnify them, was not through any default on the part of the Government. The bill is question involved only a few thousand dollars, and was for the benefit of parties who had unfortunately lost every dollar they possessed, in attempting to execute a contract with the Government, which had been arbitrarily interfered with by the Postmaster-General.

abstract: Gov. MOORE, of Alabama, sent his Message to the General Assembly on the 14th. He stretches the ...
lead_paragraph: Gov. MOORE, of Alabama, sent his Message to the General Assembly on the 14th. He stretches the events preliminary to the meeting of the State Convention, and the action taken by that body; expresses the conviction that all the people of the State will give a cordial support to the Ordinance of Secession, and gives a history of the seizure of the forts at Mobile, where were found about one hundred cannon -- 32 and 24-pounders, and of the capture of the arsenal, which contained 22,000 stand of small arms and 150,000 pounds of powder. All the indications are that Alabama must maintain her sovereignty and independence by force of arms; and, with this contingent cy in view, Gov. MOORE urges that the State should be at once placed on a war footing. Another million of dollars should be borrowed on bonds, in sums of $500 and $1,000 each, bearing interest at 8 per cent., and a force should be enlisted for twelve months, two years, or until peace should be concluded, as may seem best. The Governor frankly acknowledges that there may be much suffering and perhaps starvation among the poorer classes, unless the Legislature take some action, such as empowering the County Commissioners to levy and collect a tax for the purpose of affording relief to the needy. Gov. MOORE asks for two Secretaries, advises the increase of the contingent fund to $29,000, and says that he has purchased 9,000 stand of small arms, 10 brass rifled cannon (6-pounders;) 2 columbiads, 20,000 pounds of lead, 700 kegs of powder and 1,500,000 percussion caps. He sketches the history of the various expeditions sent to assist Florida, hints at the necessity of making provision to defray the expenses incurred, and promises to send in a secret message soon regarding the steps to be taken to arm the State.

abstract: The Canadian Fugitive Slave case now became a cause celebre has been removed from Provincial to British jurisdiction on a writ of habeas corpus, and the event foreshadows, at the very dawn of a new Southern Empire, the ...
lead_paragraph: The Canadian Fugitive Slave case now became a cause celebre has been removed from Provincial to British jurisdiction on a writ of habeas corpus, and the event foreshadows, at the very dawn of a new Southern Empire, the grave difficulties that must continually arise between a Slave Confederacy and the great Anti-Slavery Tower of the world. The technical question involved in the recent decision of Lord Chief Justice COCKBURN, as to whether the Province of Canada is within the jurisdiction of the Court of Queen's Bench, is one for the future consideration of the British lawyer; but the Chief Justice, in the emergency of the case, has, for the present, assumed that it is, and his assumption has been regarded withsatisfaction in England, and will be hailed with joy throughout the length and breadth of Canada. Upon this point there can be no mistake. Popular sympathy is unusually excited in favor of ANDERSON, and if his redemption the doom of a Toronto Court had not been effected by habeas corpus to the Queen's Bench in England, it would certainly have been effected by an appeal either to the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council, or to the Court of Error and the House of Lords.

abstract: The enterprising publishing firm of R. GRIPFIN CO., which lately migrated from Glasgow to London, and is well known as the publishers of Lord Brougham's Works, The Encyclopedia ...
lead_paragraph: The enterprising publishing firm of R. GRIPFIN CO., which lately migrated from Glasgow to London, and is well known as the publishers of Lord Brougham's Works, The Encyclopedia Metropolitans, &c., is strengthened by the admission of the second son of Mr. HENRY G. BOHN, and will in future carry on business under the style of GRIFFIN, BOHN & Co. One of the first undertakings of the new firm will be the issuing of a complete edition of Mr. HENRY MAYHEW's bocks London Labor and the London Poor, and The Great World of London. An entire new volume of new matter will now first be published, which was prepared for the work, but deferred at its unexpected stoppage several years since. The two sections, "Those that will "Work" and "Those that cannot Work," will form three volumes, with illustrations from photographs. The third division, "Those that will not Work," containing particulars of what is affectedly called in England "The Social Evil," and the dangerous classes of society, will follow. The amount of the purchase of the stock and copyright of the work from Mr. BOYNE's executors, was about $6,000.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Miss HINKLEY, of whose first appearance we were happy enough to write in terms of merited approbation, appeared last evening as Leonora in VERDI's opera of "Trovatore," and justified all the generous expectations that were excited by her debut. The part demands a greater prodigality of voice than Lucia, and we fancied that Miss HINKLEY was timid of bestowing all that she could in this way. But she demonstrated empty that she is the possessor of an organ of rare freshness and quality -- and this, too, in spite of many disadvantages, i.e., want of sufficient rehearsals with the principal singers, and a disagreeable indisposition which prevented Sig. FRARI from doing that justice to his role which we always lack for at his hands. The performance, as a whole, however, may be recorded as a success, and we are certain that it will be improved to-night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, when the same work is to be played.

FRARI from doing that justice to his role which we always lack for at his hands. The performance, as a whole, however, may be recorded as a success, and we are certain that it will be improved to-night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, when the same work is to be played.

abstract: Hon. ROBERT P. LETCHER, Ex-Governor of Kentucky, died at his residence in Frankfort on Thursday evening last. Mr. LETCHER was a native of Kentucky, which State he represented in Congress from 1823 to 1633. In 1840 he was elected Governor of the State, and in 1849 was appointed, by President FILLMORE, United States Minister to Mexico. He was a politician of the Henry Clay school, and was greatly beloved in his native State. The Louisville Journal, in noticing his death, says: " We have confided in him as a politician, loved him as a friend, and will cherish his memory as one of the glories of the past."
lead_paragraph: Hon. ROBERT P. LETCHER, Ex-Governor of Kentucky, died at his residence in Frankfort on Thursday evening last. abstract: It seldom happens in real life that poetic justice has such a striking manifestation as in the wonderful drama which has been in continuous progress on the prairies of our westernmost frontier for the past six years, and ...
lead_paragraph: It seldom happens in real life that poetic justice has such a striking manifestation as in the wonderful drama which has been in continuous progress on the prairies of our westernmost frontier for the past six years, and which has now at length closed finally and gloriously in the admission of Kansas as a Free State. The five acts of this historic drama may be epitomised thus: The foundation and organization of the Territory amid the wildest national and Congressional storms -- then the rush of pioneers from all sections and States -- next, the struggles of the ballot, ending in a warfare of bullets -- then the contest of the four Constitutions -- and lastly the triumph of the State over all factions and her entry as a coequal into the great North, American family of States. We know indeed that, in the end, the triumph of Truth and Justice is the inevitable solution of all historic problems; but it is fortifying, when events, in which we may almost be said to be actors, add assurance to our faith in the living reality of these principles.
headline: {'main': 'The New State of Kansas.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The New State of Kansas.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: There is one feature of the Compromise movement worthy of more attention than it has received. All the propositions that have ..
lead_paragraph: There is one feature of the Compromise movement worthy of more attention than it has received. All the propositions that have been offered, -- all the suggestions that are made, -- all the exhortations so freely addressed to the Republicans on the subject, assume that something effectual must be done before the 4th of March, or it will be too late to save the Union. The President's anxiety to preserve the peace extends only to the 4th of March. The Southern advocates of forbearance are careful to limit the exercise of this virtue to the 4th of March. The general current of discussion and of talk, as well as of action, indicates the 4th of March as the date which must put an end to all hope of preserving the Union unless some Compromise, satisfactory to the South, shall be adopted meantime.
headline: {'main': 'Compromising Prematurely.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Compromising Prematurely.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: John A. Underwood et al. vs. The New-York and New-Haven Railroad Company.--This was a mo- ...
lead_paragraph: John A. Underwood et al. vs. The New-York and New-Haven Railroad Company.--This was a motion for the dissolution of an injunction order granted against the defendants in August, 1859, enjoining them from paying their dividend due on the 15th of that month, until the owners of genuine stock could be ascertained by the judgment of some competent tribunal. The injunction order was subsequently modified so as to permit the payment of the dividend to such parties as held stock prior to the year 1850.

abstract: A few days since Mrs. Willy Henningsen, wife of Gen. C.F. Henningsen, lodged a complaint before Justice CONNOLLY, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, against A. Easterby, residing at No. 500 Ninth- ...
lead_paragraph: A few days since Mrs. Willy Henningsen, wife of Gen. C.F. Henningsen, lodged a complaint before Justice CONNOLLY, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, against A. Easterby, residing at No. 500 Ninth- avenue, charging him with having libeled her good name and attempted to extort money from her under the following circumstances. He called at her house, No. 78 Lexington-avenue, on the 22d inst., and left a document, printed in displayed type, containing the following:

abstract: By the arrival at this port of the Quaker City from Havana, we learn that the United States steamer Crusader arrived at Havana, from Key West, on the 25th inst., and reports the arrival of the steamer Joseph Whitney with United States troops and stores.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival at this port of the Quaker City from Havana, we learn that the United States steamer Crusader arrived at Havana, from Key West, on the 25th inst., and reports the arrival of the steamer Joseph Whitney with United States troops and stores. The Crusader convoyed the Joseph Whitney, with a schooner in tow, loaded with guns, to the fort at Tortugas, and when she left there, Capt. MEIGS, of the Engineers, had, with great perseverance and industry, succeeded in getting the fort in good condition for duty.

abstract: The destination and mission of the sloop-of-war Brooklyn are revealed in a dispatch from our Washington correspondent. The commander is ordered to land supplies at Fort Pickens, Pensacola; after which he is to remain off the harbor and watch the movements of the volunteer troops in possession of the Navy-yard and other points. Should he perceive any indication of an intention to make an attack on Fort Pickens, he is to take all needful measures to aid in the defence of the post. Our correspondent state; that he derives this information directly from the official orders. Of course, in view of the threats which have been made by the Disunionists, contingent upon the appearance of the Brooklyn at Pensacola, the greatest anxiety prevails to hear from her. We shall then know exactly how far the Floridians are prepared to carry their threats into execution Another rumor reaches us from Washington of a serious disagreement between Gen. SCOTT and the President. This time on account of the movements recently made, by order of the former, at Fortress Monroe. The President, it is alleged, is much annoyed that the guns of this fortress should be turned "inland," just at the time when he was complimenting the Virginians in his special Message for their loyalty to the Union. The messenger from the Governor of South Carolina to Colonel HAYNE reached Washington yesterday, and delivered his dispatches The nature of them has not yet transpired; but Col. HAYNE has announced in advance that if they are in accordance with the recent telegram from Charleston, his mission will soon come to a close, as he has not the slightest idea that a demand for the surrender of Fort Sumter would he listened to for one moment.

abstract: The Toronto Leader writes a very long ar ticle, saying that it is "enabled to gurantee the correctness of its original announcement," that England would recognize the new Southern Confederacy as soon as it should be formed, but declines to give any information as to the source of its intelligence. We must still be permitted not only to doubt, but to deny its authenticity.
lead_paragraph: The Toronto Leader writes a very long ar ticle, saying that it is "enabled to gurantee the correctness of its original announcement," that England would recognize the new Southern Confederacy as soon as it should be formed, but declines to give any information as to the source of its intelligence. We must still be permitted not only to doubt, but to deny its authenticity. The Editor of the Washington Constitution is the regular correspondent of the Toronto Leader at our capital, and the chances are that he is the author of the remarkable information which the Leader has given to the world. It needs no argument here to expose the extreme improbability of his having any sufficient authority for such a statement.

abstract: The annual meeting of the stockholders of the American telegraph Company took place yesterday at No. 4 Wall-street. The annual report was read, from which it appears that stock had been issued to the amount of $1,458,100. During the past year there has been expended for materials, repairs, reconstructions of the lines, &c., $135,503 73, and for instruments and fixtures $17,370 56. The Company has invested in the purchase of the Cape Cod Telegraph Company's stock and lines, and a lease of the Nova Scotia line for ten years has been obtained. The line between Atlanta and Macon, Ga., has been leased for five years, which completes the Virginia and Tennesse line. There have been constructed 352 miles of wires between New-York and Boston during the past year. The Company has now under its control, extending from Nova Scotia to New-Orleans, 8,121 miles of poles on which are stretched 13,194 miles of wire. They have 334 offices for the reception and transmission of messages. It has been the policy of the Company to abolish special contracts, and establish reasonable uniform rates, with some reduction for some kinds of business. The receipts of the Company during the past year have been $884,175 37, and the expenses $552,975 86. The rates of expenses is 74 and 8,100 of the receipts, and it is believed that it may be reduced to 60 per cent, of the receipts. The Committee of Conference with the Associated Press have entered into a satisfactory arrangement to both parties for the next five years, whereby both parties will, it is believed, be benefited and satisfied.

The line between Atlanta and Macon, Ga., has been leased for five years, which completes the Virginia and Tennesse line. There have been constructed 352 miles of wires between New-York and Boston during the past year. The Company has now under its control, extending from Nova Scotia to New-Orleans, 8,121 miles of poles on which are stretched 13,194 miles of wire. They have 334 offices for the reception and transmission of messages. It has been the policy of the Company to abolish special contracts, and establish reasonable uniform rates, with some reduction for some kinds of business. The receipts of the Company during the past year have been $884,175 37, and the expenses $552,975 86. The rates of expenses is 74 and 8,100 of the receipts, and it is believed that it may be reduced to 60 per cent, of the receipts. abstract: If the declaration of a member of Gov. PICKENS' Cabinet means anything, the attack on Fort Sumter cannot long be delayed. While the question of appropriating $950,000 for military contingencies was under discussion in the Senate a few days since, one of the members of that body declared in the most emphatic terms that he should not give his vote for any such measure. He saw no hope of taking Fort Sumter, or of South Carolina assuming her independence in fact as she had done in name. This expression called out Hon. A.C. GARLINGTON, one of Gov. PICKENS' advisers. After rehearsing in a vehement manner the preparations which had been made for assaulting Fort Sumter, he exclaimed with emphasis, which produced a marked sensation, "Fort Sumter must fall -- yes, Sir, it must fall. This is the deliberate purpose of South Carolina It must fall! This I utter in full consciousness of what I say. and I hope the announcement may go to the world." And so it has, but not through the columns of the Charleston papers, where such a declaration might naturally be looked for. The Charleston correspondent of the Baltimore American, who witnessed the scene, records it.

abstract: The Board of Supervisors held a special meeting yesterday, according to adjournment for the purpose of considering and acting upon the tax levy for the County. At the last meeting on Monday much opposition was manifested against the proposed increase of salaries of the Comptroller, his deputy, and two or three subordinate officers in the same department, the increase being urged on the ground of services rendered to the County.

abstract: Propositions are before Congress to abolish the protective duty on imported sugar, and to discontinue the Postal service in States that have seceded. There are very strong reasons for the proposed action in both cases. The sugar duties, so far as they are protective, exist for the sole benefit of Louisiana. But for the interests of that State in the sugar culture, they would have been repealed long ago. Now that she has repudiated the authority of the General Government, it is simple justice that its protection should be withdrawn.

abstract: The Nashville, Capt. MCMURRAY, left yesterday for Charleston, at her usual hour. She took a moderate cargo of beef, pork and flour, and a few passengers. A deputation of the police were on board to detect any shipment of arms, and reporters from nearly the whole City Press, to record any interesting events which might occur, but nothing on a warlike character was seen to go on board.

abstract: Who of us have not felt either directly or indirectly the baneful, demoralizing effects of intemperance? Who of us have not some cause to reproach ourselves that we have done so little to stop the flood of iniquity arising out of this evil so prevalent among us? And what are its effects upon man -- man in God's image -- made to prove a blessing to himself and society? Misery and desolation, murder, rapine, suicide and death, in all their terrors, follow in its wake, Death, temporal and spiritual. And, while we behold suffering of an aggravated character so closely following in its path, we ask, shall not something be done to stop this tide of sin and death? We answer, it ought to be, and as far as our efforts can avail, it shall be stopped. Having this object and aim in view, the undersigned have united to act as auxiliaries to the Fourth Ward Association, and to aid in this work of humanity commenced under their auspices. A house of reform for the inebriate has been opened at No. 26 New Bowery, Fourth Ward, superintended by Mr. ORVILLE GARDNER, a man who has both seen and felt the power of strong drink, and having been truly reformed and converted, was advised by Mr. CHAS. L. BEACE, of the Children's Aid Society, to undertake the charge of the institution. On the 23d of June, 1859, the Reading-room was formally opened. Speeches were made by Mayor TIEMANN, Mr. PETER COOPER, and others, and Mr. GARDNER immediately entered upon his duties. From that time to the present he has been actively employed in the effort to restore and reform the poor inebriate. He has none much and might have accomplished much more, if he had not been seriously embarrassed for want of means. Between $600 and $700 have been raised through appeals made by Mr. JOHN B. GOUGH and Mr. GARDENER'S addresses before Sabbath Schools, Temperance meetings, &c., and about as much more has been donated by private individuals. More than nfteen hundred persons have signed the pledge, and a large number have obtained employment through the assistance of Mr. GARDNER, and fifteen or sixteen of those who were brought into the Institution in a state of intoxication, are known to have been hopefully converted to God, and one of these is now filling the pulpit in one of the churches in this city. Shall this work stop for want of proper support? We appeal to you to come forward and aid us in our efforts to sustain this Institution, by donating to the subscribing Finance Committee, money, goods and clothing for men's wear, (new and second-hand.)

abstract: AN IMPERIAL INCOGNITO, One evening, just before New Year's day, which was extremely wet, the Emperor and Empress went cut incognito to see the stalls along the Bouleyards. Protected by a large umbrella, their Majesties passed along the southern side from the Rue de Paix to the Rue Montmarte, and returned along the opposite one as far as the Rue Neuve des Capucines.
lead_paragraph: AN IMPERIAL INCOGNITO. -- One evening, just before New Year's day, which was extremely wet, the Emperor and Empress went cut incognito to see the stalls along the Bouleyards. Protected by a large umbrella, their Majesties passed along the southern side from the Rue de Paix to the Rue Montmarte, and returned along the opposite one as far as the Rue Neuve des Capucines. They made numerous purchases during this long walk. The Empress filled her pockets with all sorts of little toys and nick-nacks, varying in price from one sou to ten. Their Majesties also purchased several articles of larger size, and on paying for them, requested the dealers to put them by till their return. As they never came back, of course the stall-keepers remained in possession of both money and goods. Some of the dealers recognised their Imperial customers, but were discreet enough to keep their discovery to themselves. This walk greatly amused the Empress, who, on returning to the Palace, distributed her purchases among the ladies in waiting.

abstract: The State of Georgia has made haste to relieve herelf, so far as possible, from the suspicion that her secession has been prompted by a desire to restore the Slave-trade. An ordinance was introduced on the 23d to continue in force all the laws of the United States by which that traffic is prohibited. When it came up for action it was amended so as very greatly to modify the penalties prescribed for its violation.
lead_paragraph: The State of Georgia has made haste to relieve herelf, so far as possible, from the suspicion that her secession has been prompted by a desire to restore the Slave-trade. An ordinance was introduced on the 23d to continue in force all the laws of the United States by which that traffic is prohibited. When it came up for action it was amended so as very greatly to modify the penalties prescribed for its violation. Imprisonment for five years was substituted for the punishment of death. But it was also provided that the prohibition of the traffic should not extend to the introduction of slaves from other seceded States, who may have been imported from beyond seas before Dec. 20, 1860. And in this form the ordinance was adopted.

abstract: THE NEW FEATHERING PADDLE-WHEEL. DENSMORE's improved feathering paddle-wheel was practically tested yesterday in the presence of a large number of steamboat Captains, Engineers and other persons interested in steam navigation. The Anna, a first-class tow-boat, to which the wheel has been attached, made a trial trip some fifteen miles up the East River, during which the party inspected its working with much interest.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW FEATHERING PADDLE-WHEEL. -- DENSMORE's improved feathering paddle-wheel was practically tested yesterday in the presence of a large number of steamboat Captains, Engineers and other persons interested in steam navigation. The Anna, a first-class tow-boat, to which the wheel has been attached, made a trial trip some fifteen miles up the East River, during which the party inspected its working with much interest. In the new wheel the whole power of the engine is exerted directly in propelling the boat, instead of being more or less wasted in submerging and lifting the floats, giving increased speed, or power for towing as the case may be, and wholly overcoming the unpleasant, jarring motion caused by the old wheel. There was also greater steadiness in the action of the engine, and no violent commotion or sea in the wake of the wheels. Capt. HITCHCOCK asserted that he could now tow two barges as easily and as rapidly as one could be be towed before. She made full fifteen miles an hour going and returning, with an average of 30 pounds of steam, and only partially open; revolutions from 23 to 27 per minute. The buckets more upon a pivot joint, upon strong brackets which are attached to the arms of the wheel, and are moved by means of rods which connect with an eccentric fixed at the shaft at the side of the boat. Mr. VAN SANTVORD, of the Swiftsure Liue; Capt. TALLMAN, of the steamer Daniel Drew; Capt. QUINTARD, of the Alaida, and many other steamboat men were on board, and spoke in decidedly favorable terms of the success of the new wheel. This is the fourth steamer to which the improved wheel has been attached, and they have all given satisfaction.

abstract: With the exception of a single reactionary, ultra-montone journal in Paris, and an occasional trivial demurrer, inspired by eccentricity, or a desire to appear impartial in judgement, the entire press of Europe has now discussed the American secession movement, and declared with greater vehenience than was anticipated, against the example set by South Carolina. Journals of all nations have spoken freely, and for a wonder, have displayed ...
lead_paragraph: With the exception of a single reactionary, ultra-montone journal in Paris, and an occasional trivial demurrer, inspired by eccentricity, or a desire to appear impartial in judgement, the entire press of Europe has now discussed the American secession movement, and declared with greater vehenience than was anticipated, against the example set by South Carolina. Journals of all nations have spoken freely, and for a wonder, have displayed a far letter acquaintance with the subject than they ever before manifested in discussing anything relating to this country. Writers who have grown gray in defending absolutism, men who have exhausted sophistry in making tyranny appear the better cause, shrink abruptly before the terrible spectre of a government based unconditionally on Slavery. Despotism in its darkest form, at the present day, sees itself almost as one of the shining ones robed in purest white, by the side of such an apparition.

abstract: The compromise movement was not aided by the debate in the Senate yesterday. Senator CAMERON took occasion to qualify very essentially his promise on this subject, declaring his unwillingness to make any concessions whatever unless he could have some assurance that they would be acceptible to the South. Mr. CAMERON seems to have suddenly recollected that thus for the compromise movement has been wholly on one side.
lead_paragraph: The compromise movement was not aided by the debate in the Senate yesterday. Senator CAMERON took occasion to qualify very essentially his promise on this subject, declaring his unwillingness to make any concessions whatever unless he could have some assurance that they would be acceptible to the South. Mr. CAMERON seems to have suddenly recollected that thus for the compromise movement has been wholly on one side. It has none of the features of compromise. It is simply a peremptory and arrogant protest on the part of the South against the result of the last election, -- and a demand on their part that the victorious party shall lay down their arms, and surrender at discretion, as the sole condition on which they will be allowed to march into the offices they have conquered.

abstract: -- Mr. and Mrs. Kimball, formerly residents of Syracuse, (N.Y.,) passed through Cleveland (Ohio) on Jan. 26, and they had a strange story to tell of their experiences since they left their home in 1848 to go to California, by the Overland route. While crossing the Plains on the 17th of July, the party in which they were was attacked by the Indians. The men fought to bravely that out of the party, which numbered sixty-three, but thirteen were left, counting the women and children Mr. Kimball's father, an old man, was one of the survivors, but was killed in trying to run the gauntlet. Mr. Kimball himself passed the ordeal successfully, and was told that he might save the life of whichever one of the female survivors he chose if he repeated the teat. He did so, and rescued his wife from death, while be was obliged to see his two sisters killed by slow torture. Mr. and Mrs. Kimball followed the Indians from place to place, without an opportunity to escape, till 1859, when their party met a United States surveying company. Kimball told his story to the whites, and one of them an old resident in the country, offered his aid in effecting their escape. The offer was gladly accepted, and the attempt, after many months of intense suffering, was successful.
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. and Mrs. Kimball, formerly residents of Syracuse, (N.Y.,) passed through Cleveland (Ohio) on Jan. 26, and they had a strange story to tell of their experiences since they left their home in 1848 to go to California, by the Overland route. While crossing the Plains on the 17th of July, the party in which they were was attacked by the Indians. The men fought to bravely that out of the party, which numbered sixty-three, but thirteen were left, counting the women and children Mr. Kimball's father, an old man, was one of the survivors, but was killed in trying to run the gauntlet. Mr. Kimball himself passed the ordeal successfully, and was told that he might save the life of whichever one of the female survivors he chose if he repeated the teat. He did so, and rescued his wife from death, while be was obliged to see his two sisters killed by slow torture. Mr. and Mrs. Kimball followed the Indians from place to place, without an opportunity to escape, till 1859, when their party met a United States surveying company. Kimball told his story to the whites, and one of them an old resident in the country, offered his aid in effecting their escape. The offer was gladly accepted, and the attempt, after many months of intense suffering, was successful.

abstract: In response to a call for a meeting of young men desirous of forming a volunteer battalion, to be ready at the call of the Governor of this State, or the President of the United States, to defend the Federal Government, quite a large number of persons assembled last evening, at the "Adriatic," corner of Barrow and Hudson streets. The Chair was occupied by Mr. HENRY DE FRAINE, who stated the object of the meeting, and then representatives from the companies made favorable reports of the progress of enrollment. The following preamble and resolutions were then offered by Ex-Alderman Wm. WILSON, and adopted:

abstract: THE ABSON WIFE-POISONING CASE. The Abson wife-poisoning case was continued yesterday before the Hudson County Court. A large number of witnesses was examined, but nothing new of special importance was elicited. The case will be continued to-day.
